conversations.content: What factors contribute to a company's success in the insurance industry, given the lack of traditional competitive advantages?

In my view, it's the people - the individual managers - who make a significant difference in the insurance business. The nature of the industry magnifies their impact on company performance. I feel fortunate to have a talented group of managers associated with us.
How has the investment income of your Insurance Group changed over the past few years?

Our net investment income from the Insurance Group has seen a nice uptick, growing from $8.4 million pre-tax in 1975 to $12.3 million pre-tax in 1977. That's a welcome increase, and we've also realized some capital gains along the way.
Why do you provide separate financial information and commentary on the various segments of the business in the report?

I provide that information to help our shareholders evaluate Berkshire's performance and prospects. The standard grouping of Balance Sheet and Earnings items just doesn't give a clear picture of how our different businesses are doing, so we break it down for you.
How do the 1977 figures in this report differ from the 1977 figures shown in last year's report?

The 1977 figures in this report are different because accounting rules require us to present the financial data as if the Diversified and Berkshire merger had taken place from the beginning, even though it actually happened on December 30, 1978. So, the numbers you see now are restated to reflect that merger, which makes them different from what we reported last year.
What was the market value of the common equities held by your insurance subsidiaries at the end of 1978?
The market value of those equities at the end of 1978 was $216.5 million. Not bad for a three-year run, if I do say so myself.
How did the overall performance of your equity investments compare to the Dow-Jones Industrial Average during the same period?

Well, it's pretty clear we came out on top. While the Dow-Jones Industrial Average actually declined from 852 to 805, our overall unrealized and realized pre-tax gains in equities for the three-year period came to approximately $112 million. I'd say that was a marvelous period for us value-oriented equity buyers.
Why do you think corporations are making significant mistakes in purchasing entire businesses at current prices?

I believe corporations are overpaying because the prices they're willing to pay in negotiated transactions and takeover bids are far higher than the valuations of the same businesses in the stock market. It's like paying full price for a house when you can buy the same house down the street for a significant discount just because it's being sold through a different channel.
What is your approach to buying securities, and how does it relate to market valuation?

My approach is to buy significant portions of businesses that I believe are undervalued, not just a little bit of everything. I'm not concerned if the market doesn't immediately recognize the value and revalue the securities upward. In fact, I prefer it if the market takes its time, because that gives me the opportunity to continue buying at attractive prices. It's like being able to buy your favorite food at a discount - you're happy to keep buying as long as the sale lasts.
Why did you choose to purchase SAFECO, and what made it an attractive investment opportunity?

I chose to purchase SAFECO because it's the best-run large property and casualty insurance company in the United States. Their underwriting abilities, loss reserving, and investment policies are all superb. Plus, we got it at a great price - substantially under book value. It's like buying a top-notch baseball team at a discount, why wouldn't I want that in my portfolio?
How do the earnings from SAFECO contribute to Berkshire's overall operating earnings?

The earnings from SAFECO are significant, amounting to $6.1 million in 1978, but only the dividends we receive, which is about 18% of their earnings, are reflected in our operating earnings. Think of it like owning a rental property - we get the rent, not the entire profit from the property's operations.
What do you think is the best use of retained earnings in industries with low capital requirements or when management has a record of investing in low-profitability projects?
In those cases, I believe earnings should be paid out to shareholders or used to repurchase shares - it's often the most attractive option for utilizing capital effectively.
How has the performance of the Illinois National Bank and Trust Company been since you purchased it in 1969?

The bank's performance has been exceptional. Since 1968, consumer time deposits have quadrupled, net income has tripled, and trust department income has more than doubled, all while maintaining significantly less asset risk than most larger banks.
What has been the result of Ben's management skills at Associated's business despite adverse trends?

Ben's skills have produced an outstanding record of profitability, with returns on capital often in the 20% after-tax area. It's a remarkable achievement, especially considering the challenges the business has faced.
What is it like to work with managers like Ben, Gene Abegg, and Louie Vincenti?

It's a real pleasure. These managers think like owners and genuinely enjoy coming to work. Their proprietary attitude towards the business is almost palpable, and it's been exceptionally rewarding to work with them, both financially and personally.
Why do you prefer to measure operating performance against shareholders' equity with securities valued at cost instead of market value?

I prefer measuring operating performance against shareholders' equity with securities valued at cost because it gives a more accurate picture. When you use market value, the wide swings in securities values can distort the results. It's like trying to measure the speed of a car on a bumpy road - the bumps don't change how fast the car is going, but they can make it seem like it's speeding or slowing down. By using cost, we get a smoother ride and a clearer view of how well we're really doing.
How did Blue Chip Stamps' operating performance in 1979 compare to the previous year?

Our operating performance in 1979 was reasonably good, but not quite as good as in 1978. We earned 18.6% of our beginning net worth, which is a decent return, but it fell short of the previous year's performance. And let's be clear, the increase in earnings per share doesn't tell the whole story - we had more capital to work with in 1979, so our return on that capital was actually lower than in 1978.
How have you achieved the overall results for your shareholders, and what role has capital appreciation played in this process?

I've achieved these results through a combination of our yearly operating earnings and, more significantly, the capital appreciation of our insurance equity investments. It's like having a snowball rolling down a hill, gathering size and speed - the capital appreciation has really helped our shareholders' returns roll along nicely.
You mention that the book value in 1964 might have overstated the intrinsic value of the enterprise. Can you elaborate on what you mean by this?

Well, when we looked at the assets we owned back in 1964, they weren't quite worth what we had them booked for. It's like having a house that's appraised for $100,000, but if you went to sell it, you might only get $90,000. The liabilities were solid, but the assets just weren't worth 100 cents on the dollar. We've since worked to build real value, and I think our results show that.
What do you mean by an 'investor's misery index', and how does it affect the investor's purchasing power?

The 'investor's misery index' is a combination of the inflation rate and the taxes I have to pay when I want to turn my annual gains into cash. Think of it like a one-two punch - first, inflation erodes the value of my money, and then I get hit with taxes on my earnings. If this index is higher than the return on equity my business earns, my purchasing power actually decreases, even if I don't spend a dime. It's a tough spot to be in, let me tell you.
How has Berkshire Hathaway's book value performed over the long term, and what does that mean for investors like me?

Well, I'll be honest with you - our book value at the end of 1964 could buy about half an ounce of gold, and fifteen years later, after pouring our hearts and souls into the business, it still only buys about the same half ounce. That's not exactly the kind of progress I like to see. It just goes to show that external factors like inflation and currency stability can have a big impact on the value of your investment, no matter how well we manage the business internally.
What is notable about Ben Rosner's performance at Associated Retail Stores?

Ben Rosner's performance is notable because he consistently produces very large earnings relative to the capital employed, which is quite impressive especially considering the segment of the market he operates in has little growth and unexciting demographics.
Why did you decide to expand our textile commitment by purchasing Waumbec Mills, despite the challenges in the industry?

I made the decision to purchase Waumbec Mills because, by any statistical test, the purchase price was an extraordinary bargain - we essentially got substantial amounts of machinery and real estate for less than nothing, as we bought well below the working capital of the business.
What is your policy regarding layoffs due to fluctuations in workload?

We don't lay off people just because the workload slows down. I'd rather have some slack in the organization from time to time than keep everyone busy writing business that's going to lose us money. It's just not worth the risk.
What's your outlook on the reinsurance business?

To be frank, I think the reinsurance business is a very tough business that's likely to get even tougher. With all the new capital coming in and prices softening, I worry that many companies are going to find themselves in over their heads before they even realize it. The 'long tail' of reinsurance means that problems can fester for years before they become apparent.
What is your outlook on the insurance underwriting industry for 1980 and beyond?

I disagree with the conventional wisdom that insurance underwriting will be poor in 1980 but then turn around in 1981. Instead, I think the current high interest rates will lead companies to accept underwriting losses in order to get investment income, which will create a new normal for combined ratios and make them average higher in the future than they have in the past.
How do you think higher gas prices have affected the auto insurance industry?

Higher gas prices have actually helped the auto insurance industry by reducing the frequency of auto accidents, likely due to changes in driving habits. If people hadn't changed their driving habits, auto insurance rates wouldn't be much higher, and underwriting results would be much worse. But let's be clear, this is just a temporary reprieve - it's a dose of serendipity that won't last forever.
What is your forecast for the average combined ratio for the insurance industry over the next five years?
I think the industry's average combined ratio will be in the 105 area over the next five years. That's our forecast, anyway.
How have your insurance equity investments performed in recent years?

They've done well, largely because the companies we've invested in have turned in outstanding performances. The retained earnings from these investments have been mounting annually and now add up to a very substantial number.
Why do you think the accounting convention of carrying bond investments at amortized cost contributed to losses in the insurance industry?

I believe this accounting convention contributed to losses because it didn't force management to recognize the impaired market value of their bond investments early on. If they had to mark these bonds to market, they would have seen the dangers of those long-term contracts sooner and maybe taken action to mitigate the risks.
What's the irony you see in how insurance companies handle policy durations versus bond investments in an inflationary environment?

The irony is that insurance companies think a one-year policy is too long to set a fixed price in an inflationary world, so they've switched to six-month policies. But then they take the money from those policies and invest it in long-term bonds, essentially setting a fixed price for 30 or 40 years. It's like they're saying, 'We can't predict costs for a year, but we're comfortable locking in prices for decades.' It just doesn't add up.
Why are you unhappy with your fifteen-year bonds and what do you hope will offset the losses?

I'm unhappy with our fifteen-year bonds because we'll be paying a price in terms of earning power each year, reflecting the mistake of investing in them. However, we hope that our profits from some of our convertible bonds, which appear exceptionally attractive to us, may offset these losses.
What is your approach to lending and borrowing, as mentioned at the end of the text?

My approach, inspired by Polonius, is to 'neither be a short-term borrower nor a long-term lender.' In other words, I'm cautious about committing to fixed rates for long periods, whether borrowing or lending, because it's difficult to predict the future and set fair prices for money that far ahead.
What percentage of Berkshire's shares are held by the same shareholders at the beginning and end of each year?
About 98% of our shares outstanding are held by people who were also shareholders at the beginning of the year. It's a pretty consistent group, and that informs how we approach our reporting to them.
Why don't you include a narrative with your quarterly reports?

To be honest, we just don't think there's much to say on a quarterly basis that would be meaningful in terms of long-term significance. Our owners and managers have long time-horizons, and we prefer to focus on the big picture rather than getting bogged down in short-term details.
What kind of reporting do you believe shareholders are entitled to from a public company's manager?

I believe shareholders are entitled to the same sort of reporting as I am at Berkshire Hathaway from our business unit managers - a straightforward, candid report on how the company is doing, without sugarcoating or public relations spin. It's like getting a report from someone you've hired to manage your business - you want to know the good, the bad, and the ugly, not some glossy sales pitch.
How do you think a company's approach to communicating with shareholders can influence the type of investors it attracts?

Well, I think it's pretty simple - if a company focuses on short-term results or tries to manipulate public perception, it will attract investors who are looking for a quick buck or are willing to play games. On the other hand, if a company is transparent and honest, it will attract investors who are in it for the long haul. As Phil Fisher said, it's like a restaurant attracting a certain type of customer - if you serve fast food, you'll get customers who want a quick meal, but if you serve a gourmet meal, you'll attract customers who appreciate the quality.
What is the main issue with a corporation trying to appeal to different types of shareholders with varying interests?

Well, the problem is that you can't be all things to all men. If you try to cater to multiple groups with different primary interests, you'll end up with a revolving door of confused and dissatisfied shareholders. It's like a restaurant that can't decide whether it's serving French cuisine or take-out chicken - you'll lose your loyal customer base.
What kind of shareholders do you prefer to have at Berkshire Hathaway?

I prefer owners who like our 'service and menu' and return year after year. In other words, we want long-term shareholders who are happy with our approach and stick with us. We think the shareholders we already have are a great group, and it's hard to imagine a better set of owners for Berkshire Hathaway.
How do undistributed earnings from companies Berkshire partially owns affect Berkshire's reported operating earnings?

Well, let me put it simply - undistributed earnings are ignored in our reported operating earnings. If a company we own 10% of makes $10 million but doesn't distribute it, we don't report any of that as our earnings unless they pay out dividends. It's like having a fruit tree - just because it produces a lot of fruit doesn't mean you get to eat it all if you don't pick it. In our case, the fruit is the earnings, and we only get to count the part that's picked, or paid out, as dividends.
What has happened to the proportion of Berkshire's earnings that come from companies where Berkshire owns less than 20%?

That's an easy one - the proportion of our earnings from those companies has actually decreased in terms of what we report, because many of them retain a large portion of their earnings instead of paying them out as dividends. It's a bit counterintuitive, but even though our reported operating earnings don't fully reflect the earnings power of these companies, our economic well-being is still tied to their overall performance, not just the dividends they pay us.
What has led to the significant increase in Berkshire Hathaway's holdings in the third category of companies?

Our insurance business doing well and finding some great opportunities in the common stock market have both contributed to this increase. It's like finding a couple of aces in a deck of cards - they don't come around often, but when they do, you've got to play them.
How does the accounting of earnings from partially-owned companies affect the visibility of Berkshire Hathaway's total earnings?

Conventional accounting only shows less than half of our earnings 'iceberg' above the surface. The part of earnings retained by those companies, not paid to us in dividends, is like the hidden part of the iceberg - it's there, but you can't see it in the standard financial reports.
What is your preferred use of retained earnings in a company you have an investment interest in?

I must say, I get quite enthusiastic when companies use their retained earnings to repurchase their own shares, especially when the business is selling for far less than its intrinsic value. It's a straightforward way to increase the interests of all owners at a bargain price.
How do you evaluate a company's long-term performance?

When it comes to evaluating long-term performance, I look at all capital gains or losses, whether they're realized or unrealized. This gives me a more complete picture of how the company is doing over time.
How does inflation affect the real return on investment for corporate America, especially when considering taxation?

Well, let me tell you, inflation is like a silent tax that eats away at your returns. If inflation is high, say 16%, and a company's return is less than that, the owner is actually getting a negative real return, even if we were to somehow magically eliminate income taxes on dividends and capital gains. And to make matters worse, you're paying taxes on what would essentially be a loss if you were to adjust for inflation.
Do you believe individual investors can expect a real long-term return from the average American corporation, given current inflation rates and tax brackets?

Honestly, I don't think so. For individual owners in medium or high tax brackets, the combination of inflation's implicit tax on capital and the explicit taxes on dividends and capital gains pretty much offsets the average return on equity of corporations. It's a tough spot, and as I've said before, Berkshire doesn't have a corporate solution to this problem.
How much did your initial investment in GEICO cost, and how has it performed in terms of earnings?

Our initial investment in GEICO cost us $47 million, with about half invested in 1976 and the rest in 1980. As for performance, at the current dividend rate, we're looking at about $3 million in annual reported earnings from GEICO. However, we estimate the real earning power applicable to our share is around $20 million annually.
What's your view on GEICO's management and their use of undistributed earnings?

I must say, we're extremely comfortable with GEICO's management. They've demonstrated exceptional skills not just in operations, but also in capital allocation. The fact that they're retaining an estimated $17 million of earnings applicable to our ownership doesn't bother us one bit - we trust them as much as we would if that money were in our own hands.
What have you learned from tracking the performance of turnaround businesses over the years?

Well, I've learned that when a brilliant management team takes on a business with poor fundamental economics, it's usually the business's reputation that stays intact - and not in a good way. In other words, the business's problems tend to persist despite the best efforts of its new management.
You mention GEICO as a potential exception to this rule. What made its turnaround successful?

GEICO's turnaround was successful because, despite its troubles, the company's fundamental business advantage was still intact. It was designed to be a low-cost operation in a huge marketplace, and when run correctly, it could offer great value to customers while earning strong returns for itself. Managerial brilliance, courtesy of Jack Byrne, was the key to unlocking that potential again.
How do declining bond prices affect the net worth of insurance companies that own long-term bonds?

Well, let me put it this way - if an insurance company has bonds valued at three times their net worth, and those bond prices drop by just one-third, it could essentially wipe out their net worth. It's a significant risk, and one that's not always immediately apparent because of the accounting convention that allows companies to carry bonds at amortized cost, rather than market value.
Why don't insurance companies react to declines in bond prices the same way they do to declines in stock prices?

That's a good question. It does seem a bit strange, doesn't it? But the reason is largely due to the accounting rules. When stock portfolios fall in price, it can reduce net worth significantly and trigger a reaction. But with bonds, because they're carried at amortized cost rather than market value, a decline in bond prices doesn't necessarily show up on the books right away. It's a bit like ignoring the elephant in the room, but that's how the accounting works.
What happens to an insurer's policies and premium volume if management tells underwriters to price according to exposure involved, without considering competitors?

Well, it's pretty straightforward - many of those policies will be lost to competitors in short order because most business is price sensitive and renewable annually. As a result, our premium volume will shrink significantly.
You describe a scenario where companies might sell better assets to avoid recognizing losses on poorer investments. What's your view on this strategy?

I think it's a bit like an ostrich sticking its head in the sand. While selling the better assets and keeping the losers might be less painful in the short term, it's unlikely to be a winning strategy in the long term. You're just delaying the inevitable and potentially making things worse.
What do you mean by 'ostrich-like behavior' in the context of insurance companies and their assets?
Well, I mean selling off the good assets and holding onto the losers. It's like burying your head in the sand - it might avoid short-term pain, but it's not a winning strategy in the long run.
You mention 'asset maintenance' underwriting. Can you explain what that is and why it's problematic?

Asset maintenance underwriting is when insurers take on bad business just to keep their assets at current levels. It's a short-sighted approach that prioritizes maintaining premium volume over price adequacy. The problem is, if many insurers do this, it creates a race to the bottom, where everyone has to match those low prices, making it impossible for underwriting to improve.
How does your company's financial position compare to other large property-casualty stockholder-owned groups?

I'm pleased to say that our net worth, when valuing bonds at amortized cost, is the strongest relative to premium volume among all large property-casualty stockholder-owned groups. And when you value those bonds at market, our relative strength becomes even more dramatic.
What impact do you think the financial troubles of other companies in the industry will have on your own business?

To be frank, troubles for the industry mean troubles for us. While our abundant capital and investment flexibility will give us the freedom to make sensible decisions during this period of inadequate pricing, we can't escape the fact that the struggles of our competitors will have a ripple effect on our own business.
Why did Berkshire decide to borrow $60 million through the sale of notes?

We borrowed that $60 million because we think we'll have many opportunities to put the money to good use in the future, and we want to have plenty of financial firepower when those opportunities arise. It's like having a loaded gun, ready to fire when the time is right.
What kind of businesses do you prefer to acquire, and why?

My acquisition preferences run toward businesses that generate cash, not those that consume it. As inflation intensifies, many companies struggle to maintain their existing business without spending all their internal funds, so I like businesses that can produce cash without needing a lot of additional investment.
What did you learn about a person when you purchase a business from them and they stay on to run it as an employee?

Well, I learned that you can tell a lot about a person's character in this situation. They have the opportunity to mislead you before the sale, but after the check clears, their true colors can come out. Fortunately, that wasn't the case with Gene - he shot straight with me 100% of the time.
How did Gene's behavior change after selling the Bank to you, and what did that reveal about his character?

Gene's behavior actually improved after the sale. He worked harder for us than he had for himself, and he was always upfront about problems and opportunities. That told me a lot about his integrity and his commitment to doing what's right, even when he no longer had a personal stake in the business.
What is your approach to acquiring businesses, and how do you prioritize your investments?

I'm comfortable with both total ownership of businesses and owning marketable securities that represent small portions of businesses. My goal is to maximize real economic benefits, not just to boost reported numbers or expand managerial domain. I look for significant investments in both areas, but I try to avoid small commitments - if it's not worth doing, it's not worth doing well.
What motivates corporate managers to pursue high-premium takeovers, in your opinion?

I think corporate managers often pursue high-premium takeovers because they have a lot of 'animal spirits' and enjoy the challenge and activity that comes with it. At Berkshire, we get excited about acquisitions too, but we prioritize economic substance over accounting appearance. I suspect many managers are driven by unspoken motivations, like the desire for increased activity and challenge, rather than purely economic considerations.
What motivations do you think drive most high-premium takeovers?

I believe there are three main motivations: first, leaders often have a lot of 'animal spirits' and enjoy the challenge and activity of making a deal; second, companies and their managers are often measured by their size, not their profitability; and third, many managements are overly optimistic about their ability to improve the target company's performance - they think their 'kiss' will turn a toad into a prince, so to speak.
Why do you think investors would pay a premium to acquire a company through a takeover rather than buying its shares directly?

To be frank, it's because of that optimism I mentioned earlier. Investors think that by acquiring the company, they can improve its performance and make it more valuable than it would be if they just bought the shares on the market. But, as I like to say, you can always buy toads at the going price for toads - there's no need to pay a premium unless you think you can turn it into something more valuable.
What characteristics should a business have to thrive in an inflationary environment?

To do well in an inflationary environment, a business should have two key characteristics. First, it should be able to increase prices easily without losing much market share or unit volume. Second, it should be able to handle large increases in business volume with only a small amount of additional capital investment. That's the kind of business that can really make the most of inflation.
Why should shareholders of an acquiring company want to own an interest in a target company at a takeover cost rather than buying it directly at market price?

Honestly, I don't think they should want to own it at the higher takeover cost unless there's something really special about the deal. I mean, why pay double for a 'toad' when you can buy it at the market price? The acquiring company had better have a good reason, or as I like to say, those kisses had better pack some real dynamite.
What two characteristics do you look for in a favored business?

I look for two key things: first, the ability to easily raise prices without losing market share or unit volume, even if demand is flat. Second, the ability to handle big increases in business volume with only a small boost in capital investment. It's like finding a business that can run on autopilot, without needing a lot of extra fuel to keep going.
Can you give examples of managerial superstars who have excelled in recognizing and acquiring valuable businesses?

Yes, I've had the pleasure of watching some real pros in action. Guys like Ben Heineman, Henry Singleton, Erwin Zaban, and especially Tom Murphy at Capital Cities Communications - they're the crème de la crème. They've got a keen eye for spotting hidden gems and the skills to bring out their full potential. Tom Murphy, in particular, is a standout, with a talent for both finding great businesses and running them exceptionally well.
What kind of acquisition activity has Berkshire had in Category 1, and how does it compare to your expectations?

Our acquisition activity in Category 1 has been sporadic and inadequate, I'm afraid. We've had a reasonably good understanding of the economic factors that make concentration in this category a good idea, but our actual performance hasn't lived up to our preaching. It's like predicting rain - it's one thing to forecast it, but it's another to actually build an ark.
How do you approach paying for businesses you acquire, especially in terms of what you bring to the table?

We're willing to pay a fairly fancy price for a Category 1 business if we're confident in what we're getting. However, we won't normally pay a lot for what we're supposed to bring to the party, because frankly, we don't think we bring that much to the table. We look for businesses that can stand on their own, and we're not trying to pay for some sort of secret sauce that we're going to add.
What has been the annual rate of return of Berkshire's book value per share over the past seventeen years?

Our book value per share has increased at a compounded annual rate of 21.1% over the past seventeen years. I must say, it's a number that pleases me, but I also believe it's likely to come down in the future.
How much of Berkshire's net worth gain in 1981 was due to the market performance of GEICO Corporation?

Over half of our large gain in net worth during 1981, which was $124 million or about 31%, came from the market performance of a single investment - GEICO Corporation. It was a significant contributor to our success that year.
How does the duration of insurance policies impact revenue and profitability for insurance companies?

Well, the duration of our policies means that this year's sales contracts will determine about half of next year's revenue. And if we make a mistake in pricing, we're stuck with it for a while. It's like buying a train ticket - once you've paid for it, you're on that train for the whole ride, whether you like it or not.
What happens to underwriting profitability when the industry-wide volume gain in premiums written is high or low?

It's pretty straightforward: when the volume gain is high, like in double digits, it's good news for profitability trends in the current and following year. But when the gain is small, underwriting experience will get worse, no matter how bad it is already. It's like a big ship - it takes a while to turn around, but when it does, it can either sail smoothly or crash into the rocks.
What does the combined ratio indicate in the context of the insurance industry, and what does a ratio above or below 100 signify?

The combined ratio shows total operating and loss costs compared to premiums. Think of it like a report card for insurers. If the ratio is below 100, it means we're making an underwriting profit - we're collecting more in premiums than we're paying out in costs. On the other hand, a ratio above 100 indicates a loss - our costs are exceeding our premiums, which isn't a sustainable business model.
You mention that current pricing practices promise devastating results. What factors do you think will contribute to these negative outcomes?

Well, I believe our luck will eventually run out. We've been fortunate in recent years with fewer major natural disasters, and people have been driving less. But that won't last forever. And then there are the twin inflations - monetary and social. The latter refers to how courts and juries are increasingly interpreting policy coverage more broadly than insurers intended, which will drive up our costs. These factors will catch up with us, and when they do, our underwriting experience will get even worse.
What motivates insurance managers to push for business despite potentially low profitability?

Well, I believe it's a combination of factors, including the worship of size over profitability and the fear that market share surrendered can never be regained. It's a bit like trying to keep a big machine running - once it's in motion, it's hard to slow it down, even if it's not making much sense financially.
Do you think the property-casualty insurance industry will experience a regular underwriting cycle with relatively constant profitability in the future?

No, I don't. In fact, I think the opposite is true. I believe that large underwriting losses will be the norm for the industry, and even the best years will seem substandard compared to the past. It's not a pretty picture, but that's what I see happening.
What were the main reasons for the decline in Berkshire Hathaway's operating earnings as a percentage of beginning equity capital in 1982?

The decline was largely due to three factors: a significant deterioration in insurance underwriting results, a considerable expansion of equity capital without corresponding business growth, and our increasing commitment to investments in partially-owned businesses, which don't fully reflect in our reported earnings due to accounting rules.
Why do you think the operating earnings/equity capital percentage is no longer the best yardstick for measuring Berkshire Hathaway's managerial performance?

Honestly, I think it's because the results haven't been great lately. But seriously, our business has evolved, and with more investments in partially-owned businesses, this metric doesn't fully capture our performance. It's a bit like trying to measure a distance with a ruler that's only marked in inches when you need to measure something in feet and inches.
How do accounting earnings differ from economic earnings in the context of GEICO's 1982 performance?

Well, let me tell you - accounting earnings only include the dividends we received from GEICO, which was $3.5 million after tax. On the other hand, economic earnings include all undistributed earnings, which in this case was an additional $23 million that GEICO retained. So, you see, accounting earnings can paint a very different picture from economic reality.
Why do you think the size of one's ownership percentage doesn't determine the value of retained earnings to owners?

It's quite simple, really. If you've owned even a tiny fraction of Berkshire over the past decade, you've still benefited fully from your share of our retained earnings. It's not about how much of the company you own, but how effectively those earnings are used. I mean, owning 100% of a business that doesn't generate much value from its retained earnings isn't going to make you richer than owning a small piece of a business that uses its earnings wisely.
How did Berkshire's share of undistributed 1982 operating earnings from the mentioned companies compare to the total reported earnings?

Our share of undistributed 1982 operating earnings from those companies was well over $40 million, which is actually greater than our total reported earnings of $14 million in dividends received from them. It's a significant difference, and it highlights the importance of looking beyond just the reported earnings.
What advantages do you see in purchasing fractional portions of businesses, as opposed to buying entire companies?

I think the big advantage is that we can select from a wide array of major American corporations, including some really top-notch businesses that might not be available for purchase in their entirety. And we can make these purchases in an auction market, where prices can be quite volatile - sometimes it's like dealing with an army of manic-depressive lemmings, but that volatility can create opportunities for value-oriented investors like ourselves.
What makes you and your team most enthusiastic about investments?

It's the purchase of 100% of good businesses at reasonable prices that really gets us excited. This approach has been a home run for us in the past, and we're always on the lookout for the next great opportunity.
Can you reflect on any major acquisitions made by others in 1982 and how you felt about not being involved?

Looking back at the major acquisitions of 1982, I have to say we felt relief rather than envy that we weren't a part of them. Many of those deals seemed to be driven more by the thrill of the chase than a clear-headed assessment of the consequences. We dodged a bullet by not participating, and in fact, we had our own close call with a large purchase that fell through - and that was a lucky break for us.
What happens to Berkshire's ability to utilize capital effectively in partial-ownership positions if the stock market advances to considerably higher levels?

If the stock market advances to considerably higher levels, our ability to utilize capital effectively in partial-ownership positions will be reduced or eliminated. It's simple: when prices are too high, it's just not smart to buy in, no matter how good the business is.
How did the high stock prices in 1972 affect Berkshire's equity holdings in its insurance subsidiaries?

Well, back in 1972, during that two-tier market mania, our insurance subsidiaries only had $18 million in market value of equities, which was a mere 15% of our insurance company investments. That's a far cry from the 80% it is today. The prices were just absurd, and we couldn't in good conscience put our money into those overpriced stocks.
What does a combined ratio below 100 indicate in the insurance industry?
A combined ratio below 100 indicates an underwriting profit. It's like a report card for insurers - if they can keep their costs below their revenue, they're doing something right.
Why might the underwriting picture deteriorate if the annual gain in industry premiums written falls well below 10%?

Well, it's simple: if premiums aren't growing fast enough, insurers won't be able to keep up with the increasing costs of insured losses, which are driven by things like medical inflation and broader liability concepts. It's like trying to fill a bucket with a small faucet - if the water's leaking out faster than it's coming in, you're going to end up with a problem.
What happens when weak managements are in charge of weak operations in the insurance industry?

Well, I've found that weak managements often resort to weak accounting. It's like trying to prop up an empty sack - it just can't stand upright on its own. They might use obscure accounting and reserving maneuvers to mask the true state of their business, but that's just a temporary fix.
Do you think the insurance industry's underwriting experience will improve in 1983 or 1984 as the conventional wisdom suggests?

No, I disagree with that assessment. The competitive environment has changed significantly, and I think that will prevent the usual cycle of improvement. With substantial over-capacity and commodity-like products, many businesses in the industry are primed for profit troubles, and I don't see that changing anytime soon.
What types of businesses are more likely to face profit troubles?

Businesses in industries with substantial over-capacity and a commodity product are prime candidates for profit troubles. You see, when the product is undifferentiated and the buyer doesn't care who they buy from, it's tough to make a buck.
Can businesses in such industries still do well, and if so, how?

Yes, a few producers can consistently do well if they have a cost advantage that is both wide and sustainable. It's like being the low-cost leader in a race - you can still win even if the overall economics of the industry are unexciting.
What determines long-term profitability in industries with commodity products?

It's quite simple really - the ratio of supply-tight to supply-ample years. If you have more years where supply is tight, you're likely to see better profitability. But, as I've experienced, that ratio can be dismal, and those supply-tight periods can be fleeting, like the one in our textile business that lasted just about a morning.
Why is it easier for the insurance business to create new capacity compared to other industries?

In the insurance business, creating new capacity is as easy as having some capital and an underwriter willing to sign on the dotted line. It's not like manufacturing, where you need to plan and build complicated facilities, which takes a lot of time. Insurance capacity can be created almost instantly, which is a unique aspect of that industry.
How did the insurance industry primarily set prices in the past?

Well, it's quite simple really. In the past, prices were set through negotiations between industry 'bureaus' and state regulators. It was a bit like a dignified haggling process, but instead of competing with each other, companies would negotiate with regulators to set prices that included specific profit allowances.
What happened when insurance companies found their current prices to be unprofitable?

When that occurred, both company managements and state regulators would work together to correct the situation. Essentially, we could price our way to profitability, even if there was substantial over-capacity in the market. It was a pretty predictable and profit-producing system, but those days are behind us now.
What needs to happen for the insurance industry to achieve significantly improved underwriting results?

To see significantly improved underwriting results in the insurance industry, we need a major narrowing of the gap between demand and supply. This means the supply of available insurance coverage must be curtailed, which is more about underwriters being less willing to sign on the dotted line rather than physical plants being shut down.
Why won't poor profit levels lead to a contraction in the supply of insurance coverage?

Poor profit levels will lead to a lot of complaining and blaming, but that's about it. It takes more than just bad profits to get underwriters to curb their enthusiasm for signing new policies. A real contraction in supply requires a change in mindset, not just a reaction to current profit levels.
What happens when a company issues shares to make an acquisition, in terms of the value it gets for its shares?

When a company issues shares to make an acquisition, it can customarily get no higher value set on its shares than the market chooses to grant it. In other words, the company is using its shares as a kind of currency, but that currency is only worth what the market says it's worth, not its full intrinsic value.
Why do managers still go through with acquisitions that involve issuing undervalued shares, despite the potential for value destruction?

Managers often go through with these deals because they have a strong desire for size and action, and they can find ways to rationalize their decisions. They might tell themselves that the company they're buying will be worth more in the future, or they might listen to investment bankers who reassure them that the deal makes sense. As I like to say, don't ask the barber whether you need a haircut - he's got a vested interest in giving you one!
What happens to the ownership interest of existing shareholders when a company issues new shares for an acquisition?

Well, let me tell you, their interest in the company's businesses is automatically reduced. It's like inviting a neighbor to merge his farm into a partnership - your domain may grow, but your family's ownership in both the land and the crops shrinks. In Berkshire's case, if we were to issue shares for a new acquisition, our existing shareholders' interest in great businesses like See's Candy Shops and National Indemnity would be diluted.
Why do you think managers might prioritize expanding their domain over the interests of existing owners?

I think some managers might be more interested in building their own empires than in doing what's best for the owners. As I said, if they want to expand their domain at the expense of owners, they might be better off looking for a job in government - at least there, it's expected that decisions are made for the greater good, not just personal ambition.
What are the three ways to avoid destruction of value for old owners when shares are issued for acquisitions?

Well, I've identified three ways to avoid that destruction of value. First, you can have a true business-value-for-business-value merger, where both parties get a fair shake in terms of intrinsic business value. Second, if the acquirer's stock is selling at or above its intrinsic business value, using that stock as currency can actually enhance the wealth of the acquiring company's owners. And third, while it's not explicitly stated as a separate method, the text implies that having a fair and reasonable exchange, like the Berkshire-Blue Chip combination, can also work in everyone's favor.
Can you explain why using stock as currency in mergers may not always be beneficial to the acquiring company's owners?

Think of it like trading a valuable asset for something that's not worth as much. If the acquirer's stock is overvalued, the owners of the acquired company might get a good deal, but the acquirer's owners could end up losing wealth in the long run. It's like I said, a man isn't charmed if his lawn gets defaced, regardless of whether it's by a small dog or a big one - the damage is still done.
What do you think is the primary focus when calculating dilution in mergers, and do you believe this focus is misplaced?

I think the primary focus is on current earnings per share, which I believe is overdone. This narrow focus can lead to irrational actions by managers, as it doesn't consider the bigger picture of intrinsic business value.
Can a merger that is dilutive in terms of current earnings per share still be value-enhancing for the acquirer?

Yes, that's exactly what I've seen happen. Some mergers that initially dilute current and near-term earnings per share can ultimately prove to be value-enhancing. It's all about considering the many variables that affect intrinsic business value, not just the short-term earnings numbers.
Why do you think selling a portion of a company's assets or shares based on a disadvantageous valuation is not a smart move?

I believe selling a portion of a company's assets or shares at a disadvantageous valuation isn't smart because it's essentially a smaller version of a larger mistake. As I said, a cumulation of small managerial stupidities will produce a major stupidity, not a triumph. It's like consistently making small bets in Las Vegas - over time, those small losses add up and can lead to significant wealth transfers away from you.
Can you explain how the 'giving versus getting' factor works in the context of mergers and acquisitions, using the example of Investment Company X and Y?

The 'giving versus getting' factor is pretty straightforward. In the case of Investment Company X and Y, if X is selling at 50% of its asset value and decides to issue shares to merge with Y, it's essentially trading $2 of its intrinsic value for $1 of Y's intrinsic value. This is a bad deal for X's shareholders, and it's not something that would be allowed by the SEC. The idea is that management and directors should use the same yardstick to measure the fairness of both businesses in a merger or acquisition, to avoid destroying value for the owners of the acquiring company.
What happens to the market valuation of a company when it engages in value-diluting stock issuances?

Well, let me tell you, the market valuation takes a hit. It's like finding a bug in your salad - it doesn't matter if the waiter says it's a one-time mistake, you're still going to think twice about ordering from that restaurant again. Similarly, when a company shows it's willing to dilute its shares, investors get wary and won't pay as much for those assets, even if the management team has great operating talents.
How do current and prospective owners react when management has a record of wealth-destruction through unintelligent share issuances?

They lose trust, plain and simple. If management has shown it's insensitive to the interests of owners, shareholders will suffer from a lower price-to-value ratio for their stock compared to other stocks. It's a long-term consequence, and no amount of assurances from management can quickly undo the damage. Investors will be cautious, and that caution will be reflected in the stock's market value.
What is your approach to issuing shares at Berkshire, and how does it impact the company's market value?

At Berkshire, we're very mindful of how we issue shares. We only issue them if our owners receive in business value as much as we give. Think of it like a trade - we want to make sure both parties get a fair deal. This approach, I believe, is why the market gives us a premium. When managers demonstrate they won't issue shares on unfavorable terms, it shows we're looking out for the owners' interests, and that's valued by the market.
What kind of businesses do you prefer to acquire, and what are the key criteria you look for?

We're quite specific about what we're looking for in an acquisition. First, it's got to be a large purchase - at least $5 million of after-tax earnings. We also want to see consistent earning power, not just promises of future growth. The business should have good returns on equity, minimal debt, and a simple business model that we can understand. And, importantly, the management team should already be in place. We're not looking to fix broken businesses or get into complex technologies. We want solid, well-run companies that can continue to thrive under our ownership.
What were the contributions of Phil Liesche and Ben Rosner to Berkshire's growth?

Phil Liesche and Ben Rosner were two of our managerial stars. Phil, at National Indemnity Company, and Ben, at Associated Retail Stores, made our shareholders a good bit wealthier through their outstanding performance. Phil, along with his predecessor Jack Ringwalt, was instrumental in National Indemnity's success, which has been the most important operation in Berkshire's growth. Ben, on the other hand, hit business home runs for us for fifteen years after selling Associated Retail Stores, demonstrating his care and drive in running the business as if he owned it himself.
What qualities do you look for in managers to ensure Berkshire's continued success?

I look for managers with good character, like Ben and Phil, who run their businesses with the same care and drive as if they personally owned 100% of the company. No rules or incentives are needed to motivate them; their character naturally leads them to make decisions that benefit Berkshire. If we can continue to attract managers like these, I'm confident about Berkshire's future.
How do you and Charlie Munger view your relationship with Berkshire Hathaway's shareholders?

We think of our shareholders as owner-partners, and of ourselves as managing partners. It's a partnership attitude, even though our form is corporate. We believe this mindset helps us make decisions that are in the best interest of our owner-partners.
What is Berkshire Hathaway's long-term economic goal, and how do you measure its performance?

Our long-term economic goal is to maximize the average annual rate of gain in intrinsic business value on a per-share basis. We don't measure our performance by the size of the company, but rather by the progress we make per share. It's a key distinction, and one that we believe will serve our shareholders well over time.
How do you measure the economic significance or performance of Berkshire?

We measure the economic significance or performance of Berkshire by its per-share progress, not by its size. It's like measuring the success of a recipe by the flavor of the dish, not by the size of the kitchen.
Do accounting consequences influence your operating or capital-allocation decisions?

No, accounting consequences do not influence our operating or capital-allocation decisions. We focus on the true economic performance of our businesses, and we'd rather purchase earnings that may not be immediately reportable under standard accounting principles if it makes more economic sense in the long run.
Why do you prefer to purchase earnings that are not reportable under standard accounting principles over reportable earnings, when acquisition costs are similar?

I prefer to buy $2 of unreportable earnings over $1 of reportable earnings because, in the long run, I believe those unreported earnings will increase our intrinsic business value through capital gains. It's like buying two apples for the price of one, just because the accounting rules don't let me show you one of those apples right away doesn't mean it's not a great deal.
How do you approach debt and leveraging your balance sheet?

We're very conservative when it comes to debt. We rarely use much of it, and when we do, we try to lock it in at a long-term fixed rate. I'd rather pass on an attractive opportunity than risk over-leveraging our balance sheet. It's a matter of being responsible with our shareholders' money and ensuring we can sleep well at night, knowing we're not taking unnecessary risks.
How do you evaluate the wisdom of retaining earnings in Berkshire's businesses?

I evaluate the wisdom of retaining earnings by assessing whether retention, over time, delivers shareholders at least $1 of market value for each $1 retained. It's a simple test, but it keeps us honest and focused on creating value for our shareholders.
Under what circumstances will you issue common stock?

I will issue common stock only when we receive as much in business value as we give. In other words, we won't sell small portions of our company on the cheap - we'll only issue stock if it's a fair deal for our shareholders.
Why do you believe in being candid when reporting on your company's activities?

I believe candor is essential because it helps us as managers to stay honest with ourselves. If we mislead others, we might eventually mislead ourselves, and that's a recipe for disaster. Plus, as a company with a significant communications business, we should hold ourselves to the same high standards of accuracy and balance that we expect from our news people.
Why won't you discuss your investment ideas in marketable securities?

Good investment ideas are like gold dust - rare and valuable. If we share them, others might just snatch them up, so we keep them under our hat. It's not about being secretive; it's about being smart and protecting our competitive edge. We'll only discuss them to the extent the law requires us to.
What inspired Mrs. Blumkin to name her store Nebraska Furniture Mart?

Well, it's quite simple really. After seeing the American Furniture Mart in Chicago, which was the hub of the nation's wholesale furniture activity at the time, she decided to give her store a similar name. I suppose you could say she wanted a piece of that action, and the name was her way of signaling that she was a player in the industry too.
How did Mrs. Blumkin handle her financial difficulties when her resources ran out in the early days of her business?

Mrs. B, as she's affectionately known, handled it in a way that's not exactly taught in business school. When she ran out of money, she sold the furniture and appliances right out of her own home to pay her creditors exactly as promised. Now, that's what I call keeping your word and finding a way to make things work, even when the going gets tough.
How did Mrs. B cope when her resources ran out at an early point in her business?

Well, I'll tell you - she did something that wouldn't win any awards for conventional business practice. She sold her own furniture and appliances to pay off her creditors. It was a pretty drastic measure, but it showed her commitment to keeping her promises.
Why would you rather not compete with Mrs. B and her business, Nebraska Furniture Mart?

To be honest, I think competing with Mrs. B would be a losing battle. She and her team buy incredibly well, operate on expense ratios that are unheard of, and then pass those savings on to their customers. It's a tough combination to beat, and I'd rather not try - as I said, I'd rather wrestle grizzlies!
What is it about Mrs. B and her family's business that makes it so exceptional?

It's their ability to buy brilliantly, operate at incredibly low expense ratios, and then pass those savings on to their customers. That's the key to their success - providing exceptional value to the customer, which in turn translates into exceptional economics for the owners.
What's the current role of Mrs. B in the business after the sale?

Mrs. B remains the Chairman and is still very active in the business, working on the sales floor seven days a week, specializing in carpet sales. She's a force to be reckoned with, and I'm glad she's still involved.
Why do you report Berkshire's progress in terms of book value instead of intrinsic business value?

I report our progress in terms of book value because it's a conservative but reasonably adequate proxy for growth in intrinsic business value. Plus, it's easy to calculate and doesn't require the subjective judgments that come with estimating intrinsic business value.
Can you explain the difference between book value and intrinsic business value using the college education analogy you mentioned?

Think of it like putting two kids through college - the book value would be the same, since you spent the same amount on each. But the intrinsic business value, or the future payoff, could be vastly different. One kid might become a high-flying entrepreneur, while the other might not quite reach their potential. Same input, different output. That's the difference between book value, which tells you what's been put in, and intrinsic business value, which estimates what can be taken out.
What was the situation with Berkshire's book value when you took over at the beginning of fiscal 1965?

When I took over Berkshire at the beginning of fiscal 1965, the $19.46 per share book value actually overstated the intrinsic business value. The reason was that our assets were largely in textiles, which couldn't earn a decent rate of return. It was like investing in an education that didn't pay off.
Why does Berkshire's intrinsic business value now exceed its book value?

There are two main reasons our intrinsic business value exceeds book value now. First, our insurance subsidiaries' common stocks are valued at market, but other stocks we own are carried at the lower of cost or market. This means we have about $50 million in value that isn't included in book value. More importantly, some of our businesses have significant economic Goodwill that isn't fully reflected in our accounting Goodwill, which is carried on our balance sheet. I've written more about this in the appendix, but essentially, economic Goodwill is a big part of our intrinsic value that doesn't show up in our book value.
How has your thinking about Goodwill and its role in business valuation changed over time?

My thinking has changed drastically - 35 years ago, I was taught to favor tangible assets and shun businesses whose value depended largely on economic Goodwill, but now I have a strong preference for businesses with large amounts of enduring Goodwill and minimal tangible assets.
Do you believe Berkshire possesses significant economic Goodwill value beyond what's reflected in its book value?
Yes, Charlie and I believe that Berkshire possesses very significant economic Goodwill value above that reflected in our book value.
Why did you treat the proceeds from the sale of GEICO shares as a dividend?

We treated the proceeds as a dividend because the sale was proportional to our ownership, keeping our percentage of ownership the same before and after the transaction. It's like selling a portion of your interest in a business, but still maintaining the same level of control - the proceeds feel more like a distribution of earnings to us, rather than a capital gain.
Do you expect the retained earnings of companies you own to directly increase your reported earnings?

No, we don't expect those retained earnings to directly show up in our reported earnings. However, over time, we believe those undistributed earnings will increase the market value of our holdings, effectively increasing our intrinsic business value as if we had control over those earnings. It's a bit like planting a tree - you don't see the growth immediately, but with time, it should flourish and add value.
What do you believe is the best measure of a paper's strength of franchise?
I believe a paper's penetration ratio is the best measure of its franchise strength. It shows how well the paper is read by the people it's trying to reach, which is crucial for local advertisers.
Why do you think a stable population, like the one in Buffalo, contributes to a higher penetration ratio for a local daily paper?

Well, when people are rooted in a community, they're more interested in what's going on locally. It's like being a fan of the home team - you want to know what's happening in your own backyard. A stable population is more invested in their community, so they're more likely to read the local paper to stay informed.
What is the secret to See's high-quality customer service, especially considering the large number of seasonal workers you hire?

Well, I think it's quite simple really. We've just made it a priority. Our shops are operated by us, not franchisees, which allows us to maintain control over the quality of service. And, as I said, cheerful, helpful personnel are as much a trademark of See's as our logo. It's no small achievement, but Chuck Huggins and his team have done a fantastic job.
You mentioned making some serious mistakes in the insurance business a few years ago. Can you elaborate on what you learned from those mistakes?

I'd rather not go into details, but let's just say I learned a valuable lesson. The fact that GEICO, where I don't have direct influence, performed exceptionally well while our operated companies didn't, speaks for itself. It's a reminder that past decisions can have lasting consequences, and it's crucial to get things right from the start.
What is GEICO's combined ratio compared to the industry average, and what does this reflect about the company?

GEICO's combined ratio is 96, which is significantly better than the industry average of 111. This reflects the combination of a truly exceptional business idea and exceptional management, particularly in the areas of underwriting and investment management.
Why doesn't Berkshire Hathaway split its stock, and what is the company's goal regarding its stock price?

We don't split our stock because we don't think it would be a pro-shareholder action. Our goal is to have Berkshire Hathaway stock sell at a price that is rationally related to its intrinsic business value - we want the price to reflect the company's true worth, not just be artificially inflated or deflated.
How do you attract the right kind of investors to Berkshire, and what kind of investors are you looking for?

I attract the right kind of investors by consistently communicating our business and ownership philosophy, kind of like advertising a musical event. If you advertise it as an opera, you'll draw a different crowd than if you advertise it as a rock concert. I'm looking for investors who think of themselves as business owners, plan to stay invested for a long time, and focus on business results rather than market prices.
What percentage of Berkshire's shares are held by long-term investors, and how does this compare to other companies?

I believe well over 90%, probably over 95%, of our shares are held by investors who have been with us for at least five years. This is exceptional, and I think we're the leader among large companies in terms of having shareholders who think and act like owners. It's not easy to upgrade a shareholder group like ours, but we've been fortunate to have such a loyal and long-term-focused group of investors.
What kind of investors do you aim to attract with Berkshire's policies?

We're looking to attract informed long-term investors who focus on the underlying business values, not those with a short-term focus on our stock price. We want our shareholders to be in it for the long haul, understanding the true worth of our company.
Can you explain how high share turnover affects the owners of a company?

High share turnover is like a pickpocket - it takes money right out of the owners' pockets. Let me give you an example: if a company has a 100% turnover rate and each buy and sell transaction costs 1% in commissions, the owners are essentially losing 2% of the company's net worth every year to these 'frictional' costs. That's 1/6 of the company's earnings, gone, without adding any value to the business itself.
What was the purchase price of See's and what were its net tangible assets at the time of the purchase in 1972?

We bought See's for $25 million, and at that time, it had about $8 million of net tangible assets. That's a pretty significant difference, and it highlights the value of intangible assets in a business.
What contributed to See's ability to earn a 25% after-tax return on its net tangible assets?

It wasn't the value of its inventories, receivables, or fixed assets that produced those premium returns. Instead, it was the combination of intangible assets, particularly its excellent reputation with consumers, built on many positive experiences with our products and people.
How did you determine that the amortization charges for See's were not true economic costs?

I determined that by looking at See's performance - it earned $13 million after taxes on about $20 million of net tangible assets. That kind of return indicates the existence of economic Goodwill far larger than the total original cost of our accounting Goodwill. In simpler terms, See's was making a lot more money than its tangible assets alone could explain, which means its intangible assets, like its brand and customer loyalty, were incredibly valuable.
Why do you think true economic Goodwill tends to rise in nominal value proportionally with inflation?

Well, think of it like this: as prices rise due to inflation, the value of a strong brand like See's tends to rise too. People are still willing to pay a premium for a box of See's chocolates, even if the price goes up. So, in current dollars, the value of that Goodwill increases. It's not that the Goodwill itself changes, but its value in terms of what people are willing to pay does. That's why I think true economic Goodwill will likely keep increasing in nominal value as inflation rises.
Why did you pay $25 million for See's in 1972 when it had less than half the assets of a mundane business with the same earnings?

Well, it's quite simple really. We anticipated a world of continuous inflation, and that changes the game. You see, a business like See's, with its strong economic goodwill, can increase its earnings without needing to increase its assets as much. It's like a machine that can print money, and inflation just adds fuel to the fire. In contrast, that mundane business would need to double its investment in assets just to keep up with inflation, which isn't exactly the most attractive prospect.
How would a doubling of the price level due to inflation affect the two businesses in terms of their need for investment in net tangible assets?

Inflation is like a big weight that businesses have to carry. When prices double, both businesses would likely need to double their investment in net tangible assets just to maintain their current level of operations. It's not just a matter of selling the same number of units at higher prices; you've got to invest in more assets to support that increased revenue. But, as I said, a business like See's is better equipped to handle that kind of scenario, and that's why we were willing to pay a premium for it.
How does inflation affect businesses that require significant tangible assets to operate?

Inflation hurts any unleveraged business that requires some net tangible assets to operate. Essentially, the owners have to ante up more capital just to stay even in real profits. It's like trying to fill a leaky bucket - you're putting in more water, but the bucket's still leaking. In the case of See's, the owners had to put up $8 million in additional capital just to maintain their real profits.
What type of businesses tend to perform better during inflationary periods?

Businesses that combine intangibles of lasting value with relatively minor requirements for tangible assets tend to perform better during inflationary periods. These businesses are like a ship that can sail smoothly through treacherous waters, whereas asset-heavy businesses are more like a heavy anchor that's hard to lift. A disproportionate number of great business fortunes have been built by owning operations with this kind of profile.
What types of businesses tend to earn low rates of return, according to your experience?

I've found that asset-heavy businesses generally earn low rates of return. They often barely generate enough capital to keep up with inflation, leaving little room for growth, distributions, or new acquisitions.
You mention that Goodwill can be a valuable asset during inflation. What's the key distinction you make between 'true economic Goodwill' and 'spurious accounting Goodwill'?

Well, true economic Goodwill refers to the lasting value of intangible assets, like a strong brand or franchise, which can increase in value over time. On the other hand, spurious accounting Goodwill is what you get when management overpays for a business and the excess ends up on the books as an 'asset' – I like to call that 'No-Will'.
How should managers and investors view intangible assets when analyzing operating results?

When looking at operating results, I believe managers and investors should ignore amortization charges. This gives a clearer picture of the business's underlying economics and its true earning potential on unleveraged net tangible assets.
What factors should be considered when determining the cost of a business acquisition?

When evaluating the cost of a business acquisition, I think it's essential to consider the full intrinsic business value of all consideration given, not just the recorded accounting value. This includes the market value of any securities involved, even if it differs from their intrinsic value, as we saw in the Blue Chip merger.
What is the key difference between the market value and intrinsic business value of Berkshire shares in a merger?

The key difference is that the market value is what the shares are trading for at the time of the merger, while the intrinsic business value represents the true worth of the business, which can be higher. Think of it like buying a house - the market value is what you pay for it, but the intrinsic value is what it's really worth based on its condition, location, and other factors.
How do you plan to evaluate potential business acquisitions, and what role does accounting play in this process?

When looking to acquire a business, we focus on two main things: excellent operating economics and reasonable returns. We ignore accounting consequences because they can be misleading. It's like choosing a restaurant - you don't just look at the decor, you also want to know if the food is good and the prices are fair. Accounting is just the decor; we're interested in the substance behind it.
What was Berkshire Hathaway's gain in net worth during 1984, and how does it compare to your historical performance?

Our gain in net worth during 1984 was $152.6 million, or $133 per share. While this sounds good on the surface, I consider it mediocre compared to our historical 22.1% twenty-year compounded annual gain in book value. The 1984 gain was only 13.6%, which is a significant drop from our long-term average.
You mentioned that to earn 15% annually over the next decade, Berkshire Hathaway would need profits aggregating about $3.9 billion. What kind of ideas do you think are necessary to achieve this goal?

To accomplish this, we would need a few big ideas - small ones just won't do. Unfortunately, Charlie Munger and I don't have any such ideas at present, but our experience has been that they do pop up occasionally. As I said, that's about as much of a strategic plan as we have right now!
What message do you think a company sends to its shareholders when it makes repurchases while its market value is below its business value?

When a company buys back its shares at a price below its true business value, it's like a big neon sign saying, 'Hey, we're looking out for you, shareholders!' It shows that management is focused on increasing the wealth of owners, not just expanding their own empire. And that, in turn, can boost shareholders' confidence and lead to more realistic market prices.
Can you give an example of how share repurchases have benefited your investments?

I can give you a few examples, actually. We've done very well with the large share repurchases of companies like GEICO, Washington Post, and General Foods - which happen to be three of our largest holdings. Those repurchases have worked out beautifully for us and for other shareholders, and they're a big part of why we've prospered over time.
What was Levitz Furniture's gross margin in its fiscal year 1984?
Levitz Furniture's gross margin in fiscal 1984 was 44.4%. To put that into perspective, for every $100 they sold something for, it only cost them $55.60 to buy it.
How do the Blumkins' secrets to their business success relate to their area of special competence?

The Blumkins define their area of special competence with extraordinary realism and act decisively on matters within it, but they also ignore propositions that fall outside of it. This focus is key to their success, and it's not about being flashy or chasing every opportunity - it's about knowing what you're good at and sticking to it.
What are the key characteristics that you look for in a family business, such as the Blumkin family?

I look for four main things: enthusiasm and energy, a clear definition of their area of special competence, the discipline to ignore enticing propositions outside of that area, and a commitment to behaving in a high-grade manner with everyone they deal with. As my partner Mrs. B puts it, 'sell cheap and tell the truth'.
What was unusual about the purchase of NFM, and what does it say about the Blumkin family's integrity?

What was unusual was that we didn't do any of the usual due diligence - no audit, no inventory check, no verification of receivables. We simply gave Mrs. B a check for $55 million, and she gave us her word. That's a testament to the trust we had in her and her family's integrity, and it's a deal that's worked out very well for us.
Do the economics of a dominant newspaper depend on the quality of the product it delivers?

No, the economics of a dominant newspaper are not directly tied to the quality of the product. In fact, I've seen third-rate papers making profits just as good as, or even better than, first-class ones, as long as they're dominant in their community. It's the dominance that matters, not necessarily the quality.
How do you ensure that the newspaper maintains high standards, given that the marketplace doesn't impose them?

Well, since the marketplace won't push us to be better, we have to push ourselves. That's why we've committed to spending more than average on news, and why I have confidence in our team, like Stan Lipsey and Murray Light, to apply high qualitative standards. It's up to management to set and maintain those standards.
What changes have you seen in the insurance market that have allowed you to raise prices, and how has your company's financial strength played a role in this?

Well, with the competition shaken due to poorer-than-average results in certain lines, we've been able to raise prices significantly in the last half of 1984 without losing much business. Our premier financial strength has made a real difference here - it's a promise that we can keep, even in adversity, and that's what buyers of insurance should be looking for.
How do you think your company's financial strength will impact its position in the market, particularly in areas like structured settlements and loss reserve assumptions?

I believe our financial strength is a particular asset in those areas. We're willing and able to keep our promises, even in a prolonged combination of depressed financial markets and unfavorable underwriting results. Not many other companies can say that, and I think that sets us apart, especially in businesses like structured settlements and loss reserve assumptions where stability and reliability are key.
What is more important to you when evaluating the performance of GEICO, business performance or market performance?

I can tell you straight out, it's business performance. We look at how the company is doing in terms of its core operations, not just how the market is valuing it at any given time. If the business is strong, the market will eventually catch on.
