What qualities make Lou Simpson an effective investor for GEICO's funds?

Lou has a rare combination of temperamental and intellectual characteristics that make him an outstanding long-term investor. He operates with below-average risk and has consistently delivered returns that are the best in the insurance industry.
What components make up the loss expense charged in a property/casualty company's current income statement?

The loss expense charged in our current income statement includes four key components: losses that occurred and were paid during the year, estimates for losses that occurred and were reported but haven't been settled yet, estimates of the ultimate costs for losses that occurred during the year but we're not yet aware of, and the net effect of revisions to similar estimates made in past years.
Can you provide an example of how revisions to loss estimates can affect earnings in later years?

Let me give you an example. Suppose we had a claim from 1979 that we initially thought would settle for $10,000. We'd charge that to our earnings statement for 1979 and set up a liability reserve for the same amount. But if the claim actually settled in 1984 for $100,000, we'd have to charge an additional $90,000 to earnings in 1984, even though the expense really belonged to 1979. That's how revisions can misstate earnings in the year of correction.
How do insolvent insurance companies manage to stay afloat despite being broke?

Well, it's quite simple really. In the insurance business, cash comes in upfront when a policy is sold, but the losses are paid out much later. This means an insolvent insurer can appear flush with cash even when they're actually broke, because they're collecting premiums now and won't have to pay out claims until later. It's a bit like living off a credit card - you can look wealthy for a while, but eventually, the bill comes due.
What's the impact on Berkshire when other insurance companies become insolvent?

When those 'walking dead' insurance companies finally go under, we feel the pain in two ways. First, we have to compete with them while they're still operating, and they're willing to sell policies at any price just to keep the cash coming in. That makes it tough for us to compete. And second, when they do go bust, we end up paying a portion of their asset deficiencies through state guarantee funds. It's like being asked to help clean up someone else's mess - not exactly what we signed up for.
What was the basis for your decision to purchase WPPSS bonds despite the problems associated with them?

We judged the risks at the time of purchase to be more than compensated for by the prospects of profit, given the prices we paid - which were much lower than the current prices. It's a bit like buying a good business at a discount; if you can get it cheap enough, the potential for gain outweighs the risks.
How do you approach buying marketable stocks for Berkshire's insurance companies?

We use a business-valuation approach, where we consider what it would be like to buy the entire business. If we can buy small pieces of a business with good underlying economics at a fraction of its total worth, we figure something good is likely to happen. It's not a common approach, but it's worked for us.
You mention that most businesses have a limited upside potential unless more capital is continuously invested in them. Can you explain why this is the case, even under inflationary conditions?

Well, I think it's because most businesses just can't significantly improve their average returns on equity, no matter what the economic conditions are. It's not like inflation automatically makes your business more profitable. Now, if you're reinvesting your earnings, that's a different story. But on its own, inflation doesn't magically raise returns.
You use the example of a 30-year, zero-coupon, 12% bond and a $10 million business that earns 12% on equity. How do the growth prospects of these two investments compare?

They're actually pretty similar. If you take that bond and use the coupon proceeds to buy more bonds, or if you have a business that earns 12% on equity and retains all its earnings, both will grow at a comparable rate. In fact, in my example, both will end up with $300 million in capital by 2015 and earn over $32 million in the final year. It just goes to show that sometimes bonds and businesses aren't as different as you might think.
What was the yield on 20-year AAA tax-exempt bonds in 1946 and how did it compare to potential business investments at the time?

The yield on those bonds was slightly below 1%. To put that into perspective, it's like buying a business that can only earn 1% on its book value, which is a pretty dismal prospect. Meanwhile, you could have invested in businesses with great future prospects that were earning 10%, 12%, or 15% after tax on book value. It's a no-brainer - the bond investment just didn't make sense compared to the potential of those businesses.
What advice do you think investors should take away from your discussion of bond investment and business perspective?

I think investors should approach bond investment with a businessman's perspective, as I've said. It's essential to think about the potential returns and risks in the same way you would when evaluating a business opportunity. As Ben Graham so aptly put it in 'The Intelligent Investor', investment is most intelligent when it is most businesslike. So, investors should be cautious and not rush into bond investments that offer inadequate returns, just as they wouldn't invest in a business with poor prospects.
What do you think is the key characteristic of intelligent investing, according to Ben Graham's book 'The Intelligent Investor'

I think Ben Graham nailed it when he said that investment is most intelligent when it is most businesslike. That's the core idea - treating investments like a business decision, not just some speculative gamble.
Why do you think most managers are hesitant to make unconventional decisions, even if they might be intelligent ones?

Well, it's pretty simple: their personal gain-to-pain ratio is all out of whack. If an unconventional decision pays off, they get a pat on the back, but if it doesn't, they're out of a job. It's a lot safer for them to fail conventionally - after all, no individual lemming ever gets bad press, right?
Why do you and Charlie Munger behave unconventionally with Berkshire's investments?

We behave unconventionally because, as owners of 47% of Berkshire's stock, we don't have to worry about being fired. This freedom, combined with receiving our rewards as owners rather than managers, allows us to make decisions with Berkshire's money as we would with our own. It's a simple yet powerful mindset.
What's the reasoning behind concentrating investments in a few securities rather than diversifying more widely?

Our concentration strategy makes sense for us because of our exceptional financial strength. We can afford to own large blocks of a few securities that we've carefully selected and bought at attractive prices. As Billy Rose once said, having too many investments is like having a harem of forty women - you never get to know any of them very well. By focusing on a few key investments, we can really get to know them and make more informed decisions.
Why do you choose not to disclose your investment activities in securities to shareholders or the press?

I don't disclose our investment activities because the buying and selling of securities is a competitive business. If others know what we're doing, they might follow suit, which could drive up prices or reduce the amount we can buy. It's like trying to get a good deal on a car - if the salesman knows you're willing to pay top dollar, he's not going to give you a discount. We want to keep our actions private to avoid giving others an unfair advantage.
What is your general view on purchasing long-term bonds?

To be honest, I'm not a big fan of buying most long-term bonds under most circumstances. We've bought very few in recent years, and that's because we think they often don't offer the best value. Our WPPSS purchases were an exception, but overall, we're pretty selective when it comes to long-term bonds.
Why do you generally dislike the purchase of most long-term bonds?

I dislike long-term bonds because I view the long-term outlook for dollars as dismal, and I believe substantial inflation lies ahead. It's like lending someone money for 10 or 20 years without adjusting for the fact that the money they're paying you back with might be worth a lot less by then.
What happens to a diversified stock portfolio and bonds in the event of runaway inflation?

In the case of runaway inflation, a diversified stock portfolio would likely suffer a significant loss in real value, but bonds already outstanding would suffer even more. It's a grim scenario for both, but bonds would be particularly hard hit.
Why do you think an all-bond portfolio carries a 'wipe out' risk?

I think an all-bond portfolio carries a 'wipe out' risk because, in certain circumstances like high inflation, bonds already outstanding would suffer far more than a diversified stock portfolio. It's like trying to navigate a ship through treacherous waters without a life jacket - you're exposed to a lot of potential damage.
What kind of earnings cannot be distributed as dividends without harming the business?

I call them 'restricted' earnings. These are earnings that, due to inflation, are necessary for the business to maintain its economic position. If we distribute these earnings as dividends, the business would lose ground in areas like sales volume, competitive position, or financial strength. It's like trying to run a car without gas - it just won't go far.
What happens to a company that consistently distributes 'restricted' earnings as dividends?

If a company keeps paying out these restricted earnings, it's headed for trouble - it'll lose its edge in areas like sales, competitiveness, and financial stability. Unless it gets an infusion of new equity capital, it's destined for oblivion.
You mentioned Consolidated Edison as an example. What was unusual about their situation?

Well, Consolidated Edison was in a tough spot due to regulatory policies, and their stock was selling for as low as a quarter of its book value. The irony was that even though reinvesting earnings essentially turned dollars into quarters in terms of market value, they still chose to reinvest most of their earnings rather than paying them out to owners.
If interest rates are 5%, what should a rational investor do with their 10% bond coupon, and why?

If interest rates are 5%, I'd advise taking the coupon in additional bonds and then selling them. This way, you'd get more cash than if you took the coupon directly in cash. It's like getting a better deal on your money - why settle for less when you can have more?
What would you do with your 10% bond coupon if interest rates were 15%, and why?

With interest rates at 15%, I'd take my coupon in cash. Reinvesting it in 10% bonds wouldn't make sense since their market value would be far less than the cash I could get. If I still want 10% bonds, I can just buy them in the market at a discount - it's a smarter way to use my money.

Why do CEOs often instruct subsidiaries with lower expected earnings to distribute their earnings to subsidiaries with higher expected earnings, but fail to apply the same logic to the parent company's dividend policy?

I've seen this happen time and time again - CEOs will happily shuffle money around between subsidiaries to maximize returns, but when it comes to the parent company, they often stick to traditional dividend policies without giving it much thought. It's like they're wearing two different hats, and it just doesn't make sense.
How should shareholders evaluate whether managers should retain earnings, according to you?

Shareholders should be careful not to just look at the total earnings and capital of the company as a whole. They need to dig deeper and consider what's going on in the core business, especially during inflationary periods. If a company has a strong core business, it can generate a lot of excess cash, even with minimal incremental capital. So, shareholders should ask themselves - and management should be prepared to explain - why earnings are being retained, and whether it's really in the best interests of the owners.
What is the date and location of Berkshire's annual meeting, and what makes it different from other annual meetings?

Our annual meeting will be on May 21, 1985, in Omaha. I think what sets ours apart is the quality of the discussion - we get a wide variety of thoughtful questions about the business, and Charlie and I are happy to answer them all. It's a real forum for business discussion, not just a stage for theatrics or personal agendas.
Are there any limits to the questions you'll answer at the annual meeting?
Yes, there are some limits. We won't discuss business matters where candor might cost our company real money. Other than that, we're open to answering any questions our shareholders might have.
What was the gain in Berkshire Hathaway's net worth during 1985, and how does it compare to the likelihood of seeing Halley's Comet again in your lifetime?

Our gain in net worth during 1985 was $613.6 million, or 48.2%. I must say, it's fitting that this percentage gain coincided with the visit of Halley's Comet - neither will be seen again in my lifetime. It was a remarkable year, and I'm glad we could capitalize on the opportunities that presented themselves.
You mentioned that the current stock market offers very little opportunity for undervalued equities. How does this compare to the market situation about a decade ago?

The current situation is 180 degrees removed from what we saw about a decade ago. Back then, we were spoiled for choice - there were so many bargains to choose from, the only question was which one to pick. Today, it's a very different story. We're having a hard time finding significantly undervalued equities to purchase for our insurance company portfolios.
What kind of impact does the elimination of the discount between Berkshire's market value and intrinsic business value have on new owners?

Well, let me tell you, it's not exactly a welcome gift for new owners. When we used to sell at a modest discount to our intrinsic business value, purchasers could be fairly certain their investment experience would at least match the financial performance of the business. But now that the discount has disappeared and sometimes we even trade at a premium, new owners face a challenge. If they pay that premium, they need the market to maintain it just to match the business's future financial performance. It's not exactly the best starting point for them.
Do you, as the manager, have any influence over Berkshire's market price in relation to its intrinsic business value?

As much as I'd like to wave a magic wand and set the market price exactly where I think it should be, the truth is, I don't have direct control over it. What I can do, though, is provide transparent disclosures and implement sensible policies that encourage market participants to behave rationally. My personal preference? I'd love to see our market price consistently reflect our business value. That way, all owners would see their investments perform in line with the actual success of the business.
What is your preference when it comes to market price in relation to business value?

My preference is for a market price that consistently approximates business value. This way, all owners can prosper precisely as the business prospers during their period of ownership, without the wild swings in market prices that can lead to inequitable distribution of gains.
Why do you think Berkshire's market value has had a more consistent relationship with its business value compared to other publicly-traded equities?

I believe it's because of our shareholder group - virtually all of our shareholders are individuals, not institutions, and they've been rational, interested, and investment-oriented. This unusual demographic has led to a market price for Berkshire stock that's almost always been sensible.
Why do you think investment professionals, despite being highly paid and experienced, often contribute to inappropriate stock valuations?

Well, I think Ben Graham's story about the oil prospector heading to heaven illustrates this point pretty well. It shows how even experienced professionals can't resist the urge to follow the crowd, even if it means chasing a rumor. In the story, the prospector and the other oil men march out of the compound to head for the nether regions based on an unverified claim of 'oil discovered in hell.' This behavior is similar to what we see in financial markets, where professionals often prioritize following the crowd over making independent, reasoned decisions.
What kind of financial data do you and Charlie Munger focus on when evaluating Berkshire's performance?

Charlie and I focus on the detailed sub-segment numbers, which give us a clearer picture of how each part of Berkshire is doing. We don't find consolidated figures very helpful for managing or evaluating the company, which is why we never prepare them for internal use. Instead, we look at the major sources of Berkshire's reported earnings, like the ones shown in the table on the next page.
What do you mean by comparing security profits to a college graduation ceremony?

Well, just like a graduation ceremony recognizes the knowledge gained over four years all at once, security profits in a given year reflect the growth in value of a stock over its entire holding period, not just what happened in that specific year. It's a way of acknowledging the cumulative effort, if you will.
How do gains or losses in market value of stocks owned by your insurance subsidiaries affect your financials?

If the stock is owned by our insurance subsidiaries, any gain or loss in market value is reflected in our net worth annually. This is different from stocks we hold elsewhere, where the gain or loss is only reflected in the year we sell the stock.
How do you view the role of capital gains in measuring a company's performance in a given year?

I think reported capital gains or losses in any given year are meaningless as a measure of how well we've done. You see, all growth in value since purchase will be reflected in the accounting earnings of the year of sale, so it's not a good indicator of our current year's performance.
What factors contributed to the realized gain from the sale of General Foods shares in 1985?

We benefited from four key factors: a bargain purchase price, a business with strong underlying economics, able management that looked out for shareholders, and a buyer willing to pay full business value. It was a great example of how we like to build value for Berkshire shareholders.
Why did you agree to sell shares in certain companies, and what condition did you set for doing so?

I agreed to sell shares when managements initiated the idea, and I did so because I believed non-selling shareholders benefited from the repurchases at prices below the intrinsic business value. I only sold to the extent that our proportional share of the business remained undiminished, meaning our stake in the company didn't get diluted.
What lesson does Charlie Munger emphasize, and how does it relate to your experience with Berkshire Hathaway's businesses?

Charlie Munger emphasizes the importance of studying mistakes rather than successes. I've certainly provided him with plenty of material to study, particularly with our textile and insurance businesses. In fact, our experience with the textile business, which we recently shut down, is a prime example of what can be learned from mistakes.
What was the main challenge faced by the domestic textile industry, according to your experience?

The main challenge we faced was competing in a world market with substantial excess capacity, and dealing with competition from foreign countries whose workers were paid a small fraction of the U.S. minimum wage. It's a tough spot to be in, kind of like trying to sell a hamburger for $10 when the guy next door is selling one for $2.
Do you believe the labor force was to blame for the troubles experienced by your textile mill?

Not at all. In fact, our workers were poorly paid compared to the rest of American industry, and they were very cooperative in contract negotiations. They understood our cost position and didn't push for unrealistic wage increases. I think they did a superb job, even during the tough times when we were liquidating.
What was the outcome for Burlington's shareholders despite the company's significant capital expenditures and efforts to improve its textile business?

The outcome was devastating for Burlington's shareholders. Despite the company's large capital expenditures and efforts to improve its textile business, the shareholders saw the purchasing power of their shares decrease significantly. The stock price, adjusted for splits, is now just a little over its 1964 price, and with the CPI more than tripling, each share commands about one-third the purchasing power it did back then. Additionally, the regular dividends paid out have also shrunk significantly in purchasing power.
What do you believe is more important for a company's success: the industry it operates in or how well it is managed?

From my experiences and observations, I believe a good managerial record is far more a function of what business or industry you're in, rather than how effectively you manage it. Don't get me wrong, intelligence and effort are important, but they can only take you so far if you're in a struggling industry. It's like the old saying about the horse that can count to ten - it's a remarkable horse, but not necessarily a remarkable mathematician. Similarly, a company can be a remarkable operator in its industry, but if the industry itself isn't strong, the company's overall success will be limited.
What do you believe is more important for a company's success, the industry it operates in or the management's ability to allocate capital effectively?

I think it's clear that the industry, or what I call the 'business boat,' is far more important. A good managerial record is more a function of what business you're in than how well you're rowing, although intelligence and effort certainly help. It's like trying to row a boat with a hole in it - no matter how hard you row, you're not going to get very far.
What lesson did you learn from the auction of your textile machinery in 1986 regarding book value and replacement value?

Well, I learned that book value and replacement value aren't as important as some people think. We sold off our textile equipment, which was still very usable, and it was a real education for me and others who put a lot of weight on those values. It showed me that just because something has a high book value or replacement value, it doesn't mean it's worth that much in reality.
What was the original cost of the textile machinery, and how much did it sell for at the auction?

The original cost of the textile machinery was about $13 million, and it sold for a gross of $163,122 at the auction. After accounting for pre- and post-sale costs, our net proceeds were actually less than zero.
How did the value of the relatively modern looms change from their purchase price to their sale price?

We bought those looms for $5,000 apiece in 1981, but when we tried to sell them, we couldn't find any takers even at $50. We eventually had to sell them for scrap at $26 each, which is less than what it cost us to remove them.
What was the title of your grandfather's book that he was working on?
My grandfather's book title was 'How to Run a Grocery Store and a Few Things I Have Learned About Fishing'. I must say, it's a title that certainly catches your attention!
How have the earnings of Nebraska Furniture Mart, See's Candy Shops, and Buffalo Evening News changed over the past 15 years?

The earnings of these three businesses have increased from $8 million pre-tax 15 years ago to $72 million pre-tax in 1985. That's a pretty significant jump, and I'm pleased to say that the earnings 15 years ago were already excellent compared to the capital employed at the time.
How do you think stock options for managers should be structured to better reflect individual performance?

Honestly, I think the current system is flawed because it's blind to individual performance. A manager who does a great job and one who's just along for the ride can end up with the same rewards from their options. It's like giving everyone a trophy just for showing up. To fix this, options should be more closely tied to actual performance, not just the passage of time.
Can you give an example from your experience where a stock option reward seemed out of balance with the recipient's contribution?

The Chrysler example comes to mind. The U.S. Government got a great deal on some stock options as part of a loan guarantee, and when they paid off big, Chrysler wanted to renegotiate. It just goes to show that even companies can feel like the reward isn't always aligned with the effort or contribution. It's a bit like winning the lottery - it's great for the winner, but it doesn't necessarily mean they deserved it.
Why did Chrysler's managers object to the government's payoff from the options, and how does this compare to managers' typical behavior with their own options?

Chrysler's managers were upset because they felt the government's payoff was far greater than intended and out of proportion to its contribution to the company's recovery. What's interesting, and a bit humorous, is that this reaction is quite rare - managers usually don't complain about getting more than they deserve from their own options. In fact, I've never seen managers object to unwarranted payoffs from options granted to themselves or their colleagues.
How do the interests of option holders differ from those of owners, particularly in terms of dividend policy?

Well, let me tell you - option holders and owners are in different boats, financially speaking. As an owner, I have to consider both the upside potential and the downside risk of a business project. But an option holder doesn't have that downside risk, so their interests can be quite different. For example, when it comes to dividend policy, an option holder would typically prefer a no-dividend policy, so they can benefit from the retained earnings. On the other hand, as an owner, I'd want a total payout so I can prevent the option holder from sharing in those earnings.
Why do you think managers should price options at true business value, rather than using market prices?

I believe options should be priced at true business value because it's only fair to owners. If managers think market prices are unrealistic when it comes to selling their company, they shouldn't use those same depressed prices to sell parts of the business to themselves or insiders. It's like selling a piece of your house to a family member at a lowball price just because the overall market is down - it doesn't make sense.
You mention that some managers you admire use fixed-price options successfully. What's your stance on altering their approach?

Look, if it ain't broke, don't fix it. If a company has built a corporate culture that works, and fixed-price options are part of that, I'm not inclined to mess with it. Even if the option program has some inefficiencies, the overall culture and leadership are more important. At Berkshire, we do things differently, but I recognize that what works for us may not work for everyone else.
How do insurers typically handle the risk of writing large policies, such as a $25 million D&O liability policy?

Well, traditionally, many insurers want to write this kind of business, but they don't want to take on all that risk themselves. So, they use reinsurance arrangements that let them keep just a small portion of the risk, while passing on most of it to their reinsurers. It's like sharing a big pizza - they take a small slice and give the rest to their reinsurers.
How do you determine the fair division of premiums among the various layers of risk in a reinsurance arrangement?

One way to approach this is to look at past experience, kind of like the Patrick Henry approach. You see how much of the total premium the reinsurers would have needed in the past to fairly compensate them for the losses they actually had to bear. It's a simple, yet effective way to guide your decision-making.
What percentage of premiums did the issuing company keep from the $6 billion of business it wrote in 1984?
The issuing company kept around 40% of the premiums, which was about $2 1/2 billion.
How did the underwriting loss of the issuing company compare to the loss of its reinsurers in 1984?

My example shows a stark contrast - the issuing company had an underwriting loss of less than $200 million on the part of the business it kept, while its reinsurers suffered a loss of over $1.5 billion on the part they covered.
What seems to be the main reason for reinsurers' poor performance in certain lines of insurance, according to your observation?

It's not due to natural catastrophes, but rather run-of-the-mill insurance losses that have been occurring with surprising frequency and size. These losses have led to dramatically unbalanced results for reinsurers, making them wary of continuing in these lines.
How have reinsurers responded to their poor experience in certain insurance lines, and what impact has this had on issuing companies?

Reinsurers have essentially become gun-shy, much like Mark Twain's cat that won't sit on any stove again, hot or cold. They've had too many unpleasant surprises and have decided to pull back or even give up on certain lines entirely, regardless of the price. This has left many issuing companies under pressure, as they can no longer easily commit their reinsurers to large risks and don't have the capital or appetite to take on those risks themselves.
How has Berkshire's approach to underwriting large risks changed in relation to other insurers?

Well, I'd say the tables have turned in our favor. Unlike others, we never played the game of laying off risks at a profit, which put us at a disadvantage. Now, with others lacking the capital or appetite for large risks, we're in a position to write net lines larger than most insurers, as long as the price is right.
What was the outcome of National Indemnity Company's ad soliciting large policies in mid-1985?
That ad was a real success. We received about 600 replies and it ultimately generated around $50 million in premiums. Not bad for a simple ad in an insurance weekly, if I do say so myself.
What was the nature of the underreserving revealed at the end of 1984?

The underreserving revealed at the end of 1984 was largely confined to the reinsurance area, and a significant portion of it was attributed to a few contracts that had been discontinued several years prior.
What lesson do you believe managers should learn from their mistakes, according to the story about the Except-For Insurance Company?

I think the key lesson for managers is to avoid making excuses and instead own up to their mistakes. The story about the Except-For Insurance Company highlights the tendency for managers to downplay their errors by saying 'except for' this or that. The real mistake, in my view, is not the error itself, but rather the manager's inability to acknowledge and learn from it.
What was the estimated intrinsic business value of WPC, and how did it compare to its stock market valuation at the time?

The estimated intrinsic business value of WPC was around $400 to $500 million, which was significantly higher than its stock market valuation of $100 million at the time. It's like comparing apples and oranges - the real value of the business was obscured by the market's misguided pricing.
How did the market value of your WPC holding change by the end of 1974, compared to your initial investment?

By the end of 1974, our WPC holding showed a loss of about 25%, with the market value dropping to $8 million from our initial cost of $10.6 million. It was a tough period, but we stuck to our principles, knowing that the intrinsic value of the business was still growing, even if the market didn't reflect it yet.
What was the outcome for our WPC holding by the end of 1974, and how did it compare to our initial cost?

By the end of 1974, our WPC holding showed a loss of about 25%, with a market value of $8 million compared to our initial cost of $10.6 million. It's amusing to think that what we thought was ridiculously cheap a year earlier had become an even better bargain, with the market price dropping to well below 20 cents on the dollar of its intrinsic value.
How did our investment in WPC ultimately perform compared to investing in other media companies at the time?

Our investment in WPC performed exceptionally well. If we had invested our $10.6 million in other media companies that were favorites in mid-1973, our holdings would have been worth around $40 to $60 million by the end of the period. Instead, our WPC investment, including proceeds from the 1985 redemption and the market value of our remaining holdings, totaled $221 million. It's a great example of how focusing on intrinsic value and the exceptional economics of a business can lead to outstanding investment results.
What are the key criteria you look for when considering an acquisition?

We've got six key things we look for: large purchases with at least $10 million of after-tax earnings, consistent earning power, good returns on equity with little to no debt, management already in place, simple businesses that we can understand, and an offering price that's clear from the start.
How do you handle the process of evaluating potential acquisitions, and what kind of response time can sellers expect?

We keep it straightforward - when someone approaches us with an opportunity, we can promise complete confidentiality and a very fast answer, usually within five minutes, on whether we're interested or not. We like to buy for cash, but we're open to issuing stock if the deal makes sense for both parties.
What was the gain in net worth for Berkshire Hathaway Inc. during 1986?
Our gain in net worth during 1986 was $492.5 million, which translates to a 26.1% increase. I'm pleased with that performance, and I think it reflects the solid work of our team.
How has the per-share book value of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. changed since you took over as manager?
Since I took over, our per-share book value has grown from $19.46 to $2,073.06. That's a compounded annual growth rate of 23.3% over 22 years. It's a remarkable run, if I do say so myself.
What is the main reason for the improvement in business value relative to book value at your company?

The main reason is the outstanding performance of our key managers at our major operating businesses. They've done a superb job in improving earnings without needing a lot of additional capital, which builds economic value that isn't reflected in our balance sheet or book value.
What is your approach to managing the talented managers who run your various operations?

My approach is simple: I don't get in their way. These managers are stars and have proven themselves over the years. If I were managing a golf team with Jack Nicklaus or Arnold Palmer, I wouldn't be telling them how to swing - and it's the same with our managers. We just make sure to attract and keep them, and then let them do their thing.
What is your approach to managing talented individuals, such as those who work for Berkshire?

My approach is simple: I don't get in their way. If you've got someone as talented as Jack Nicklaus or Arnold Palmer on your team, you're not going to tell them how to swing a golf club. You just let them do what they do best, and that's exactly what we do with our key managers. We give them the freedom to operate and make decisions, because they're the experts in their field.
What philosophy do you and Charlie follow when it comes to hiring people to work for Berkshire?

Charlie and I subscribe to the philosophy of David Ogilvy, which is to hire people who are bigger than we are. In other words, we look for talented individuals who can help us build a company of giants, not dwarfs. We believe that by hiring the best people, we can create a team that will make us look good, and more importantly, drive the success of Berkshire.
What factors made Fechheimer an attractive acquisition for Berkshire, and how do you assess the management continuity of the company?

Fechheimer was a standout acquisition for us due to its strong economic characteristics and the quality of the people involved. The managing family, the Heldmans, had a strong track record and a clear vision for the business. As for management continuity, I'm pleased to say that we have multiple generations of the family involved, including Bob and George, who are still active in their mid-60s, and the next generation - Gary, Roger, and Fred - who will ensure the business continues to thrive.
Do you and Charlie Munger typically visit the companies you acquire, such as Fechheimer, to inspect their operations?

Actually, we don't. In fact, neither Charlie nor I have visited Fechheimer's headquarters in Cincinnati. And that's not unusual for us. We focus on evaluating the economic characteristics of the business and the quality of the people, rather than relying on plant inspections. It's worked out just fine for us so far - and it's a two-way street, by the way. Some of our long-time managers, like Chuck Huggins at See's, have never even been to Omaha!
What is the minimum threshold for annual after-tax earnings that you look for in potential acquisitions?

We've raised our threshold to $10 million. That's the minimum annual after-tax earnings we're looking for in potential acquisitions. It's a significant increase from our previous $5 million level, but we're looking for substantial opportunities that can make a real impact.
Do you consider issuing stock as a form of payment for acquisitions, or do you prefer cash deals?

While we prefer to buy for cash, we're open to issuing stock if the deal makes sense. The key is that we need to receive as much in intrinsic business value as we give. It's a fair trade, if you will. We're not looking to give away value, but if the numbers work, we're willing to consider stock as part of the deal.
How does your firm's approach to pricing affect your customers when many other insurers are offering lower prices?

Our firmness on prices doesn't work any hardship on the consumer. When lots of other insurers are around and slashing prices, our customers might leave us to take advantage of those bargains. But that's okay - they're not missing out on anything because they're being bombarded with attractively priced offers from our competitors at those times.
What happens to your employees during cyclical slowdowns in your insurance operations?

We don't engage in layoffs when we experience a slowdown. This no-layoff practice is in our self-interest, really. If our employees thought we'd start cutting jobs whenever business slowed down, they might not produce as much business for us. But since they know their jobs are secure, they keep on working hard - and that's good for everyone.
What do you mean by 'reserve strengthening' in the context of insurance executives establishing proper reserves?

Well, I think 'reserve strengthening' is a bit of a euphemism. To me, it's more like correcting previous mistakes. When insurance executives finally get around to setting proper reserves, they're not adding extra layers of strength to their balance sheet, they're just fixing errors they made earlier. It's like I said, a more proper term would be 'correction of previous untruths'.
Despite the challenges in the insurance industry, what advantages do you think your company has that will allow it to grow and make significant amounts of money?

I believe we have a few advantages that will help us navigate this treacherous business. First, we have an advantage in attitude - we're wary and cautious. We also have an advantage in capital, which gives us a solid foundation. Additionally, we're developing an advantage in personnel, and I think we have a long-term edge in investing the float from policyholder funds. These advantages should help us grow and make money, but I want to be clear: progress won't be smooth, and we'll have some unpleasant surprises along the way.
What advantages do you believe Berkshire's insurance operations have, and why are they important for prospering in the business?

I think our insurance operations have an advantage in attitude, capital, and personnel, and we're also developing an edge in investing the float from policyholder funds. These advantages are crucial because the nature of the business is tough, and we need all of them to come out on top.
What is the key factor behind GEICO's success in the insurance industry, according to you?

It's quite simple really - GEICO's rock-bottom operating costs are the key to its success. This sets them apart from hundreds of competitors and acts like a protective moat around their business. Their underwriting and loss adjustment expenses were only 23.5% of premiums in 1986, which is significantly lower than many major companies in the industry.
What is your view on the investment approach taken by Lou at GEICO?

I think Lou has done a terrific job at GEICO, consistently investing in undervalued common stocks that are unlikely to result in a permanent loss. His approach has not only yielded great figures but has also been done in the right way, making GEICO an exceptional business run by exceptional managers.
Why did your insurance companies purchase $700 million of tax-exempt bonds in 1986?

To be honest, we didn't buy those bonds because we were enthusiastic about them - they're just mediocre investments. At the time, they seemed like the least objectionable alternative, and that's still how we view them. We need to hold marketable securities, and they were the best option among the five directions we could go: long-term common stocks, long-term or medium-term fixed-income securities, short-term cash equivalents, or short-term arbitrage commitments.
What is your current view on the stock market, and do you think it's a good time to invest?

I don't have a view on the stock market's direction, and I never have. What I do know is that we're not finding any equities that meet our criteria for investment right now. It's not about timing the market; it's about finding good companies at prices below their intrinsic value. And right now, we're just not seeing that.
How do you approach investing when the market is driven by fear and greed, as you've described?

My approach is simple: I try to be fearful when others are greedy and greedy when others are fearful. It's not about predicting when those emotions will strike; it's about being prepared to act when they do. When everyone's euphoric, like they are now, it's hard to find good investments. But when fear takes over, that's often when the best opportunities arise.
What is the total market value of your common stock holdings?
The total market value of our common stock holdings is $1,874,033. That's a pretty significant chunk of change, if I do say so myself.
Do you plan on selling your primary holdings, such as Capital Cities/ABC, Inc., even if they become overpriced?

No, we don't plan on selling those holdings, even if they appear overpriced. We consider them permanent holdings, much like See's or the Buffalo Evening News. We're not in the business of constantly buying and selling just to appease Wall Street.
What is the scheduled change in the tax rate on corporate ordinary income from 1986 to 1988?
The tax rate on corporate ordinary income is scheduled to decrease from 46% in 1986 to 34% in 1988. That's a pretty significant drop, if I do say so myself.
According to the 'pipeline' theory, what should happen to prices when corporate tax rates are cut?

Well, according to the 'pipeline' theory, when corporate tax rates are cut, the benefits should flow through to consumers in the form of lower prices. In other words, companies like Berkshire, The Washington Post, and Cap Cities should pass the tax savings along to their customers, rather than keeping them as extra profits.
How do tax changes affect companies with strong franchises compared to those in price-competitive industries?

Well, let me tell you - for companies with strong franchises, like many of the ones we own, tax cuts are a boon. The benefits largely end up in our pockets, rather than our customers'. It's like the electric company without a regulator; we get to keep the savings. But for companies in price-competitive industries, it's a different story. Tax changes eventually affect prices more than profits, so the benefits get passed on to customers.
Do you think professionals with strong franchises, like top brain surgeons or lawyers, will reduce their fees in response to tax cuts?

Ha! I doubt it. Think about it - if you're the best brain surgeon in town, you're not going to start charging less just because your tax rate goes down. You're still the go-to expert, and people will pay for your expertise. It's the same with our companies that have strong franchises; we're not going to pass on all the savings from tax cuts to our customers.
Why do you think tax increases will affect the profits of Berkshire's property/casualty companies differently than other price-competitive industries?

I believe tax increases will impact our property/casualty companies differently because not all major insurers are working with the same tax equations. Some will be hit harder by the new alternative minimum tax, while others have huge loss carry-forwards that will shield their income from significant taxes. This disparity will lead to varying marginal tax rates, making it tougher for companies to simply pass on increased taxes to customers.
Can you explain why the property/casualty industry is an exception to the general rule that tax increases are largely passed along to customers in price-competitive industries?

The property/casualty industry is an exception because of the differing tax situations among major insurers. Unlike industries like aluminum or autos, where the big players all have similar tax equations, our industry has companies with unique tax profiles. This means we can't just raise prices in tandem with our competitors, as their tax burdens may be quite different from ours.
What is the expected total benefit from the fresh-start adjustment and how will it affect Berkshire's financials?

I expect the total benefit from the fresh-start adjustment to be in the $30 - $40 million range. This benefit will flow into our earnings statement and consequently into our net worth over the next few years by way of reduced tax charges. It's a one-time benefit, so we shouldn't expect it to recur in future years.
How does the repeal of the General Utilities Doctrine affect corporate liquidations and what impact does it have on your investment evaluations?

The repeal of the General Utilities Doctrine means that if a company is liquidated, there will be a double tax - one at the corporate level and another at the shareholder level. This change affects our evaluations of prospective investments, particularly in industries like oil and gas, media, and real estate, where companies might consider selling out. The values that shareholders can realize from such sales will likely be significantly reduced, not because the companies' operating economics have changed, but simply due to the change in tax law.
What's wrong with using 'cash flow' numbers as presented in Wall Street reports, according to you?

Well, the problem is those numbers usually include capital expenditures and depreciation, but they don't subtract the capital expenditures needed to maintain a business in real terms. It's like saying you're saving money because you didn't replace your car's tires this year, but next year you'll have to buy four new ones - it's just not a realistic way to look at it.
Can 'cash flow' be a useful concept for any types of businesses?

Yes, it can be. For businesses that make huge initial outlays and then have very small expenses thereafter, like owning a bridge or a long-lived gas field, 'cash flow' can be a useful shorthand. But for most businesses, like manufacturing or retailing, it's just not that simple because you always have significant capital expenditures to consider.
What was the gain in Berkshire Hathaway's net worth during 1987?

Our gain in net worth during 1987 was $464 million, which translates to a 19.5% increase. I'm pleased with that performance, and I think it reflects the strength of our businesses and the quality of our management team.
You mentioned that book value and business value can be unrelated - can you give an example of this?

Well, let's take LTV and Baldwin-United, for instance. Right before they went bankrupt, their book values were $652 million and $397 million, respectively. On the other hand, Belridge Oil was sold to Shell for $3.6 billion in 1979, despite having a book value of only $177 million. These examples illustrate how book value can sometimes be a poor indicator of a company's true worth.
What was the combined operating earnings before interest and taxes of Berkshire's seven largest non-financial units in 1987?
In 1987, our seven largest non-financial units had combined operating earnings before interest and taxes of $180 million. That's a pretty impressive figure, if I do say so myself.
What was the return on equity capital for these seven business units in 1987?

The return on equity capital for these seven units was about 57% - a number you'll seldom see, especially at large, diversified companies with minimal debt. It's a testament to the strong performance of our operating managers.
What characteristics do the 25 companies identified in the Fortune study share, and how did they perform in the stock market?

Those 25 companies share a couple of interesting traits - they use very little leverage and are mostly in mundane businesses. And as for their performance, 24 out of 25 of them outperformed the S&P 500 over the decade from 1977 to 1986. Not bad for a bunch of 'ordinary' businesses, if you ask me.
How has Berkshire's experience been in terms of producing exceptional economic results, and what approach have our managers taken to achieve this?

Berkshire's experience has been quite similar to those Fortune champs. Our managers have done rather ordinary things, but they've done them exceptionally well. By focusing on making the most of our strong business franchises and concentrating on winning business themes, we've been able to produce some extraordinary results.
How much did NFM's customers save by buying from them in 1987?
In 1987, our customers at NFM saved about $30 million by choosing to shop with us. That's the difference between what they paid and what they would have paid elsewhere for the same goods.
What approach does NFM follow for its business strategy, as per Mrs. B's maxim?

NFM's secret to success is quite simple, really. We follow Mrs. B's maxim: 'Sell cheap and tell the truth.' It's a straightforward approach that has served us well and will continue to guide our business decisions.
How does your pricing policy differ from that of other insurers, and what impact does it have on your business?

My pricing policy is based on exposure, not competition. This means we set our prices based on the risk we're taking on, regardless of what others are charging. It's a bit like being the reliable neighbor who always has a spare room available for rent, but only at a price that makes sense for me. When others are 'out' of the market due to losses or capital issues, we're still available to write policies. And when the market is hot and everyone wants to do business, we're available too, but often at prices that are higher than the market. It's a steady approach that works for our shareholders and, as it turns out, is also good for society.
Can you give an example of how your pricing policy has played out in practice?

One story that comes to mind is from 1987. A large family-owned insurance broker, whose owner is actually a Berkshire shareholder, had some big risks to place and found that our prices were higher than what others were offering. So, he took his business elsewhere, but here's the interesting part: he also bought more Berkshire stock. It just goes to show that our approach, while it may not always be the cheapest option, is based on a long-term perspective that our shareholders appreciate.
What kind of business does your company write that makes it challenging to predict earnings?

We write a lot of 'long-tail' business, which includes policies like product liability and directors and officers liability coverages. These types of policies can generate claims that take many years to resolve, making it tough to accurately predict our earnings.
Why should investors be cautious when relying on auditors' opinions about an insurer's financial position?

Investors should be cautious because, despite auditors' reassuring language, the numbers they certify are likely to differ dramatically from our true earnings due to the unpredictability of our legal system and the long-tail nature of our business. I've seen it happen in our own company and in many other well-known insurers over the years.
What do you think the standard opinion letter to shareholders of a property-casualty company should say to accurately reflect the limitations of an audit?

I believe it should read something like: 'We have relied upon representations of management in respect to the liabilities shown for losses and loss adjustment expenses, the estimate of which, in turn, very materially affects the earnings and financial condition herein reported. We can express no opinion about the accuracy of these figures. Subject to that important reservation, in our opinion, etc.' This way, it's clear what we can and cannot vouch for.
Do you fault auditors for their inability to accurately assess loss reserves and therefore earnings?

No, I don't fault them for that. What I do fault them for is failing to publicly acknowledge the limitations of their role. They can't accurately assess loss reserves, and that's okay - it's a tough job. But they should be upfront about it, rather than giving investors a false sense of security.
How do you and Charlie approach buying common stocks for Berkshire's insurance companies?

We approach it as if we're buying into a private business. We look at the economic prospects of the business, the people running it, and the price we have to pay. It's a very straightforward, business-like approach.
What role does an active trading market play in your investment strategy?

An active trading market is useful because it periodically presents us with great opportunities. But it's not essential - we're happy to hold a stock indefinitely if we think the business will continue to increase in value at a good rate.
Who is Mr. Market and what is his role in the context of investment?

Mr. Market is a metaphorical fellow who represents market quotations. He's like a business partner who shows up daily to either buy your interest or sell you his, at a price he names. The key thing about Mr. Market is that he has emotional problems, which cause his quotes to fluctuate wildly, regardless of the actual stability of the business.
What is the investor's relationship with Mr. Market supposed to be, according to Ben Graham's description?

According to Ben Graham, Mr. Market is there to serve me, not to guide me. This means I should take advantage of his emotional swings to make transactions that benefit me, but I shouldn't let his quotes dictate my investment decisions. I can ignore him if his price isn't interesting, and he'll be back with a new one tomorrow.
Why do you sometimes sell a security that is fairly valued or undervalued?

I sell a security that's fairly valued or even undervalued if I need the funds for an even more undervalued investment or one that I believe I understand better. It's all about making the most of our investments and allocating our resources wisely.
Are there any investments that you would not sell, even if they became overpriced in the market?

Yes, our insurance companies own three marketable common stocks that we consider a permanent part of Berkshire. We view these investments just like our successful controlled businesses, and we have no intention of selling them simply because the market price rises. However, if we had to pay for extraordinary insurance losses, we might sell a portion of these holdings, but we aim to manage our affairs so that sales are never necessary.
What is your primary goal when looking to buy into a business?

My goal is to find an outstanding business at a sensible price. I've learned that it's better to invest in a great business, even if the price isn't a bargain, rather than trying to make a mediocre business work just because it's cheap.
How do you approach situations where you may have misjudged the fundamental economics of a business or its management?

If Charlie and I misread the economics of a business, we'll encounter problems whether it's a wholly-owned subsidiary or a marketable security. And if we make a mistake about the managers, having a controlled company gives us the power to effect change, although in practice, making management changes can be painful, time-consuming, and chancy.
How do tax costs affect Berkshire's financial results when owning partial positions versus 80% or greater holdings?

Well, let me tell you - when we own 80% or more of a business, the tax costs are significantly lower. In fact, our financial results can be as much as 50% better compared to owning a lesser stake. It's a big difference, and it's something we've had to deal with for a while, but the recent changes in the tax code have really amplified the issue.
Can you give examples of instances where buying non-controlling pieces of businesses at low prices has worked out well for Berkshire?

I'd be happy to. Take our purchases of Washington Post stock in 1973 and GEICO stock in the late 1970s, for example. We bought them at ridiculously low prices - $5.63 per share for Washington Post and an average of $6.67 per share for GEICO. And look at how they've performed: Washington Post's per-share operating earnings after taxes were $10.30 in 1987, and GEICO's were $9.01. It just goes to show that sometimes Mr. Market can be a very good friend indeed.
Do you think portfolio insurance is a rational strategy for managing investments?

No, I don't think portfolio insurance makes sense. It's like selling pieces of your farm just because a neighbor's property sold for a lower price. That's not how you build long-term value. This approach tells you to sell when prices are low and buy back when they're high, which is the opposite of what a rational investor should do.
Do you believe small investors are at a disadvantage in markets dominated by large institutional investors with significant resources?

Not at all. In fact, I think volatile markets caused by irrational behavior from big investors can create opportunities for small investors like you and me. As long as you stick to your investment strategy and don't get spooked into selling at the wrong time, you can actually benefit from the chaos. It's like being a disciplined shopper who waits for sales to buy what you need - if you keep your wits about you, you can come out ahead.
Why don't you comment on rumors about Berkshire's investments, even if they are false?

Well, if we were to deny the incorrect reports and stay mum on the correct ones, we'd essentially be confirming the true rumors by our silence. It's just not a game we want to play, especially when our investment ideas are our most valuable assets.
What was the outcome of Berkshire's debenture sale, and who was your investment banker?

We sold two issues of debentures totaling $250 million, with both maturing in 2018. Our overall interest cost came out to slightly over 10%. Salomon was our investment banker, and I must say, their service was top-notch.
What happened to K & W's profits in 1987 compared to 1986?

Well, let me tell you, it was a remarkable turnaround. In 1987, K & W's profits set a record, increasing by more than 300% from 1986. It just goes to show that with the right leadership, a company can quickly get back on track.
How do you feel about corporate charitable contributions, particularly when it comes to whose preferences should be reflected?

I believe that charitable contributions should reflect the preferences of the owners, not just the officers and directors. It's their money, after all. I think it's a bit like taxation, where someone is taking money from one person to give to another. In a corporation, that someone is the officer or director, and I think they should be mindful of whose money they're giving away.
What was the gain in net worth for Berkshire Hathaway Inc. during 1989?
Our gain in net worth during 1989 was $1.515 billion, which translates to a 44.4% increase. I'm pleased with that performance, and it's a testament to our team's hard work.
How has the per-share book value of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. changed since you took over 25 years ago?

Since I took the reins, our per-share book value has grown from $19.46 to $4,296.01. That's a compounded annual growth rate of 23.8%. It's a remarkable journey, and I'm proud of what we've accomplished.
What is the main obstacle you face in achieving high growth rates for Berkshire's net worth, and how does this relate to the example of bacteria growth described by Carl Sagan?

The main obstacle we face is that high growth rates must eventually self-destruct in a finite world. Carl Sagan's example of bacteria growth illustrates this point nicely. Just as the bacteria's exponential growth is eventually halted by obstacles like running out of food or poisoning each other, our own growth at Berkshire will be limited by our increasingly large base of net worth. It's simple math: the bigger you are, the harder it is to keep growing at a rapid pace.
How did taxes impact Berkshire's gain in 1989, and what was the significance of this gain in relation to your company's overall performance?

Taxes took a significant bite out of our 1989 gain - we had to pay about $712 million in income taxes. Despite this, we still managed to achieve a gain of $1.5 billion, which is a testament to our overall performance. It's worth noting, however, that our growth rate is likely to slow down from here, given our large and growing base of net worth. We're not expecting to double our net worth every 15 minutes, unfortunately!
How does the deferred tax liability on your balance sheet compare to a traditional liability payable to a trade creditor?

Well, they're not equal, despite having the same effect on our audited net worth. The deferred tax liability is more like an interest-free loan from the U.S. Treasury that comes due only when we choose to sell our securities. It's a unique situation, and I think it's helpful to think of it that way.
Can you provide an example of how this deferred tax liability has affected your investment decisions or outcomes in the past?

Yes, in 1989, we sold some smaller holdings and incurred about $76 million in taxes on $224 million of gains. It's a good illustration of how the tax law works and why our long-term investing approach, which I like to call 'Rip Van Winkle' style, has a mathematical edge over more frequent buying and selling.
How does the configuration of hundreds of participants selling a commodity-like product at independently-established prices affect industry profitability?

Well, it's quite simple really. This setup is bound to cause subnormal profitability most of the time. It's like trying to make a profit in a crowded marketplace where everyone's selling the same thing - it's tough unless there's a shortage of what you're selling, which in our case is usable capacity.
What determines the amount of industry capacity in the insurance world, and how effective are the constraints in place?

In the insurance world, capacity is typically described in financial terms, but to be honest, those constraints haven't proven very effective. It mostly comes down to the mental state of insurance managers - they can choose to write a lot of business with relatively little capital if they want to. Regulators, brokers, and customers are often slow to step in and discipline companies that overextend themselves.
What is the expected drop in Berkshire's premium volume in 1990 compared to its high in 1986?
Our premium volume may drop to $150 million or so in 1990, which is a significant decrease from our high of $1 billion in 1986. That's a pretty steep fall, but as I said, it won't disturb us.
How do CAT covers work in terms of loss payment and reinstatement?

CAT covers are reinsurance contracts that primary insurance companies buy to protect themselves against large catastrophes. Here's how they work: the primary insurer retains the loss up to a certain amount, say $10 million, and then the reinsurer pays 95% of the excess up to its limit. The primary insurer keeps 5% of each layer, so they have a stake in each loss settlement. And if their coverage is exhausted, they can buy a second cover for the rest of the year by paying another premium. It's a way for us to provide protection while also making sure the primary insurer has some skin in the game.
What is your current situation with float compared to premium volume, and how do you expect it to affect your insurance results?

We currently hold an exceptional amount of float compared to premium volume. I expect this to produce quite favorable insurance results for us during the next few years, similar to what we saw in 1989. Our underwriting losses should be manageable, and the investment income from policyholder funds should be substantial.
How do you approach selecting marketable securities for your insurance companies?

When it comes to choosing marketable securities, we consider five major categories and look for the highest after-tax returns. We don't have a bias towards any particular category; we just focus on finding investments that we understand and that will maximize our eventual net worth, rather than trying to boost short-term earnings.
What triggered your decision to finally invest in Coca-Cola in 1988?

It was when my brain finally established contact with my eyes, and I saw the incredible turnaround Roberto Goizueta and Don Keough had achieved since taking over in 1981. Their perfect blend of marketing and financial skills had given the company new momentum, especially with sales exploding overseas.
Why do you think Roberto Goizueta was so successful in leading Coca-Cola?

Roberto had a truly rare blend of marketing and financial skills, which allowed him to maximize both the growth of the product and the rewards that this growth brings to shareholders. Unlike many CEOs who might favor one discipline over the other, Roberto's approach was perfectly balanced, making him a dream for shareholders like me.
What are the key features of the Champion International Corp. preferred stock you purchased?

The Champion International Corp. preferred stock we bought has a few attractive features: it's got a mandatory redemption in ten years, pays a 9 1/4% dividend, and can be converted into common stock at $38 per share. Plus, it's structured in a way that we can't sell or convert it for a while, which means we won't be tempted to try to time the market or react to short-term price swings.
Why do you say you're 'agnostics, not atheists' when it comes to the future of certain industries like investment banking or airlines?

Well, when I say we're 'agnostics, not atheists,' I mean that we don't have strong feelings one way or the other about the long-term prospects of those industries. We're not predicting doom and gloom, but we also don't have enough insight to make a confident bet on their future. It's not that we think they're bad businesses, it's just that we don't understand them well enough to invest in them with the same level of conviction that we do in businesses like Gillette, which we think we understand pretty well.
What do you expect to get from your investment in preferred stocks, and what would be a disappointing outcome?

I expect to get my money back plus dividends from these preferred stocks. However, if that's all we get, it'll be a disappointing outcome because we'll have missed out on other significant opportunities due to the lack of flexibility in these investments. It's like putting money in a savings account - it's safe, but you're not going to get rich off the interest alone.
How do you plan to work with the CEOs of the companies you've invested in through preferred stocks?

Charlie and I plan to be supportive, analytical, and objective in our dealings with these CEOs. We recognize they're experienced and in command of their businesses, but we're also happy to provide a sounding board for their ideas, unencumbered by industry ties or past decisions. It's a collaborative approach, really.
How does the tax treatment of Berkshire's bonds benefit the company?

The tax treatment of our bonds is a significant benefit to us. Since we're entitled to deduct the 5.5% interest accrual each year, even though we make no payments to the bondholders, it results in reduced taxes and positive cash flow for Berkshire.
What's the difference between Berkshire's bonds and the typical zero-coupon bonds that you and Charlie have criticized?

Our bonds are quite different from the typical zero-coupon bonds that have been issued in recent years. For one, the taxable holders of our bonds have to pay tax each year on the 5.5% interest, even though they receive no cash. This symmetry in the tax law is key. We've been critical of other zero-coupon bonds because they've often been used deceptively, but our bonds, and those of a few other companies like Loews and Motorola, don't resemble those problematic bonds.
What is the main advantage of zero-coupon bonds to the issuers, according to you?
The main advantage of zero-coupon bonds to the issuers is that it's impossible to default on a promise to pay nothing. It's a clever way for shaky credits to avoid default, at least for a while.
How did the lending practices change over time during the leveraged buy-out craze, in your observation?

Well, when the leveraged buy-out craze first started, lenders were reasonably cautious, requiring borrowers to have enough free cash flow to cover both interest and debt reduction. But as time went on and deal-makers got more aggressive, lenders started accepting deals where all the free cash flow went towards paying interest, with no plan to pay down the principal. It was like a Scarlett O'Hara approach - 'I'll think about it tomorrow' - and it wasn't a very sound way of doing business, if you ask me.
What happens to a business if it routinely skips capital outlays and doesn't make them up?

Well, just like a human body weakens and eventually dies if it doesn't get the nourishment it needs, a business will weaken and eventually die if it doesn't invest in itself through capital outlays. It's not a matter of if, but when, the business will start to feel the effects of neglecting its own needs.
How did promoters and investment bankers justify ignoring depreciation expense and a portion of interest expense when assessing the financial feasibility of a transaction?

They came up with a clever trick - or so they thought. They started measuring EBDIT against cash interest only, which allowed them to ignore depreciation expense and the interest accruing on zero-coupon or PIK bonds. It's a bit like stepping through the Looking Glass, where up is down and down is up. Unfortunately, many professional investment managers bought into this nonsense, but usually only with their clients' money, not their own.
What do you suggest doing when investment bankers show you income and balance sheet projections for a company they barely knew a few months prior?

I suggest you join in the fun and ask the investment banker for their own firm's one-year budgets from the last few years, and then compare those with what actually happened. It's a great way to gauge the reliability of their projections.
Can you explain how zero-coupon bonds can create the illusion of 'earnings' for bondholders?

Well, with zeros, it's possible for one party to experience 'income' without the other feeling the pinch of expenditure. For instance, a company that can only earn $100 million annually can still magically create 'earnings' of $150 million for bondholders. It's a bit of financial wizardry that doesn't quite add up, if you ask me.
What was your first mistake in your investment career, as mentioned in the text?
My first mistake was buying control of Berkshire, despite knowing its textile manufacturing business was unpromising, because the price looked cheap at the time.
Can you explain what you mean by the 'cigar butt' approach to investing?

The 'cigar butt' approach is when you buy a stock at a very low price, hoping to make a profit even if the business itself isn't doing well. It's like finding a cigar butt on the street with one puff left - it's not much, but since it's free, that one puff is all profit. However, I've come to realize that this approach is foolish unless you're a liquidator, because the original 'bargain' price often isn't as good a deal as you think.
What did you learn from your experience with Hochschild Kohn and how do you approach buying companies or stocks now?

Well, I learned the hard way that it's far better to buy a wonderful company at a fair price than a fair company at a wonderful price. Now, when buying companies or common stocks, Charlie and I look for first-class businesses accompanied by first-class managements. It's a simple yet important lesson: good businesses with good management are more likely to succeed than average businesses, even with good management.
You mention that you and Charlie haven't learned how to solve difficult business problems after 25 years. Can you elaborate on what you mean by that?

What I mean is that we've found that some businesses are just inherently tough to fix, no matter how hard you try or how smart your management team is. As I said, 'Good jockeys will do well on good horses, but not on broken-down nags.' We've learned to focus on buying businesses with good economic characteristics, rather than trying to turn around struggling ones. It's just easier to succeed when you're starting with a strong foundation.
What approach do you and Charlie take when it comes to business problems, and why has it been successful for you?

We've found that it's best to stick with the easy and obvious, rather than trying to tackle tough problems. We look for one-foot hurdles that we can step over, rather than trying to clear seven-footers. This approach has been successful for us because it allows us to focus on what we're good at, rather than trying to be heroes and solve every difficult problem that comes our way.
You mention the 'institutional imperative' as a surprising discovery in business. Can you explain what you mean by this term?

The institutional imperative refers to the way that organizations can exert a kind of pressure on their managers to make decisions that aren't necessarily rational. I learned that even decent, intelligent, and experienced managers can make irrational decisions when the institutional imperative comes into play. It's a force that can cause people to act in ways that aren't in the best interest of the business, and it's something that I didn't understand when I first started out in business.
What have you learned about the institutional imperative and its impact on businesses?

I've learned that the institutional imperative can lead businesses down misguided paths, not because of venality or stupidity, but due to inherent institutional dynamics. It's like Newton's First Law of Motion - institutions resist change and tend to keep doing what they're doing, even if it's not the best course. I've also seen how this imperative can cause companies to mindlessly imitate their peers and pursue projects just because they have the funds available.
How do you approach investing in and partnering with other companies, given your understanding of the institutional imperative?

I try to invest in companies that are aware of the institutional imperative and its potential pitfalls. Charlie and I look for businesses with decent economic characteristics and leaders who are alert to these issues. Additionally, I've learned to only go into business with people I like, trust, and admire. It's not a guarantee of success, but it's a crucial starting point. After all, you can't make a silk purse out of a sow's ear, but with the right people and a good business, you can accomplish wonders.
What was the gain in Berkshire Hathaway's net worth during 1988, and how does it compare to the long-term growth rate of per-share book value?

In 1988, our gain in net worth was $569 million, or 20.0%. Over the long haul, since I took over, our per-share book value has grown at a rate of 23.0% compounded annually. So, while 1988 was a good year, our long-term track record is even stronger.
You mention several factors that will impact Berkshire's future prospects. Can you elaborate on these challenges and how they differ from the conditions we've faced in the past?

Well, let's just say the game has changed. We're facing a less attractive stock market, higher corporate tax rates, and a more expensive market for buying businesses. Additionally, some of our key investments, like Capital Cities/ABC and GEICO, are operating in less favorable industry conditions than they were five to ten years ago. It's like trying to hit a home run in a different ballpark - the rules and conditions are not what they used to be.
What are some of the important negatives affecting Berkshire's prospects today?

Well, let me tell you, there are a few. First, the stock market isn't as attractive as it used to be. We're also dealing with higher corporate tax rates, which doesn't help. The market for acquiring businesses is also pretty richly priced, making it tougher for us to find good deals. And lastly, the industry conditions for some of our key investments, like Capital Cities/ABC, GEICO, and The Washington Post Company, aren't as favorable as they were five to ten years ago.
How much in profits does Berkshire need to achieve a 15% annual return over the next decade?

That's a big number - $10.3 billion. It's a lot to swallow, and I've got to say, it seems daunting even to me and Charlie Munger. Just four years ago, we needed $3.9 billion to hit that 15% return, so you can see how our growing capital base is making it tougher to deliver those kinds of returns.
What is the main challenge you face in achieving Berkshire's 15% goal?

The main challenge we face is not whether our operating managers can deliver superb returns - I'm confident they will. The question mark is whether Charlie and I can effectively employ the funds that they generate.
