What is your view on the limitations of generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP)?

While I think GAAP has its shortcomings, I believe CEOs should treat GAAP statements as just a starting point in their obligation to inform owners and creditors. They should provide more information, not just the bare minimum required by GAAP.
Why should CEOs provide more information than just the bare GAAP numbers to their shareholders?

I believe CEOs should provide more information because, just like a subsidiary manager reports to their CEO, a CEO should report fully to their bosses - the shareholder-owners. Providing just the minimum GAAP numbers is like giving your boss a partial picture, which isn't very helpful. As a CEO, you should give your owners the whole story, so they can make informed decisions.
What kind of information do you think is necessary for financially-literate readers to understand a company's situation?

In my opinion, financially-literate readers need data that helps them answer three key questions: what's the company worth, can it meet its future obligations, and how well are its managers doing with what they've got. This information might be GAAP, non-GAAP, or even extra-GAAP - whatever it takes to give a clear picture of the company's situation.
What techniques do honest and well-intentioned managements sometimes use to present their performance in a more favorable light?

Well, I've seen honest and well-intentioned managements use techniques like smoothing of earnings and the 'big bath' quarter to present their figures in a better light. These are what I call 'white lie' techniques - they're not exactly deceitful, but they're not entirely straightforward either.
Have you and Charlie Munger observed instances of accounting-based frauds, and if so, what has been the typical outcome for the perpetrators?

Unfortunately, yes, Charlie and I have seen many accounting-based frauds over the years, and some of them have been staggering in size. The sad truth is that few of the perpetrators have been punished, and many haven't even been censured. It's been far safer for them to cook the books than to commit more traditional forms of theft.
What change did GAAP mandate for 1988, and how did it affect Berkshire's financial reporting?

Well, GAAP required us to fully consolidate all our subsidiaries in our balance sheet and earnings statement, starting in 1988. This means we had to break out each asset and liability of our subsidiaries, like Mutual Savings and Loan and Scott Fetzer Financial, instead of just showing our equity in them as a single line item. It's like going from a simple recipe to a detailed blueprint - we're providing a lot more detail now.
Why have you decided to publish additional supplementary information, and what do you hope it will achieve?

We're publishing this extra information because, frankly, the new GAAP rules make our consolidated figures a bit of a mess. With all these different businesses lumped together, it's hard to get a clear picture of what's going on. By providing more segmented data, we hope to give our investors a better understanding of our business value and how well our managers are performing. It's like trying to judge a baseball team by just looking at the total score - you need to see the individual player stats to really know what's happening.
Why do you and Charlie prefer to present earnings without charging amortization of Goodwill and other purchase-price accounting adjustments against specific businesses?

We prefer this approach because it lets us - and our investors - view the earnings of our businesses as they would have been reported had we not purchased them. It's a more useful way to look at things, in our opinion, than the standard GAAP presentation.
Where can investors find further information about Berkshire's businesses?
Investors can find more details about our businesses in the Business Segment section on pages 32-34, and in the Management's Discussion section on pages 36-40.
What was the key to the success of Mrs. B's family members when they reunited in Omaha?

It's quite simple really - they came equipped with brains, integrity, and a strong enthusiasm for work. That's all they needed to prove themselves invincible, and it's a testament to the power of those core values.
What are the fundamental principles that guide both the furniture and jewelry businesses operated by the families mentioned?

The cornerstone of both businesses is Mrs. B's creed: 'Sell cheap and tell the truth.' Additionally, we focus on single-store operations with huge inventories, daily attention to detail, rapid turnover, shrewd buying, and keeping expenses incredibly low. It's a straightforward approach that has served us well.
How will the management of Borsheim's change after its link to Berkshire?
The management of Borsheim's won't change a bit. All members of the Friedman family will continue to operate just as they have before, and Charlie and I will stay on the sidelines where we belong.
What is the key to the success of families like the Friedmans and the Blumkins, according to you?
I think the key to their success is that they focus on what's right for the customer. That approach inevitably works out well for them too. It's a simple but powerful formula.
What does a combined ratio below 100 indicate in the insurance industry?

A combined ratio below 100 indicates an underwriting profit. It means the total insurance costs, including losses incurred and expenses, are less than the revenue from premiums. That's a good thing, just like having more money coming in than going out of your wallet.
Why do you expect the industry's underwriting losses to mount if premium growth lags behind the 10% annual growth rate of incurred losses?

Well, it's simple math really. If the costs, or incurred losses, are growing at a 10% clip and the premiums aren't keeping pace, then the gap between what's coming in and what's going out is going to grow. That gap is essentially the underwriting loss, and it will mount over time unless something changes. It's like trying to fill a bucket with a hole in it - if the water's coming in slower than it's leaking out, you're going to end up with less water over time.
How would Proposition 103 affect the pricing of See's candies if it were applied to them?

Well, if Proposition 103 applied to See's candies, we'd have to sell them for $5.76 per pound instead of the $7.60 we charge now. And let me tell you, we'd be losing money by the bucketful if that were the case.
What's at risk for GEICO if socialized auto insurance becomes a reality?

GEICO has a huge amount of economic goodwill at risk if socialized auto insurance becomes a reality. As a low-cost producer that's able to earn high returns on equity, we've got a lot to lose if we're forced out of the auto insurance business by government pricing actions.
What are the names of the companies that make up your permanent holdings?
Our permanent holdings include Capital Cities/ABC, Inc., GEICO Corporation, and The Washington Post Company. We've got a lot of faith in these companies and the people running them.
Why do you think it's easier for an inadequate CEO to keep their job compared to other employees?

Well, I think it's because there often aren't clear performance standards for CEOs like there are for other jobs. If a secretary can't type fast enough, it's easy to measure and they're out. But for CEOs, it's not always so clear-cut, and that makes it harder to hold them accountable.
Why do CEOs who don't perform often get carried indefinitely?

Well, it's because performance standards for their job are often fuzzy or nonexistent. It's like shooting an arrow and then painting the bullseye around where it lands - it's a pretty loose way to measure success. And to make matters worse, the CEO's boss, the Board of Directors, doesn't have its own performance measured, so there's no one to hold them accountable for keeping a subpar CEO on board.
What happens to a CEO's career if the company they lead is taken over due to their poor performance?

Ironically, they often end up with a pretty soft landing. Even if the company is taken over because of their mistakes, the deal will likely give them substantial benefits. As I like to say, 'the bigger they are, the softer they fall.' It's a pretty nice safety net, if you ask me.
What is your approach to holding onto investments in companies with outstanding management?

When we own portions of outstanding businesses with outstanding managements, our favorite holding period is forever. We believe in holding onto these investments for the long haul, rather than selling and booking profits when they perform well.
How do you decide which companies to invest in, given that you concentrate your investments in a very few companies?

We try to understand the businesses well and only invest in a handful of companies about which we have strong long-term convictions. It's not about spreading our bets, but about putting our money into businesses that we truly believe in and can see a bright future for.
What was the outcome of your WPPSS purchase in terms of unleveraged, after-tax returns through 1988, compared to other business acquisitions made in 1983?

Our WPPSS purchase actually worked out better than the average business acquisition made in 1983, in terms of unleveraged, after-tax returns through 1988. It was a pleasant experience, but it didn't change our overall view on long-term bonds.
How did your arbitrage activities perform in 1988, and what was the pre-tax gain on the average invested funds?

In 1988, our arbitrage activities did exceptionally well, with a pre-tax gain of about $78 million on average invested funds of about $147 million. It was a significant profit, and as Charlie likes to say, it kept us out of trouble - or as he puts it, 'out of bars' - by providing a better return than Treasury Bills and discouraging us from compromising our investment standards.
What was the significance of the 1954 Tax Code in the context of Rockwood's cocoa inventory distribution?

The 1954 Tax Code had a provision that eliminated the tax on LIFO profits if inventory was distributed to shareholders as part of a plan to reduce the scope of a corporation's business. This came in handy for Rockwood, as it allowed us to avoid a hefty 50% tax on the proceeds from selling off the cocoa inventory.
How did the value of Rockwood stock change during the period surrounding the tender offer, despite the company experiencing large operating losses?

The Rockwood stock price appreciated significantly, going from 15 to 100, even though the company was experiencing large operating losses at the time. This just goes to show that sometimes there's more to stock valuation than just looking at price-earnings ratios.
What are the four key questions you need to answer when evaluating arbitrage situations?

When evaluating arbitrage situations, I look at four key questions: How likely is the promised event to occur, how long will my money be tied up, what are the chances something better will come along, and what happens if the event doesn't occur due to issues like anti-trust action or financing glitches.
Can you give an example of one of your arbitrage experiences, as mentioned in the text?

One example that comes to mind is Arcata Corp. We had a pretty interesting experience with that one. The company was in the process of being sold to Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co. in 1981, and it had some unique assets, including a lot of old-growth redwood timber that had been taken over by the U.S. Government a few years earlier.
How did the commissions appointed by the trial judge determine the value of the redwoods and the interest rate in the Arcata case?

Well, the first commission determined that the redwoods were worth $275.7 million, and the second commission recommended a compounded, blended rate of return of about 14%. These conclusions were upheld by the judge in August 1987, leading to a net amount of about $600 million due to Arcata.
What approach does Berkshire take to arbitrage activities, and how does it differ from other arbitrageurs?

We take a pretty unique approach to arbitrage. Unlike many others who participate in 50 or more deals per year, we only get involved in a few, usually very large, transactions each year. This means we don't have to spend all our time monitoring a multitude of deals and market movements. Charlie and I just don't want to spend our lives staring at a ticker tape all day. We diversify little, so one big win or loss can really impact our yearly results from arbitrage.
Why did Berkshire's directorships in Salomon cost the company significant money in the RJR deal?

Our directorships in Salomon cost Berkshire significant money because we had to be walled off from information about Salomon's merger and acquisition work, which limited the times when we could buy RJR stocks. Essentially, we couldn't buy when we normally would have, which affected our arbitrage operations.
Do you plan to increase Berkshire's involvement in arbitrage in 1989, given the company's good results in 1988?

Actually, we expect to be on the sidelines in 1989 when it comes to arbitrage. One reason is that our cash holdings are down, which is a good thing because it means our position in equities that we plan to hold for a long time is substantially up. Even if we had a lot of cash, we probably wouldn't do much in arbitrage this year.
What is your view on the current state of the takeover field and how will it influence your investment decisions?

I think the takeover field has developed some extraordinary excesses, and to be frank, it's making me a bit cautious. As I always say, the less prudence others show, the more prudence we should. We're not interested in arbitraging transactions that seem to be driven by unwarranted optimism. It's a bit like Dorothy said, 'Toto, I have a feeling we're not in Kansas any more.' We're going to stick to our principles and not get caught up in the frenzy.
What do you think about the Efficient Market Theory, and do you believe it's an effective way to approach stock analysis?

Well, I think the Efficient Market Theory is a bit of a myth. The idea that all public information is already reflected in stock prices, and therefore analyzing stocks is useless, just doesn't hold water. It's like saying that because all the information is out there, someone throwing darts at the stock tables can do just as well as a seasoned analyst. I don't buy it. We've always believed in doing our homework and making informed decisions, and I think that's what sets us apart.
What kind of return would an investor have seen if they had invested $1,000 in the general market over 63 years, assuming all income was reinvested?

Well, if you had invested $1,000 in the general market over those 63 years, with all income reinvested, you would have ended up with about $405,000, given the market's annual return of just under 10%. Not bad, but as I like to say, it's nothing to write home about compared to what could have been achieved with a 20% rate of return.
Why do you think the Efficient Market Theory (EMT) remains part of the investment curriculum despite its shortcomings?

I think EMT stays in the curriculum because, quite frankly, it's a way for the 'priesthood' to maintain its mystique. There's a reluctance to admit when one is wrong, especially when it comes to something as deeply ingrained as EMT. It's a bit like how theologians can be hesitant to recant - it's just not in their nature. And that, of course, has been a boon for those of us who follow Graham's principles.
You mention that arbitrage has looked easy recently, but what's the reality of its potential for profits?

Well, let me tell you, arbitrage is not a guaranteed path to profits. In fact, I've said it's no better than throwing darts at a portfolio. The market is reasonably efficient most of the time, and for every opportunity we've seized, many more have been passed on because they were properly priced. You can't just commit to arbitrage and expect 20% returns or any returns for that matter.
What's the minimum number of Berkshire shares that can be bought or sold on the New York Stock Exchange?

That's an easy one. While our round lot for trading on the NYSE is ten shares, the truth is any number of shares from one on up can be bought or sold. So, if you want to buy just one share, you can do that.
What is the minimum number of Berkshire shares that can be bought or sold on the NYSE?
The minimum number of shares that can be bought or sold is just one share. While our round lot for trading on the NYSE is ten shares, there's no requirement to buy or sell in those increments.
How do you feel about the price of Berkshire shares fluctuating significantly from their intrinsic business value?

Charlie and I are bothered by both significant overvaluation and undervaluation of Berkshire shares. We want the shares to trade in a narrow range centered around their intrinsic business value, which we hope will increase at a reasonable rate over time.
What is your ideal scenario for Berkshire's stock price in relation to its intrinsic business value?

I wish for our stock price to trade in a narrow range centered at intrinsic business value. In other words, I hope our stock price consistently mirrors the true value of our business, which ideally increases at a reasonable or even unreasonable rate over time.
Why do you prefer very little trading activity in Berkshire's stock?

To be frank, I don't understand why any CEO would want lots of stock activity. It's like cheering when members leave a club or church. Our goal is to attract long-term owners who plan to stay with us indefinitely, not to have a revolving door of investors constantly buying and selling.
What kind of shareholders do you try to attract to Berkshire?

We try to attract shareholders who understand our operations, share our time horizons, and measure us as we measure ourselves. In other words, we're looking for like-minded folks who are in it for the long haul, not those with short-term or unrealistic expectations.
Who was Dave Dodd and what impact did he have on Berkshire?

Dave Dodd was a friend, teacher, and mentor of mine for 38 years. He co-authored Security Analysis with Ben Graham and taught at Columbia University. While he may not be well-known to many of our shareholders, his influence on me and my approach to investing has had a significant, indirect impact on Berkshire's success. I can safely say that long-time shareholders are wealthier today because of the lessons I learned from Dave.
Who were the key influencers in your investment education, according to the text?
That would be Dave and Ben Graham. They both had a profound impact on my understanding of investments, with Dave's teachings and Ben's book being instrumental in shaping my approach.
How have you and Charlie applied the principles taught by Dave and Ben Graham in Berkshire's investments?

We've employed those principles directly in our investment strategy. I like to think of it as harvesting the fruit of their intellectual tree - our prosperity is a direct result of applying the simple, sound, and enduring principles they taught us.
What is Berkshire's goal for average annual gain in intrinsic value, and how does the size of the equity base affect this goal?

Our goal is to achieve a 15% average annual gain in intrinsic value. However, I must say that reaching this goal becomes increasingly difficult as our equity base grows - it's like trying to move a big ship, it takes a lot more effort to get it going faster. With our equity base now at $5.3 billion, it's a daunting task, but we're aiming for it nonetheless.
How do the premiums at which a shareholder buys and sells Berkshire shares affect their personal return, compared to the company's corporate gains?

Well, let me put it this way - if you buy our shares at a 10% premium to intrinsic value and sell them at the same premium, your return will match the company's 15% average annual gain. But, if you buy at a premium and sell at a lower premium, your results will be somewhat lower than ours. Ideally, we want our shareholders' results to mirror the company's performance, which is why Charlie and I hope our shares will consistently trade at around intrinsic value.
What is your preferred scenario for Berkshire's market price in relation to its intrinsic value?

I prefer Berkshire to sell consistently at about its intrinsic value. This steadiness is more appealing to me than the volatility we've seen in the past, where market price has swung wildly compared to our actual value.
How do you and Charlie Munger view your roles in the operation of Berkshire's businesses?

Charlie and I see our job as identifying talented managers and giving them the environment they need to succeed. We don't try to develop their skills - they're already superstars when we find them. Our main task after that is to intelligently deploy the cash they generate for us.
What happened to Christmas sales in Albuquerque after Chuck sent personal letters and gift certificates to loyal customers?
Christmas sales in Albuquerque were up substantially after Chuck's gesture. It just goes to show you that a little appreciation can go a long way in business.
Why do you think media businesses, such as newspapers, have become more vulnerable to recession?

I believe media businesses have become more vulnerable because their pricing power has been eroded. With advertising dollars growing slowly and retailers taking market share without relying on media advertising, the industry just isn't as robust as it used to be.
What percentage of the paper will you maintain as a news hole, regardless of earnings pressures?
I'm committed to maintaining at least a 50% news hole. To me, cutting product quality is not a proper response to adversity, and our readers expect a certain level of news coverage from us.
How did the operating performance of Fechheimer change in 1990?
Fechheimer's operating performance improved considerably in 1990. We were able to moderate or solve many of the problems that arose from the large acquisition we made back in 1988.
What does a combined ratio below 100 indicate in the insurance industry?
A combined ratio below 100 indicates an underwriting profit. It's like being in the black, rather than the red - you're making money from your premiums after accounting for losses and expenses.
Why do you expect the industry's incurred losses to grow at an average of 10% annually, even when general inflation is lower?

Well, over the last 25 years, we've actually seen incurred losses grow at an even faster rate of 11%. It's just the nature of the business - as time goes on, the costs of claims and payouts tend to rise, regardless of what's happening with inflation. It's a trend we've observed and expect to continue.
What is expected to happen to the combined ratio in 1991 and how will results improve in the insurance industry?

The combined ratio is expected to increase by about two points in 1991. As for improvement, I believe results will get better when insurance managers become fearful and start running from business, even at higher prices. It's like they need to learn to stop digging when they're in a hole. Only then will they raise prices significantly, and that's when we'll see a change.
How will Berkshire's insurance business perform in the next few years, and are there any specific factors that could affect its volatility?

Our insurance volume is currently small but satisfactory. Looking ahead, if a particular line of business we're pursuing expands, our underwriting experience might be more volatile than expected. This means we might exceed expectations in most years but fall short in some years. That's just the nature of this business, and I want our investors to be aware of it.
How do the yearly combined ratios on super-cat business typically compare to the industry range?

Our yearly combined ratio on this business will almost never fall in the industry range of 100 - 120. Instead, it will be close to either zero or 300%. That's because we're concentrating risk rather than spreading it, which leads to some pretty wild swings in our results.
Why are most insurers unable or unwilling to tolerate the volatility associated with super-cat reinsurance?

Most insurers are financially unable to tolerate such swings, and even if they can, they often lack the desire. This is because they may write a lot of primary property insurance that would deliver them dismal results at the same time they're experiencing major losses on super-cat reinsurance. Plus, many corporate managements believe their shareholders don't like volatility in results.
What kind of return do you and Charlie Munger prefer, and why?

Charlie and I always have preferred a lumpy 15% return to a smooth 12%. You see, we're not afraid of a little volatility if it means we can achieve superior long-term results. It's like choosing between a steady, slow-cooked meal and a potentially explosive, but delicious, barbecue - we'll take the barbecue, even if it means getting burned occasionally.
How do you approach pricing for super-cat insurance, given the limited historical loss data?

We rely on subjective judgments to decide what rates to charge today. And let me tell you, we're not afraid to walk away if the price isn't right. We'll only write significant quantities of super-cat business at prices we believe are commensurate with the risk. If competitors become too optimistic and start underpricing, our volume will fall - we're not interested in leaving the field on a stretcher.
What is the typical range that a property-casualty insurer can absorb losses and expenses that exceed premiums and still break even?

The typical range is 7% to 11%. This means that if losses and expenses exceed premiums by this amount, the insurer can still break even due to the investment income generated from the 'float' - the funds of others that we temporarily hold in the conduct of our business.
Can you give an example of a type of insurance that produces a very high amount of float compared to annual premium volume?

One example is malpractice insurance, which covers the potential liabilities of doctors, lawyers, and accountants. This type of insurance is often referred to as 'long-tail' business because claims are frequently brought long after the alleged wrongdoing takes place, and their payment may be further delayed by lengthy litigation. This delay allows us to hold onto large sums of money for an extended period, generating significant float.
What does the term 'long-tail' business refer to in the insurance industry?

The term 'long-tail' business refers to types of insurance, like malpractice and certain liability insurance, where claims and their payments are significantly delayed, sometimes by years. This allows insurers to hold onto large sums of money, which we call 'float,' for an extended period.
Why is aiming for a combined ratio of 110-115 in long-tail insurance lines considered 'business suicide'?

Aiming for a combined ratio of 110-115 in long-tail insurance can be disastrous because, even though the float can make such ratios seem profitable at first, the eventual payout of claims can far exceed initial estimates, leading to significant losses. It's crucial to price with a healthy margin of safety to account for unforeseen societal trends and surprises.
How would you describe the cost of float for Berkshire's insurance operation in 1990, and what does this cost represent?

In 1990, our cost of float was about 1.6%, which is the underwriting loss of $27 million divided by the $1.6 billion of float we held. This cost represents the price we pay to use the funds that our insurance operation generates - think of it like an interest rate on a loan, but instead of borrowing money, we're essentially 'borrowing' these funds from our policyholders.

You mention that the tax penalty for indirect investments, such as those made through an insurance company, adds to the cost of float. Can you estimate the impact of this tax penalty on Berkshire's cost of float?

Yes, I estimate that the tax penalty adds about one percentage point to our cost of float. This means that if our pre-tax cost of float is, say, 1.6%, the tax penalty would bring it up to around 2.6%. It's a substantial penalty, and it's something we need to consider when evaluating the value of our insurance operation to shareholders.
What challenges do well-known insurance companies face that can lead to negative results for their owners?

Well, these companies often incur underwriting losses and float costs, which combined with tax penalties, can produce negative results. They're also vulnerable to catastrophe losses that can exceed their reinsurance protection, really taking their cost of float through the roof. It's a bit like a bank paying more interest on deposits than it earns on loans - not a great business model.
How has the insurance business treated your company, and what factors have contributed to your success in this area?

The insurance business has treated us very well, thank you for asking. We've been able to expand our float at a reasonable cost, and we've earned good returns on these low-cost funds. Yes, our shareholders have had to pay some extra taxes, but so far, the benefits of the float have more than made up for that cost. And let me tell you, it's not because I've been perfect - I've made some colossal mistakes in the insurance business over the years, but fortunately, we've still managed to come out on top.
Why do you think the intrinsic value of your insurance business is difficult to calculate?

I think the intrinsic value of our insurance business is tough to pin down because, as I said, there's no statute of limitations on stupidity. Mistakes can come back to haunt us years later, making it hard to put a precise figure on its worth. It's like trying to predict the weather - you can make educated guesses, but you can't always be sure what's going to happen.
What was the one change you made to your major holdings this year?

This year, we only made one move with our major holdings, and that was to increase our stake in Wells Fargo to just under 10%. It's a great bank with superb management and high returns, so we were happy to own a bit more of it - although we had to stop there because of Federal Reserve Board rules.
What qualities do you think make the managerial team of Carl Reichardt and Paul Hazen at Wells Fargo effective?

I believe the combination of Carl and Paul is effective because they understand, trust, and admire each other, making their partnership stronger than the sum of its parts. They also share some key traits, such as paying able people well, keeping a lean head count, attacking costs vigorously regardless of profit levels, and sticking to what they know and do best.
How did you manage to purchase a 10% interest in Wells Fargo at what seems to be a favorable price in 1990?

We were able to purchase our 10% interest in Wells Fargo for $290 million, which was less than five times after-tax earnings and less than three times pre-tax earnings, due in part to the chaotic market in bank stocks at the time. The market was in disarray because of the foolish loan decisions of other banks, which led to a flight from bank stocks and created an opportunity for us to buy in at a relatively low price.
What was the cost of purchasing a 10% interest in Wells Fargo, and how does it compare to buying a whole bank with similar financial characteristics?

We purchased our 10% interest in Wells Fargo for $290 million. If we were to buy a whole $5 billion bank with the same financial characteristics, we'd likely have to pay about twice that amount, or around $580 million. It's a much better deal to buy a portion of a well-run bank like Wells Fargo, if you ask me.
What are some of the risks associated with owning a bank, specifically a California-based bank like Wells Fargo?

Well, there are a few risks to consider. First, there's the risk of a major earthquake, which could cause significant problems for borrowers and, in turn, the banks that lend to them. Then there's the systemic risk of a severe business contraction or financial panic, which could affect even well-run banks. And finally, there's the concern about West Coast real estate values declining due to overbuilding, which could lead to big losses for banks that have financed these projects.
What are the major risks you see affecting Wells Fargo's performance, according to the text?

I see three major risks: the risk of a business contraction or financial panic, the risk associated with being a highly-leveraged institution, and the fear of a drop in West Coast real estate values due to overbuilding, which could lead to huge losses for banks that have financed this expansion.
How would a 10% default rate on Wells Fargo's loans, with 30% loss of principal, affect the bank's earnings?

If 10% of Wells Fargo's $48 billion in loans were to default, resulting in a 30% loss of principal, the bank would roughly break even. This scenario, which we consider a low-level possibility, would not cause us significant distress at Berkshire.
How do you approach market fluctuations when it comes to buying investments?

I think investors should welcome market declines if they're going to be ongoing buyers of investments. It's like buying food - if you know you're always going to be buying it, you want the price to be low, not high. So, when stock prices fall, I see it as an opportunity to pick up more shares at a better price, just like we did with Wells Fargo stock back in 1990.
Can you give an example of how this approach applies to one of your businesses, like the Buffalo News?

The Buffalo News is a great example. We always keep a large inventory of newsprint on hand, and if the price of newsprint falls, that means we have to mark down the value of our inventory. But we're not sellers of newsprint, we're buyers - we're always going to be buying more of it. So, we actually cheer when the price goes down, because it means we can buy what we need at a lower cost going forward.
Why do declining prices for businesses benefit Berkshire, and what is the most common cause of these low prices?

Declining prices for businesses benefit us because we're always on the lookout to buy, and lower prices mean better deals. The most common cause of these low prices is pessimism - sometimes it's a general gloomy outlook, and other times it's specific to a company or industry. We like the prices that pessimism produces, not the pessimism itself.
What was a significant addition to Berkshire's portfolio last year, and what's unusual about this investment?

Last year, we made large additions to our holdings of RJR Nabisco bonds, which is an unusual investment for us since they're below-investment-grade bonds. We first bought into these securities in late 1989, and by the end of 1990, we had $440 million invested in them.
What is the 'dagger thesis' and how does it relate to debt in business?

The 'dagger thesis' is the idea that huge debt will cause operating managers to focus their efforts as never before. It's like having a dagger mounted on your car's steering wheel - it'll definitely make you a more alert driver, but it's also a recipe for disaster if you hit any bumps in the road. And in business, those bumps are inevitable.
Can you give an example of a company that failed due to excessive debt, as you mentioned in the context of the 1990s debt mania?

One example that comes to mind is the purchase of a mature television station in Tampa. The buyer took on so much debt that the interest payments alone exceeded the station's gross revenues. It was a 'kill-'em-at-birth' situation - the business was doomed from the start.
What was the flaw in the salesmen's logic when comparing newly-minted junk bonds to low-grade fallen angels?

The flaw was assuming that the two groups were identical, which isn't true. It's like comparing apples and oranges, or in my example, checking the historical death rate from Kool-Aid before drinking the version served at Jonestown. The universes are just dissimilar in several vital respects.
How did the behavior of managers of fallen angels differ from that of junk-bond operators, according to you?

Well, the manager of a fallen angel usually wants to regain investment-grade status and works towards that goal. On the other hand, the junk-bond operator is like a heroin user, always looking for the next fix, not a cure for their debt-ridden condition. It's a pretty stark difference, if you ask me.
Why do you describe the junk bond market as a mine field, and under what conditions would you consider buying these bonds?

I call the junk bond market a mine field because it's filled with risks, and many of these bonds were sold to people who didn't do their due diligence. As for buying them, I've said the only time to buy is on a day with no 'y' in it - meaning never, under normal circumstances. However, now that the market is in disarray, we're willing to take a closer look for potential opportunities.
You mention holding convertible preferred stocks in several companies. How do you assess the value of these holdings as of the end of 1990?

As of yearend 1990, I assess our holdings in Salomon and Champion as being worth about what we paid for them. Our Gillette holdings are worth somewhat more, thanks to the upcoming conversion into common stock. Unfortunately, our USAir holdings are worth substantially less. It's a mixed bag, but that's the nature of investing - you win some, you lose some.
What is happening to Berkshire's Gillette holdings on April 1?
Our Gillette holdings will be converted into 12 million shares of common stock on April 1. It's a straightforward conversion, and we'll end up with a sizable chunk of common stock.
How do you assess the performance of your USAir investment so far?

Honestly, I'd say it's been a bit of a disappointment. I made an 'unforced error' by investing at a time when the airline industry was about to run into severe problems. The company's troubles were exacerbated by both industry conditions and post-merger integration issues with Piedmont. However, the team at USAir, led by Ed Colodny and Seth Schofield, has made significant improvements in service, and I'm hopeful that unless the industry collapses, our investment should still work out all right in the end.
What kind of businesses are you looking to acquire, and what are the key characteristics you consider when evaluating potential purchases?

I'm looking for businesses with at least $10 million in after-tax earnings, consistent earning power, good returns on equity, and little to no debt. I also prefer simple businesses with management already in place, and I need to know the offering price upfront. Think of it like buying a house - I want to know the address, the price, and that it's in good condition before I even think about making an offer.
How do you typically structure your purchases, and what kind of timeline can sellers expect for a decision?

My favorite way to buy is with cash, but I'll consider issuing stock if it's a fair trade. As for the timeline, I can promise a very fast answer - usually within five minutes - on whether we're interested in making a deal. And don't worry, I can keep everything confidential. It's like making a quick phone call to decide if we're going to meet for lunch - if it's not a good fit, we'll know right away.
Why is Ken Chace not seeking reelection as a director at Berkshire's upcoming annual meeting?
Ken Chace has decided to cut back his activities at the age of 75, and that's the reason he's not seeking reelection. It's a personal decision, and I respect that.
What will happen to your Berkshire stock if you were to pass away tomorrow?

If I were to die tomorrow, none of my stock would have to be sold. My wife, Susan, would inherit all of my stock and effectively control the company, ensuring that Berkshire's character and management philosophy are preserved.
What happens to your Berkshire stock if you were to die tomorrow?

None of my stock would have to be sold. I've made sure that my estate plan is set up in a way that avoids any forced selling of Berkshire shares, so you won't see any big changes in ownership just because I'm no longer around.
How much do the managers of Berkshire's operating businesses contribute to charities each year?

The managers of our operating businesses make contributions, including merchandise, that average about $1.5 million annually. These contributions go to local charities and also happen to produce some benefits for our businesses, which is a nice bonus.
How much do the managers of Berkshire's operating businesses contribute to local charities annually?
Our managers contribute about $1.5 million annually to local charities, such as The United Way, in the form of merchandise and other support.
What arrangements have been made for attendees of the annual meeting who choose to stay at the Marriott hotel?
For those staying at the Marriott, we've arranged for buses to take them to the meeting at the Orpheum Theater, departing at 8:30 and 8:45, and returning after the meeting ends.
What are the two categories of buyers that you think most companies will fall into if I decide to sell my business?

If you decide to sell, I believe the buyers will typically fall into one of two categories: either a company from elsewhere that operates in your business or a similar one, or a financial maneuverer who's looking to resell for a profit, often using a lot of borrowed money.
How do you think the managers of a larger acquiring company will likely interact with the operations of the business they've acquired?

Well, I think it's just human nature - the managers of a larger acquiring company, especially if they're familiar with the industry, will eventually want to apply their own 'help' and run things their way. They might have a bunch of managers who are itching to get their hands on a new acquisition and show off their skills, even if the business was doing just fine on its own.
What kind of buyer is Berkshire, and how do you approach the management of the businesses you acquire?

I'd say Berkshire is a rather unusual kind of buyer - we buy to keep. When we acquire a business, we don't interfere with its operations. Instead, we let the sellers continue running it just as they did before the sale. We adapt to their methods, not the other way around. This approach allows the businesses to maintain their autonomy, and we don't have a team of people in our parent organization who need to be involved in the day-to-day operations.
What's your view on the type of buyers who plan to resell a business soon after acquiring it, particularly if the sellers have a strong emotional attachment to their business?

Well, I think those buyers - the financial maneuverers - can be a poor fit if the sellers have put their heart and soul into the business. If the business represents a lifetime of creative work and is closely tied to the seller's sense of identity, then a buyer who just plans to flip it or manipulate the accounting to make a quick profit isn't going to be very satisfactory. They just don't have the same level of commitment or understanding of the business that the original owners do.
Why do you want the operating members of the family to retain a 20% interest in the business?

I want the operating members of the family to retain a 20% interest because we need them to stay on as our partners. We believe their continued ownership and involvement are crucial to the business's success. Contracts can't guarantee their interest, so we rely on their word.
What happens to the management of a business after you buy it?

When we buy a business, the sellers continue to run it just as they did before the sale. We adapt to their methods, rather than the other way around. This approach allows the business to keep operating smoothly, without any disruption from our end.
What is your role in the companies that Berkshire acquires, and how much involvement do you have in their operations?

My role is pretty limited. I focus on capital allocation and selecting and compensating the top person. Everything else, like operating strategies and personnel decisions, is up to the manager. Some of them like to bounce ideas off me, but it's really their show to run.
What kind of treatment can a seller expect if they decide to do business with Berkshire, in terms of the deal process and their business's future?

If you sell to us, you can expect a straightforward, no-nonsense deal. We pay in cash, your business won't be used as collateral, and there won't be any brokers or last-minute changes. You'll know exactly who you're dealing with, and we won't announce a deal only to back out later. And let's be honest, you're already wealthy from owning your business, so the sale won't change that.
Mr. Buffett, why would selling my business not make me wealthier?

Well, it's quite simple really. Selling your business would just change the form of your wealth, not the amount. Think of it like trading a valuable painting for a pile of cash. You still have the same value, it's just in a different form. And in this case, you'd be trading a business you understand and own 100% for smaller pieces of other businesses, which you might not know as well.
What would happen if I decided to sell my business to Berkshire?

If you were to sell to Berkshire, I believe we would do very well financially, and I think you'd find that running the business would be just as enjoyable over the next 20 years as it has been over the past 20. We'd be proud to have your business as part of Berkshire, and I think it would be a great fit for both of us.
What was the gain in Berkshire Hathaway's net worth during 1991 and how does that compare to your long-term growth rate?

Our gain in net worth during 1991 was $2.1 billion, or 39.6%. Over the long haul, our per-share book value has grown at a rate of 23.7% compounded annually over the last 27 years. So, 1991 was a particularly good year for us, but we don't expect to sustain that kind of growth going forward.
You mentioned that as Berkshire grows, it becomes harder to find opportunities that can significantly influence the company's performance. Can you explain why that is?

Well, think of it like this: when we were smaller, a relatively small idea or investment could make a big difference in our overall performance. But now that we're much larger, it takes a much bigger idea or investment to move the needle. For example, we need an idea that can generate over $550 million of pre-tax profit to achieve the same impact that a $1 million profit would have had when we were working with much less capital. It's just a numbers game, and the reality is that there are many more ways to make $1 million than to make $370 million.
What message did your decision to take the job imply about Berkshire's operating managers?

My decision to take the job sent a clear message: I have immense confidence in Berkshire's operating managers. They're so outstanding that I can reduce my time spent at the company without worrying about its economic progress. It's a testament to their exceptional abilities.
How do you describe the role you and Charlie play in the success of Berkshire's operating units?

I like to think of our role as similar to that of a coach. We provide the support and resources needed, but it's our talented managers who do the heavy lifting. As I illustrated with the story of George Mira and his coach, Andy Gustafson, sometimes the best coaching is simply letting your stars shine. We're fortunate to have such managerial talent at Berkshire.
What do you mean by 'look-through earnings' and how can investors benefit from focusing on them?

Look-through earnings, to me, are like looking at the total earnings of a private company you own - you consider all the earnings from your various investments, not just the dividends they pay out. By focusing on look-through earnings, investors can benefit by thinking about the long-term business prospects of their investments rather than just short-term stock market fluctuations. It's a way to think about your portfolio as a whole company and aim to maximize its overall earnings potential over time.
How do you calculate the total look-through earnings of Berkshire, as shown in the provided financial data?

Calculating total look-through earnings for Berkshire involves adding our reported operating earnings to our share of undistributed earnings from major investees, and then subtracting the hypothetical tax on those undistributed earnings. In the example given, we start with $316 in reported operating earnings, add $230 in undistributed earnings from our major investees, and then subtract $30 for the hypothetical tax, resulting in total look-through earnings of $516.
How do you think investors should focus their attention to improve their investment results?

I believe investors should focus on long-term business prospects rather than short-term stock market prospects. It's like watching a baseball game - to score runs, you need to watch the playing field, not the scoreboard. In other words, pay attention to the company's fundamentals and future earnings potential, rather than just the current stock price.
What's your take on the current state of the media industry, and how has it changed over time?

Well, I've said before that the decline in media companies' profitability is due to both secular and cyclical factors. Unfortunately, it's one of those cases where hindsight is 20/20 - a few years ago, nobody saw this economic deterioration coming, not even the lenders, owners, or financial analysts. Now, it's clear that the industry is eroding, with newspaper, TV, and magazine properties behaving more like regular businesses than franchises.
What are the key characteristics of an economic franchise?

An economic franchise has three main characteristics: the product or service is needed or desired, customers think it has no close substitute, and it's not subject to price regulation. Think of it like a favorite restaurant - if people love the food and can't get it elsewhere, and the government isn't telling them how much to charge, they can raise prices and make a pretty penny.
How have media properties like newspapers, television, and magazines changed in terms of their economic behavior?

Well, they used to behave like franchises, but now they're acting more like regular businesses. They used to have a lot of pricing power and could tolerate some mismanagement, but now consumers have a lot more choices for information and entertainment, so media properties can't just coast anymore.
What has changed for media properties in terms of their ability to price and manage themselves?

Well, media properties used to have the characteristics of a franchise, which allowed them to price aggressively and be managed loosely. But now, with consumers having many more choices for information and entertainment, the industry's franchise strength has weakened. It's like trying to sell lemonade on a street with many other lemonade stands - you can't charge as much or be as careless with your business as you could when you were the only game in town.
How did the conventional wisdom about media properties' earnings growth relate to their value?

The conventional wisdom held that media properties would increase their earnings by 6% annually without needing much additional capital. This made their reported earnings essentially the same as their freely-distributable earnings. So, owning a media property was like owning a perpetual annuity that grew 6% a year. And if you used a 10% discount rate to calculate the present value of that earnings stream, you could estimate the property's value. It's a simple but useful way to think about the value of these businesses.
Why did buyers previously value a dollar of earnings from media higher than a dollar from steel?

It's quite simple, really. Buyers valued media earnings more because they expected those earnings to grow consistently over time without needing a lot of additional capital. It's like comparing a fruit tree that keeps producing more fruit every year without needing much care, to a steel mill that requires constant investment just to keep production steady.
How has the intrinsic value of your media investments been affected by the industry's secular transformation?

Well, the intrinsic value of our media investments has declined materially due to the secular changes in the industry. However, it's worth noting that some of our media holdings, like the Buffalo News under Stan Lipsey's leadership, and our investments in Cap Cities and Washington Post, have performed better than most because they're exceptionally well-managed.
What factors have moderated the intrinsic value losses of your media holdings?

The strong performance of the Buffalo News under Stan Lipsey's leadership and the exceptional management of Cap Cities and Washington Post have helped moderate the intrinsic value losses. Specifically, these companies avoided paying irrational prices for media properties in the late 1980s and have small debt levels, which has reduced the impact of asset value shrinkage.
How do the debt levels of Cap Cities and Washington Post compare to other publicly-owned media companies?

Cap Cities and Washington Post are essentially debt-free, with their small debt levels roughly offset by the cash they hold. In contrast, most other publicly-owned media companies have debt equal to five or more times their current net income, due to a combination of aggressive acquisition policies and shrinking earnings.
How much of See's profits were distributed to Blue Chip/Berkshire over the 20-year period, and what was the initial net worth of the company?

See's distributed $410 million of its pre-tax profits to Blue Chip/Berkshire over 20 years. As for the initial net worth, when we first acquired See's, its net worth was $7 million, which has since grown to $25 million through reinvested earnings.
What was the outcome of See's sales volume in 1991 compared to 1990, and how did this impact profits?

In 1991, See's sales volume in dollars was the same as in 1990, but when measured in pounds, it was actually down 4%. Despite this weakness, particularly in the last two months of the year which are crucial for our annual profits, we managed to grow our profits by 7% and achieved a record pre-tax profit margin of 21.6%.
What did you learn from owning See's, and how has it impacted your investment decisions?

Well, owning See's has taught me and Charlie a great deal about evaluating franchises. We've applied those lessons to other investments and made significant money as a result. It's like learning a new recipe - once you master it, you can use it to cook up all sorts of delicious dishes, or in our case, profitable investments.
Can you tell me about the history of H. H. Brown Company and its previous owner, Ray Heffernan?

Ray Heffernan bought H. H. Brown for $10,000 back in 1927, and he ran it for 62 years. That's a remarkable run, and he built the company into a sizable business with plants in the US and Canada, employing nearly 2,000 people. He was a real entrepreneur, and his story is a testament to the power of hard work and smart decision-making. And, as an aside, he seemed to have a good sense of humor about his son-in-law's career choices - or lack thereof!
What was the performance of Melville Shoe under Frank's leadership?
Under Frank's leadership, Melville's earnings averaged more than 20% on equity, and its stock price rose from $16 to $960 over his 23-year tenure. Not a bad run, if I do say so myself.
Why were you enthusiastic about purchasing Brown, and what role did Frank play in this decision?

I was enthusiastic about buying Brown largely because Frank was willing to stay on as CEO. He's one of those rare managers who doesn't need to work for the money but does it because he loves the challenge and wants to excel. Having him at the helm made the purchase a lot more attractive to me.
What are you looking for in a company when considering a major purchase?

I'm looking for several key things: large purchases with at least $10 million of after-tax earnings, demonstrated consistent earning power, good returns on equity with little to no debt, management already in place, simple businesses, and a clear offering price. That's what gets my attention.
Have investment banks been effective in bringing you potential acquisition opportunities?

Unfortunately, no. Despite being involved in four major purchases where the sellers were represented by prominent investment banks, we were only contacted by the investment bank once. The other three times, I or a friend had to initiate the transaction after the bank had already solicited other prospects. It's a bit discouraging, to be honest.
What is your investment approach, as reflected in the list of common stock holdings?

Our approach is what I like to call 'Rip Van Winkle' - we tend to hold onto our investments for a long time, rather than constantly buying and selling. In fact, if you look at the list, you'll see that we've held seven of those stocks for over a year, and in six of them, we haven't changed the number of shares we own. It's a patient approach, and we believe it serves us well.
Which of the listed companies is a new position in your portfolio?
Guinness PLC is the new kid on the block - it's the only new position we've added to the list. All the other seven stocks were already in our portfolio a year ago.
What approach do you and Charlie take when it comes to investing in businesses?

We focus on finding the superstars - great businesses with outstanding managers. We're not trying to be clever by buying and selling pieces of mediocre companies. Instead, we look for a few exceptional operations that we can buy into at a sensible price and hold onto for the long term.
What's your view on actively trading investments, and how do you think it relates to real investing?

To be frank, I think actively trading investments is more like flitting from flower to flower - it's not a real investment strategy. We believe that true investors should be focused on finding great businesses and holding onto them, rather than constantly buying and selling. As I said, calling someone who does that an 'investor' is like calling someone who has one-night stands a romantic - it just doesn't fit.
What is your approach to investment, as inspired by John Maynard Keynes?

I believe in putting fairly large sums into enterprises I think I know something about and have confidence in the management. It's not about spreading yourself too thin across many investments you're not familiar with. As Keynes said, it's a mistake to think you're limiting risk by doing so. I think it's better to focus on a few areas where you have real knowledge and confidence.
What type of mistakes do you and Charlie typically make in your investments?

Our most egregious mistakes usually fall into the category of omissions, rather than commissions. In other words, it's often what we don't do, rather than what we do, that proves to be the mistake. And while these errors might not be visible to others, they still come with a cost.
Why do you say that smoothness in attaining your objective is elusive, particularly in terms of accounting rules for common stocks owned by your insurance companies?

Well, it's because of the accounting rules that require us to value those securities at their market prices. This means that even minor fluctuations in the market can cause our annual results to jump all over the place, making it look like we're on a wild rollercoaster ride. It's a bit like trying to measure the progress of a long-distance runner by looking at their every step - it's just not a very accurate way to gauge how they're doing overall.
How did the performance of your textile operation impact your overall performance in the early years?

To be frank, it was a drag. The returns from our textile operation were far less than what we could have earned if we had invested that money in the S&P 500 instead. It's a bit like having a anchor tied to your leg when you're trying to swim - it's going to slow you down and make it harder to make progress.
Who were some of the key individuals that helped resolve Salomon's problems?

I'm grateful to say that Deryck Maughan, Bob Denham, Don Howard, and John Macfarlane were instrumental in righting the firm. They were tireless, effective, and selfless in their work, and I'll always be thankful for their efforts. Our lead lawyer, Ron Olson, also played a crucial role in navigating the complex government matters we faced.
What approach do you and Charlie take when looking for businesses to acquire?

Well, I like to think of it like looking for a spouse - you want to be active, interested, and open-minded, but not in a hurry. We're always on the lookout for businesses with excellent economic characteristics and management teams we like, trust, and admire. It's not easy to find the right ones, but we're patient and persistent in our search.
What is the main difference in your acquisition strategy now compared to the past, as influenced by the professional's statement?

Well, I used to focus on buying fair businesses at good prices, but now I prioritize buying good businesses at fair prices. It's a subtle shift, but it's made a big difference in how I approach acquisitions.
Can you tell us a bit about Central States Indemnity, your latest acquisition, and its current financial performance?

Central States Indemnity is an insurer based in Omaha, and it's a great business. Currently, it generates about $90 million in annual premiums and $10 million in profits. I'm excited about its potential, and I think it's a fantastic addition to our portfolio.
What is the composition of look-through earnings, and why do you believe it's a more accurate portrayal of Berkshire's earnings?

Look-through earnings consist of our operating earnings, plus the retained operating earnings of our major investees, minus an allowance for the tax that would be paid if those retained earnings were distributed to us. I believe this number gives a truer picture of Berkshire's earnings because it takes into account the earnings of our investees that aren't reflected in our GAAP profits.
What is the target growth rate for look-through earnings, and what does Berkshire need to achieve by the year 2000 to meet this goal?

We're aiming for a 15% annual growth rate in look-through earnings, which means we need to reach over $1.8 billion by the year 2000. To put that in perspective, our look-through earnings were $604 million in 1992, so we've got our work cut out for us. It's an ambitious goal, but it guides our decision-making and pushes us to deliver excellent performances from our subsidiaries and investees.
What does a combined ratio below 100 indicate in the insurance industry?

A combined ratio below 100 indicates an underwriting profit. It's like having a store where you sell more than you spend - you're making money on the sales themselves, before you even count any investment income from your float.
How much of the industry's 1992 combined ratio is attributed to Hurricane Andrew?

About four points of the industry's 1992 combined ratio can be attributed to Hurricane Andrew. That storm was a real wake-up call for many insurers, showing them that their reinsurance protection wasn't as strong as they thought.
What initially caught your attention about the company, and how did your perspective change over time?

I initially paid little attention to the company until they announced a Dutch tender to repurchase about 30% of its shares. Seeing an arbitrage opportunity, I started buying the stock for Berkshire, expecting a small profit. However, after studying the company and CEO Bill Anders' strategy and accomplishments, my perspective changed. I was impressed by his clear and rational strategy, focus, and sense of urgency, which led to remarkable results. This made me decide to dump my arbitrage thoughts and become a long-term investor in the company.
What are the key factors you consider when selecting marketable equity securities for Berkshire?

When selecting marketable equity securities, I look for businesses that meet four main criteria: (a) we can understand the business; (b) it has favorable long-term prospects; (c) it's operated by honest and competent people; and (d) it's available at a very attractive price. This approach hasn't changed much over the years, and it's the same way we'd evaluate a business for acquisition in its entirety.
How do you determine what makes a stock's price 'attractive' for investment?

Well, I think it's quite simple really. To me, an attractive price is one where the value of the business is sufficiently high to justify the amount paid. It's not about guessing what the market will do next, but rather about understanding the intrinsic value of the company and making sure we're not overpaying. We consider growth as a component of that value, and we're looking for a price that reflects a sensible trade-off between what we're getting and what we're paying.
Do you see a distinction between 'value' and 'growth' investing, or are they intertwined in your view?

I think the distinction between 'value' and 'growth' is a bit fuzzy, to be honest. Growth is always a part of calculating value - it's a variable that can range from not very important to extremely important, and it can even be negative. So, in my opinion, the two approaches are joined at the hip. Investing is always about seeking value, and growth is just one aspect of that. I think the term 'value investing' is actually redundant - what else would investing be, if not seeking value?
You mentioned that growth can hurt investors in a low-return business. Can you explain why that is?

Well, think of it like this: if a business can't generate attractive returns on the money it invests, then growth just means more money is being thrown at a problem that isn't very profitable. It's like trying to fill a leaky bucket - the more water you add, the more water you lose. In the case of the domestic airline business, for example, all the growth in the world hasn't helped investors because the returns just aren't there.
You referenced John Burr Williams' equation for value. How does this equation differ for stocks versus bonds?

The equation itself is the same for both stocks and bonds - it's all about the cash inflows and outflows, discounted at an interest rate. But the key difference is that with bonds, you've got a clear picture of those future cash flows because of the coupon and maturity date. With stocks, it's up to the investment analyst to estimate what those future 'coupons' will be, and that's where the quality of management comes in - it can make all the difference in the world.
How does the quality of management typically affect bonds versus equities?

The quality of management affects bonds only rarely, usually when they're so bad that they can't even pay the interest. On the other hand, management's ability can have a huge impact on the value of equities - think of it like the engine of a car, it can make all the difference in how well the investment performs.
What makes a business particularly attractive to own from a long-term investment perspective?

The best business to own is one that can use a lot of extra capital to generate very high returns over a long period. It's like finding a money machine that just keeps cranking out more and more value. Unfortunately, these kinds of businesses are hard to come by, and often the ones that do exist don't need a lot of capital to begin with.
What was the total capital gain you realized from fixed-income investments in 1992?
In 1992, we realized $80 million in capital gains from our fixed-income investments. It was a good year for us in that regard.
How do you compare the performance of your fixed-income investments made in the secondary market to those made through negotiated purchases of preferreds?

To be honest, our overall performance with negotiated purchases of preferreds has been inferior to what we've achieved with purchases made in the secondary market. This isn't surprising to us, as we've always believed that an intelligent investor will do better in the secondary market than with new issues.
Why do you believe an intelligent investor in common stocks will do better in the secondary market than in buying new issues?

I believe that's the case because the secondary market is constantly setting a 'clearing' price, which can sometimes be foolishly low. This means shares might sell for half their business value or less. In contrast, the new-issue market is controlled by sellers who can time their offerings to avoid unfavorable markets, so they're not likely to offer bargains.
How have your negotiated purchases of preferred stock performed relative to your initial expectations?

Our negotiated purchases have fulfilled, but not exceeded, our expectations. As we stated in our 1989 Annual Report, we anticipated that these investments would produce returns modestly above those of most fixed-income portfolios, and that's exactly what's happened so far.
How have your negotiated purchases performed relative to your initial expectations?

Our negotiated purchases have fulfilled, but not exceeded, the expectations we set forth in our 1989 Annual Report. We expected returns modestly above those achieved by most fixed-income portfolios, and that's exactly what we've gotten.
What's your assessment of the airline industry's behavior in recent years?

I've got to say, the airline industry has been acting like its members are in a competitive tontine, trying to bring it to a conclusion as rapidly as possible. It's been a real challenge, with companies engaging in prolonged kamikaze behavior. But despite all this turmoil, Seth Schofield, CEO of USAir, has done a truly extraordinary job in repositioning the airline.
How will the new rule regarding deferred taxes affect Berkshire's financial reporting?

The new rule will cause us to reflect future changes in tax rates immediately in our liability for deferred taxes, which in turn affects our net worth. It's a bit like adjusting the price tag on a store shelf as soon as a sale is announced - the change is instantaneous, even if the sale hasn't happened yet.
How has Berkshire historically handled post-retirement health benefits in its acquisition strategy?

Charlie and I have tended to steer clear of companies with significant post-retirement liabilities. It's a deliberate choice, much like avoiding a pothole on the road - we'd rather not have to deal with the bumps and bruises that come with those kinds of obligations. Luckily, this approach has kept our own liability and future costs for post-retirement health benefits very low.
What role did accounting rules play in the accumulation of post-retirement health costs liabilities in major American industries?

Well, I believe accounting rules allowed companies to use cash-basis accounting, which meant they didn't have to book these costs as they were incurred. This approach vastly understated the liabilities that were building up, and it's a big part of why we're facing such large problems today. It was like an 'out-of-sight, out-of-mind' attitude, and it didn't serve anyone well.
Why do you think the business world has resisted accounting for stock options in a logical way?

It's quite simple, really. For decades, the business world has been trying to keep the costs of stock options from being reflected in corporate profits. It's a war against accounting rulemakers, and the lack of logic in how options are accounted for isn't accidental - it's a deliberate attempt to avoid showing the true costs on the books.

You've mentioned that Berkshire will pay a substantial sum for the right to any future gain realized on a restricted option. Can you explain why you're making this offer and what it signifies about the value of options?

I'm making this offer because I believe options have real value, even if they're restricted or out of the money. By offering to buy these options, I'm putting my money where my mouth is. It's a straightforward way to demonstrate that options aren't worthless, as some executives might claim. If an option has no value, then the executive should be more than happy to sell it to us. The fact that we're willing to pay a substantial sum for it shows that we think options are worth something, and companies should account for them as such.
You seem critical of the accounting profession and the SEC for their handling of stock option accounting. Can you elaborate on why you think they've failed in this regard?

I think the accounting profession and the SEC have been too soft on executives when it comes to stock option accounting. They've allowed companies to avoid treating options as an expense, which is ridiculous. If options are a form of compensation – and they clearly are – then they should be accounted for as such. It's basic common sense: if you're giving someone something of value, you should recognize the cost of it. By not doing so, companies are distorting their earnings and misleading investors. It's a shame that the accounting profession and the SEC have let themselves be swayed by corporate interests on this issue.
What is your opinion on the accounting profession and the SEC's handling of the option-accounting issue?
I think they should be ashamed of themselves for letting business executives push them around on this issue. It's like they're letting the fox guard the henhouse.
What changes are happening in your team at Berkshire, and how do you feel about them?

Well, I'm sad to see Gladys Kaiser, my friend and assistant of 25 years, retire from her post, but I'm glad she'll still be my friend. And Verne McKenzie, our Chief Financial Officer, is stepping down after 30 years, but he'll stay on as a consultant, which I'm happy about. His successor, Marc Hamburg, is a capable guy who's been learning from Verne for five years.
What was the increase in Berkshire's shares outstanding and net worth as a result of the transactions mentioned?
Our shares outstanding increased by 29,147 and our net worth grew by about $478 million. Not a bad day's work, if I do say so myself.
You mentioned that Berkshire's book value and intrinsic value are related, but not at most companies. Can you explain the difference between these two values?

Well, book value is just an accounting term that measures the capital put into a business, including retained earnings. Intrinsic value, on the other hand, is a present-value estimate of the cash that can be taken out of a business during its remaining life. Think of it like a house - book value might be what you paid for it, but intrinsic value is what you can really get out of it over time.
What was the outcome of your acquisition of Lowell Shoe, and how did it compare to your initial expectations?

The outcome of our acquisition of Lowell Shoe was terrific - the results have surpassed our expectations. We knew the business needed some fixing when we acquired it, but Frank Rooney and his team have done a great job turning it around.
How does Dexter Shoe manage to compete with low-wage countries, despite being a domestic shoe manufacturer?

Well, it's quite simple really - the management at Dexter Shoe, led by Harold Alfond and Peter Lunder, is just ingenious. They've built a highly competitive business with skilled labor forces in Maine and Puerto Rico, proving that with the right team, U.S. plants can compete against all comers.
What is the expected sales figure for Berkshire's shoe operations in 1994?
We're expecting our shoe operations to have more than $550 million in sales in 1994. It's a big number, and I'm pleased with how our investments in the shoe industry are turning out.
How do you approach deciding which businesses or industries to enter at Berkshire?

To be honest, we don't have some grand plan or vision that dictates which businesses or industries we'll enter. Instead, we focus on finding businesses with strong economic characteristics and talented managers. We look for the right combination of these factors and then hope we get lucky. It's a simple approach, but it's worked well for us so far.
What do you typically look for when considering a business to own, and how did Dexter fit into this approach?

I look for businesses with strong economic characteristics and talented managers. With Dexter, we got lucky and found both - a great business and capable leaders, Harold and Peter. It was a perfect combination for us.
Why did Harold and Peter's decision to exchange their Dexter stock for Berkshire shares make sense, according to you?

Well, they essentially traded a 100% stake in one excellent business for a smaller stake in a diverse portfolio of great businesses. This move gave them flexibility, tax efficiency, and the ability to diversify without the complications that come with privately held companies. It solved their reinvestment problem and provided them with more options for the future.
How much profit did Berkshire realize from the sale after paying 35% capital gains taxes?
We realized a $297 million profit from the sale after paying those taxes. It's a significant amount, and I'm pleased to say it far exceeded the undistributed earnings allocable to those shares.
What portion of the 1993 federal income taxes paid by Berkshire is attributable to operating earnings versus realized capital gains?

About $200 million of our 1993 federal income taxes is attributable to operating earnings, while $190 million is due to realized capital gains. It's a substantial tax bill, but Charlie and I believe it's a price we're happy to pay given the success of our investments.
Do you and Charlie Munger have any complaints about the taxes on Berkshire's shares?

No, we have absolutely no complaint about these taxes. We believe taxation partially redresses the inequity of a market-based economy that rewards our efforts more bountifully than others whose output may be of equal or greater benefit to society.
How does your investment strategy of buying and holding help mitigate the tax penalty imposed by Berkshire's corporate form?

Our buy-and-hold policy helps because taxes are due only when gains are realized. By holding onto our investments for the long term, we delay the payment of those taxes, which is a sound strategy for investing and also happens to fit our personalities.
How much would Li'l Abner have accumulated after 20 years if he doubled his money annually, but was subject to a 35% federal tax rate?

Well, let me tell you, if Li'l Abner had managed to double his money every year for 20 years, but had to pay a 35% tax on each of those doubles, he would have ended up with only $22,370. Not exactly the kind of money that would impress Appassionatta Van Climax, if you know what I mean.
What would have been the outcome if Li'l Abner had instead put his dollar in a single investment and held it until it doubled 27 1/2 times?

Now that's an interesting question. If Abner had just put his dollar into a single investment and let it ride, doubling 27 1/2 times, he would have ended up with about $200 million pre-tax. And after paying a $70 million tax in the final year, he would have been left with around $130 million.
