Now, that's what I call a real fortune, and I'm pretty sure Appassionatta would have been impressed.
How much could Berkshire potentially lose from a super-cat event similar to Hurricane Andrew today, compared to what was paid out in 1992?
Well, if a storm like Hurricane Andrew were to happen today, we're estimating our losses could be around $600 million, which is roughly five times what we paid out back in 1992, about $125 million.
What advantage does Berkshire have over its competitors in the super-cat business, according to your assessment?

Our main advantage is our enormous capital base - our net worth is ten to twenty times larger than that of our main competitors. This allows us to offer much higher limits than they can, without risking our financial stability. Plus, we've got the best manager in the business, Ajit Jain, which certainly doesn't hurt.
Why do you think it's foolish to part with an interest in a business that is both understandable and durably wonderful?

I think it's foolish because business interests of that kind are simply too hard to replace. It's like finding a crown jewel - you wouldn't sell it just because someone offered you a good price. The same logic applies to stocks: if you've got a stake in a wonderful business, it makes sense to hold on to it with the same tenacity that an owner would exhibit if they owned the whole business.
What's wrong with the argument 'You can't go broke taking a profit'?

That argument is superficial and misguided. I mean, can you imagine a CEO using that line to justify selling a star subsidiary? It just doesn't make sense. In business, you don't sell your best assets just because you can make a profit - and the same principle should apply to your investment portfolio. It's about holding on to what's truly valuable, not just cashing out for a quick gain.
How has Coca-Cola's sales volume changed from 1938 to 1993?

Well, it's quite remarkable. In 1938, Coca-Cola sold 207 million cases of soft drinks, and by 1993, that number had grown to about 10.7 billion cases - a 50-fold increase. That's what I call a pretty impressive track record.
What investment strategy have you and Charlie adopted for Berkshire?

We've decided to keep things simple and focus on making just a few smart decisions, rather than trying to make hundreds of them. We're looking for one good idea a year, and we're not afraid to go against the standard diversification dogma. As I like to say, we don't need to be geniuses to be successful - just smart, and not too smart at that, a few times.
How do you define risk in the context of investing, and how does it differ from the definition used by academics?

I define risk as the possibility of loss or injury, using simple dictionary terms. This is quite different from how academics define it - they focus on the relative volatility of a stock or portfolio compared to a large universe of stocks, which they quantify using 'beta'. I think their approach can be misleading, as it prioritizes precise calculations over real-world common sense.
Can you provide an example of how the academic definition of risk can lead to absurd conclusions?

A great example is Washington Post when we bought it in 1973. According to beta-based theory, the stock became 'riskier' after its price dropped sharply, simply because it had become more volatile compared to the market. That doesn't make sense to me - the business itself didn't change, just the price. It's a clear case of being precisely wrong, rather than approximately right.
How do you think about risk as an owner of a business, and how does that differ from the academics' definition of risk?

I think about risk in a very practical way - as an owner of a business, I want to understand the company's fundamentals, like what it produces, its competitive landscape, and its financial health. The academics' definition of risk, based on beta and price history, just doesn't cut it for me. It's like trying to judge a book by its cover, without ever reading the contents. And it can lead to some pretty silly conclusions, like a stock being 'riskier' just because its price has dropped.
You mention 'Mr. Market' from Ben Graham's book - can you explain how this concept relates to volatility and investment opportunities?

Ah, 'Mr. Market' - he's a great guy to have around, even if he is a bit manic-depressive. The idea is that the market is like a fellow who shows up every day, offering to buy from you or sell to you at his current price. When he's feeling down, he might offer you some great deals on solid businesses, just because he's not thinking clearly. And that's when we investors can really capitalize on his folly. So, the more volatile the market, the more opportunities we have to snag good companies at irrationally low prices.
What do you think is the main reason why companies like Coke and Gillette have a competitive advantage over other companies?

I believe it's the might of their brand names, the attributes of their products, and the strength of their distribution systems that give them an enormous competitive advantage. It's like having a protective moat around their economic castles, making it harder for others to compete with them.
Do you think the beta of a stock is a good measure of the investment risk of a company like Coke or Gillette?

No, I don't think beta is a good measure of investment risk for companies like Coke or Gillette. Just because their beta might be similar to that of run-of-the-mill companies, it doesn't mean their competitive strength doesn't reduce their risk. In fact, I think equating beta with investment risk just doesn't make sense.
Why do you and Charlie prefer to focus on easy cases rather than trying to predict the future of rapidly-evolving businesses?

Well, it's simple - why search for a needle buried in a haystack when one is sitting in plain sight? We've seen many investors and corporate managers get burned trying to predict the future of industries they don't fully understand. We'd rather stick with what we know and can reasonably predict.
You mention that some investment strategies require wide diversification. Can you give an example of when this approach might be necessary?

Sure thing. Take arbitrage, for instance. If you're making a bunch of bets where each one has a significant risk of loss, it makes sense to spread those bets out across many unrelated opportunities. That way, you can reduce your overall risk. It's like being the casino that owns a roulette wheel - you want to see lots of action because the odds are in your favor, but you don't want to let anyone make a single, huge bet that could hurt you if it goes the wrong way.
What investment strategy do you recommend for an investor who does not understand the economics of specific businesses?

I think that investor should own a large number of equities and space out their purchases, perhaps by periodically investing in an index fund. That way, they can actually out-perform most investment professionals, even if they don't know much about individual businesses.
Why do you think some investors choose to diversify their portfolio by investing in their 20th favorite company instead of putting more money into their top choices?

Honestly, I don't understand it. If you've found a few great companies with long-term competitive advantages, it makes more sense to me to put your money into those rather than spreading it out into lesser choices. As Mae West said, 'Too much of a good thing can be wonderful.'
What do you believe directors should do when a corporation has no controlling shareholder?

I believe directors should behave as if there is a single absentee owner, whose long-term interest they should try to further in all proper ways. It's a simple concept, really - they should act in the best interest of the owner, even if that owner isn't actively involved.
What can happen if directors lack integrity or the ability to think independently in such situations?

Unfortunately, they can do great violence to shareholders while still claiming to be acting in their long-term interest. It's a bit like a doctor saying they're helping a patient when they're really just lining their own pockets - it's not what you want to see, and it's not what shareholders deserve.
What should a director do if they can't get other directors to agree with their views on an issue with management?

If I'm a director and I see something I don't like but can't get the other directors on board, I think it's perfectly fine for me to make my views known to the shareholders. It's a serious step, of course, and I should expect a strong response from the other directors, but if the issue is important, I believe it's my responsibility to speak up.
How many directors do you think a board should have, and where should they come from?

I believe a board should be relatively small - ten members or less. And I think most of those members should come from outside the company. This outside perspective is crucial for establishing standards for the CEO's performance and for evaluating that performance honestly, which is something that's harder to do when the CEO is in the room.
What qualities do you believe are essential for board membership?

I think the requisites for board membership should be business savvy, interest in the job, and an owner-orientation. It's not about being prominent or adding diversity for its own sake; it's about having the right skills and mindset to make a real difference.
In situations where the controlling owner is also the manager, what options do outside directors have if they disagree with the owner/manager's actions?

Well, in those cases, the outside directors can try to make a unified argument to persuade the owner/manager to change course. If that doesn't work and the issue is serious enough, the outside directors should resign. It's a tough spot to be in, but sometimes that's the only way to make a statement and potentially bring about change.
What happens to your Berkshire stock after your death?

After I'm gone, all of my stock will go to my wonderful wife, Susie, if she survives me, or to a foundation if she passes away before I do. The good news is that neither scenario will require selling significant amounts of stock, so Berkshire's ownership structure will remain stable.
How do you think a controlling owner can impact the governance of a company like Berkshire?

I believe a controlling owner, especially one who's intelligent and self-confident, can make a huge difference. They can select outside directors who bring real value to the table, and those directors know their advice will be heard. Plus, the owner can make meritocratic decisions that benefit shareholders and correct any mistakes quickly. It's a much more efficient and effective way to run a company, in my opinion.
How will Berkshire's governance change when your stock is transferred to either your wife or the foundation?

Well, when that happens, Berkshire will enter a new governance mode. We'll have a vitally interested, but non-management, owner - that's either my wife or the foundation - and a management team that must perform for that owner. It's a bit like having a new boss, but one who's deeply invested in the company's success.
What's unique about Berkshire's approach to discretionary philanthropy compared to other publicly-held corporations?

At Berkshire, we believe that the company's money is the owners' money - just like it would be in a private business. So, we let our shareholders decide where their portion of the company's philanthropic efforts go, rather than having the CEO or directors make those decisions. It's a more personal approach, and one that reflects our commitment to treating our shareholders like owners.
What has been the growth rate of Berkshire's per-share book value over the last 30 years?
Our per-share book value has grown at a rate of 23% compounded annually over the last 30 years. That's a pretty impressive track record, if I do say so myself.
Why do you expect Berkshire's future performance to not match its past performance?

It's not that our formula for success is going to stop working - we still believe in buying good businesses at sensible prices. The problem is that our net worth has grown so much, to $11.9 billion, that it's harder to find investments that can make a significant impact. We need to deploy at least $100 million in a security to make it worth our while, which limits our options.
How do you calculate the intrinsic economic value of a college education?

Well, I think of it like this: you estimate the earnings that the graduate will receive over their lifetime, then subtract what they would have earned without the education. That gives you an excess earnings figure, which you then discount back to graduation day using an appropriate interest rate. The result is the intrinsic economic value of the education - it's like figuring out if the investment in education was worth it.
What happens when the book value of an education exceeds its intrinsic value?

That's a straightforward one: if the book value exceeds the intrinsic value, it means the person who paid for the education didn't get their money's worth. It's like buying a stock for more than its true value - you overpaid, and that's not a good investment.
What happens to the premium paid over book value for an acquisition, like the $142.6 million paid for Scott Fetzer, after it's initially recorded on Berkshire's balance sheet?

Well, that premium has to be written off over time through annual charges that show up as costs in our earnings statement. It's like gradually paying off a debt, but in this case, we're reducing the carrying value of Scott Fetzer on our books.
Do these annual charges to extinguish the acquisition premium have any effect on Berkshire's cash or taxes?

No, they don't. These charges are just an accounting exercise, a way for us to match the book value of Scott Fetzer with its actual net worth over time. They don't affect our cash or the taxes we pay, and we don't consider them an economic cost.
What is the current carrying value of Scott Fetzer on Berkshire's books, and how does it compare to its intrinsic value?

The current carrying value of Scott Fetzer on Berkshire's books is $148.2 million, which is significantly less than its intrinsic value. In fact, the intrinsic value of the business has consistently grown, and the difference between the two is now huge.
What is the key to Ralph Schey's success as a manager, according to you?

Ralph's success can be attributed to his ability to handle the basics well and stay focused on his goals. He establishes the right goals and never loses sight of what he set out to do. As Ben Graham taught me, it's not necessary to do extraordinary things to get extraordinary results - just doing the basics well can lead to great outcomes.
What qualities do you look for in a manager like Ralph, and how does his age factor into your decision-making?

I look for qualities like being forthright about problems, self-confidence without self-importance, and experience. As for age, it's irrelevant to me. At Berkshire, we focus on performance, not the calendar. Ralph, like many of our managers, is over 65, but that doesn't matter. What matters is how well he performs, and I'm glad to say he does a great job.
Can you explain why understanding intrinsic value is crucial for managers when making capital allocation decisions, including share repurchases?

Understanding intrinsic value is vital for managers because it helps them make decisions that increase per-share intrinsic value. It's not just about short-term earnings or book value. I use the example of an MBA student merging his economic interests with a day laborer to illustrate the point. If managers focus solely on short-term gains, they might make decisions that hurt shareholders in the long run. At Berkshire, we prioritize increasing intrinsic value, and that guides our capital allocation decisions.
Why do you think it's unwise for a company to focus on current earnings when considering a merger or acquisition?

Well, it's quite simple really. Focusing solely on current earnings is like looking at where the puck is right now, not where it's going to be. You have to consider the prospects, non-operating assets, and capital structure of the company you're looking to acquire. If you don't, you might end up making a deal that boosts earnings in the short term but reduces the intrinsic value per share in the long run.
What has been the result of Berkshire's approach to mergers and acquisitions, and how does it compare to the standard approach?

Our approach has been to prioritize per-share intrinsic value over short-term earnings gains. And I'm happy to say it's paid off - our shareholders are now many billions of dollars richer than they would have been if we had followed the standard catechism. We've rejected many deals that would have given us a quick earnings boost, but would have ultimately reduced shareholder wealth. It's not always the popular choice, but it's the right one.
What typically happens to the wealth of the acquirer's shareholders in most major acquisitions?
Unfortunately, it usually gets reduced, and often to a substantial extent. That's because the acquirer typically gives up more intrinsic value than it receives.
Why do CEOs with a lot of 'animal spirits' and ego tend to make acquisition decisions that may not be in the best interest of their shareholders?

Well, it's quite simple really - those traits don't just disappear when they reach the top. Their abundance of animal spirits and ego can lead them to make decisions like pursuing acquisitions, which might not always be the best use of capital.
How do you determine the compensation for managers like Ralph Schey at Berkshire?

I determine compensation for managers like Ralph Schey based on the results of the specific operation they're responsible for, in this case, Scott Fetzer. It just makes sense to tie their rewards directly to their performance, rather than to the overall fortunes of Berkshire. This way, they're incentivized to make good decisions that benefit their own operation, without being unfairly penalized or rewarded for things outside their control.
What happens to a manager's bonus when they employ incremental capital at good returns?

When a manager like Ralph can employ additional capital at good returns, their bonus actually increases. We charge them a high rate for the incremental capital they use, but if they can generate earnings that exceed that hurdle charge, it pays off for them - literally. Their bonus goes up, which I think is a pretty fair and logical way to do things.
How did you determine the compensation arrangement with Ralph Schey, and what was unique about this process?

I determined the compensation arrangement with Ralph Schey in about five minutes, right after we purchased Scott Fetzer, and without the help of lawyers or compensation consultants. What was unique about this process was its simplicity - we just worked out a few straightforward ideas that made sense to both Ralph and me, and that arrangement has never been changed.
What is your view on compensation arrangements that reward managers in ways unrelated to their personal accomplishments?

I believe such arrangements are wasteful to the company and cause the manager to lose focus on what should be their real areas of concern. They can be likened to a free lottery ticket - who wouldn't want one? But in the end, they encourage irrational behavior and can lead to imitative behavior at subsidiaries, which is not beneficial to anyone involved.
How do you determine the cost of float in your insurance business?

I determine the cost of float by our underwriting loss or profit. In years when we've had an underwriting profit, like the last two, our cost of float has been negative. It's pretty straightforward: if we're making money on our underwriting, it means our float is essentially free, or even better than free.
What happens to the value of an insurance business if its cost of float is higher than market rates for money?

If the cost of float is higher than what we could borrow for in the market, then the business has a negative value. Think of it like paying more for a loan than you need to - it's just not a good deal. In our case, though, Berkshire's insurance business has been a big winner, and we've managed to keep our cost of float low, which has helped us come out on top.
What makes the super-cat business potentially volatile, and how does its performance in 1994 relate to its overall attractiveness?

The super-cat business can be volatile because truly major catastrophes occur infrequently, leading to large profits in most years but huge losses occasionally. The performance in 1994, with its relatively small losses from the California earthquake, should be regarded as close to a best-case scenario. This means we had a good year, but we can't expect every year to be like that.
What advantages does Berkshire have in the super-cat business, and how do these contribute to its success?

Berkshire has two major advantages in the super-cat business. First, we have Ajit Jain, whose underwriting skills are the finest. His ability to make sound judgments is invaluable to us. Second, our towering financial strength gives us an edge. It assures other insurers that we can cover them in the event of a mega-catastrophe, which is essential for them. This strength, combined with Ajit's expertise, makes us a reliable and attractive partner in the super-cat business.
What makes our insurance business so valuable, despite its volatile results?

Our insurance business has intrinsic value that far exceeds its book value, and that's what makes it a gem. Think of it like a great baseball team - the players may have off days, but the team's overall strength and potential for winning championships remain strong. In our case, the insurance operation's fundamentals are rock-solid, even if the results can be a bit of a rollercoaster.
What kind of businesses do you look for when making common stock investments?

We like businesses with enduring competitive advantages, run by able and owner-oriented people. It's like looking for a great restaurant - you want one with a secret sauce that keeps customers coming back, and owners who care about serving up the best experience possible. We believe these kinds of businesses can create long-term value, and that's what we're after.
What kind of businesses do you like to invest in and why?

I like to invest in businesses with enduring competitive advantages that are run by able and owner-oriented people. It's like finding a great athlete - if you've got someone who's talented, dedicated, and has a strong work ethic, you can bet they'll perform well over time. And when we can buy into these businesses at sensible prices, it's hard to go wrong.
How do you approach the timing of your investments, and do you consider short-term market fluctuations?

We try to price, rather than time, our purchases. In other words, we focus on whether the price is right, not whether the timing is perfect. We don't let short-term worries about the economy or the stock market scare us off from buying into an outstanding business with a predictable long-term future. Why scrap an informed decision because of an uninformed guess about what the market might do next?
What was the price of Cap Cities stock when you sold 10 million shares in 1993 and what was the price at the end of 1994?

I sold those 10 million shares of Cap Cities at $63 in 1993, and by the end of 1994, the price had risen to $85.25. That's a difference of $22.25 per share, which adds up to $222.5 million in missed opportunity.
What was the outcome of your $358 million purchase of USAir preferred stock?

That purchase turned out to be a big mistake. The dividend on that preferred stock was suspended in September 1994, making it a fully ripened error, and one that I consider the worst of 1994 - bad enough to earn the gold medal in my 'Mistake Du Jour' awards.
Why did you write down the USAir investment to $89.5 million at the end of 1994?

We wrote down the USAir investment to $89.5 million because that's what we believed it was worth at the time, reflecting both the possibility that its value could be restored and the possibility that it could become worthless. It's like valuing a house - you have to consider both the best and worst-case scenarios.
Will the writedown of $269 million affect Berkshire's net worth?

No, it won't. The decline in value had already been reflected in our net worth, so the writedown is more of an accounting formality at this point. Think of it like recognizing a loss you've already taken - it's not going to change your overall financial situation, but you need to acknowledge it for accounting purposes.
What two advantages do you believe will help improve the figures in both columns over time?

I believe we have two significant advantages that will help us improve those figures. First, our operating managers are truly outstanding and have a strong loyalty to Berkshire, which is a huge plus. Second, Charlie and I have a lot of experience in allocating capital, and we try to do it in a rational and objective way.
Do you have a specific plan or roadmap for achieving growth in the company's operating earnings and investment income?

No, we don't have a master plan or roadmap for achieving that growth. We knew what we hoped to accomplish back in 1965, but we didn't know what specific opportunities would make it possible. And to be honest, we still don't have a detailed plan - we just proceed with our strengths and try to make rational decisions about allocating capital.
What are the two advantages you believe Berkshire has, according to your experience?

We have two key advantages: first, our operating managers are outstanding and have a strong attachment to Berkshire, and second, Charlie and I have considerable experience in allocating capital in a rational and objective manner.
Why do you and Charlie Munger remain skeptical of most acquisitions, despite making a few yourselves?

We believe most deals do damage to the shareholders of the acquiring company, largely because sellers and their representatives often present overly rosy financial projections that are more entertaining than accurate - as the saying goes, 'skim milk masquerades as cream.'
Why do you and Charlie Munger not consider projections prepared by sellers when evaluating potential acquisitions?

To be honest, I just don't think they're reliable. It's like the story of the man with the ailing horse - when things are going well, that's when the seller wants to make a deal. We've found it's better to use our own judgment and consider multiple opportunities, rather than relying on potentially rosy projections.
What unique approach do you think gives Berkshire an advantage when evaluating potential acquisitions?

I think our lack of a strategic plan is actually a big plus. It means we don't feel pressured to make a deal just to fit into some predetermined plan. Instead, we can take a step back and compare any potential acquisition to other opportunities, like buying stocks in great companies. It's a more disciplined approach, and it helps us make smarter decisions that benefit our owners.
What kind of business owners do you prefer to deal with when it comes to acquisitions?

I like dealing with owners who genuinely care about what happens to their companies and people. You see, when someone has a personal stake and emotional investment in their business, they're more likely to be transparent and honest about its condition, which reduces the risk of unpleasant surprises down the line.
What is your company's appetite for buying companies, and what kind of companies are you interested in?

We have a healthy appetite for buying companies with good economics and excellent management. If a business is earning $25 million or more before tax and meets our criteria, we're interested. And I mean it when I say our appetite isn't going away - we're always on the lookout for great companies to add to our portfolio.
What philosophy did Bill use to build R.C. Willey into a successful company?
Bill employed Mae West's philosophy: 'It's not what you've got - it's what you do with what you've got.' I think that sums up his approach to business pretty well.
Why do you think retailing is a particularly tough business?

I believe retailing is tough because you have to stay smart every day. Your competitors are always trying to one-up you, and shoppers have countless options to choose from. As I see it, to coast is to fail in retailing - you've got to keep innovating and adapting to stay ahead.
How do you determine the ideal number of people reporting to you?

Well, I've always believed that if I have someone reporting to me who isn't pulling their weight, that's one too many. But if I have talented managers like Bill and Sheldon, the number can be almost unlimited. It's all about the quality of the people, not the quantity.
What sparked your interest in GEICO, and how did you first learn about the company?

My interest in GEICO started with my hero, Ben Graham. I was studying under him at Columbia University's business school, and when I looked him up in Who's Who in America, I found out he was the Chairman of Government Employees Insurance Company, which was GEICO. I then dug deeper by reading about the company in Best's Fire and Casualty insurance manual, and eventually, I even took a train to Washington, DC to visit their headquarters in 1951.
What lesson did you learn from selling your GEICO position in 1952?

I learned a valuable lesson about not selling a stake in a wonderful company. Selling my GEICO position in 1952, only to see it grow in value to about $1.3 million over the next 20 years, taught me the importance of holding onto great investments for the long haul.
Why did Berkshire purchase a large interest in GEICO in 1976?

I believed in Jack Byrne, who came in as CEO in 1976, and in GEICO's fundamental competitive strength. The company had made some serious errors, but with Jack at the helm, I thought it had a bright future, so Berkshire purchased a large interest in the company during the second half of 1976.
What qualities do you look for in a manager, using Tony Nicely as an example?

When it comes to managers like Tony Nicely, I look for a combination of brains, energy, integrity, and focus. Tony has all of these qualities in spades, which is why I'm so confident in his ability to manage GEICO's insurance operation. He's been with the company for 34 years, and I think that kind of experience and dedication is invaluable.
What is the key to GEICO's success, according to you?

The ultimate key to GEICO's success is its rock-bottom operating costs. This is what gives the company a significant competitive advantage - virtually no competitor can match these costs. It's like having a economic castle protected by a wide, unbreachable moat.
What do you mean by 'economic castles protected by unbreachable moats' in the context of GEICO's performance in 1995?

Well, think of a business like a castle - it's a valuable asset that you want to protect. The 'moat' is what keeps others from crossing over and taking it. In GEICO's case, their ability to reduce underwriting and loss adjustment expenses is like widening that moat, making it harder for competitors to catch up. It's a competitive advantage that helps them maintain their edge.
How does the concept of 'float' work in your insurance business, and what are the key factors that determine its success?

Float is simply money that doesn't belong to us, but we get to hold onto it for a while. In insurance, it's the prepaid premiums we receive before we have to pay out claims. The two key things that matter are how much float we generate, and how much it costs us to hold it. The more float we have, and the less it costs us, the better our insurance business performs. It's like having an interest-free loan - as long as we can invest that float wisely, it's a big advantage for us.
How does float benefit a business, according to your experience?

Float benefits a business wonderfully if it's obtained at a low cost. In our case, the float from our insurance operations actually throws off profits, which means it costs us nothing. It's like having someone else's money in your pocket, and that's a pretty nice feeling.
What impact did you expect the acquisition of GEICO to have on Berkshire's float?

We expected the acquisition of GEICO to immediately increase our float by nearly $3 billion, with additional growth almost certain. That's a significant boost, and we're hopeful that GEICO will operate at a decent underwriting profit in most years, which would increase the probability that our total float will cost us nothing.
What types of insurance transactions did Berkshire undertake last year, according to your description?

Last year, we insured some pretty interesting things - the life of Mike Tyson, Lloyd's against a large number of its 'names' dying, and the launch and orbit of two Chinese satellites. It's a diverse set of risks, to say the least.
What advantages does Berkshire have in the insurance business that sets it apart from competitors?

We've got three main advantages: our unmatched financial strength, which means we can pay out even in tough times; our speed in supplying quotes, which is faster than anyone else; and our willingness to issue policies with larger limits than others are comfortable with. This combination makes us pretty unique in the industry.
What happened to Berkshire when we wrote business at inadequate rates in the early 1970s?

Well, let me tell you, it was a costly lesson. We received significant bills stemming from the mistakes of that era, and I'm guessing we'll still be getting surprises from that business 20 years from now. It was a heavy tuition for my education in the business, that's for sure.
What is the importance of aligning the interests of people who write insurance business with those who put up the capital?

When that kind of symmetry is missing, insurers almost invariably run into trouble. It's crucial that the interests are aligned on both the upside and the downside, or else you're likely to end up with problems, even if they don't surface right away.
What was the outcome of your prediction that the convertible securities would return your money plus dividends?

Well, I'd say that prediction didn't quite pan out as I'd hoped. In fact, I've said that's one I'd like to have back. My assertion that it was almost impossible for us to lose money on our preferreds has caused me some well-deserved heartburn.
How did the performance of the convertible securities compare to your initial expectations of moderately exceeding medium-term fixed-income returns?

We actually beat our initial expectation, but only because of the performance of a single issue. Overall, I'd say the returns were not as impressive as we'd anticipated, and certainly not as strong as what we can achieve when we invest in a business with wonderful economic prospects.
Why do you expect most shareholders to stick with the Class A stock instead of converting to Class B?

I expect most shareholders to stick with the Class A stock because it comes with full voting rights and access to Berkshire's contributions program, making it superior to the Class B shares. It's like choosing between a full-service restaurant and a fast-food joint - if you have the option, you'd likely prefer the one with all the extras.
Do you think the current price of Berkshire stock is a good value for buyers?

Honestly, no. As I said, Charlie and I wouldn't consider buying it at the current price of $36,000. We don't think it's undervalued, so the offering of Class B shares won't change the intrinsic value of our existing stock.
What happened to the book value of Berkshire when you acquired the remaining 49% of GEICO in 1995?

Well, let me tell you - when we acquired that remaining 49% of GEICO, our book value actually took a hit. Accounting rules required us to write down the value of our original 51% stake, which resulted in a $478.4 million writedown. That's right, our book value decreased, even though the economic value of our GEICO ownership increased significantly.
You mentioned that the change in book value doesn't fully reflect Berkshire's economic progress. What do you consider a better indicator of the company's performance?

That's an easy one - Charlie Munger and I have always said that intrinsic value, not book value, is what really counts at Berkshire. Book value can be a useful rough guide, but it's intrinsic value that gives you a true sense of our economic progress. And that's what we focus on around here.
What is the main focus for Berkshire, as repeatedly emphasized by you and Charlie Munger?

It's intrinsic value, not book value. Think of it like a house - the book value might be what you paid for it, but the intrinsic value is what it's really worth today, considering all the factors that affect its value.
Where can shareholders find more information about estimating Berkshire's intrinsic value?

We've made it easy for you - just refer to the Owner's Manual, specifically pages 64 and 65 for a definition of intrinsic value, and check out the table we provided which lists two key indices of value. It's all there to help you get a better understanding of Berkshire's worth.
What are the two main factors that you believe will affect Berkshire's future growth rates?

I think our past rates of growth are unsustainable simply because our equity capital is now so large - we're talking about one of the ten largest in America. That kind of size tends to dampen returns. And second, the path forward won't be smooth: securities markets will impact our investment earnings, and our catastrophe-reinsurance business will see wide swings in profitability.
How do the two columns in the table you provided relate to Berkshire's overall performance?

The two columns essentially show what Berkshire would look like if it were broken into two parts. One column is our operating earnings, excluding any investment income, and the other is our investment earnings per share. Our goal is to keep both numbers moving forward at a good pace, though we know that won't always be easy or consistent.
How do you think the benefits of Berkshire's performance should be distributed among shareholders?

I believe that the benefits should be distributed fairly, without some shareholders receiving outsized benefits at the expense of others. It's like a partnership - when partners enter or exit, their interests should be valued equitably. In a public company, that means market price and intrinsic value should be in sync as much as possible.
What kind of shareholders do you hope to attract to Berkshire?

We hope to attract owners with long-term horizons. The longer a shareholder holds their shares, the more their financial experience will be tied to Berkshire's business results, and the less it will matter what price they bought or sold at. We think this approach has served us well - Berkshire probably ranks number one among large American corporations in the percentage of its shares held by owners with a long-term view.
What is the age of Al, the founder of FlightSafety, and how will his age be treated when he turns 100?
Al is currently 79 years old, and I've jokingly told him that when he hits 100, we'll split his age 2-for-1 - though I must note, we don't actually believe in splitting Berkshire stock.
What seems to be the hiring practice at Berkshire regarding the age of managers, and what's the reasoning behind it?

At Berkshire, we seem to favor hiring managers who are a bit older - many of our managers are past 70. The reason is simple: it's difficult to teach new tricks to old dogs, but our experienced managers have already proven themselves and continue to perform exceptionally well, hitting home runs at the same pace they did when they were younger.
How do you determine the cost of float in Berkshire's insurance business?

I determine the cost of float by looking at our underwriting loss or profit. When we have an underwriting profit, our cost of float is negative - in effect, we're being paid to hold money. It's a pretty sweet deal, if you ask me.
What happens to the cost of float when Berkshire's insurance business has an underwriting profit?

When we have an underwriting profit, our cost of float is less than zero. Think of it like being paid interest on a loan, but instead of lending money, we're essentially being paid to hold onto the float. It's a great position to be in, and it's one of the reasons our insurance business has been such a huge winner for Berkshire.
What is the nature of Berkshire's super-cat business, and how often can we expect it to show large profits?

Our super-cat business involves selling policies to insurance and reinsurance companies to protect them from mega-catastrophes. Given that truly major catastrophes are rare, we can expect this business to show large profits in most years, but it will inevitably record a huge loss occasionally. It's a bit like playing a game where you win small most of the time, but every now and then, you might lose big.
How should Berkshire shareholders react if the company reports a significant loss due to a large catastrophe in the super-cat business?

If that happens, I wouldn't want our shareholders to panic and sell their Berkshire stock. A truly terrible year in the super-cat business isn't a possibility, it's a certainty - the only question is when it will come. Selling fine businesses on 'scary' news is usually a bad decision. As Robert Woodruff, the business genius behind Coca-Cola, once said when asked about selling Coke stock, 'I don't know. I've never sold any.' That's the kind of long-term thinking I encourage our shareholders to have.
What kind of product does Berkshire's super-cat operation sell to its customers, and what is the goal of this product?

Our super-cat operation sells a product that shifts major earnings volatility from our customers' books to ours. Essentially, we're selling them a way to reduce their exposure to big swings in earnings. We think of it as a form of insurance - they pay us a price, and in return, we take on the risk of those earnings swings.
How much could Berkshire potentially lose in a 'worst-case' mega-catastrophe scenario, and what percentage of the company's book and market value would that represent?

In a true mega-catastrophe scenario, our after-tax 'worst-case' loss is probably no more than $600 million. To put that into perspective, that's less than 3% of our book value and about 1.5% of our market value. So, while it's a significant amount, it's manageable for us.
What is the estimated worst-case loss for Berkshire from a mega-catastrophe, and how does it compare to the company's book and market value?

Our worst-case loss from a true mega-catastrophe is probably no more than $600 million. To put that into perspective, it's less than 3% of our book value and 1.5% of our market value. That's a risk we're comfortable with, considering the potential rewards.
Why does Berkshire choose not to 'lay off' part of the risks it insures, and what benefit does this provide to its clients?

We never 'lay off' part of the risks we insure because, frankly, we're not sure we could collect from others when disaster strikes. By keeping all the risk on our own account, our clients know with certainty that they can collect promptly from us, even in the most adverse circumstances. That's a promise we can keep, and it gives them peace of mind.
How do you approach potential risks and catastrophes at Berkshire, and what steps do you take to mitigate them?

Well, I like to think of it as 'reverse engineering' our future. We try to anticipate potential problems and avoid them altogether. As Charlie Munger says, 'All I want to know is where I'm going to die so I'll never go there.' It's about being prepared and not taking on risks that we can't handle. For example, we don't borrow big amounts and we make sure our super-cat business losses won't put a major dent in Berkshire's intrinsic value.
What are your thoughts on GEICO's performance since Berkshire gained total ownership, and what role has Tony Nicely played in its success?

GEICO has exceeded our high expectations, both in terms of business and personal relationships. Tony Nicely, the operating chief, is a superb business manager and a delight to work with. Under his leadership, GEICO is reaching performance levels that would have been thought impossible just a few years ago. I think it's safe to say that GEICO is an exceptionally valuable asset, and with Tony at the helm, it's only going to continue to thrive.
What is the main reason behind GEICO's competitive strength?

It's quite simple really - our position as a low-cost operator. This allows us to offer low prices, which in turn attract and retain good policyholders. It's a virtuous circle that has worked very well for us.
What was the growth rate of GEICO's voluntary auto policy count in 1996?

In 1996, our voluntary auto policy count grew by 10%, which is a significant milestone for us. In fact, it's the highest growth rate we've achieved in the last 20 years, surpassing our previous best of 8%.
How does Berkshire's profit-sharing plan at GEICO work, and what were the results in 1996?

Our profit-sharing plan at GEICO is straightforward: every quarter, all 9,000 associates can see the results that determine our contribution. In 1996, the plan did incredibly well, with a record contribution of 16.9% - that's $40 million. To put it simply, we had to enlarge the chart we'd constructed at the start of the year because the results were literally off the chart.
How do you tie compensation to performance for investment managers like Lou Simpson at GEICO?

For investment managers like Lou Simpson, we tie compensation to investment performance over a four-year period. This makes sense to me because it allows us to reward great investment work without worrying about the ups and downs of underwriting results or the overall performance of GEICO. It's like baseball - if you bat .350, you should get paid well, regardless of how the rest of the team does.
How much in income taxes did Berkshire have to mail to the U.S. Treasury, and what's the significance of this amount?

We had to mail $860 million in income taxes to the U.S. Treasury. To put that into perspective, if only 2,000 other taxpayers had paid an equal amount, the government would have had a balanced budget in 1996 without needing any taxes from other Americans. It's a significant contribution, and Charlie and I believe it's fitting given how much Berkshire prospers in America.
Why does Berkshire present its earnings in a way that differs from generally-accepted accounting principles (GAAP)?

We present our earnings without assigning purchase-accounting adjustments to specific businesses, instead showing them separately. We think this gives a clearer picture of how our businesses would have performed if we hadn't purchased them. It's a more useful way for investors and managers to look at things, even if it doesn't follow GAAP.
Why do you favor businesses and industries unlikely to experience major change?

I favor those businesses because we're searching for operations that are virtually certain to possess enormous competitive strength ten or twenty years from now. A fast-changing industry environment may offer huge wins, but it doesn't give us the certainty we're looking for.
What's your view on selling off portions of successful investments just because they dominate a portfolio?

I think that's a bad idea. It's like suggesting the Bulls trade Michael Jordan just because he's become so important to the team. If an investment is doing well and has strong competitive strength, there's no reason to sell it off just for the sake of diversification.
How do you and Charlie Munger view change as citizens versus as investors?

As citizens, Charlie and I welcome change - it's what drives our country's standard of living to rise. However, as investors, we're a bit more cautious. We applaud the endeavor, but we prefer to skip the ride, much like space exploration. We like to see change, but from a safe distance, especially when it comes to our investments.
What qualities do you look for in a business that make it a desirable investment, using Coca-Cola as an example?

When it comes to investing, I look for businesses with predictable fundamentals. Take Coca-Cola, for instance. While Roberto Goizueta and his team have done a fantastic job of innovating and improving the company, the underlying qualities that make Coke dominant and economically stunning have remained constant over the years. That's what I look for - a business with a strong foundation that's unlikely to change much over time.
What were Coca-Cola's sales like in 1896, and how have they grown since then?

In 1896, Coca-Cola reported sales of $148,000, with syrup sales of 116,492 gallons. Fast forward to 1996, and those syrup sales had skyrocketed to about 3.2 billion gallons. That's what I call stunning growth!
What kind of sales strategy did Coca-Cola employ back in 1896, according to Asa Candler's report?

Well, I love this part - according to Asa Candler, they employed ten traveling salesmen, backed up by systematic correspondence from the office, to cover almost the entire territory of the Union. That's my kind of sales force, simple yet effective!
What happens to investors when a company loses focus, as seen in the cases of Coke and Gillette in the past?

Well, their suffering is often prolonged. It's like taking a wrong turn on a road trip - you might not notice it right away, but eventually, you'll realize you're lost and it's going to take a while to get back on track. Loss of focus can lead to stagnating value, and that's what worries Charlie and me when we think about investing in businesses that otherwise look great.
What advice do you have for individual investors who want to construct their own portfolio instead of using an index fund?

I'd say intelligent investing is not complex, but it's not easy either. You don't need to be an expert on every company, just the ones within your circle of competence. Knowing the boundaries of that circle is key. It's like being a specialist in a particular field - you don't need to know everything, just what's relevant to your area of expertise.
What approach has produced gains for Berkshire shareholders over the years?

It's quite simple really - we've put together a portfolio of companies whose aggregate earnings have consistently marched upward over the years. As a result, our look-through earnings have grown at a good clip, and our stock price has risen correspondingly.
What was the outcome of your investment in USAir, and what lesson did you learn from it?

Well, let's just say I learned a valuable lesson from Richard Branson's joke about becoming a millionaire by starting as a billionaire and then buying an airline. My investment in USAir didn't exactly work out as planned. I was wrong in my analysis, overlooking the fact that the company's cost structure was a relic of a bygone era, and it couldn't compete in an unregulated market. It was a costly mistake, but one that taught me to dig deeper and not be swayed by superficial factors.
What was the main reason you overlooked the potential issues with USAir's business when you initially invested?

I was too focused on the company's history of profitable operations and the perceived protection of owning a senior security. It was a superficial analysis that didn't account for the changing market conditions and the company's outdated cost structure.
How did USAir's financial performance unfold after your investment, and what actions did you take in response?

After we invested, USAir's costs and revenues became increasingly imbalanced, leading to significant losses - $2.4 billion from 1990 to 1994. We initially received our preferred dividends, but they were suspended in 1994. I eventually wrote down our investment by 75% and even tried to sell our shares at 50% of face value, but fortunately, I was unsuccessful.
What commission rate did you arrange for the B shares offering, and how does it compare to typical rates?

We set the commission rate for the B shares offering at 1.5%, which is the lowest payoff we've ever seen in a common stock underwriting. This was a deliberate move to discourage brokers from pushing the issue too aggressively, as they usually do with new offerings where the commissions are higher.
How did the trading volume of the B shares immediately following the offering compare to the norm for new issues?

The trading volume of the B shares right after the offering was significantly lower than what you'd typically see with a new issue. This was a good sign for us, as it indicated that our efforts to attract long-term investors were successful, and there wasn't as much 'flipping' going on as we'd feared.
What was the gain in net worth for Berkshire Hathaway during 1997?
Our gain in net worth during 1997 was $8.0 billion, which is a pretty significant number if I do say so myself.
How does our performance in 1997 compare to the S&P Index?

To be honest, we didn't exactly cover ourselves in glory compared to the S&P Index. Those passive investors who simply put their money in the Index did almost as well as we did, which doesn't exactly make me want to quack with pride.
How does Berkshire's tax liability affect its performance compared to the S&P Index?

Our tax liability is a significant drag on our performance. Last year, we paid or accrued $4.2 billion in federal income tax, which is about 18% of our beginning net worth. This means we have to work harder to justify our existence and overcome that handicap in order to maintain a modest advantage over the Index.
What is the relationship between gains in book value and gains in per-share intrinsic business value at Berkshire?

Gains in book value and per-share intrinsic business value tend to move roughly in tandem. In 1997, for example, our intrinsic value grew at nearly the same pace as book value, thanks in part to a strong performance at GEICO. However, it's worth noting that intrinsic value is what truly counts, and that's a measure that far exceeds book value.
Why did you and Charlie decide to invest in silver, and what was your expectation for its price?

We invested in silver because we believed a higher price would be needed to balance supply and demand. Our calculation didn't consider inflation expectations, just the fundamentals of the market. We thought the price needed to rise to equilibrium, and that's why we made our move.
What kind of return do the long-term zero-coupon U.S. Treasury obligations provide, and what happens to their market price when interest rates change?

These zeros don't pay interest, but instead, you get a return through the discount at which you buy them. If interest rates rise, you can lose big, but if they fall, you can make some outsized gains. It's a bit like a seesaw - when rates go down, the value of these securities goes up, and that's what happened in 1997, resulting in a nice unrealized gain for us.
Should a net saver, like myself, hope for a higher or lower stock market during the next five years?

I think it's pretty straightforward: as a net saver, you should prefer a lower stock market. It's like wanting to buy hamburgers - you want the price to be low when you're buying, not high. A lower stock market means you can buy more 'hamburgers' for your money, which is a great deal if you're planning to be a net buyer of stocks for years to come.
How does Berkshire's practice of retaining all earnings benefit its shareholders?

Well, it's simple: when Berkshire retains its earnings, it's essentially saving on behalf of our shareholders. We then use those savings to buy businesses and securities, and the cheaper we can make those buys, the more profitable it will be for our owners. So, in a way, our shareholders are automatically saving and investing, even if they spend every dime they personally earn.
How does Berkshire's approach to retaining earnings and purchasing businesses benefit its owners?

Well, you see, when Berkshire retains all earnings and uses them to buy businesses and securities, it's essentially saving on behalf of our owners. The more cheaply we make these purchases, the more profitable it is for them in the long run. It's like having a savings program that works even if they spend every dime they personally earn.
Why should Berkshire's shareholders rejoice when market prices decline?

That's an easy one. When markets decline, it allows us and the companies we invest in to buy back shares at lower prices, increasing our ownership stake. It's like getting more bang for your buck. And with about 97% of our shareholders holding onto their shares year after year, they should be happy to see prices drop because it means we can make more advantageous investments. So, the next time you see a headline about the market falling, just remember: disinvestors might lose, but investors like us gain.
What is 'float' in the context of an insurance operation, and how does it work?

Float is money we hold but don't own. In our insurance business, it's the premiums we receive before we pay out losses, which can sometimes take years. During that time, we get to invest that money, which is a nice bonus. However, the premiums we take in often don't cover the losses and expenses we eventually have to pay, leaving us with an underwriting loss - that's the cost of float.
How do you currently view the state of investment opportunities for Berkshire, and what part of your business is exciting to you?

To be honest, we've found few new opportunities that really get us excited in recent years. We've been looking for ways to sensibly deploy our capital, but it may take some time to find something that really sparks our interest. On the other hand, our insurance business, particularly GEICO, is doing fantastically well and we expect that to continue.
What is the expected trend of Berkshire's float over the long term?
We expect our float to grow substantially over the long term, despite a decline in the first quarter of 1998 due to the expiration of several large contracts.
How do you view the potential risks and rewards of Berkshire's involvement in the super-cat insurance business?

Our super-cat business can be expected to show large profits in most years, but it's also certain to record a huge loss occasionally when a major catastrophe strikes. I view it as a volatile but attractive business, where our financial strength gives us a unique advantage.
What happened with our super-cat operation last year?

We were very lucky - the world didn't suffer any huge catastrophes, so almost all the premiums we received ended up as profit. It was a pleasant result, but as I always say, you have to be careful what you wish for.
Can you explain how these 'catastrophe bonds' work and what's misleading about them?

Well, they're not really bonds at all - they're more like contracts that might pay out if something bad happens. The name is a bit of an Orwellian misnomer, if you ask me. And the problem is, people who don't know much about insurance might think they're less risky than they actually are, just because they're called 'bonds'. It's a bit like calling a tiger a kitten - it doesn't change what it is.
What is the probability of throwing a 12 with a pair of dice, and how does this relate to the example of the bond-buyer?

The probability of throwing a 12 with a pair of dice is 1 out of 36. In the example, if you're the bond-buyer, you'd pay $50 million if a 12 appears, and you'd collect an annual premium of $1 million for taking on that risk. It's a bad bet, but you might think you're making easy money for a long time - there's a 75.4% chance you'd go a decade without paying out a dime. However, eventually, the odds would catch up with you, and you'd go broke.
How do experts influence the perception of risk in catastrophe bonds, and what's the consequence of their involvement?

Experts can be found who will downplay the risk, making the odds seem more favorable than they really are. In the dice example, an expert might claim the chance of rolling a 12 is 1 in 100, not 1 in 36. They don't have any skin in the game, but they get paid upfront regardless of how accurate their predictions are. Their involvement can lead to investors taking on more risk than they should, and it's contributed to the deterioration of super-cat prices.
What factors determine the profit-sharing contribution and cash bonuses at GEICO?

It's quite simple, really. Two key variables set the amount: policy growth and the profitability of our seasoned business. These are the metrics that determine both the profit-sharing contribution for our associates and the cash bonuses for our top executives.
How does GEICO's compensation structure differ from what you might see elsewhere, and what's the reasoning behind this approach?

At GEICO, and across all of Berkshire's subsidiaries, we don't tie compensation to our stock price. Instead, we link bonuses directly to each unit's business performance. This approach makes sense because our associates can't influence the stock price in any meaningful way, but they can certainly impact their unit's performance. We believe in rewarding people based on what they can control, not on market whims.
How do the earnings of Berkshire's subsidiaries, like Buffalo News or Scott Fetzer, compare to their publicly-owned peers?

At first glance, their performance might seem unexceptional compared to their publicly-owned peers. But here's the thing: most public companies retain a significant portion of their earnings to fund their own growth, whereas our subsidiaries pay out 100% of their earnings to us, their parent company. So, when you compare their records, you have to remember that the public companies' records get a boost from the earnings they've retained over time, while our subsidiaries' records don't get that same benefit.
What kind of financial information can shareholders find in the additional pages of the report, and how is it presented?

We've got additional information about our various businesses on pages 36-50, where you'll also find our segment earnings reported on a GAAP basis. And if you flip to pages 55-61, you'll see that we've rearranged Berkshire's financial data into four segments on a non-GAAP basis. This is how Charlie and I think about the company, and we're presenting it this way to give you the same insight we'd want if our positions were reversed.
What was the condition of the company when the new managers took over, and how did they improve it?

When the new managers took over, they inherited a real mess - a jumble of different franchising agreements and some unwise financing arrangements that had the company teetering on the edge. But they got to work, rationalized the operation, and extended food service to many more locations, ultimately building a strong organization. It's a great example of how good management can turn things around.
Why do you prefer to use cash rather than Berkshire stock in acquisitions?

Well, I've learned from experience that using our stock in mergers hasn't always worked out in favor of our shareholders. If you look at our track record, you'll see that in deals where we used only Berkshire stock, our shareholders ended up slightly worse off than if we hadn't done the deal at all. That's why I prefer to use cash - it's a cleaner, more straightforward way to do business.
Why do you prefer to pay cash for acquisitions rather than trading shares?

I prefer to pay cash because our roster is filled with high-performing businesses, what I call .380 hitters. Trading shares would mean giving up some of these excellent performers, which doesn't make sense for us. By paying cash, we can add new businesses without sacrificing the strong ones we already have.
Under what conditions will you consider offering a premium to acquire a public company?

We'll consider offering a premium if one of two conditions is met: either our own stock is overvalued relative to the acquiree's, or we expect the combined companies to earn more than they would separately. It's a high bar, but that's what it takes to make a deal worthwhile for Berkshire.
What conditions must be present for Berkshire to offer a premium when merging with a public company?

When we're considering merging with a public company, two conditions must be met for us to offer a premium. Either our own stock must be overvalued relative to the company we're looking to acquire, or we must expect that the combined companies will earn more than they would if they were operating separately. It's pretty straightforward, like having two clear doors to choose from.
How does Berkshire handle the compensation costs of an acquired company that has been issuing stock options as part of its compensation package?

When we acquire a company that's been granting stock options, we switch to a cash compensation plan that has the same economic value as the old option plan. This way, the true cost of compensation gets properly accounted for and charged against earnings. We believe in bringing all costs out into the open, so to speak, rather than leaving them hidden in the accounting fine print.
What has happened to the 'margin of safety' in investing due to current price levels?

The current price levels have materially eroded the 'margin of safety' that Ben Graham identified as crucial for intelligent investing. Think of it like a moat around a castle - it's the protection that gives you comfort when things don't go exactly as planned. With today's prices, that moat has gotten a lot smaller.
What qualities did Roberto Goizueta, the former CEO of Coca-Cola, exhibit in his leadership that you found impressive?

Roberto had a brilliant and clear strategic vision, always focused on advancing the well-being of Coke shareholders. He knew where he was going, how to get there, and why it made sense. But what really stood out to me was his sense of urgency - he wasn't just planning for the future, he was driven to get there as quickly as possible. And I must say, I appreciate his sense of humor too, as evidenced by his preference for the term 'focus' over 'obsession'!
When did you first meet Charlie Munger and what was the context of your meeting?

I first met Charlie Munger in 1959 when he was 35 years old. At the time, I was managing a small investing partnership, and we met in Omaha, where Charlie was born and raised, although he had spent most of his life living elsewhere.
What advice did Charlie Munger give you regarding Berkshire Hathaway, and did you follow his advice?

Charlie advised me to add wonderful businesses to Berkshire at fair prices, rather than buying fair businesses at wonderful prices. He essentially told me to abandon the strategies I learned from Ben Graham, which worked well at a small scale but not for a company like Berkshire. I must admit, I didn't follow his advice immediately and had some backsliding, but over time, I did come to follow his guidance, and it turned out to be incredibly beneficial for Berkshire and our investors.
What role did Charlie Munger play in the development of Berkshire Hathaway?
Charlie was the 'architect' of the present Berkshire, responsible for the overall vision, while I acted as the 'general contractor', handling the day-to-day construction of that vision.
How did Charlie Munger handle situations when you made mistakes in your decision-making?
Even when I blundered, Charlie never reminded me of my mistake. He gave me the reins and let me learn from my errors without rubbing them in my face.
Who do you envision as the target audience when writing your annual letter to Berkshire shareholders?

I picture investors who trust Berkshire with their savings for the long haul, not those looking to make a quick buck or flip their shares. They're like people saving to buy a farm, not buying lottery tickets. And, personally, I think of my sister Bertie - she's smart, wise, and keeps me on my toes.
What kind of relationship do you have with your sister Bertie, who serves as a mental model for your target audience?

Bertie and I have a great relationship - she's smart, wise, and always challenges my thinking, which I appreciate. We've never had a disagreement that's come close to ruining our relationship; she's the perfect sounding board, really.
What is Bertie's level of expertise in accounting and economics?

Bertie understands many accounting terms, but she's not ready for a CPA exam. She follows business news but doesn't consider herself an economic expert. She's sensible and knows her limits, which is more than I can say for some of the so-called experts out there.
What kind of information can be found in Berkshire's official annual report, and where does it start?

Our official annual report starts on page K-1 and goes on for 124 pages. It's got a vast amount of information - some important, some trivial. I reckon it's like looking for a needle in a haystack, but if you're interested, it's all there.
What are the reported 'Net earnings (loss)' for the years 2021, 2022, and 2023 according to the text?
The reported 'Net earnings (loss)' are $90 billion for 2021, a loss of $23 billion for 2022, and $96 billion for 2023. These numbers can be found on page K-72.
Why does Berkshire report 'operating earnings' in addition to the standard 'net income' figure?

At Berkshire, we believe that 'earnings' should be a sensible and useful concept for evaluating a business. The standard 'net income' figure doesn't quite cut it for us, so we also report 'operating earnings' to give a more meaningful picture - it's a starting point, not the final word, in understanding our business performance.
What is the primary difference between the mandated earnings figures and the 'operating earnings' that Berkshire prefers to report?
The primary difference is that we exclude unrealized capital gains or losses from our operating earnings. These gains or losses can be quite significant, sometimes exceeding $5 billion a day.
How do you view the significance of capital gains in relation to Berkshire's value accretion in the future?

I expect capital gains to be a very important component of Berkshire's value accretion during the decades ahead. That's why we've committed huge amounts of money to marketable equities, just as I have with my own funds throughout my investing lifetime.
How do you prioritize the interests of different stakeholders, such as employees, communities, suppliers, and shareholders?

Well, I believe in treating our employees, communities, and suppliers well - who wouldn't want to do that? But at the end of the day, our allegiance is to our country and our shareholders. We never forget that their money is on the line, and it's our job to protect it.
What kind of opportunities can Berkshire capitalize on during market seizures or panics?

During those times, we can respond quickly with large sums of money and a high degree of certainty. This allows us to take advantage of mispriced stocks and bonds of good businesses, which can be a real opportunity for us.
What is the main goal behind Berkshire's extreme fiscal conservatism?

Our main goal is to avoid inflicting permanent financial damage on our owners, like Bertie, who have trusted us with their savings. We want Berkshire to be built to last, and that means being cautious and prepared for any situation.
What characteristics do you look for in companies like Coca-Cola and American Express that make them attractive long-term investments for Berkshire?

We look for companies with timeless products and services that can withstand the test of time. In the case of Coca-Cola and American Express, their products 'traveled' well and became recognizable worldwide, and their core businesses have been hugely successful over the years. We also prefer companies with a long history, like American Express starting in 1850 and Coca-Cola in 1886 - we're not big on newcomers!
Why do you think AMEX and Coke have been successful investments for Berkshire, and what lesson can be learned from their performance?

I believe AMEX and Coke have been successful because their products are timeless essentials that 'travel' well worldwide. The lesson here is simple: when you find a truly wonderful business, stick with it. Patience pays, and one wonderful business can offset many mediocre decisions.
What is your approach to stock repurchases, and how do they benefit Berkshire's shareholders?

My approach to stock repurchases is that they should be price-dependent. It makes sense to repurchase shares at a discount to business value, but it's stupid to do so at a premium. These repurchases increase shareholders' participation in every asset Berkshire owns, including great businesses like Coke and AMEX.
What percentage of Occidental Petroleum's common shares does Berkshire own?
We own 27.8% of Occidental Petroleum's common shares. It's a significant stake, but as I mentioned, it's not huge relative to our resources.
Why does Berkshire like its investment in Occidental Petroleum?

We like Occidental's vast oil and gas holdings in the United States, as well as its leadership in carbon-capture initiatives. Both of these activities are in our country's interest, and we think they have a lot of potential.
How much did Berkshire gain from the weakened yen, and over what period was this gain recognized in income?
Our gain from the weakened yen was $1.9 billion, and this sum was recognized in income over the 2020-23 period, as required by GAAP rules.
What benefits do you see in partnering with the five Japanese companies, and what comfort do their CEOs derive from Berkshire's investment?

I see a significant benefit in potentially partnering with these five large, well-managed companies around the world. As for their CEOs, they can take comfort in knowing that Berkshire has huge liquid resources that can be instantly available for such partnerships, no matter the size.
How do you think climate change will impact Berkshire's investments in the utility industry, particularly in vulnerable western states?

Well, I think it's clear that climate change is going to make our investments in the utility industry more challenging, especially in western states where forest fires are becoming more frequent and intense. It's like trying to predict the weather - we can make our best estimates, but we won't know the full extent of the losses for years to come. That's why we're taking a cautious approach and won't throw good money after bad.
What might happen to certain utilities if they can't attract the savings of American citizens due to the financial risks associated with climate change?

If certain utilities can't attract the savings of American citizens, they might be forced to adopt the public-power model. It's not a new concept - Nebraska made this choice back in the 1930s, and there are many public-power operations throughout the country. It's a possible outcome, and one that we're watching closely as we consider our own investments in the utility industry.
What lesson have you learned from your experience in the property-casualty insurance business?

I've learned that our underwriters can't be optimists at the office. It's a quality that's great in life, but in the P/C business, surprises are almost always negative, and you need people who are cautious and prepared for the worst.
How do you view the future of the utility industry, particularly in terms of attracting American citizens' savings?

To be honest, I think the future of the utility industry may be ominous. Certain utilities might not attract the savings of American citizens and could be forced to adopt the public-power model. It's ultimately up to voters, taxpayers, and users to decide which model they prefer.
Why does Berkshire release important communications on Saturday mornings?

We release important communications on Saturday mornings to give our shareholders and the media a couple of days to digest the news before the markets open on Monday. It's like giving everyone a head start on the week, allowing them to think things over before any trading begins.
What criteria do you use to select the stocks that Berkshire owns?

When it comes to selecting stocks, Charlie and I look for businesses with durable economic advantages and a first-class CEO. We're not in it for short-term market moves; we invest based on our expectations about a company's long-term business performance. It's about finding companies that have a strong foundation for success and leaders who know how to build on that foundation.
What is your primary goal when investing in businesses?

My goal, and Charlie's too, is to have meaningful investments in businesses with both durable economic advantages and a first-class CEO. We're looking for businesses that have strong fundamentals and great leadership.
How do you view the companies that Berkshire owns, and what's the significance of the $158 billion in domestic infrastructure assets on our balance sheet?

I view the companies we own as businesses, not just stocks. And regarding our infrastructure assets, I think it's surprising to many that Berkshire owns and operates more U.S.-based infrastructure assets than any other American corporation, with those assets valued at $158 billion on our balance sheet. It's not something we set out to achieve, but it's a fact nonetheless.
What was the state of Berkshire's net worth in the nine years following the merger with Hathaway?

Well, it's not a pretty picture. Berkshire's net worth cratered from $51.4 million to $22.1 million in those nine years. It was a tough time for the company, and the shareholders certainly felt the pain.
How did Berkshire's income tax payments to the U.S. Treasury change after the company changed its management and strategy in 1965?

It's a night-and-day difference. Before the change, we were paying a pathetic $100 per day in income tax. But after we got our act together and started reinvesting our earnings into good businesses, our tax payments soared. Today, Berkshire pays roughly $9 million daily to the Treasury. That's a pretty stunning turnaround, if I do say so myself.
How has Berkshire's daily payment to the Treasury changed over time?
Well, it's gone from $100 daily to roughly $9 million daily, which is a staggering increase. I think it's a testament to the growth and success of Berkshire over the years.
What has been the overall profit from Berkshire's underwriting activities that generated its float?

We've earned a modest profit over 55 years from our underwriting activities, and I'm pleased to say that our float has cost us less than nothing. It's been a key factor in our success, and I'm grateful we've been able to put it to good use.
How did you initially assess Ajit Jain's qualifications for the insurance role at Berkshire, and what was the outcome of that hiring decision?

I'll never forget that Saturday morning when I first met Ajit. I asked him about his insurance experience, and he told me he had none. My response was, 'Nobody's perfect,' and I hired him on the spot. It turned out to be one of the luckiest decisions I've ever made. Ajit has been an incredible asset to Berkshire, and his contributions to our insurance business have been immense.
