What is your expectation regarding Berkshire's ability to maintain its float without incurring long-term underwriting losses?

While I believe it's likely that we can maintain our float without incurring long-term underwriting losses, I'm far from certain about it. In fact, I'm sure we'll have some years where we experience significant losses. But that's just the nature of the insurance business, and Berkshire is built to handle those kinds of catastrophic events.
What is the current valuation of Berkshire's investment in Occidental Petroleum, and what does it consist of?

Our investment in Occidental Petroleum is currently valued at $10.7 billion, and it consists of preferred stock and warrants to buy common stock. Think of it like having a special ticket that not only gets you a preferred seat but also gives you the option to buy another ticket at a later time if you choose to.
Why does Berkshire aim to hold more than $30 billion of cash and equivalents, and what portion of the U.S. national debt does our current holding in U.S. Treasury bills finance?

Charlie and I want Berkshire to be financially impregnable, so we've pledged to always hold more than $30 billion in cash and equivalents. This way, we're never dependent on others for help. As for our U.S. Treasury bills, currently valued at $120 billion, it's interesting to note that this amount finances about half of one percent of the publicly-held national debt. It's a significant amount, but still just a drop in the bucket, or as I like to say, a small slice of a very large pie.
Why do you think it's important for Berkshire to have a significant amount of cash on hand, even if it means not being fully invested in businesses?

I like to think of our cash stash as a fortress wall, protecting us from any unexpected storms. It lets me and Charlie sleep soundly, knowing we can meet our obligations without relying on others. Plus, it gives us the flexibility to pounce on opportunities when they arise.
You mentioned that you've always kept at least 80% of your net worth in equities. What drives your preference for business ownership and investing in stocks?

Well, I've just always believed in the power of American business and the potential for long-term growth. I mean, look at that Dow Jones number from back in 1942 - 99! It's a reminder that, over time, the market tends to go up. And I've seen it firsthand, starting with those three shares of Cities Services preferred stock I bought when I was just a kid. Business ownership, to me, is like planting a tree: you nurture it, and with patience, it can grow into something truly remarkable.
What are the three ways you aim to increase the value of your investors' investments?

We've got three paths to increase the value of your investment. First, we focus on growing the earning power of our controlled businesses, either through internal growth or acquisitions. Second, we look to buy into other great publicly traded businesses. And third, when the price is right, we repurchase Berkshire shares to increase your stake in our businesses.
Why do low long-term interest rates make it harder for you to find attractive investment opportunities?

Low long-term interest rates are like a rising tide that lifts all boats - they push up the prices of all kinds of productive investments, whether it's stocks, real estate, or whatever. That makes it tougher for us to find investments that excite us, because everything starts to look a bit pricey.
How do repurchases affect the 'float' per share in Berkshire's insurance business?

Well, as it turns out, repurchases automatically increase the amount of 'float' per share. It's like having a bigger pie to work with - the slices get larger. In our case, the 'float' per share has increased by 25% over the past two years, going from $79,387 to $99,497 per 'A' share. That's a meaningful gain, if I do say so myself.
What was the initial investment Paul Andrews used to found Tex-Tronics, later renamed TTI?

Paul Andrews, a wonderful man with a great story, founded Tex-Tronics with just $500 of his savings. That's right, $500. It's a terrific example of betting on oneself and making it pay off. Today, TTI is a huge success, marketing over a million different items with annual sales of $7.7 billion. Not bad for a $500 start-up, eh?
What advice do you give to university students when it comes to finding a job?

I tell them to seek employment in a field they love and with people they would want to work with, even if they didn't need the money. It's not always easy, given economic realities, but I believe it's worth the search. When you find that kind of job, it doesn't feel like 'work' anymore.
What was your first job, and how did it compare to what you do now?

My first job was working part-time at my grandfather's grocery store, starting in 1942. Let's just say it wasn't exactly what I had in mind - boring tasks and not much pay. But, after a few stumbles, Charlie and I eventually found our way to Berkshire, where we've been able to do what we love, with people we like and trust. It's a whole different story now.
What kind of people do you think Berkshire's individual holders are, based on your experience?

I believe our individual holders are largely the 'once-a-saver, always-a-saver' type. They live well but tend to dispense most of their funds to philanthropic organizations, rather than leaving them to their families or using them to build dynasties.
How do you and Charlie Munger allocate the savings of Berkshire's shareholders?

Charlie and I allocate your savings between two related forms of ownership: investing in businesses we control, usually by buying 100% of each, and directing capital allocation at these subsidiaries while selecting the CEOs who make day-to-day operating decisions.
What is your approach to managing subsidiaries within Berkshire, and how do you view mistakes made by these businesses?

At Berkshire, we direct capital allocation and select the CEOs who make day-to-day decisions for our subsidiaries. We emphasize trust to a high degree, understanding that business mistakes are inevitable. However, our tolerance for personal misconduct is zero. We're willing to give our managers room to make business errors, but we expect them to act with integrity.
How do you distinguish between your approach to investing in businesses and what might be considered traditional stock-picking?

Charlie and I are business-pickers, not stock-pickers. We invest in businesses based on their long-term economic characteristics and the trustworthiness of their managers, not with the intention of making quick buys and sells. Our goal is to own pieces of businesses that have favorable economics over the long haul, whether through direct ownership or through publicly-traded stocks.
You mention that most of your capital-allocation decisions have been no better than so-so. Can you elaborate on what you mean by 'so-so' in this context?

Well, by 'so-so', I mean that they weren't particularly outstanding or disastrous. They were just average, not really contributing much to our overall success. It's only been about a dozen truly good decisions over 58 years that have really made a significant difference for Berkshire.
You also mention 'creative destruction' as a phenomenon in capitalism. Can you explain what you mean by this term?

Creative destruction is a concept coined by Schumpeter. It refers to the fact that capitalism is a system where businesses and products are constantly being replaced by new, improved ones. It's a process where the old, inefficient, or unwanted are destroyed, making way for the new and innovative. It's a natural part of the capitalist cycle, and it's what drives progress and improvement in goods and services.
What was the total cost of Berkshire's purchase of 400 million shares of Coca-Cola in 1994 and what were the cash dividends received from Coke in 1994 and 2022?

The total cost of our Coca-Cola purchase was $1.3 billion. As for the dividends, in 1994, we received $75 million from Coke, and by 2022, that had grown to $704 million. It's been a steady climb, just like getting older - it happens every year!
How do the current values of the Coca-Cola and American Express investments compare to their original purchase prices, and what percentage of Berkshire's net worth do they represent?

Our Coke investment is now valued at $25 billion, and Amex at $22 billion, which is a significant increase from the $1.3 billion we paid for each. Today, each of these holdings accounts for about 5% of Berkshire's net worth, which is roughly the same weighting they had long ago. Not bad for just cashing dividend checks over the years!
What lesson do you believe investors can learn from how Berkshire's investments have performed over time?

The lesson for investors is that it takes just a few winners to work wonders over time. As I like to put it, 'The weeds wither away in significance as the flowers bloom.' In other words, even if you have some investments that don't perform well, the ones that do can make up for them and then some.
Why do you and Charlie focus on operating earnings rather than GAAP earnings?

We focus on operating earnings because the GAAP figure can be misleading, especially when viewed quarterly or annually. It fluctuates wildly due to capital gains or losses from equity holdings, which can be unpredictable. By looking at operating earnings, we get a clearer picture of the company's performance, and I think that's what investors should focus on too.
Why do you think GAAP earnings can be misleading when viewed quarterly or annually?

I think GAAP earnings can be misleading because they include capital gains, which can fluctuate wildly from quarter to quarter. It's like trying to judge a baseball player's performance based on a single at-bat - it just doesn't give you the full picture. Our capital gains have been important to Berkshire's success, but their quarter-by-quarter swings don't accurately reflect our overall performance.
What is the significance of the 'float' in Berkshire's insurance business, and how has it grown over time?

The float is essentially the money that our insurance subsidiaries hold to pay future claims. It's like having a large pool of money that we can invest, and if we're disciplined in our underwriting, it can be cost-free over time. Since we purchased our first property-casualty insurer in 1967, our float has grown an astonishing 8,000-fold. It's an extraordinary asset for Berkshire, and I encourage new shareholders to read our explanation of float on page A-2 to understand its value.
What is the effect of share repurchases on the intrinsic value of Berkshire's shares?

When we repurchase shares at value-accretive prices, it increases your interest in our businesses. Think of it like a pie - if the number of slices decreases, but the pie itself remains the same size, each slice you own gets a bit bigger. In 2022, our repurchases increased your stake in Berkshire by 1.2%, which is a small but meaningful gain.
Who benefits from value-accretive share repurchases?

All owners benefit from value-accretive repurchases. It's not just the selling shareholders who gain, but all continuing shareholders as well. To illustrate, imagine a local auto dealership with three owners - when one owner sells back their shares at a good price, the other two owners' stakes in the business increase, and no one is harmed in the process.
What is your view on companies manipulating numbers to beat expectations?
I think it's disgusting. It requires no talent at all, just a desire to deceive. As one CEO once put it to me, it's 'bold imaginative accounting,' and it's a shame of capitalism.
How did Berkshire's journey begin, and what factors contributed to its growth?

Berkshire's journey began when we shifted our resources from the textile operation to insurance and other non-textile operations after acquiring National Indemnity in 1967. Our growth can be attributed to a combination of continuous savings by our owners, the power of compounding, avoiding major mistakes, and what I call the 'American Tailwind' - the overall growth and prosperity of the US economy.
How much did Berkshire contribute to the Treasury via corporate income tax over the decade, and what percentage of total revenue collected does that represent?

Berkshire contributed $32 billion to the Treasury via corporate income tax over the decade, which is almost exactly a tenth of 1% of all the money the Treasury collected. To put it simply, if about 1,000 taxpayers matched our payments, no other businesses or households would have needed to pay federal taxes.
You used an analogy with stacks of $100 bills to help understand the scale of these large numbers. How high would a stack of $1 billion in $100 bills reach?

Well, if you were to convert $1 billion into newly-printed $100 bills and stack them up, it would reach about 3/4 of a mile into the sky. It's a pretty staggering visual, and it helps put these enormous figures into perspective.
Why do you believe it's essential for Berkshire to pay its fair share of taxes?

I believe we owe it to the country because America's dynamism has significantly contributed to Berkshire's success. It's only fair that we give back, and I think of it as a necessary investment in the country that has helped us thrive.
What advice would Charlie Munger give to someone who wants to be a successful investor?

Charlie would say that the world is full of foolish gamblers, and to do well, you need to be a patient investor. He'd also advise you to see the world as it is, without any distorted views, and to behave rationally to achieve good results.
What's your approach to investing in the stock market, and how do you view its behavior over time?

I don't focus on the short-term fluctuations, the 'froth' of the market. Instead, my partner and I seek out good long-term investments and hold them for a long time. As Ben Graham said, the stock market is like a voting machine in the short term, but in the long term, it's a weighing machine - if you keep making something more valuable, wise investors will notice and start buying.
You mention that patience can be learned. How does having patience impact your investment strategy?

Having a long attention span and the ability to concentrate on one thing for a long time is a huge advantage. It allows me to stubbornly hold good investments for a long time, even when the market is volatile. This approach has served me well, as I believe that a great company will keep working and creating value long after I'm involved.
What advice do you give for finding a good business partner?

I say find a very smart, high-grade partner - preferably someone slightly older than you - and then listen very carefully to what they have to say. It's worked out pretty well for me with Charlie, that's for sure.
How many sales did See's make during the two-day shareholder event?
See's rang up a total of 6,621 sales - 2,690 on Friday and 3,931 on Saturday. And let me tell you, that's a lot of peanut brittle and chocolates! It added up to $400,309 in volume over the two days.
What was the outcome for Berkshire's operating earnings last year?
Our operating earnings actually fell by 9% last year, which wasn't what we were hoping for.
How do you and Charlie Munger view Berkshire's holdings of marketable stocks?
Charlie and I view those holdings as a collection of businesses. We may not control their operations, but we share in their long-term prosperity, and that's how we think about it.
What is your approach to owning businesses within Berkshire, and what factors do you consider when making investment decisions?

My approach, which I've developed with Charlie's influence, is to own all or part of a diverse group of businesses with good economic characteristics and good managers. Whether we control these businesses or not is unimportant to us. We consider a company's durable competitive strengths, the capabilities and character of its management, and price when deciding where to deploy capital.
You mention that owning a non-controlling portion of a wonderful business can be more profitable and enjoyable. Can you elaborate on why you believe this to be the case?

Well, I've learned from experience, including my 20-year struggle with the textile operation I inherited at Berkshire, that owning 100% of a marginal enterprise is a lot of work and not very rewarding. On the other hand, owning a part of a wonderful business, even if it's not a controlling stake, can be much more profitable and enjoyable, with less hassle. As I like to say, in business, you don't get points for 'degree of difficulty,' so why take on more work than you need to?
What is unique about Berkshire's family of insurers and its manager, Ajit Jain?

Our family of insurers is unique in the insurance field, and so is its manager, Ajit Jain. He's been with us since 1986, and together, we've built an insurance operation that operates with far more capital than any of its competitors worldwide.
How does Berkshire's insurance operation invest its funds differently from its competitors?

Our insurance companies can safely follow an equity-heavy investment strategy, which isn't feasible for most insurers due to regulatory and credit-rating reasons. They have to focus on bonds, but our financial strength and huge cash flow from non-insurance businesses give us the freedom to invest differently.
What happens to Berkshire shareholders as Apple repurchases its shares?

As Apple repurchases its shares, Berkshire shareholders will indirectly own a larger portion of Apple over time. It's a slow process, but the math of repurchases can be powerful, allowing our shareholders to own an ever-expanding portion of exceptional businesses like Apple.
Why is the Kraft Heinz holding not included in the list of common stock investments?

We exclude Kraft Heinz from the list because Berkshire is part of a control group, which means we have to account for that investment using the 'equity' method. It's a bit like being part of a team - we have a different role and different accounting rules apply.
What was the initial investment in Occidental Petroleum and what is it valued at now?
Our initial investment in Occidental Petroleum was $10 billion, consisting of preferred stock and warrants to buy common stock. Currently, that combination is valued at $9 billion.
How has Berkshire's approach been to managing See's Candy since its purchase in 1972?

Well, our approach to managing See's Candy has been pretty straightforward - we don't mess with it. The customer is the boss when it comes to non-essential consumer products, and after 100 years, it's clear that our job is to let See's continue doing what it does best without interference from us.
How did 'Big Jim' Haslam start what became Pilot Travel Centers?
He started it by purchasing a service station for $6,000 back in 1958. Not a bad investment, if I do say so myself!
What role did Kevin Clayton play in the sale of a portion of Pilot to Berkshire?
Kevin encouraged the Haslams to sell a large portion of Pilot to Berkshire. I guess you could say he was a bit of a matchmaker in that deal.
What is your view on America's economic progress and its potential for the future?
I believe America's economic progress has been breathtaking, despite some interruptions. And I'm optimistic about its future - as I always say, 'Never bet against America.'
What responsibilities do Berkshire's directors have, and to whom do they owe their loyalty?

Our directors have a responsibility to act in the best interest of the corporation and its stockholders. They must faithfully represent the long-term interests of Berkshire and its owners, while also considering the interests of our customers, associates, lenders, and the communities we operate in.
How did you get compensated as the general partner of Buffett Partnership Ltd.?

I was compensated by my limited partners only after they secured returns above an annual threshold of 6%. If returns failed to meet that level, the shortfall was to be carried forward against my share of future profits. Fortunately, that never happened, and partnership returns always exceeded the 6% threshold.
What kind of investors did you and Charlie Munger have in your partnerships?

Neither of us had any institutional investors, and very few of our partners were financially sophisticated. They were mostly individuals who trusted us to treat their money as we treated our own, including family members and friends who invested based on that trust.
What was the outcome for your partners when you dissolved your partnership in 1969?

When I dissolved my partnership in 1969, the outcome for my partners was that they received a distribution of all the cash, along with three stocks, including our 70.5% interest in Berkshire. It was a pro-rata distribution, so everyone got their fair share.
What was the main reason you and Charlie laid out Berkshire's 'major business principles' in the 1983 annual report?

Charlie and I wanted to make sure everyone - old, new, and prospective shareholders - was on the same page. We believed it was essential to clearly define our relationship and approach, which we summed up with the principle 'Although our form is corporate, our attitude is partnership.'
What is the nature of the relationship between index funds and Berkshire shares?

Index funds own Berkshire shares simply because they have to, as part of mimicking the S&P 500 index. They're on automatic pilot, buying and selling only to maintain the right weighting. It's not like they're actively choosing to invest in us because they love our prospects or valuation.
How do you view the role of professional managers who actively manage their clients' money?

I think being a professional manager is an honorable, though tough, job. They have to make judgment calls on where to put their clients' money, trying to find the best investments. We're happy to have them as part of our investor base, and we're working for them as they try to find the best places to put their clients' funds.
What are the different types of shareholders you have at Berkshire, and how do they approach their investments?

We've got a few different buckets of shareholders. First, there are the active institutional managers who are always on the lookout for better opportunities to deploy their clients' funds. Then, we've got individual shareholders who operate similarly, thinking of their Berkshire shares as a potential source of funds for other exciting investments. And lastly, we've got our long-term individual investors who trust us to represent their interests, no matter what the future holds. They're in it for the long haul, just like our original partners.
Can you tell us about any notable long-term individual investors who have been with Berkshire for a long time?

One great example is Stan Truhlsen, an Omaha ophthalmologist and personal friend of mine. Stan turned 100 in 2020 and has been with me since 1959, when he and 10 other young Omaha doctors formed a partnership with me. He's a terrific example of the kind of long-term investor we feel a special kinship with.
What was the name of the venture formed by Stan Truhlsen and the other Omaha doctors in 1959?
The docs creatively labeled their venture Emdee, Ltd. I've got to say, I've always liked the simplicity of that name.
Why is Berkshire reluctant to court Wall Street analysts and institutional investors?

We already have the investors we want, and to be honest, we don't think replacing them with new ones would be an upgrade. It's like having a great group of friends - you don't go looking to trade them in for new ones just for the sake of change.
What advice did Phil Fisher give in his 1958 book about running a public company?

Phil Fisher's advice was to be consistent in your message to potential customers, just like a restaurant should consistently serve the type of cuisine it advertises. You can't switch between serving hamburgers and French cuisine, or you'll confuse your customers and ultimately lose them.
According to you, what will happen to a patient and level-headed investor, even one who constructs a portfolio randomly, over time?

Well, I like to use the example of a monkey throwing darts at a board. As long as that patient and level-headed monkey, or investor, doesn't get tempted to make changes in its original selections, it will enjoy dividends and capital gains over time. It's a 'positive-sum' game, after all.
What is Berkshire's depreciated cost of domestic fixed assets and how does it compare to AT&T's?

Our depreciated cost of domestic fixed assets is $154 billion, which puts us ahead of AT&T, who has $127 billion in property, plant and equipment. That's a significant lead, but as I always say, size isn't everything - it's what you do with it that counts.
How have the earnings of BNSF and BHE changed over time, and what can we expect in terms of future capital expenditures?

I'm pleased to report that the combined earnings of BNSF and BHE have grown from $4.2 billion in 2011 to $8.3 billion in 2020. That's a remarkable increase, especially considering 2020 was a tough year for many businesses. As for future capital expenditures, both BNSF and BHE will require significant investments for decades to come, but we're confident they'll deliver appropriate returns on that investment.
What was the main challenge in investing in western transmission lines for wind and solar generation, according to your assessment in 2006?

The main challenge was the huge investment required, which very few companies or governmental entities were in a financial position to undertake. It was a costly project that needed billions of dollars invested before we could see any meaningful revenue, and it involved navigating complex rules, contracts, and interests across different states and jurisdictions.
What gave you the confidence to proceed with the western transmission project despite the anticipated challenges and delays?

It was our trust in America's political, economic, and judicial systems, combined with BHE's strong managerial talent, institutional commitment, and financial capabilities. We were confident that we had the wherewithal to fulfill our promises and see the project through to completion, despite the complexities and uncertainties involved.
What do you advise shareholders to focus on when evaluating Berkshire's performance?

I advise shareholders to focus on operating earnings, which gives a clearer picture of our performance. Quarterly and annual gains or losses from investments can be quite volatile, so Charlie and I recommend ignoring those and concentrating on the operating earnings instead.
What was the outcome of Edgar Lawrence Smith's research for his book Common Stocks as Long Term Investments?

Well, Edgar Lawrence Smith's research actually led him to a surprising conclusion. He initially thought he'd find that stocks perform better than bonds during inflation and worse during deflation, but the facts didn't support that theory. Instead, his studies showed him that his preconceived notions were wrong, and that led him to think more deeply about how stocks should be evaluated.
What was the key insight from Smith's book that changed how investors thought about stocks?

Well, I think the key insight from Smith's book was that well-managed industrial companies retain a part of their profits and put them back into the business, which creates an element of compound interest that increases the real value of the property over time. It's a pretty simple concept, but it was a game-changer for investors.
Can you give an example of successful business leaders who amassed wealth by retaining earnings and reinvesting in their businesses?

Yes, there are plenty of examples. Just think of titans like Carnegie, Rockefeller, and Ford - they all became incredibly wealthy by retaining a huge portion of their business earnings and using that money to fund growth and generate even greater profits. It's a strategy that's worked for big-time capitalists and small-time ones alike.
How do you expect the retained earnings of the companies Berkshire partially owns to impact Berkshire's value?

I believe the retained earnings of our investees will be of major importance in the growth of Berkshire's value. Logic and our past experience tell us that we'll realize capital gains at least equal to, and probably better than, the earnings they retained. It's not a precise science, but the odds are in our favor.
What advice did Tom Murphy give you about acquisitions, and how has that advice worked out for Berkshire?

Tom Murphy told me to 'just be sure you buy good businesses' if I want to achieve a reputation as a good manager. Well, I've acquired many dozens of companies over the years, and while I initially thought they were all good businesses, some proved disappointing and a few were outright disasters. So, while the advice is sound, it's not a guarantee of success – as our track record shows!
What have you learned from your experience with acquisitions at Berkshire?

Well, I've learned that acquisitions are a lot like marriage - they start out with high hopes, but reality can be quite different. Sometimes they work out wonderfully, and other times they're disappointments. I've found that it's usually the buyer who encounters unpleasant surprises, and it's easy to get caught up in the excitement of the deal and overlook potential problems.
How do the performances of your successful and unsuccessful businesses tend to diverge over time?

I've noticed that our successful businesses tend to grow and find new opportunities to invest capital at attractive rates, while our less successful ones tend to stagnate and require a smaller percentage of our capital over time. This means that the assets employed by our winners gradually become a larger portion of our total capital, which helps to mitigate the impact of our errors.
How has the proportion of Berkshire's capital employed in its original textile business changed over time?

Well, it's a great example of how our 'good' businesses can grow and take over. When we first acquired the textile company in 1965, it used up nearly all of Berkshire's capital. But as we acquired more successful businesses, the textile operation's share of our capital dwindled to almost nothing by the early 1980s. It's a dramatic shift, and I'm glad we were able to move away from that struggling business and into more profitable areas.
Which of your businesses has been the standout performer in terms of returns?

That's an easy one - our insurance business has been the superstar. It's got some unique characteristics that set it apart, but the bottom line is that it's been a real winner for us. I'm planning to dive into more details about what makes it tick in the next section, so stay tuned for that.
What has been the key factor in Berkshire's favorable situation compared to other insurers?
It's our unrivaled mountain of capital, abundance of cash, and a huge and diverse stream of non-insurance earnings that gives us far more investment flexibility than others in the industry.
How would you describe the importance of disciplined risk evaluation in Berkshire's insurance operations?
At Berkshire, disciplined risk evaluation is a religion, Old Testament style. Our insurance managers know that poor underwriting results can drown the rewards of float, so it's their daily focus.
What kind of catastrophic event do you think could potentially cause huge losses for Berkshire, and how would the company handle it?

I think a mega-catastrophe, which we refer to as 'The Big One', could come from traditional sources like wind or earthquake, or even a surprise event like a cyber attack. When it happens, Berkshire will certainly take a hit, but unlike many other insurers, we've got the resources to handle the loss without breaking a sweat. We'll be ready to get back to business the next day, eager to take on new opportunities.
How did the acquisition of GUARD Insurance Group work out for Berkshire, and what were some key factors in its success?

The GUARD acquisition has been a home run for us. Since we bought the company in 2012 for $221 million, its premium volume has grown by 379% to $1.9 billion in 2019, and it's delivered a satisfactory underwriting profit. I think a big part of its success is due to the leadership of Sy Foguel, who has done a fantastic job of expanding the company into new products and regions, and growing its float by 265%. Ajit Jain's instincts in buying GUARD were spot on, and it's a great example of how we can find hidden gems in unexpected places.
Why did you instruct your executors and trustees to hold onto your Berkshire shares instead of selling them and investing in U.S. Treasury bonds?

I did that because I believe Berkshire shares will provide a safe and rewarding investment over the long haul. I've got faith in the company and its directors to make smart decisions, and I think this approach will ultimately deliver more resources to society than playing it safe with Treasury bonds.
What makes you confident that Berkshire's directors will make good decisions and resist the influence of Wall Street?

Well, I've just got a lot of trust in the people we've got leading Berkshire. I think they've got the judgment and integrity to do what's right, even when the Wall Street types come knocking with their fees and pitches. It's not that I think they're immune to temptation, but I believe they've got the character to make the right calls.
What is the primary challenge that boards of directors face, according to your experience?

The bedrock challenge for directors is to find and retain a talented CEO with integrity who will be devoted to the company for their business lifetime. It's a tough task, but when they get it right, they don't have to do much else.
How have you seen the composition of corporate boards change over your 62 years of service as a director?

Well, let me tell you, it's been a significant change. In my early years, it was rare to see a woman in the boardroom unless she represented a family with controlling interest. Thankfully, that's changing, although we still have work to do to achieve equal representation.
How much did you used to earn as a director of Portland Gas Light in the early 1960s?
I earned $100 annually for my service as a director of Portland Gas Light back in the early 1960s. It was a princely sum, indeed, considering I had to commute to Maine four times a year for it.
What kind of director does a CEO typically look for when seeking new board members?

CEOs don't look for pit bulls, if you know what I mean. They prefer someone more like a cocker spaniel - friendly, not too challenging. If a director has a history of questioning the CEO's decisions, like compensation or acquisitions, they're unlikely to get recommended for another board position.
What is your preference when it comes to directors of the companies in your portfolio owning shares of the company's stock?

I feel better when directors have purchased shares with their own money, rather than just receiving grants. It's not that it guarantees wisdom or business smarts, but it gives me comfort to know they have a personal stake in the company's performance.
What is your general impression of the directors you've met over the years?

Almost all of the directors I've met have been decent, likable, and intelligent. They're good people, and I've enjoyed their company. However, I've found that many of them aren't necessarily the right people to handle money or business matters - it's just not their area of expertise.
How do the tax costs affect Berkshire's performance compared to the S&P 500 in different market conditions?

Well, it's quite simple really. When the S&P 500 has a positive return, our after-tax numbers would lag behind because we have to pay taxes, which reduces our gains. On the other hand, in years when the S&P 500 has a negative return, our after-tax numbers would actually look better because we wouldn't have to pay as much in taxes. Over time, though, those tax costs add up and cause us to trail the S&P 500 pretty substantially.
What was Berkshire's earnings figure for 2018, and what were the main components of that figure?

In 2018, Berkshire's earnings were $4.0 billion under GAAP. Now, if you break that down, you'll see we had $24.8 billion in operating earnings, but then we had a few other significant items - a $3.0 billion non-cash loss from an impairment of intangible assets, mainly from our stake in Kraft Heinz, $2.8 billion in realized capital gains from selling some of our investment securities, and a $20.6 billion loss due to a reduction in unrealized capital gains. That last one's a bit of a wild card, if you ask me, and Charlie Munger agrees - we don't think it's sensible to include those mark-to-market changes in our earnings.
Why do you advise investors to focus on operating earnings rather than quarterly GAAP earnings?

I advise investors to focus on operating earnings because our huge equity portfolio can experience significant one-day price fluctuations, which are then immediately reflected in our quarterly GAAP earnings. This can create wide swings in our quarterly results, making them less reliable as an indicator of our overall performance. By focusing on operating earnings, investors can get a clearer picture of how our businesses are doing.
What change have you made to the way you open your annual letter, and why?

I've stopped opening the letter with the percentage change in Berkshire's per-share book value, a practice I've followed for nearly three decades. It's simply time for a change, and I've decided to move away from that tradition.
Why are you abandoning the practice of featuring the percentage change in Berkshire's per-share book value in the initial paragraph?

I'm abandoning that practice because the metric has lost its relevance over time. You see, Berkshire has changed significantly since its early days - we've shifted from a company focused on marketable stocks to one with major value in operating businesses. And to be honest, accounting rules don't accurately reflect the value of those businesses in our book value. Plus, with our plans to repurchase shares, the book value metric will only become more disconnected from our true economic performance.
What will you focus on instead of the book-value scorecard to measure Berkshire's performance?

Going forward, we'll be focusing on Berkshire's market price. Now, I know markets can be a bit crazy at times - just look at our 54-year history for proof of that. But over the long haul, our stock price will provide the best reflection of how the business is really doing.
What changes did you make to Berkshire's management in early 2018?

In early 2018, I put Ajit Jain in charge of all insurance activities and gave Greg Abel authority over all other operations. These moves were long overdue, and I'm happy to say that Berkshire is now far better managed than when I was handling everything on my own.
Why do you suggest investors focus on the 'forest' rather than individual 'trees' when evaluating Berkshire?

I suggest focusing on the 'forest' because analyzing each of our many businesses individually can be mind-numbing. Fortunately, our operations can be grouped into five major 'groves,' each of which can be evaluated as a whole with reasonable accuracy, making it easier to estimate Berkshire's intrinsic business value.
How do you and Charlie Munger view acquisition-related amortization expenses, and how do you account for them when evaluating businesses?

Well, we don't consider acquisition-related amortization expenses to be a true economic cost. In fact, when we're evaluating both private businesses and marketable stocks, we add back those amortization 'costs' to GAAP earnings. It's like calling a dog's tail a leg - just because you call it something doesn't make it so.
What was the total value of Berkshire's equity investments at the end of the year, and what would be the tax implication if the portfolio were sold at that valuation?

Our equity investments were worth nearly $173 billion at yearend, which is far above their cost. If we were to sell the portfolio at that valuation, we'd be looking at a federal income tax bill of about $14.7 billion on the gain. That's a significant tax bite, but it's a good problem to have, considering the portfolio's value.
How much in federal income tax would Berkshire have had to pay if the equity portfolio was sold at its yearend valuation?

If we had sold our equity portfolio at its yearend valuation, we would have had to pay about $14.7 billion in federal income tax on the gain. That's a big number, but as I said, we're not planning to sell anytime soon.
What is the significance of the retained earnings of the companies in Berkshire's portfolio?

The retained earnings of our investees are incredibly valuable to us. Over time, for every dollar they've reinvested, we've seen more than a dollar in capital gains. It's like having a snowball that grows as it rolls - the earnings they retain and reinvest eventually deliver big returns to Berkshire.
How have the retained earnings of your investees benefited Berkshire over the years?

Well, I'm happy to report that for every dollar our investees have reinvested, we've eventually seen more than a dollar in capital gains. It's a pretty straightforward equation: they reinvest, we benefit from the growth, and it's been a winning formula for us.
Can you give an example of how share repurchases have increased Berkshire's ownership in a company?

American Express is a great example. Even though our holdings haven't changed in eight years, their share repurchases have increased our ownership from 12.6% to 17.9%. It's like having a bigger slice of the pie without having to buy more pie – we love it when that happens.
What is the benefit to continuing shareholders when a company repurchases its shares?

The benefit is an increase in per-share intrinsic value. Think of it like a pizza that's being divided among fewer people - each slice gets bigger. If the market is pricing our shares at, say, 90¢ on the dollar, and we repurchase shares at that price, the value of each remaining share goes up for the continuing shareholders.
What kind of information do you and Charlie try to provide to shareholders when the company contemplates repurchases?

We try to give them the information they need to make an intelligent estimate of value. We want our shareholder-partners to have all the facts so they can make informed decisions about whether to sell their shares back to the company or hold on to them. We don't want anyone to sell because they've been misled or don't have all the information they need.
Why doesn't Berkshire prepare monthly earnings reports or balance sheets like other companies?

We don't prepare those reports because Charlie and I have never focused on current-quarter results. We make decisions with the long-term in mind, for the shareholders who are staying with us, not those who are leaving. It's just not how we operate.
What kind of behavior have you seen result from the pressure to meet Wall Street's quarterly expectations?

Unfortunately, we've seen all sorts of bad behavior - accounting and operational tricks that start as small fudges but can lead to full-fledged fraud. It's a slippery slope, and once the boss starts playing with the numbers, it's easy for others to follow suit. We've made a conscious decision to avoid that kind of pressure at Berkshire.
What happened to the Treasury Department's 'ownership' in Berkshire when the corporate tax rate was reduced to 21%?

Well, I'd say the Treasury's 'ownership' took a bit of a hit. With the tax rate dropping from 35% to 21%, 40% of their 'ownership' - or 14/35ths - was essentially returned to Berkshire, free of charge. That's a significant shift, and it's had a positive impact on the value of our shares.
How did the reduced corporate tax rate affect the intrinsic value of the stocks Berkshire holds?

The reduced tax rate was a boon for the intrinsic value of almost all the stocks we hold. It's simple: when the tax rate goes down, the value of the businesses goes up. And that's exactly what happened here - the new law made our businesses and the stocks we own considerably more valuable.
What attracted you to the property/casualty insurance business, and how does the 'float' from this business benefit Berkshire?

I was attracted to the P/C business because of its unique model: we collect premiums upfront and pay claims later. This creates a 'float' of money that we get to invest for our own benefit until the claims are paid out. It's like having a large sum of money in a savings account that we can use to generate more wealth over time.
How has the 'float' from your insurance business grown over the years, and what kind of decline can you envision for it in the future?

Our float has grown significantly - from $39 million in 1970 to $122,732 million in 2018. As for a decline, I think it's unlikely to happen quickly. If it does happen, it will be very gradual, no more than 3% in any given year. The nature of our insurance contracts is such that we're not exposed to sudden, large demands on our cash resources.
What has been the result of Berkshire's disciplined risk evaluation in its insurance business over the past 16 years?

I'm pleased to say that our disciplined risk evaluation has led to an underwriting profit for 15 of the past 16 years, with a total pre-tax gain of $27 billion over that span. That's no accident - it's the result of our insurance managers' daily focus on prudent risk assessment.
Why does Berkshire use debt sparingly, despite the potential for it to increase returns for equity owners?

We use debt sparingly because, while it may juice returns most of the time, it can become financially fatal when credit vanishes. I just don't think it's a good idea to play a game of financial Russian roulette, where you usually win but occasionally die. That's not a strategy I'm comfortable with for Berkshire.
What do you and Charlie Munger view your holdings as, rather than just a collection of ticker symbols?

We view our holdings as an assembly of companies that we partly own, which are earning a significant return on the net tangible equity capital required to run their businesses. It's like owning a piece of a successful business, not just a stock certificate.
What kind of returns are the companies in your portfolio earning, according to your assessment?

On a weighted basis, these companies are earning about 20% on the net tangible equity capital required to run their businesses. I think that's remarkable, especially considering they're large, established businesses that don't rely on excessive debt to generate their profits.
What was the approximate population of the United States when it was founded, and how did it compare to the world's population at that time?
The United States started with about four million people, which was roughly 1/2 of 1% of the world's population. It's amazing to think about how far we've come since then.
If you had invested $114.75 in a no-fee S&P 500 index fund in 1942, how much would it be worth by January 31, 2019?

That's a pretty stunning figure - if I had invested that $114.75 in 1942 and reinvested all the dividends, it would have grown to be worth $606,811 by January 31, 2019. It just goes to show the power of long-term investing.
What would an investment in the 'magical metal' have delivered compared to an unmanaged investment in American business?

Well, let me tell you, it would have delivered a whopping $4,200, which is less than 1% of what you would have gotten from a simple investment in American business. That's a pretty poor showing if you ask me.
How does the growth of America's household wealth reflect the country's economic prosperity?

It's staggering, really. The Federal Reserve estimates our household wealth at $108 trillion, which is almost incomprehensible. It just goes to show that, despite all the ups and downs we've faced as a country, our economic framework has been incredibly successful in turning the ambitions of our people into reality.
What do you attribute much of Berkshire's success to?

I attribute much of Berkshire's success to what I call The American Tailwind. It's the idea that our country's overall prosperity and growth have given us a significant boost, and we're lucky to have that force at our back.
How do you think Americans will benefit if other nations thrive?
I believe Americans will be both more prosperous and safer if all nations thrive. It's a win-win situation, and that's why at Berkshire, we hope to invest significant sums across borders.
Why do you publish financial reports late on Friday or early on Saturday morning?

I do this to give our shareholders and investment professionals some breathing room to analyze the reports before the markets open on Monday. It's like giving everyone a chance to digest their dinner before rushing off to the next meal - it helps prevent indigestion, or in this case, knee-jerk reactions to the news.
What qualities do you look for when searching for new stand-alone businesses to acquire?

When we're on the hunt for new businesses to join the Berkshire family, we look for five key qualities: durable competitive strengths, able and high-grade management, good returns on the net tangible assets, opportunities for internal growth at attractive returns, and a sensible purchase price. It's like buying a house - you want a solid foundation, a good neighborhood, and a price that won't break the bank.
What was the initial investment Berkshire made in National Indemnity and its sister company in 1967?

We invested $8.6 million in early 1967 to purchase National Indemnity and a smaller sister company. It was a smart move, as it came with $6.7 million of tangible net worth that we could deploy into marketable securities.
Why do you trust Mark Donegan, CEO of Precision Castparts, to make good decisions for the company?

I trust Mark because he's an extraordinary manufacturing executive. Sometimes, betting on the right people can be more certain than betting on physical assets or businesses. Mark's expertise in manufacturing gives me confidence in the future of Precision Castparts, even if I don't fully understand the intricacies of the manufacturing operations myself.
What makes Berkshire less vulnerable to massive 'runs' in times of financial stress, according to you?

It's the nature of our property and casualty float. Unlike bank deposits or life insurance policies, it can't be withdrawn. That means we don't have to worry about a bunch of people suddenly pulling out their money at the same time, which gives us a lot of stability.
You mention that the downside of float is that it comes with risk. Can you give an example of when this risk became a significant problem for an insurance market?

The Lloyds insurance market is a great example. They had a good run for three centuries, but then some huge problems surfaced in the 1980s from certain long-tail lines of insurance. It was a big mess and threatened to destroy the whole operation. Luckily, they've since recovered, but it's a reminder that even the most predictable-looking insurance situations can turn out to be anything but.
What is your estimate of the total insured losses from the three hurricanes that hit Texas, Florida, and Puerto Rico last September?

My guess is that the insured losses from those hurricanes are around $100 billion, but I must admit that figure could be far off the mark. History has shown us that initial loss estimates often run low.
What do you believe will be Berkshire's share of losses in future American mega-catastrophes, based on your current estimates?

If our current estimates hold up, I believe our share of losses in future American mega-cats will be around 3%. That's roughly the percentage of the industry loss we're expecting from the recent hurricanes.
What percentage of the industry loss did Berkshire experience from the three hurricanes, and how does that compare to potential future losses?

Our share of the industry loss from those hurricanes was about 3%, and I believe that's a reasonable estimate for our share of losses in future American mega-cats as well. It's a relatively small percentage, but one that we're well-prepared to handle.
How does Berkshire's financial preparedness for a $400 billion mega-catastrophe compare to other companies in the industry?

No company comes close to Berkshire in being financially prepared for a $400 billion mega-cat. If such an event were to occur, our share of the loss might be around $12 billion, which is significant but still below our annual earnings from non-insurance activities. Meanwhile, many other companies in the industry would likely be out of business.
What is the key to success in the property and casualty insurance business, according to you?

It's quite simple, really. In this business, there are no trade secrets, patents, or locational advantages. What counts are brains and capital. Our managers supply the brains, and Berkshire provides the capital.
Did Berkshire's property and casualty insurance business experience underwriting profits every year prior to 2017?

Actually, we had 14 consecutive years of underwriting profits before 2017, which is a remarkable streak. And I've always said that while I expect us to be profitable most years, we will inevitably experience losses from time to time - which is exactly what happened in 2017 when we lost $3.2 billion pre-tax from underwriting.
You mentioned that Berkshire shares have suffered four major dips in the last 53 years. Can you tell me more about those dips and the percentage decrease in each case?

Yes, I'd be happy to share those details with you. We've had four significant dips: the first from March 1973 to January 1975 with a 59.1% decrease, then in 1987 with a 37.1% drop, followed by a 48.9% decrease from June 1998 to March 2000, and lastly, a 50.7% decrease from September 2008 to March 2009. These are stark reminders of the volatility of the stock market in the short term.
You quoted Ben Graham's maxim about the market being a voting machine in the short run and a weighing machine in the long run. Can you elaborate on what this means for investors like Berkshire?

Ben Graham's quote is a powerful reminder that in the short term, stock prices can be all over the place, driven by sentiment and speculation - that's the voting machine part. But over the long haul, the market starts to reflect the true value of a company, which is where the weighing machine comes in. For Berkshire, this means that even though our stock price may fluctuate wildly in the short term, our focus on building real value through retained earnings and smart investments will ultimately be reflected in our stock price over time.
Why do you advise against using borrowed money to own stocks?

I advise against using borrowed money to own stocks because it can rattle your mind when the market plunges, leading to poor decision-making. Even if your borrowings are small, scary headlines and breathless commentary can unsettle you, causing you to make mistakes. It's better to keep a clear head and avoid debt so you can take advantage of extraordinary opportunities when they arise.
What was the purpose of the ten-year bet you made on December 19, 2007?

I made the bet for two reasons: first, to leverage my initial outlay into a larger sum that would be donated to Girls Inc. of Omaha if I won; and second, to demonstrate my conviction that a low-cost S&P 500 index fund would outperform most investment professionals over time.
What were the two reasons you made the bet about the S&P 500 index fund?

I made the bet for two reasons: first, to leverage my initial outlay into a larger sum that would be donated to Girls Inc. of Omaha if I won, and second, to demonstrate my conviction that a low-cost S&P 500 index fund would outperform the picks of most investment professionals over time.
How many hedge funds were indirectly involved in the bet through Protégé Partners' selection of five 'funds-of-funds'?

Through Protégé Partners' selection of five 'funds-of-funds', more than 200 hedge funds were indirectly involved in the bet. Essentially, these funds-of-funds were a collection of investments in numerous hedge funds, each managed by its own team of experts.
What was the original intention for the $1 million prize funded by the zero-coupon U.S. Treasury bonds?
My partner Protégé and I originally intended to simply tally the annual returns and distribute the $1 million to the winning charity when the bonds matured late in 2017.
What happened to the yield of the bonds by November 2012, and how did their price change?

By November 2012, the yield of our bonds had dropped to less than 1% as they were selling for 95.7% of their face value, with about five years left to maturity. It was a pretty strange turn of events in the bond market, if you ask me.
What was the outcome of selling the bonds and buying Berkshire 'B' shares in 2012, in terms of the donation to Girls Inc. of Omaha?
The outcome was a donation of $2,222,279 to Girls Inc. of Omaha, more than double the original hoped-for amount of $1 million.
Why did you consider the bonds in 2012 to be a riskier investment than common stocks, despite being perceived as 'risk-free'?

I considered the bonds riskier because, in my view, investing is about sacrificing consumption today for more later. Those bonds, with their low returns, were less likely to achieve that goal than a long-term investment in common stocks, which have a higher potential for growth over time.
You mentioned that for investors with long-term horizons, a diversified portfolio of U.S. equities becomes progressively less risky than bonds. Can you explain why this is the case?

Well, it's quite simple really. As time goes on, the impact of inflation on bonds becomes more pronounced. Even a low annual inflation rate can significantly decrease the purchasing power of a bond over the long term. On the other hand, a diversified portfolio of U.S. equities has a better chance of keeping pace with inflation, assuming the stocks are bought at a sensible price relative to their earnings and interest rates. It's like trying to outrun a slow-moving tide - bonds might look safe in the short term, but over the long haul, they can get swept away by inflation.

You criticized the approach of measuring investment risk by the portfolio's ratio of bonds to stocks. Why do you think this is a mistake, especially for investors like pension funds and college endowments?

It's a mistake because it focuses on the wrong metric. Just because a portfolio has a high percentage of bonds doesn't mean it's safe. In fact, high-grade bonds can actually increase the risk of a portfolio if they're not keeping pace with inflation. For investors with long-term horizons, like pension funds and college endowments, the real risk is not meeting their future obligations. By focusing too much on the bond-to-stock ratio, they might be inadvertently taking on more risk than they realize. It's like trying to navigate a ship by only looking at the anchor - you need to keep an eye on the horizon, not just the present moment.
Why do you and Charlie Munger release financial data late on Fridays or early on Saturdays?

We do that so all shareholders have simultaneous access to new information and enough time to digest and analyze it before any trading takes place. It's only fair that everyone gets the same information at the same time.
What motivates Berkshire's operating managers, according to you?

I believe our managers are motivated by the joy of achieving business successes, which they call 'hitting home runs.' For many of them, the thrill of accomplishment is just as important as their paycheck, and that's what drives them to perform well.
What was the gain in Berkshire's net worth during 2016 and how did it affect the per-share book value of the stock?

In 2016, Berkshire's gain in net worth was $27.5 billion, which led to a 10.7% increase in the per-share book value of both our Class A and Class B stock. That's a pretty significant bump, if I do say so myself.
How has Berkshire's approach to valuing its assets changed over time, and what impact has this had on the relevance of balance sheet figures?

Well, in the early days, our balance sheet was largely 'marked to market' because we held a lot of marketable securities that were regularly revalued. But as we shifted towards owning businesses outright, the accounting rules changed, and our balance sheet didn't always reflect the true value of our assets. It's a bit like trying to value a marriage - you can't just put a number on it, and sometimes the surprises come after the fact.
What is your view on America's economic achievements, and how would you describe them?

I think America's economic achievements are nothing short of miraculous. The country has come a long way from its humble beginnings 240 years ago, and the sheer abundance we see today is a testament to the power of human ingenuity, a market system, and the rule of law.
How does debt affect the overall wealth of the American people, according to your perspective?

In my view, debt doesn't necessarily diminish the overall wealth of the American people. When an owner defaults on a loan, the asset itself doesn't disappear - it just changes hands. As Gertrude Stein said, 'Money is always there, but the pockets change.' So, the nation's wealth remains intact, even if the ownership of specific assets shifts from one person to another.
How does the US allocate rewards, and what role does the government play in this process?

Our market system is the primary factor in allocating rewards, but the government also plays a significant role through taxation at the federal, state, and local levels. This helps distribute a portion of our country's bounty, ensuring that those in their productive years support both the old and the young.
What is the estimated annual cost of providing public education to American babies, and how does this relate to the US GDP?

The annual cost of providing public education to American babies is over $600 billion, which is roughly 3.5% of our GDP. This is a significant societal commitment, with each baby essentially having an entitlement to about $150,000 in public education costs over their lifetime.
What should an investor remember during periods of market decline or panic?

During those scary periods, you should remember two key things: First, widespread fear is your friend because it can lead to bargain purchases. Second, personal fear is your enemy, and it's usually unwarranted. Just stick with a collection of solid, conservatively-financed American businesses and you'll likely do well in the long run.
How do you view share repurchases from the standpoint of exiting shareholders?

From the standpoint of exiting shareholders, repurchases are always a plus. It's simple: having an additional buyer in the market is always better for a seller, even if the day-to-day impact of these purchases is usually small.
Do repurchases always benefit continuing shareholders?

No, repurchases only make sense for continuing shareholders if the shares are bought at a price below intrinsic value. If the price paid is too high, it can actually hurt the value of the remaining shares. Think of it like buying out a partner in a business - if you overpay, the remaining partners lose out.
Why don't companies usually disclose a maximum price they're willing to pay for repurchases?

That's a great question, and to be honest, I find it puzzling too. When buying an outside business, price is always a key factor in the decision. But for some reason, when CEOs or boards are buying back their own company's shares, they often seem to ignore price. It's as if they'd behave differently if they were running a private company with just a few owners - they'd certainly think twice about overpaying to buy out one of them.
Under what circumstances should a company not repurchase its own shares, even if they are underpriced?

There are two occasions when repurchases shouldn't take place, even if shares are underpriced. First, if the business needs all its available money to protect or expand its operations and is uncomfortable adding debt. Second, when a business acquisition or other investment offers far greater value than the undervalued shares.
At what price are you authorized to buy back Berkshire shares?
I'm authorized to buy large amounts of Berkshire shares at 120% or less of book value, as our Board believes purchases at that level bring an instant and material benefit to continuing shareholders.
What is your stance on share repurchases and how do you think they affect shareholders?

I believe share repurchases can benefit both continuing and exiting shareholders under the right market circumstances. We'll be ready to act if such a situation arises. It's not about diverting funds from productive endeavors, as some might claim. The fact is, there's no shortage of capital for good projects.
What attracted you to the property/casualty insurance business, and how does its financial model work?

We were drawn to the P/C business because of its unique financial characteristics. Essentially, insurers collect premiums upfront and pay claims later, sometimes decades later. This creates a 'float' of money that we get to invest for our own benefit while we hold it. It's a collect-now, pay-later model that's been a key driver of our growth since 1967.
What is 'float' in the context of your insurance business, and how does it benefit your company?

Float refers to the large sums of money we hold that will eventually go to others. It's like having a big pool of money that we get to invest for our own benefit while we wait for claims to be made. As our business grows, so does our float, which means we have more money to invest and potentially earn more investment income.
Is the amount of float your company holds expected to continue growing, and are there any factors that could cause it to decline?

Yes, our float is expected to continue growing, especially with the recent huge policy we wrote that increased our float to over $100 billion. However, we do have some large run-off contracts in our reinsurance division that will cause the float to drift downward over time. If we do experience a decline, it will be very gradual, no more than 3% in any year.
How does Berkshire's financial strength impact its investing flexibility?

Our unrivaled financial strength gives us far more flexibility in investing than most P/C companies. It's like having a wide-open highway versus a narrow road - we've got many more alternatives available to us, and that's always an advantage. Occasionally, it even offers us major opportunities that others can't seize.
How do you view the concept of 'float' in relation to Berkshire's intrinsic value?

I think of float as a revolving fund, not a typical liability. We deduct the full amount of our float as a liability when calculating book value, but that doesn't capture its true value. Since we're constantly paying old claims and writing new business that generates its own claims, float is more like a costless, long-enduring resource. If we can maintain that, its true value is dramatically less than the accounting liability.
What is the current value of goodwill in Berkshire's insurance business and how has the company's float changed since 2000?

The value of goodwill in our insurance business is $15.5 billion, and it's been largely unchanged since 2000 when our float was $28 billion. However, we've since increased our float by $64 billion, which isn't reflected in our book value. It's like having a big, valuable asset that isn't showing up on the balance sheet.
How would Berkshire's overall performance be affected if the insurance industry were to experience a $250 billion loss from a mega-catastrophe?

If the insurance industry were to experience a $250 billion loss from a mega-catastrophe, Berkshire as a whole would likely still record a large profit for the year. That's because we're far more conservative in avoiding risk than most large insurers, and our operations are managed in a way that protects our resources.
How would Berkshire's overall performance be affected if the insurance industry experienced a $250 billion loss from a mega-catastrophe?

We'd likely still record a large profit for the year, thanks to our many streams of non-insurance earnings. Plus, we'd have plenty of cash on hand and be ready to write business in a market that might be in disarray.
What are the key disciplines that a sound insurance operation needs to follow, according to your experience?

There are four disciplines: understanding all exposures, conservatively assessing the likelihood and cost of losses, setting premiums that will deliver a profit, and being willing to walk away if the right premium can't be obtained. That's how we've built a successful insurance business at Berkshire.
What are the four disciplines that a sound insurance operation needs to adhere to?

A sound insurance operation needs to follow four key disciplines: understanding all exposures, conservatively assessing the likelihood and cost of losses, setting a premium that will deliver a profit, and being willing to walk away if the right premium can't be obtained. It's like a recipe for success - leave out any one ingredient, and you're likely to end up with a mess.
What initially impressed you about GEICO when you first visited the company in 1951?

My first visit to GEICO in 1951 was an eye-opener. What really impressed me was the huge cost advantage the company had over the industry giants at the time. It was clear that GEICO was doing something right, and that advantage has been a key factor in the company's success over the years.
How do you define interest coverage for companies like BNSF, and what was BNSF's interest coverage last year?

I define interest coverage as the ratio of earnings before interest and taxes to interest. Last year, BNSF's interest coverage was more than 6:1, which is a pretty comfortable cushion, if you ask me. It means they've got more than enough earnings to cover their interest payments, even in a tough year like last year was for railroads.
What factors contribute to BHE's ability to service its debt, and how has being owned by Berkshire benefited the company?

BHE's ability to service its debt is supported by two key factors: recession-resistant earnings, since people will always need the essential services utilities provide, and a diverse range of earnings streams that protect it from being too vulnerable to any one regulatory body. As for being owned by Berkshire, it's given BHE the strength to lower its cost of debt, which is a win-win for both us and BHE's customers.
How do the average retail rates of BHE in Iowa compare to other major electric utilities in the state and adjacent states?

Our average retail rate at BHE in Iowa is 7.1¢ per KWH, which is significantly lower than Alliant, the other major electric utility in the state, at 9.9¢. We're also competitive with rates in adjacent states like Nebraska, Missouri, Illinois, and Minnesota, where the rates range from 9.0¢ to 10.0¢. And let's not forget, our rate is even better than the national average of 10.3¢.
How does BNSF's revenue per ton-mile compare to other major U.S.-based railroads?

At BNSF, our revenue per ton-mile was 3¢ last year. Now, I know comparing railroads can be a bit like comparing apples and oranges due to differences in cargo mix and distances, but our 3¢ per ton-mile is lower than the 4¢ to 5¢ range of the other four major U.S.-based railroads. That's a significant difference, and it shows we're working hard to keep costs down for our customers.
Why do GAAP-prescribed depreciation charges sometimes understate true economic costs, and what industry does this particularly affect?

GAAP-prescribed depreciation charges can understate true economic costs because they're based on historical cost, not current costs. This is a big issue in the railroad industry, where the cost of replacing or maintaining assets has gone up significantly since they were originally purchased. It's like trying to maintain a classic car - the parts may not be made anymore, or they may be a lot more expensive than they used to be.
How do some managements manipulate their earnings reports, and what are two common expenses they might omit?

Some managements like to play games with their earnings reports by featuring 'adjusted earnings' that are higher than their GAAP earnings. They do this by omitting certain expenses, like 'restructuring costs' and 'stock-based compensation'. It's like trying to make a bad meal taste better by leaving out some of the ingredients - it may look appetizing at first, but it's still not a healthy serving of financial truth.
Do you ever exclude restructuring charges when reporting Berkshire's earnings?

No, we've never singled out restructuring charges and told our owners to ignore them. If there were some truly major expenses in a single year, I'd mention it, but generally, we consider these charges a normal part of our business operations.
Why do you think some CEOs and analysts exclude stock-based compensation as an expense?

I think it's misleading and cavalier. Essentially, CEOs who exclude stock-based compensation are saying, 'Don't worry about the cost of my compensation package, I'll just adjust it away.' It's not a realistic or honest way to report earnings, in my opinion.
What percentage of total compensation for top executives at most large companies is usually stock-based compensation?
At most large companies, stock-based compensation usually makes up at least 20% of the total compensation for the top three or four executives.
What do you think CEOs should be required to affirm to their owners if they want to exclude stock-based compensation from reported earnings?

I believe CEOs should be required to affirm one of two things to their owners: either explain why items of value used to pay employees are not a cost, or justify why a payroll cost should be excluded when calculating earnings.
What is the average monthly payment for Clayton's customers, and what does it include?

The average monthly payment for our customers at Clayton is $587, which includes not just the loan payment itself, but also the cost of insurance and property taxes. It's a reasonable amount, especially considering the strong desire these families have to own a home.
How does Clayton's assistance program benefit both the borrowers and the company itself?

Our experience has shown that by helping borrowers through difficulties with programs like loan extensions and payment forgiveness, we end up helping ourselves as well. Last year, for instance, we had 93% of borrowers who received help through these programs remain in their homes. This is crucial because we lose significant sums on foreclosures - $150 million last year. So, by keeping people in their homes, we're not only doing something good for our customers, but we're also reducing our own losses.
Why do you consider cash held in offshore accounts by American companies to be less valuable than cash held domestically?

Well, it's quite simple really. When cash is held offshore, it's subject to certain limitations on how it can be used, primarily because companies are hoping for a reduction in taxes to bring that cash back to the States. It's like having money in a savings account that you can't easily access - it's just not as useful as having it in your checking account, ready to go.
Do you intend to hold all of Berkshire's marketable securities forever?

No, we've made no such commitment. While it's true that I have no intention of selling some of our stocks anytime soon, we've always maintained the flexibility to adjust our portfolio as needed. I think some folks may have misinterpreted our Economic Principle 11, but let me be clear: we're not tying ourselves to any investment forever.
Do you consider all marketable securities held by Berkshire as available for sale?
Yes, I do. In fact, I've added a clarification to our Economic Principle 11 to make it clear that we regard any marketable security as available for sale, even if a sale seems unlikely at the moment.
How does the tax treatment of dividends received by Berkshire compare to the tax treatment of capital gains?

For Berkshire, the tax treatment of dividends is actually more favorable than that of capital gains. We net more from a dollar of dividends than from a dollar of capital gains, thanks to lower tax rates on dividends - for example, 10.5 cents per dollar for a non-insurance company like our parent company, and as low as 7 cents per dollar when we own more than 20% of the investee.
What is the process for participating in a bet on Longbets.org?

Well, it's pretty straightforward. A 'proposer' posts a proposition on the site, and then waits for a 'doubter' to take the other side of the bet. Once that happens, each side chooses a charity that will benefit if they win, puts up their wager, and writes a short essay defending their position. That's about it.
You mentioned a bet about pilotless planes; what's the status of your involvement in that bet?

Ha! Well, I recently got involved in that bet by taking $500 of Eric Schmidt's action. He had initially bet $1,000 against Craig Mundie's assertion that pilotless planes would be flying passengers by 2030. Now, if we lose, I'll be on the hook for $500 of the payment - assuming I'm still around in 2030, of course!
What was the core of your argument in Berkshire's 2005 annual report regarding active investment management by professionals?

I argued that, over time, the aggregate returns of active investment management by professionals would be lower than those of rank amateurs who simply invested in an unmanaged low-cost index fund, due to the high fees levied by various 'helpers'.
How many investment professionals took you up on your $500,000 wager that they couldn't select a set of hedge funds to match the performance of an unmanaged S&P-500 index fund?

Despite the thousands of professional investment managers out there, only one man, Ted Seides, stepped up to my challenge. It was a bit surprising, given how vocal they are about their abilities, that more didn't put their money where their mouth is.
What was the basic structure of the bet you made with Ted Seides, and how did the investment choices work?

The bet was simple: Ted's pick of five funds-of-funds, whose results would be averaged, versus my choice of a Vanguard S&P index fund. Ted's funds-of-funds invested in over 100 hedge funds, which helped spread the risk and gave a clearer picture of their overall performance. It was a straightforward comparison to see which approach would come out on top over ten years.
How did the fee structure work for the funds-of-funds selected by Ted Seides, and how did it compare to your investment choice?

The fee structure for Ted's funds-of-funds was a bit like a layer cake - they charged their own fees on top of the fees already charged by the hedge funds they invested in. My choice, the Vanguard S&P index fund, didn't have this extra layer of fees, making it a more straightforward and cost-effective option.
What were the results of the first nine years of your bet comparing fund-of-funds to an S&P Index Fund?
