But in 2013, the sale of new homes started to pick up, and now earnings from both manufacturing and retailing are becoming significant again. It's a great example of how a business can adapt and thrive in changing markets.
What was the outcome of your investment in EFH, and what lesson did you learn from it?

Well, let's just say it wasn't one of my brightest moments. We sold our EFH holdings for $259 million and had previously received $837 million in cash interest, but overall, we still suffered a pre-tax loss of $873 million. The lesson here is that even with a significant income stream, the underlying investment can still go sour if the fundamentals aren't sound. It's a reminder to always keep a close eye on the big picture and not get too comfortable with any one investment.
You mentioned that some of your subsidiaries use derivatives in their operations. What's your general view on derivatives, and how have they performed for your company?

Derivatives can be useful tools for our utilities and other subsidiaries to manage their operations, but as for speculative investments, we've largely steered clear of them for years. The ones we do have on the books have actually delivered large profits and provided several billion dollars of medium-term float. Of course, past performance isn't a guarantee of future results, but we're hopeful that the remaining contracts will continue to perform well.
What was the approximate yield from the farm and the New York retail property when you initially invested in them?
The unleveraged current yield from both the farm and the New York retail property was about 10%. That simplicity of analysis was part of their appeal to me.
What made you confident that the New York retail property's income would increase over time?

A couple of things gave me confidence. First, the property had been undermanaged by the Resolution Trust Corp., so there was room for improvement with better management. Additionally, we had a tenant paying very low rent, about $5 per foot, which was significantly below the average of $70 per foot for other tenants. I knew that when their lease expired in nine years, we'd be able to renegotiate for a much higher rate, which would give our earnings a nice boost.
What is the key difference between investing and speculating, according to your perspective?

To me, the key difference is focus. Investing is about focusing on what an asset will produce, whereas speculating is about focusing on the prospective price change of that asset. It's like the difference between focusing on the game itself versus constantly checking the scoreboard.
Why do you believe forming macro opinions or listening to market predictions can be dangerous for investors?

I think it's dangerous because it can blur your vision of the facts that truly matter. It's easy to get caught up in predictions and opinions, but they often don't amount to much. As I like to say, games are won by players who focus on the playing field, not by those glued to the scoreboard.
How do you think the constant valuation of stocks affects investors?

I believe it should be a huge advantage for investors in stocks to have those constant valuations, but unfortunately, many let the irrational behavior of others influence their own decisions. It's like having a neighbor who yells out a price for your farm every day - if he's being irrational, you should be able to take advantage of that, not let it dictate your actions.
What was your thought process when making investments in 1987 and 1994, regarding the economy and stock market?

To be honest, I didn't pay much attention to what the economy, interest rates, or stock market might do in the short term. I focused on the fact that certain things would remain constant - like corn growing in Nebraska and students attending NYU. Those fundamentals guided my investment decisions, not the chatter of pundits or headlines.
How do you think the constant stream of market information and commentary affects investors?

I believe it causes many investors to behave irrationally. They start listening to all the chatter and pundits, and before you know it, they're making decisions based on fear or greed instead of sound judgment. It's like trying to navigate a ship through treacherous waters while being bombarded with conflicting instructions from the shore.
You mention that a climate of fear can be helpful to the true investor. Can you explain what you mean by that?

Well, when everyone else is fearful and selling, that's often when the best opportunities arise. If you have cash available and a solid understanding of the businesses you're invested in, you can take advantage of prices that have gotten far out of line with values. It's like being able to buy a wonderful farm at a discounted price just because your neighbor is having a fire sale – it's a great chance to pick up something valuable at a bargain price.
What should be the goal of a non-professional investor when it comes to investing in the stock market?

The goal of the non-professional investor shouldn't be to pick individual winners, because let's face it, neither they nor their advisors can consistently do that. Instead, their goal should be to own a cross-section of businesses that, in aggregate, are bound to do well over time. It's a simple, yet effective approach.
What investment vehicle do you recommend for non-professional investors to achieve their investment goals?

I recommend a low-cost S&P 500 index fund. It's a straightforward way for non-professional investors to own a piece of America's economy, and historically, it's been a very smart move. As I said, the key is to own a cross-section of businesses, and an index fund like this does just that.
What's the main danger for a timid or beginning investor in the market?

The main danger is that they'll enter the market when it's extremely exuberant, only to become disillusioned when paper losses occur. It's a bit like a party - it's most fun just before it ends, as my friend Barton Biggs used to say.
How should an investor approach buying and selling stocks to achieve satisfactory results?

I advise investors to accumulate shares over a long period and never sell when the news is bad and stocks are off their highs. It's like investing in a farm - you don't frantically buy and sell farms based on daily news. Just keep your costs minimal, diversify, and you'll likely get satisfactory results.
What investment advice do you give to the trustee for your wife's benefit, as outlined in your will?

I've instructed the trustee to put 10% of the cash in short-term government bonds and 90% in a very low-cost S&P 500 index fund, specifically Vanguard's. I believe this simple approach will yield superior long-term results compared to most investors who pay high fees to managers.
How did reading Ben Graham's book, The Intelligent Investor, impact your investment approach?

Reading Ben's book in 1949 was a game-changer for me. Before that, I was all over the place, trying out different investing strategies like charting and using market indicia. But after reading The Intelligent Investor, my financial life changed - I finally had a clear direction and understanding of investing that has stuck with me to this day.
What was the market value of Northern Pacific when you read the book, and how does that compare to its current earnings?

The market value of Northern Pacific was about $40 million back then. Now, its successor, BNSF, earns that amount every four days. It's a staggering difference, and it really drives home the power of long-term investing and the importance of understanding value versus price.
You mention that local and state financial problems are accelerating due to pension issues. What role do you think investment policies play in these problems?

Investment policies play a significant role in these pension problems. I've been warning about the pitfalls of pension promises and the importance of sound investment policy for decades, in fact, I wrote a memo about it to Katharine Graham back in 1975. It's crucial for public entities to get their investment policies right to avoid exacerbating these financial issues.
Why do you and Charlie prefer to release financial information on Fridays or Saturdays?

We want all our shareholders to have equal access to new information and sufficient time to digest it. Releasing it late on Fridays or early on Saturdays gives everyone the weekend to analyze it without the pressure of immediate market reactions.
What motivates your operating managers, given that most have no financial need to work?

It's the joy of achieving business successes, or as I call them, 'hitting business home runs.' This drive is just as important to them as their paycheck, and it's what makes them so shareholder-oriented and effective in running their businesses.
How do the tax costs affect Berkshire's performance compared to the S&P 500?

Well, it's quite simple really. Since our numbers are after-tax and the S&P 500 numbers are pre-tax, we lag behind in years when the S&P 500 has a positive return, but we do better in years when it has a negative return. Over time, those tax costs add up and cause a substantial difference in our aggregate performance.
What was the total gain for Berkshire's shareholders in 2012, and how did it affect the company's net worth?

In 2012, we achieved a total gain of $24.1 billion for our shareholders. After using $1.3 billion of that to repurchase our stock, we were left with an increase in net worth of $22.8 billion for the year. Not bad, if I do say so myself.
What has been the long-term performance of the Dow Jones Industrials, and what does this suggest about the fate of stocks?

The Dow Jones Industrials have done incredibly well over the long term, advancing from 66 to 11,497 in the 20th Century. That's a staggering 17,320% increase, and it happened despite some very tough times, including four costly wars, a Great Depression, and many recessions. To me, this suggests that the fate of stocks is closely tied to business performance, and that investors can expect to do well over the long haul, even with some periodic setbacks along the way.
You made your first stock purchase in 1942, during a time of great uncertainty. What was your outlook at the time, and how did that experience inform your investment approach?

Well, I have to say that even though the headlines were full of bad news back in 1942, I didn't know anyone who thought we were going to lose the war. There was a sense of uncertainty, of course, but there was also a deep-seated belief that America would prevail. And that's exactly what happened. The country's success since then has been just incredible. For me, that experience taught me to focus on the big picture, and not to get too caught up in short-term worries. It's a lesson that has served me well over the years, and it's one that I still believe in today.
What are the key strategies you and Charlie aim to use to build per-share intrinsic value at Berkshire?

We've outlined five key strategies: improving the earning power of our subsidiaries, increasing their earnings through bolt-on acquisitions, participating in the growth of our investees, repurchasing Berkshire shares at a meaningful discount, and making the occasional large acquisition. We believe these building blocks will serve us well over time.
Can you provide a precise estimate of Berkshire's intrinsic business value?

I'm afraid not. Charlie and I have discussed the elements that contribute to a sensible estimate of Berkshire's intrinsic value, but we can't provide a precise number. We did lay out those elements in our 2010 annual report, which is reproduced on pages 104-105 for those interested in diving deeper.
How does the float from property-casualty insurance work for Berkshire's benefit?

Well, it's quite simple really. We collect premiums upfront and pay claims later, sometimes much later. This means we get to hold onto large sums of money, which we call 'float,' and invest it for our benefit. It's like having a big pool of money that we can use to generate even more money through investments, and that's a pretty sweet deal.
What happens to Berkshire's float if the company experiences a decline in the future?

If we do experience a decline in float, it will be very gradual - no more than 2% in any year. And let me tell you, our insurance CEOs are working hard to make sure that doesn't happen. In fact, they've already proven me wrong once by increasing float last year, and I expect GEICO's float to continue growing. So, while a decline is possible, I'm not losing too much sleep over it.
How does achieving an underwriting profit impact the use of float in the insurance industry?

When we achieve an underwriting profit, it's like having free money - and getting paid for holding it. This is because our premiums exceed our expenses and losses, allowing us to use the float to generate additional investment income.
How is Berkshire's float accounted for when calculating the company's book value?

Our float is deducted as a liability when calculating Berkshire's book value, as if we had to pay it out tomorrow and couldn't replenish it. This treatment reflects the fact that float is essentially a loan from our policyholders that we need to account for accurately.
Why do you believe Berkshire's intrinsic business value exceeds its book value?

I believe Berkshire's intrinsic business value substantially exceeds its book value primarily because of the value of our float. You see, our insurance operations, particularly those run by exceptional managers like Ajit Jain, generate a significant amount of cost-free float, which is a huge advantage. This float is essentially money that doesn't cost us anything, and we can invest it to generate more returns.
What makes Ajit Jain's Berkshire Hathaway Reinsurance Group unique in the insurance business?

Ajit's operation is unique because it combines capacity, speed, decisiveness, and brains in a way that's unmatched in the insurance industry. He takes on risks that others can't or won't, and he does it with a level of expertise and agility that sets us apart. It's a remarkable combination that's been incredibly successful for us.
What makes Ajit's insurance operation unique in the industry?

Ajit's operation stands out because it combines capacity, speed, decisiveness, and brains in a way that's unmatched. He's got the ability to take on risks that others can't or won't, but he does it in a smart way that doesn't expose Berkshire to inappropriate risks.
What are the key disciplines that a sound insurance operation needs to follow?

A sound insurance operation needs to follow four key disciplines: understanding all potential exposures, conservatively assessing the likelihood and cost of losses, setting premiums that will deliver a profit, and being willing to walk away if the right premium can't be obtained. It's pretty straightforward, but you'd be surprised how many companies get it wrong.
How much will your renewables portfolio have cost upon completion of the current projects under construction?
Our renewables portfolio will have cost $13 billion upon completion of these projects. It's a huge capital investment, but we believe it's worth it for the returns we expect to see.
How much will BNSF spend on the railroad in 2013?

BNSF will spend about $4 billion on the railroad in 2013. That's roughly double its depreciation charge, and it's more than any railroad has spent in a single year. We're committed to keeping America's rail system in top shape.
What percentage of amortization charges do you consider 'real' and why is this distinction important?

I consider about 20% of amortization charges to be 'real'. This distinction is crucial because, from an investor's viewpoint, not all amortization charges are created equal. GAAP accounting treats them all the same, but in reality, some are more relevant than others when evaluating a company's performance.
Can you give an example of a company where 'non-real' amortization charges are significant and how it affects their reported earnings?

Take Wells Fargo, for instance. They report an 'amortization of core deposits' charge, which was about $1.5 billion last year. Now, this charge makes it seem like their core deposits are disappearing quickly, but in reality, these deposits are actually increasing. This 'non-real' charge heavily burdens their reported earnings, and I think it's essential for investors to look beyond the GAAP numbers to get a clearer picture.
What made local newspapers so valuable to their readers, according to your text?

Well, it's quite simple really. Local newspapers were valuable because they provided readers with a wide range of information that was relevant to their daily lives, from news and sports to job listings, apartment rentals, and supermarket specials. And the best part was, readers got all this information at a very low cost, thanks to advertisers who footed most of the bill.
Why were local newspapers a crucial advertising platform for businesses like Sears or Safeway?

That's an easy one. Local newspapers were the 'megaphone' that businesses needed to reach their target audience. When a big retailer like Sears or Safeway opened a new store in a city like Omaha, they needed a way to tell people about it, and the local newspaper was the perfect platform. With no other advertising channel as effective, businesses relied heavily on newspapers to get the word out and drive sales.
What was the main reason for the decline of multiple newspapers in a city?

Well, it's quite simple really. Most people only wanted to read and pay for one paper, so when competition existed, the paper that gained a significant lead in circulation would almost automatically get the most ads. It was a symbiotic process that spelled doom for the weaker paper.
In what area do newspapers still maintain their dominance?

Newspapers continue to reign supreme in the delivery of local news. If you want to know what's going on in your town, whether it's about the mayor, taxes, or high school football, there's no substitute for a local newspaper that's doing its job.
Why do local newspapers remain essential for delivering local news?

I believe local newspapers remain essential because they provide news that's directly relevant to their readers' lives. When people read about their own community, whether it's about the mayor, local taxes, or high school football, they're more engaged. It's like the difference between reading a letter from a friend versus a generic newsletter - the personal connection keeps them interested.
What strategy has worked for some newspapers, like the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette, to retain circulation?

Well, it's quite simple really. The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette, under Walter Hussman, Jr., adopted a pay format early on. This approach has helped them retain their circulation much better than other large papers. It's a straightforward strategy that recognizes the value of their content and doesn't give it away for free, unlike some other publishers who have struggled with falling sales after offering their papers free on the Internet.
What is the approach you believe will lead to the success of local newspapers?

I believe that delivering comprehensive and reliable information to tightly-bound communities, along with having a sensible Internet strategy, is key to success. Cutting news content or publication frequency is not the way to go - it's like trying to make a recipe work with fewer ingredients, it just won't taste as good.
Is there an example of a newspaper that has successfully implemented a pay model?

Yes, the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette, published by Walter Hussman, Jr., is a great example. They adopted a pay format early on and have retained their circulation far better than any other large paper in the country over the past decade. Walter's approach is a powerful example that others, including us at Berkshire, have only recently started to explore.
What happens to the value of our shares if we buy them back above their intrinsic value?

Well, let me tell you, when purchases are made above intrinsic value, value is destroyed. It's like overpaying for a piece of furniture - you're not getting a good deal, and it's going to cost you in the long run.
In the scenario you described, how much would my dividend be after ten years if we maintain a one-third payout of the company's annual earnings?

After ten years, your dividend would be $86,357. That's because the company's earnings and net worth are growing at a rate of 8% per year, and we're maintaining that one-third payout. It's a nice steady increase, if I do say so myself.
How has your ownership percentage of Berkshire changed over the last seven years, and what's happened to your investment in the business?

Well, my ownership percentage of Berkshire has significantly decreased - I've given away about 41⁄4% of my shares annually for the last seven years. However, my investment in the business has actually increased. The book value of my current interest in Berkshire is $40.2 billion, which exceeds the $28.2 billion it was seven years ago. So, even though I own fewer shares, I have more money working for me at Berkshire.
What do you believe is essential for a company's dividend policy to be effective?

Above all, I think a dividend policy should be clear, consistent, and rational. If it's capricious or unpredictable, it will just confuse owners and drive away potential investors. You want people to understand what they can expect from your company, and a well-thought-out dividend policy is key to that.
Why do you and Charlie Munger release financial information after the market close on a Friday and hold the annual meeting on Saturdays?

We do it to give all shareholders a fair shot at getting the information at the same time and having enough time to digest it. It's like calling a timeout in a game - we want to make sure everyone has a chance to catch their breath and think about what we're sharing before making any decisions.
What's the selection process for audience members to ask questions during the annual meeting?

We keep it simple and fair - we hold drawings at 8:15 a.m. at each of the 11 microphones in the arena and main overflow room. It's like a lottery, and if your name is drawn, you get to ask your question. We try to take as many questions from the audience as time allows, so everyone's got a chance to participate.
What was the growth rate of Berkshire's book value per share over the last 47 years?
The book value has grown at a rate of 19.8% compounded annually over the last 47 years, from $19 to $99,860. That's a pretty impressive run, if I do say so myself.
How do you feel about the company's succession planning, particularly with regards to your own successor as CEO?

I feel very good about it. Our Board of Directors has done an excellent job in identifying and preparing the next generation of leaders. We have a great candidate lined up to succeed me as CEO, and two superb back-up candidates as well. Plus, with Todd Combs and Ted Weschler on board, I'm confident that our investment portfolio is in good hands for the long term.
How much would Berkshire's dividends from the 'Big Four' have been if you owned the current positions throughout last year?
Our dividends from the 'Big Four' would have been $862 million if we had owned our present positions throughout last year.
What was the outcome of your $2 billion investment in Energy Future Holdings' bond issues?
That was a mistake - a big mistake. The company's prospects were tied to the price of natural gas, which tanked shortly after our purchase and remains depressed.
What conditions must be met for you and Charlie to favor share repurchases?

For us to favor repurchases, two conditions must be met: first, the company must have ample funds to take care of its operational and liquidity needs; second, its stock must be selling at a material discount to its intrinsic business value, which we calculate conservatively.
What was the outcome of Berkshire's share repurchase announcement last September?

We were only in the market for a few days, buying $67 million of stock, before the price advanced beyond our limit of 110% of book value. It was a brief foray, but it demonstrates our commitment to repurchasing shares when the price is right.
What is the primary goal when buying back Berkshire's own stock, and how do you ensure it benefits continuing shareholders?

Our primary goal when buying back our own stock is to make money for our continuing shareholders. We achieve this by buying our stock at a price lower than its intrinsic value, which we believe to be at least its book value. We ensure it benefits continuing shareholders by only repurchasing at a price that increases Berkshire's per-share intrinsic value, such as at our limit price of 110% of book value or lower. The more and cheaper we buy, the greater the gain for those who remain invested with us.
Under what conditions will Berkshire not buy back its shares, despite having the opportunity to do so at favorable prices?

We won't buy back our shares if our cash-equivalent holdings fall below $20 billion, because maintaining financial strength is our top priority. Additionally, we won't support the stock price in particularly weak markets, so our bids will fade away in such conditions. Our focus is always on ensuring Berkshire's financial foundation remains rock-solid.
Why should a long-term shareholder like Berkshire wish for IBM's stock price to languish over the next five years?

I wish for IBM's stock price to languish because if the price is lower, IBM can buy back more shares with the $50 billion it plans to spend. This means there will be fewer shares outstanding, and as a result, our share of the company's earnings will be larger. It's simple math, but it's counterintuitive to what most people want - they usually cheer for rising stock prices.
How does the average stock price during the five-year period affect the number of shares Berkshire will own?

Let me put it this way: if the stock price averages $200, IBM will buy back 250 million shares, leaving about 910 million shares outstanding, and we'll own around 7% of the company. But if the stock price averages $300, IBM will only buy back 167 million shares, leaving about 990 million shares outstanding, and our ownership stake will be about 6.5%. So, a lower stock price actually benefits us as long-term shareholders because we end up owning a larger percentage of the company.
How did your perspective on stock prices change over time?

Well, I used to rejoice when the market rose, just like most people. But then I read Chapter Eight of Ben Graham's The Intelligent Investor, and it completely changed my view. I realized that low prices should be my friend, not something to fear. It was a lucky moment for me, and it's a lesson that has stuck with me ever since.
What condition would trigger you to give Berkshire employees a paid holiday?

That's an easy one - if IBM's repurchases ever reduce the shares outstanding to 63.9 million, I've promised to abandon my frugality for a day and give our employees a paid holiday. It's a fun benchmark, and I'm looking forward to seeing if it happens!
You mentioned that if your premiums exceed expenses and losses, you register an underwriting profit. Can you explain how this underwriting profit contributes to your investment income from float?

Well, think of it like this: when we have an underwriting profit, it's essentially free money that we get to add to the investment income our float produces. It's like someone depositing a big chunk of cash with us and saying, 'Hey, not only can you hold this money, but we'll also pay you for doing so.' This profit then gets invested, generating even more income for us. It's a pretty sweet deal.

You also mentioned that State Farm, a well-managed company, has incurred an underwriting loss in eight of the last eleven years. Do you think your company will be able to continue operating at an underwriting profit in the future?

I believe it's likely we'll continue to underwrite profitably in most years, though certainly not all. The insurance industry is competitive, and there are many ways to lose money. But we've managed to operate at an underwriting profit for nine consecutive years now, with a total gain of $17 billion. If we can keep that up, our float will be better than cost-free – it'll be a source of profit for us, just like someone paying us to hold and invest their money.
What makes Berkshire's float so valuable and unique in the insurance industry?

Our float is incredibly valuable because it's cost-free, and that's a rare thing in the P/C industry. The reason we have this advantage is due to our terrific managers, like Ajit Jain, who run extraordinary insurance operations. They make smart decisions that combine capacity, speed, and brains in a way that's unique in the business.
How would Berkshire perform financially if the insurance industry were to experience a massive loss, such as a $250 billion mega-catastrophe?

If the insurance industry were to face a $250 billion loss, which is about triple anything it's ever seen, Berkshire as a whole would likely still record a moderate profit for the year. That's because we have many streams of earnings that help us weather such storms. We're also very conservative in the risks we take on, so we wouldn't be exposed to losses that are inappropriate for our resources.
How would Berkshire's performance compare to other major insurers if the industry were to experience a $250 billion loss from a mega-catastrophe?

Well, I'd say we'd be in a pretty enviable position. While other major insurers and reinsurers would be deeply in the red, possibly even facing insolvency, Berkshire as a whole would likely still record a moderate profit for the year. That's because of our diverse streams of earnings, which help cushion us against such massive losses.
What are the key disciplines that a sound insurance operation needs to follow, according to your experience?

In my view, a sound insurance operation needs to adhere to four disciplines. First, it must understand all exposures that might cause a policy to incur losses. Second, it needs to conservatively evaluate the likelihood and cost of those losses. Third, it should set a premium that will deliver a profit, on average, after covering loss costs and expenses. And fourth, it must be willing to walk away if the right premium can't be obtained. Many insurers struggle with that last one - they just can't resist writing business, even if it's not profitable.
What is the main reason why many insurers fail the fourth test, according to you?

I believe many insurers fail the fourth test because they can't resist following the crowd. They see their competitors writing certain business and they feel compelled to do the same, even if it's not a good idea. It's like that old saying, 'The other guy is doing it so we must as well.' This kind of thinking can lead to trouble in any business, but especially in insurance.
How has GEICO's market share changed under Tony Nicely's leadership as CEO?

Under Tony Nicely's leadership, GEICO's market share has grown significantly - from 2.0% to 9.3% over his 18-year tenure as CEO. That's a remarkable increase, and it's a testament to Tony's brilliant execution of our business model.
What is the 'social compact' you mention in relation to MidAmerican, and how does it work?

The 'social compact' at MidAmerican is essentially an understanding that if we operate reliably and efficiently, putting up the necessary investments to meet our customers' future needs, we can expect a fair return on those investments. It's a mutual agreement where good behavior by us begets good behavior from the regulators, who represent our customers' interests.
How has MidAmerican's performance improved since its acquisitions, particularly with Northern Natural Gas pipeline?

Well, let me tell you, it's been a remarkable turnaround. When we purchased Northern Natural Gas pipeline in 2002, it was ranked dead last out of 43 pipelines. But in the most recent report, it's ranked second. And if that's not enough, our other pipeline, Kern River, holds the top spot. Similarly, in our electric business, MidAmerican's U.S. utilities ranked second among 60 utility groups surveyed in terms of customer satisfaction. It's a testament to our commitment to improvement and customer satisfaction.
What is your relationship like with the Blumkin family, and how have they contributed to the growth of their business?

The Blumkins are a remarkable family and close friends of mine. I've known Louie and his wife Fran for 55 years, and their sons Ron and Irv have taken the company to new heights. I've had many great times with them, and I'm thrilled to see the fourth generation joining the business. They're a talented family that hasn't let their extraordinary abilities go to waste.
You mention that you've made mistakes buying small companies. Can you elaborate on what you've learned from these experiences?

Well, I've learned that just because something can be done, doesn't mean it should be done. Charlie Munger once told me, 'If something's not worth doing at all, it's not worth doing well.' I wish I had listened harder to that advice earlier on. Thankfully, our larger purchases have generally worked out well, and overall, this sector has been a winner for us.
How did the pre-tax earnings of your two leasing companies change from 2009 to 2011?

Our two leasing companies saw a significant improvement in pre-tax earnings over that period. In 2009, they earned $13 million, which increased to $53 million in 2010 and then to $155 million in 2011. It's a great example of how our non-housing businesses steadily recovered from the economic downturn.
Why did Clayton's mortgage portfolio perform relatively well despite the housing meltdown?

Clayton's mortgage portfolio performed well because we stuck to old-fashioned loan policies. We required meaningful down payments and made sure monthly payments were sensible in relation to the borrowers' regular income. This approach helped us keep losses to acceptable levels, even when the housing market was struggling.
What is your assessment of Bank of America's current situation and its potential for the future?

I believe Bank of America has strong earnings, solid assets, and record capital levels. While prior management made huge mistakes, Brian Moynihan is making excellent progress in cleaning them up. It will take a few years, but the underlying business is huge and attractive, and I'm confident our warrants to buy 700 million shares will be very valuable before they expire.
How do you evaluate the performance of your investment managers, Todd Combs and Ted Weschler?

Todd and Ted are both doing great work. They each receive 80% of their performance compensation from their own results and 20% from their partner's, which encourages them to work together and think about the overall portfolio. Todd built a $1.75 billion portfolio last year, and Ted will soon create one of similar size. I'm impressed with their 'business minds' and think they'll be helpful in making acquisitions for Berkshire's next CEO.
What was the total amount of premiums received for the portfolio, and how does it compare to the total payments made?

We received $3.4 billion in premiums, which is significantly more than the $2.6 billion we paid out. This difference is what gives us confidence that we'll realize an underwriting profit on this portfolio.
How do you define investing at Berkshire, and what is the key expectation for the future?

At Berkshire, we define investing as transferring purchasing power now with the expectation of receiving more purchasing power in the future, after taxes. Essentially, it's about forgoing consumption now so that we can consume more later. It's a straightforward concept, but one that we believe is essential for making smart investment decisions.
How do you define investing at Berkshire?

At Berkshire, we define investing as transferring purchasing power now with the expectation of getting more purchasing power later, after taxes. It's about forgoing consumption now so you can consume more later. Simple as that.
Why do you consider investments like money-market funds and bonds to be risky, despite their reputation as 'safe'?

Well, it's because their risk isn't measured by how much their price fluctuates, but by the likelihood they'll lose purchasing power over time. And let me tell you, over the past century, these so-called 'safe' investments have destroyed the purchasing power of many investors, even if they did get their interest and principal payments on time.
What are the two significant shortcomings of gold as an investment, according to you?

I believe gold has two significant shortcomings: it's neither of much use, meaning it has limited industrial and decorative utility, and it's not procreative, meaning if you own one ounce of gold, you'll still just own one ounce of gold, it won't generate more wealth on its own.
Can you explain why the price of gold has been rising over the past decade, in your view?

Well, I think the rising price of gold is largely driven by people's fear of other assets, especially paper money. As more and more people become fearful, they buy gold, which in turn drives up the price, creating a sort of self-fulfilling prophecy. It's like a bandwagon effect, where people jump on because they see others doing it and the price is going up, but this can only go on for so long before it inevitably pops.
How does the fuel efficiency of BNSF's railroads compare to trucking?
Our railroad is three times more fuel-efficient than trucking. To put it simply, last year BNSF moved each ton of freight it carried a record 500 miles on a single gallon of diesel fuel.
What are Berkshire's plans for capital spending in 2011, and where will this spending be focused?

In 2011, we will set a new record for capital spending - $8 billion. Notably, we will spend all of the $2 billion increase in the United States. This reflects our confidence in the abundance of opportunities in America.
You mention that despite uncertainties, America's best days lie ahead. What makes you so confident in the American system's ability to unleash human potential?

I'm confident because, despite all the setbacks and challenges we've faced over the centuries, the American system has consistently proven itself to be resilient and effective. It's like a powerful engine that just keeps chugging along, fueled by human ingenuity and determination. We're not smarter or harder-working than our ancestors, but we've built upon their foundations and created a world that's beyond their wildest dreams.
You criticize managers who don't establish clear performance goals, saying they 'paint the bull's-eye around wherever the arrow lands.' Can you elaborate on what you mean by this?

Well, it's quite simple really. When managers don't set clear goals upfront, they're tempted to retroactively define success based on whatever results they happen to get. It's like shooting an arrow and then drawing a target around it, so it looks like you hit the mark. That's not how you measure real performance. At Berkshire, Charlie and I believe in setting clear standards from the start, so we can honestly evaluate how well we're doing.
How do you evaluate the potential for a company's retained earnings to increase its intrinsic value?

I evaluate the potential for a company's retained earnings to increase its intrinsic value by considering what management will do with the money. It's like giving someone a dollar - some will turn it into fifty-cent pieces, while others will turn it into two-dollar bills. The 'what-will-they-do-with-the-money' factor is crucial, and it depends on the CEO's talents and motives. If they're suspect, today's value must be discounted.
What advantages do you believe Berkshire has despite the challenges of its size?

Despite the anchor of size, I believe Berkshire has several important advantages. First, we have a cadre of truly skilled managers who are committed to their operations and to Berkshire. Many of our CEOs are independently wealthy and work because they love what they do - they're volunteers, not mercenaries. This makes a big difference.
How do you decide when to invest in a business versus marketable securities?

I decide by comparing the attractions of one business against a host of others and also against opportunities available in marketable securities. If a business is priced ridiculously high against what can likely be earned from investments in stocks or bonds, we'll buy securities and wait for a better opportunity.
What motivates the directors at Berkshire to make decisions that are in the best interest of the company?

Our directors are motivated by the fact that they think and act like owners. They receive very little compensation and no perks like liability insurance, so if they make a mistake with your money, they'll lose their own money too. Plus, they and their families have a significant amount of their own wealth invested in Berkshire shares, over $3 billion worth, so they keep a keen eye on our actions and results.
How much are Berkshire shares worth that are owned by directors and their families?
Our directors and their families own Berkshire shares worth more than $3 billion. I think that's a pretty strong indication that they're invested in the company's success, if you know what I mean.
What is the total investment in the Berkshire 'World Headquarters' for things like furniture and equipment?

We've kept things pretty lean at our headquarters. The total investment in things like furniture, art, and equipment is $301,363. I like to think that shows we're focused on using our resources wisely.
How do you ensure that Berkshire's managers handle investor money with care?

I ensure that Berkshire's managers handle investor money with care by treating it as if it were my own, and by designing our compensation programs, annual meeting, and annual reports to reinforce the Berkshire culture. This culture encourages careful management of funds and repels managers who don't share our values.
What sparked your interest in GEICO, and how did you first learn about the company?

My interest in GEICO was sparked when I found out that my hero, Ben Graham, was the chairman of the company. I was a 20-year-old graduate student at Columbia at the time, and I discovered this connection by checking out Ben's entry in Who's Who in America at the library. The librarian then directed me to a compendium of insurers, where I read about GEICO and decided to pay the company a visit.
What is 'float' in the context of Berkshire's insurance business, and how does it benefit the company?

Float refers to the large sums of money we hold that will eventually go to others. Think of it like an interest-free loan - we get to invest this money for Berkshire's benefit while we're holding onto it. It's a pretty sweet deal, and as our business grows, so does our float.
Has the insurance industry as a whole been able to achieve underwriting profits in recent years, and what's an example of a well-managed company's experience?

Unfortunately, the industry as a whole has operated at a significant underwriting loss in most years due to intense competition. Take State Farm, for example - they're the country's largest insurer and a well-run company, but they've incurred an underwriting loss in seven of the last ten years. That's just the way the cookie crumbles in our line of work.
How does Berkshire's underwriting performance compare to the rest of the industry, and what does this mean for our float?

Well, I'm happy to say that Berkshire has operated at an underwriting profit for eight consecutive years, with a total underwriting gain of $17 billion. This is in stark contrast to the industry as a whole, which has often incurred underwriting losses - just look at State Farm, which has lost over $20 billion in seven of the last ten years. As for our float, if we continue to underwrite profitably, it will be better than cost-free, similar to having someone deposit $66 billion with us and letting us invest it for our own benefit.
What role do you think Berkshire's management and unique businesses play in the company's outstanding economics?

I believe our terrific managers and unusual businesses are the key to our success. We've got some real stars in our portfolio, including GEICO and the Berkshire Hathaway Reinsurance Group, run by Ajit Jain. These businesses, along with a few others, are the reason we've been able to achieve such outstanding economics, far surpassing the average return of the American industry.
What makes Ajit Jain's operation at Berkshire Hathaway Reinsurance Group unique in the insurance business?

Ajit's operation stands out because it combines capacity, speed, decisiveness, and brains in a way that's hard to find elsewhere in the insurance business. He's got the ability to take on big risks, but he does it in a smart way that never puts Berkshire in a tough spot relative to our resources.
What are the key disciplines required for a sound insurance operation, according to your discussion of General Re?

To run a sound insurance operation, you need four key disciplines: understanding all the exposures that might cause losses, making a conservative evaluation of the likelihood and cost of those losses, setting premiums that will deliver a profit on average, and being willing to walk away if you can't get the right premium. That's the approach Tad Montross takes at General Re, and it's served us well.
What was the average FICO score of the borrowers for the mortgages originated by Clayton?
The average FICO score of our borrowers was 648. And I might add, about 47% of them had scores of 640 or below, which, as your banker will tell you, isn't exactly a stellar credit rating.
How did Clayton's approach to lending contribute to the performance of its mortgage portfolio during stressful conditions?

We kept things simple and sensible. We required a meaningful down-payment and made sure the fixed monthly payments were a reasonable percentage of the borrower's income. And because we were holding these mortgages ourselves, not reselling them, we had a strong incentive to get it right. If we'd been reckless, we would have been the ones to suffer the consequences. That tends to focus the mind, if you know what I mean.
What are your expectations for the investment income from Coke in the next ten years?

I expect our investment income from Coke to double within ten years. In fact, by the end of that period, I wouldn't be surprised if our share of Coke's annual earnings exceeds 100% of what we paid for the investment. Time is the friend of a wonderful business like Coke.
What prompted Lou Simpson's decision to retire, and how do you view his contributions to Berkshire?

Lou Simpson told me he wished to retire last summer, which was a surprise to me since he was only 74 - an age that Charlie and I consider quite young. As for his contributions, Lou has been invaluable to GEICO, and I consider him one of the investment greats. His record with equities has been outstanding, and we will certainly miss him.
How will the performance compensation of investment managers be structured at Berkshire?

We're planning to have 80% of each manager's performance compensation dependent on their own portfolio and 20% on that of the other manager(s). This way, we encourage individual success while also fostering a spirit of cooperation, not competition.
What role will investment managers play in the acquisition of businesses when you and Charlie are no longer around?

Our investment managers will bring a useful perspective to the table when it comes to purchasing businesses, and we expect them to be consulted on potential acquisitions. However, they won't have a vote - the Board will ultimately make the call on any major acquisition.
Why did you choose not to require collateral for most of your derivatives contracts, and how did this decision impact Berkshire during the financial crisis?

I chose not to require collateral for most of our derivatives contracts because it allowed us to charge lower premiums. While this meant foregoing some additional income, it also gave us the comfort and flexibility to make some advantageous purchases during the financial crisis. It was a trade-off that proved to be well worth it.
Why do you consider net income to be a meaningless number for Berkshire, and how can you influence this figure?

I consider net income to be a meaningless number for Berkshire because it can be heavily influenced by realized gains or losses on investments, which can be volatile and don't necessarily reflect the performance of our businesses. Charlie and I have the flexibility to impact net income by choosing when to realize gains or losses, which can result in a figure that doesn't accurately represent our company's true financial health.
Why do you suggest ignoring the net income figure when evaluating Berkshire's performance?

I suggest ignoring net income because it can be misleading due to the impact of realized gains and losses. For instance, if we had significant realized gains in the previous year, it could make our current year's earnings look worse by comparison, even if our business is actually doing better. It's like comparing apples and oranges. Instead, I recommend focusing on our operating earnings and book value, as they provide a more accurate picture of our performance.
Can you give an example of how the reporting of net income can be capricious?

A great example is our equity puts. If they had a termination date of June 30, 2010, we would have had to pay out $6.4 billion, which would have significantly impacted our reported net income. But that's just an accounting rule - it doesn't reflect the true performance of our business. It's a good reminder that reported net income can be influenced by all sorts of factors that don't necessarily reflect reality.
Why do you and Charlie Munger believe that the Black-Scholes formula produces wildly inappropriate values for long-dated options?

Well, we've seen some pretty absurd examples of how Black-Scholes can misvalue options, and we've even pointed some out in the past. For instance, we've noted how it can produce values that just don't make sense when you're dealing with long-dated options. We've put our money where our mouth is, too, by entering into equity put contracts that implicitly bet against the Black-Scholes values used by our counterparties.
Why do you continue to use the Black-Scholes formula in your financial statements despite believing it produces inappropriate values?

It's quite simple, really. Black-Scholes is the standard that everyone uses, and if we deviated from it, we'd be accused of shoddy accounting. Our auditors would also have a tough time dealing with the discrepancy, since they have clients who are our counterparties and use Black-Scholes values for the same contracts. So, even though we don't think it's the best method, we stick with it to avoid any unnecessary headaches.
Why do you think auditors and regulators prefer the Black-Scholes model for valuing contracts?

I believe auditors and regulators like Black-Scholes because it gives them a precise number. It's comforting to have a specific value, even if it's not entirely accurate. As I said, I'd rather be approximately right than precisely wrong, but that's not how they operate.
What's your view on the academic community's approach to teaching Black-Scholes and option valuation?

Honestly, I think it's time for a re-examination. The academic community tends to cling to theories like Black-Scholes as if they're absolute truth. It reminds me of the efficient market theory - they called contradicting evidence 'anomalies' back in the day. I think it's high time for a fresh look at how we teach and approach option valuation.
Do you think it's necessary for investors to know how to value options?

No, I don't think it's necessary at all. In fact, I believe you can be highly successful as an investor without having the slightest ability to value an option. What's more important is knowing how to value a business, because that's what investing is all about.
What's your view on the use of leverage in business and investing?

I think leverage can be addictive and potentially lethal to businesses. While it can magnify gains when it works, it can also produce big zeroes when it doesn't. I've seen very smart people get into trouble with leverage, and I believe it's essential to be cautious and conservative in its use. As I always say, to finish first, you must first finish - and that means being mindful of the risks of leverage.
What is Berkshire's top priority, according to your memo to the managers?
Our top priority at Berkshire is to zealously guard the company's reputation. We can afford to lose money, but losing reputation is something we just can't afford.
How should Berkshire managers respond when someone justifies a business action by saying 'Everybody else is doing it'?

When someone says 'Everybody else is doing it,' it's usually a weak rationale. I'd tell our managers to point out that this explanation won't hold water with a reporter or a judge, and it's likely a sign that the action itself isn't justified.
What should I do if I'm unsure about the propriety or legality of a particular action?

If you're unsure, it's best to err on the side of caution. I always say, there's plenty of money to be made in the center of the court, so why risk being close to the line? If in doubt, just assume it's outside the line and forget it. And if you're still unsure, give me a call.
How do you think the culture of a business is developed, and what role do leaders play in it?

I believe culture is more important than rule books in determining how an organization behaves. As a leader, your attitude and behavior set the tone for the rest of the company. By jumping on any hint of impropriety immediately and being transparent, you can shape the culture of your business and minimize bad behavior. It's not about having all the answers, but about being willing to face problems head-on and lead by example.
How has Berkshire's performance compared to the S&P 500 over the years, particularly in terms of book value gain?

Well, I'm pleased to say that over 41 five-year periods, our gain in book value has never been less than the S&P's gain. That's a pretty consistent track record. However, it's worth noting that our performance advantage has shrunk as we've grown in size, which is an unfortunate trend that's likely to continue.
What kind of businesses or investments do you and Charlie tend to avoid, and why?

Charlie and I are quite cautious when it comes to investing in businesses whose futures we can't evaluate. It doesn't matter how exciting their products may be - if we can't get a handle on where they're headed, we'll steer clear. We like to think of it as following Charlie's inversion approach, which is inspired by that great Prussian mathematician, Jacobi: 'Invert, always invert.' In this case, it means avoiding the things that could potentially harm us, rather than trying to find the next big winner.
How do you envision Berkshire's organizational structure as it grows, and what steps will you take to prevent it from becoming too bureaucratic?

I see Berkshire operating as a collection of separately-managed medium-sized and large businesses. Charlie and I will keep our role simple - we'll allocate capital, control risk, choose managers, and set their compensation. This way, decision-making stays at the operating level, and we avoid getting bogged down in committees and red tape.
What kind of investors are you looking to attract to Berkshire, and what characteristics do you think are essential for a successful long-term partnership?

We're looking for investors who want to make a long-term investment in a business they understand and believe in. We want partners, not speculators who buy and sell based on what the media or analysts say. We're looking for people who share our goals and values, because when owners and managers are on the same page, that's when the real magic happens.
What kind of partners do you and Charlie Munger look for when it comes to investing in a business?

We look for partners who join us because they want to make a long-term investment in a business they understand and agree with our policies. It's like a marriage - we want to be in sync with our partners, working towards common goals.
How do you approach communicating financial information to your shareholders, and what's the reasoning behind posting it on the Internet over weekends?

We try to communicate directly and informatively with our owners, telling them what we'd like to know if we were in their shoes. We post our quarterly and annual financial info on the Internet over weekends so our shareholders have plenty of time to digest the information during a non-trading period, without the pressure of a trading day.
How does the collect-now, pay-later model of the P/C industry benefit Berkshire?

Well, it's quite simple really. This model gives us something we call 'float' - large sums of money that we get to hold onto and invest for our benefit, even though we'll eventually have to pay out claims. It's like having a big pool of money that we can use to generate investment income, and as our business grows, so does the size of this pool.
What happens when the P/C industry as a whole operates at a significant underwriting loss?

In those cases, the underwriting loss essentially becomes the cost the industry pays to hold its float. Think of it like a fee for being able to use all that money. Usually, this cost is relatively low, but in years with a lot of catastrophes, the cost can be much higher and even outweigh the benefits of having the float.
What has been the growth of Berkshire's float since you entered the insurance business in 1967?
Our float has grown from $16 million in 1967 to $62 billion at the end of 2009. That's a staggering increase, and I'm proud of what our team has accomplished.
How does Berkshire's insurance operation perform compared to the rest of the P/C industry?

To be frank, we've done exceptionally well. We've operated at an underwriting profit for seven consecutive years, which is unusual in this industry. In fact, I've said that the P/C industry as a whole has typically seen premiums that are inadequate to cover claims plus expenses, leading to a lower return on tangible equity compared to the S&P 500. But Berkshire's outstanding managers have made all the difference.
What similarities do you see between BNSF and your electric utilities in terms of their economic characteristics?

I see several key similarities. Both provide essential services that will remain vital to our customers and the nation. Both require significant investments that far exceed depreciation, and both need to plan ahead to meet future demand. It's like building a house - you need a solid foundation, and for us, that means investing in our utilities and railroad to ensure they can support the country's economic growth.
Why do you think it's important for regulators to provide certainty about allowable returns for BNSF and your utilities?

It's quite simple really. If regulators provide certainty about allowable returns, we can confidently make the huge investments needed to maintain, replace, and expand our operations. It's a social compact - we need to know we'll get a fair return on our investments, and in return, we'll provide the essential services the public needs. Without that certainty, it's like trying to build a bridge without knowing if the other side will meet you halfway - it just won't work.
What were the three possible ways to address the housing overhang, and which one did the country choose?

Well, I outlined three ways to cure the housing overhang: blowing up houses, which doesn't sound very practical; speeding up household formations, which is also not very feasible; or reducing new housing starts to below the rate of household formations. Fortunately, our country chose the third option, which I think is the wisest choice. By reducing new housing starts, we're allowing the market to correct itself and get back to a more balanced state.
You mentioned that the burst of the housing bubble has made homes more affordable for some families. Can you elaborate on that?

Yes, that's right. When the bubble burst, prices came down significantly. And that's good news for buyers. Many families that couldn't afford to buy a home a few years ago now find that it's well within their means. It's a simple matter of supply and demand, and when prices are lower, more people can participate in the market. Of course, it's not good news for everyone, especially sellers or lenders who were caught up in the bubble. But for every seller who's hurt, there's a buyer who benefits.
What is the main issue with mortgage rates for factory-built homes compared to site-built homes?

The main issue is the punitive differential in mortgage rates. While buyers of conventional site-built homes can get a 30-year loan at about 5.25%, a meritorious buyer of a factory-built home has to pay about 9% on their loan. That's a significant difference that can negate the attractive price of a factory-built home for those who need financing.
How does the government's role in the residential mortgage market affect factory-built homes?

The government's rules, expressed through FHA, Freddie Mac, and Fannie Mae, shape the residential mortgage market. Since very few factory-built homes qualify for agency-insured mortgages, buyers of these homes are left out of the low-interest loan options that are available to buyers of site-built homes. This makes it tougher for people to afford factory-built homes, even though they might be a great value if you're paying cash.
What was the aggregate cost and carrying value of the non-traded securities you purchased in the last 18 months, and what annual dividends and interest do they provide?

The aggregate cost of those non-traded securities in Dow Chemical, General Electric, Goldman Sachs, Swiss Re, and Wrigley is $21.1 billion, with a carrying value of $26.0 billion. They deliver $2.1 billion annually in dividends and interest to us.

You mentioned that big opportunities come infrequently and used the analogy of reaching for a bucket when it's raining gold. Can you elaborate on what you meant by this in the context of the corporate and municipal bond markets in 2009?

Well, I meant that when exceptional opportunities arise, like they did in the bond markets back in 2009, you should take full advantage of them. Those securities were ridiculously cheap compared to U.S. Treasuries, and I wish I had invested more. It's like when it's raining gold - you don't want to be collecting it with a tiny thimble, you want to grab a big bucket to catch as much as you can.
What was the total amount of cash-equivalents Berkshire Hathaway had at the beginning of 2008, and how did it change by the end of 2009?

We started 2008 with $44.3 billion in cash-equivalents, and by the end of 2009, that amount had decreased to $30.6 billion, with $8 billion of it earmarked for the BNSF acquisition. I like to think of it as reaching for a bucket when it's raining gold - we put a lot of money to work during that time.
Do you expect Berkshire Hathaway's derivatives contracts to be profitable over their lifetime?

While it's no sure thing, I do expect our derivatives contracts to deliver a profit to us over their lifetime. In fact, I've said that even if you exclude the investment income from the float they provide, I still think they'll be profitable in the end.
Who is responsible for monitoring derivatives contracts at Berkshire, and what happens if the company gets into trouble?

I'm the one who initiates and monitors every derivatives contract on our books, except for some operations-related contracts at a few subsidiaries. If Berkshire ever gets in trouble, it will be my fault, not because of some Risk Committee or Chief Risk Officer. I take full responsibility.
What do you think should happen to CEOs and directors of failed financial institutions?

In my view, if their recklessness harms their institutions and the country, they should pay a heavy price - one that can't be reimbursed by the companies they've damaged or by insurance. It's time for their behavior to change, and they should face severe financial consequences for their actions.
What happens when an acquirer's stock is undervalued in an all-stock deal?

Well, it's quite simple really. If the acquirer's stock is undervalued, it's impossible for them to make a sensible deal. They can't exchange an undervalued stock for a fully-valued one without hurting their own shareholders. It's like trying to trade a dollar for 80 cents - it just doesn't add up.
How does an overvalued stock affect the acquirer in an all-stock deal?

Now that's a different story. If the acquirer's stock is overvalued, they can use it to their advantage. It's like having counterfeit money - they can overpay for the acquisition because the market value of their stock is artificially high. And that's exactly what sly promoters do during market bubbles - they issue stock and use it to make deals that might not be so smart in the long run.
What do you think is missing from the discussions investment bankers have with boards about acquisitions?

I think what's missing is a discussion about the true value of what's being given, particularly when it comes to the acquirer's stock. They always seem to focus on the value of what's being bought, but not what's being paid.
How do you suggest boards can get a more balanced view when considering an acquisition that involves issuing stock?

Well, I think one way to do it is to hire a second advisor whose job is to make the case against the acquisition, with their fee contingent on the deal not happening. It's a bit unorthodox, but it could help directors get a more rational discussion. As I always say, 'Don't ask the barber whether you need a haircut.'
What advice do you give regarding the use of advisors when considering an acquisition?

I say, 'Don’t ask the barber whether you need a haircut.' It's a simple reminder that advisors often have a vested interest in the deal going through, so it's wise to be cautious of their advice. In fact, I think it's a good idea for directors to hire a second advisor whose fee is contingent on the deal not happening, to get a more balanced view.
Can you share an example of a time when a company made a poor acquisition decision?

Yes, I recall a story about a bank we owned stock in. The managers, who were otherwise fine people and able bankers, got caught up in the excitement of making a deal after being restricted from acquisitions for decades. They ended up overpaying for a smaller bank, agreeing to a price close to three times book value, just to 'be in the hunt.' My partner Charlie Munger's comment at the time summed it up well: 'Are we supposed to applaud because the dog that fouls our lawn is a Chihuahua rather than a Saint Bernard?' It was a value-destroying deal, and a good example of how companies can make poor decisions when it comes to acquisitions.
What was the state of the credit market by the end of 2008, according to your description?
By the end of 2008, the credit market had become dysfunctional and in important respects, non-functional. It was a bit like a car that won't start - it just wasn't working.
What do you think is a likely consequence of the massive economic action taken by the Treasury and the Fed?

I believe a likely consequence of these actions is an onslaught of inflation. Just like when you take too much medicine, there can be unwelcome aftereffects, and in this case, inflation seems like a probable one.
What do you think will be a likely consequence of the high dosages of Federal assistance?
I believe one likely consequence is an onslaught of inflation. It's a bit like taking a strong medicine - it may cure the immediate problem, but it can also have some nasty side effects.
How do you think America will fare in the face of these challenges?

Well, I'm an optimist. America has faced far worse challenges in the past - two great wars, the Great Depression, and more - and we've always come out on top. Our standard of living has improved nearly seven-fold during the 1900s, and I have no doubt we'll overcome these current obstacles as well.
What are the four main goals that you and Charlie focus on for Berkshire?

We focus on four key goals: maintaining Berkshire's strong financial position, widening the 'moats' around our operating businesses, acquiring and developing new streams of earnings, and expanding our team of outstanding operating managers.
How did Berkshire's businesses perform in 2008, particularly those affected by the economy?

Many of our businesses that are significantly affected by the economy didn't earn up to their potential in 2008, and we expect that to continue in 2009. However, in aggregate, our businesses still earned substantial sums, and most of them, especially the larger ones, continue to strengthen their competitive positions.
What was the performance of your utility business last year, and who are the key managers behind its success?

Our utility business had record earnings last year, and I'm thrilled with its performance. The credit goes to Dave Sokol and Greg Abel, the talented managers who have achieved results that are unmatched in the utility industry. They've done a fantastic job, and I'm excited to see what the future holds for this business.
You mentioned making some investment mistakes in 2008. Can you tell us more about what went wrong?

Well, I'd rather not go into too much detail just yet, but let's just say I made at least one major mistake and several smaller ones that didn't work out as planned. I also made some errors of omission, where I failed to act promptly when new information came in. I'll share more about these mistakes later, but suffice it to say that I learned some valuable lessons from them.
What is the total value of Berkshire's investments, including stocks, bonds, and cash equivalents, at the end of the year?
The total value of our investments, including stocks, bonds, and cash equivalents, was $122 billion at yearend. And let me tell you, that's a pretty big war chest.
How do you and Charlie Munger view price declines in the market, particularly when it comes to the stocks and bonds you already hold?

We actually enjoy such price declines if we have funds available to increase our positions. As my mentor Ben Graham taught me, 'Price is what you pay; value is what you get.' It's like buying quality merchandise when it's on sale - who doesn't love a good bargain?
How has MidAmerican's investment in wind generation contributed to its position in the nation?

Well, I'm proud to say that our $1.8 billion investment in wind generation back in 2008 has paid off. Today, MidAmerican is the number one regulated utility in the nation in terms of wind capacity ownership. It's a great example of how investing for the future can really pay dividends, or in this case, watts.
What is Berkshire's approach to managing the businesses it acquires?

We take a very straightforward approach. We keep our promises, don't load up the businesses with debt, give our managers a lot of autonomy, and stick with them through the good times and the bad. It's a partnership approach, not a 'flipping' mentality. We're in it for the long haul, and our record shows that it works.
What do you think is the main difference between how you approach acquisitions and how private equity firms approach them?

I think the main difference is that we're looking for long-term value and care about the future of the businesses we acquire, whereas private equity firms seem to be focused on short-term gains and 'exit strategies' from the get-go. It's like they're buying merchandise, not a business they intend to nurture.
How do you think Berkshire can be the 'buyer of choice' for regulators in the utility field?

Well, I believe it's because regulators want to see stability and a commitment to the long-term health of the businesses they oversee. Since we're not burdened by the same fee structures and love of leverage as private equity firms, we can offer a more sustainable future for these utilities. It's a straightforward approach, really - we prioritize the well-being of the business over quick profits.
What do regulators consider when evaluating the fitness of purchasers in proposed transactions?

When regulators evaluate the fitness of purchasers, they consider our history and how we've behaved in all aspects of the business, including our willingness to commit adequate equity capital. They don't just take our word for it, either - they'll call their counterparts in other states where we operate to get the full picture.
How has the insurance industry performed in terms of return on net worth compared to the Fortune 500 over the 25 years ending in 2007?

Well, the insurance industry's return on net worth has been a bit of a lagging indicator, averaging 8.5% over those 25 years. That's compared to a 14.0% average for the Fortune 500. So, our insurance CEOs haven't exactly had the wind at their back, but we've still managed to propel Berkshire's growth through their hard work.
What makes General Re stand out from other reinsurers?

General Re stands out because it's backed by an AAA corporation, which is unparalleled in the reinsurance business. As I like to say, quoting Ben Franklin, 'It's difficult for an empty sack to stand upright.' General Re's clients don't have to worry about that - we've got the financial strength to back up our promises.
How did you come to realize Ajit Jain's exceptional talent after he joined Berkshire in 1986?

I realized Ajit's exceptional talent very quickly after he joined us in 1986. His ability to handle huge and unusual risks, combined with his incredible speed of execution, made it clear that he was an extraordinary talent. I was so impressed that I even jokingly asked his parents if they had another one like him at home - of course, I knew the answer would be no, because there isn't anyone like Ajit.
What is the primary reason for foreclosures, according to you?

The primary reason for foreclosures is not because the value of the home has dropped, but because borrowers can't make their monthly payments. It's like trying to carry a load that's just too heavy - if you can't afford the payments, you're going to stumble and fall behind.
What do you think is a key factor in ensuring stability in home purchases and preventing future housing debacles?

I believe that requiring an honest-to-God down payment of at least 10% and carefully verifying the borrower's income to ensure they can comfortably handle the monthly payments is crucial. It's just common sense - if you can't afford the house, you shouldn't be buying it. And lenders should be careful not to put people into homes they can't afford, because that's a recipe for disaster.
Why is Clayton's lending operation threatened despite its borrowers performing well?

It's quite simple really. The credit crisis has created a situation where lenders with government guarantees have extremely low borrowing costs, while highly-rated companies like Berkshire are facing record-high borrowing costs relative to Treasury rates. This uneven playing field makes it unprofitable for us to compete with those who have government backing.
How does Berkshire's creditworthiness impact its borrowing costs in the current environment?

Ironically, our pristine credit doesn't seem to matter much right now. Despite being one of only seven AAA corporations in the country, our cost of borrowing is significantly higher than that of competitors with shaky balance sheets but government guarantees. It's a bit like being a strong, healthy person who can't get a loan, while your neighbor who's on life support can get all the credit they need because they've got a rich uncle backing them up.
What was the main cause of the problems faced by the major players in the bond insurance business by the end of 2007?

The main cause of their problems was that they drifted away from insuring low-risk, tax-exempt bonds and turned to ever-riskier propositions, such as insuring residential mortgage obligations, as competition intensified and rates fell. As Mae West would say, 'I was Snow White, but I drifted.'
What was the nature of Berkshire's offer to the three largest monolines, and how did they respond to it?

We offered to assume all of the insurance issued on tax-exempts that was on their books, which involved taking over guarantees on about $822 billion of bonds for a 1.5% rate. Unfortunately, they rejected our offer, and in some cases, even added an insult or two to their response.
What is the total amount of primary business you've written, and what premium did you receive for it?
We've written $3.7 billion of primary business, for which we received a premium of $96 million. It's a significant amount of business, and I'm pleased with the terms we've negotiated.
You mention that a universe of tax-exempts fully covered by insurance would likely have a different loss experience. Can you elaborate on why you think that's the case?

Well, it's just common sense. When you have a group of bonds that are uninsured, the issuers are more likely to be careful and prudent in their financial dealings. But when you introduce insurance into the mix, it can change the behavior of those issuers. They might take on more risk, knowing they've got a safety net. So, it's reasonable to assume that a fully insured universe of tax-exempts would have a different loss experience than a group of uninsured bonds.
What would have happened if all of New York City's bonds had been insured by Berkshire in 1975, according to your analysis?

If all of New York City's bonds had been insured by Berkshire in 1975, I believe the city would not have received the same level of concessions and cooperation from its bondholders. Instead, we at Berkshire would have been expected to 'share' in the required sacrifices, and given our deep pockets, our contribution would have been substantial.
What is one of the key factors that you think will contribute to local governments' fiscal problems in the future?

I think pension liabilities will be a huge contributor to local governments' fiscal woes in the future. Many cities and states were likely shocked when they reviewed the status of their funding at the end of 2008, and this issue will only continue to grow in importance.
What makes insuring tax-exempt bonds a potentially dangerous business, in your opinion?

I think insuring tax-exempt bonds is a dangerous business because it's similar to insuring natural catastrophes - you can have a string of loss-free years, but then one devastating event can wipe out all your earlier profits. In this case, if a few communities default on their bonds and get away with it, others may follow, leading to correlated losses among issuers.
How do you plan to approach this business given the potential risks?

We plan to proceed carefully, avoiding many classes of bonds that other monolines regularly insure. We don't want to take on unnecessary risk, so we'll be selective about which bonds we choose to insure.
