What's the main issue with using history-based models in finance, according to you?

The main issue is that these models often ignore the fact that the current situation may be very different from the past. It's like trying to navigate a new road using a map from a different city. Just because something worked in the past doesn't mean it'll work now, especially if the circumstances have changed dramatically.
Why should investors be skeptical of models constructed by financial experts using complex terms and formulas?

I think investors should be skeptical because these models can look impressive, but they're only as good as the assumptions behind them. It's easy to get caught up in the jargon and the math, but if you don't understand the assumptions, you're just blindly following a formula. As I said, beware of geeks bearing formulas - make sure you understand what's behind the numbers before you make any decisions.
What was the outcome of your investment in the two Irish banks in 2008?

Well, I'd call it a tennis-style 'unforced error.' We spent $244 million on shares of those two Irish banks, and by the end of the year, we had to write them down to $27 million - that's an 89% loss. And to make matters worse, the stocks have declined even further since then.
Why did you have to sell some of your preferred holdings to fund the large purchases of fixed-income securities?

I had to sell portions of some great holdings, like Johnson & Johnson, Procter & Gamble, and ConocoPhillips, to fund those big purchases. The reason is simple: I've pledged to always keep Berkshire running with more than enough cash on hand. I don't want to rely on others to meet our obligations, so I made the choice to let go of some investments I liked to ensure we've got the cash we need.
What is your approach to risk in investing, and how does it relate to your sleep?

I never want to take on so much risk that I lose sleep over it. In fact, I'd rather not trade even a night's sleep for the chance of extra profits. It's just not worth it to me. I believe in being prudent and not relying on the kindness of strangers to meet my obligations.
Why do you think holding cash equivalents or long-term government bonds at current yields is a bad idea?

Holding cash equivalents or long-term government bonds at present yields is almost certainly a terrible policy if continued for long. The reason is simple: that cash is earning close to nothing and will surely find its purchasing power eroded over time. Just because it might make you feel comfortable or 'smug' in the short term doesn't mean it's a good investment strategy.
What's your view on seeking approval in investing?

I think seeking approval is a bad idea when it comes to investing. It can actually be counter-productive because it makes you less receptive to new information or questioning your earlier conclusions. The goal of investing shouldn't be to get applause, but rather to make smart, informed decisions.
You mentioned that derivatives are dangerous. Can you give an example from your own experience with Berkshire?

Yes, our experience with General Re's derivatives book is a great example. When we acquired the company in 1998, we were faced with a massive, complex book of 23,218 derivatives contracts. To be honest, Charlie and I couldn't even get our minds around it, so we decided to close it down. It took us five years and over $400 million in losses to largely complete the task, which just goes to show how treacherous derivatives can be.
How long did it take you to largely complete the task of closing up shop and how much did it cost in losses?

It took us five years and more than $400 million in losses to largely complete the task. I'd say that's a pretty steep price to pay for getting out of a business, but sometimes that's what it takes to cut your losses and move on.
Do you think improved transparency and regulatory oversight can effectively mitigate the risks associated with derivatives?

No, I don't think so. In fact, I believe that improved transparency won't cure the problems that derivatives pose. The risks in a huge and complex portfolio of derivatives are just too difficult to describe and measure, and auditors and regulators can't effectively audit or regulate these contracts.
Why did the Fed step in to rescue Bear Stearns, according to Tim Geithner's explanation?

Well, as I see it, the Fed stepped in to prevent a financial chain reaction of unpredictable magnitude. In simpler terms, they didn't want Bear's counterparties to suddenly find out their protection against financial risk wasn't working, which would have caused them to scramble and liquidate collateral, making already fragile markets even more unstable.
How do derivatives contracts differ from normal stock or bond trades in terms of settlement and counterparty risk?

That's a great question. You see, with normal stock or bond trades, the deal is done in a few days, and the counterparty risk disappears quickly. But derivatives contracts are a different story - they can go unsettled for years or even decades, with counterparties building up huge claims against each other. It's like a big game of IOU, where the bills don't come due for a long time, but they can still cause a lot of trouble when they do.
Why do large derivatives dealers seem to be assured of government aid if trouble hits?

Well, it's quite simple really. When these large dealers are heavily involved with many other institutions - what I call 'sleeping around' - they become too big to fail. The government can't just let them go under because their problems could infect the entire financial system, causing widespread trouble. It's a bit like having a big, messy web - if one thread breaks, the whole thing could unravel.
Why does Berkshire participate in derivatives contracts despite the potential risks you've outlined?

That's a fair question. You see, we do have 251 derivatives contracts, but it's worth noting that most of those are for operational purposes at MidAmerican or leftovers from Gen Re. I didn't go into details about our specific strategies, but let's just say we're cautious and thoughtful in our approach. The key is to understand what you're getting into and not to overextend yourself.
Why does Berkshire participate in derivatives contracts despite the risks associated with them?
I believe each contract we own was mispriced at inception, sometimes dramatically so. That's why we're a party to these contracts - we think we got a good deal.
What is the current status of Berkshire's derivatives float, and how does it benefit the company?

As of yearend, our derivatives float totaled $8.1 billion. This float is similar to insurance float - if we break even on the underlying transactions, we get to use that money for free for a long time. And if things go as we expect, the investment income we earn on those funds will be a nice bonus.
Why did you record a loss of $631 million on the derivatives contracts at yearend, despite feeling good about the bonds they covered?

That loss was due to mark-to-market accounting, which required us to value those contracts at their current market price at the end of the year. It's a bit like valuing your house every day based on what similar houses in the neighborhood are selling for - the value can fluctuate significantly, even if the actual condition and value of your house haven't changed.
Do you think the Black-Scholes formula is always reliable for valuing equity put options?

While we do use the Black-Scholes formula for financial statement purposes, I believe it has its limitations. If you apply it to extended time periods, it can produce some pretty absurd results. I think Black and Scholes themselves would agree with that assessment.
What is the mathematical expectation of loss on the contract based on your assumptions?

The mathematical expectation of loss on our contract would be $5 million, which is calculated by multiplying the total amount by the probability of decline and the most likely decline amount - $1 billion X 1% X 50%.
Why do you think the Black-Scholes formula is inappropriate for this scenario?

I believe the Black-Scholes formula is inappropriate because it includes volatility, which is determined by short-term stock price movements. This metric is irrelevant when estimating the probability-weighted range of values for American business 100 years from now. It's like using the daily quotes from a manic-depressive neighbor to predict the value of a farm a century later - it just doesn't make sense.
How do the tax costs affect Berkshire's performance compared to the S&P 500 in different market conditions?

Well, it's quite simple really. When the S&P 500 has a positive return, our after-tax numbers would lag behind because we have to pay taxes on those gains. On the other hand, in years when the S&P 500 has a negative return, our after-tax numbers would actually look better because we don't have to pay taxes on losses. Over time, though, those tax costs add up and cause a substantial lag in our performance compared to the S&P 500.
What was the impact of the housing-related issues on our operating businesses last year?

The housing-related issues did cause some setbacks for a few of our businesses, like brick, carpet, and real estate brokerage operations. But I'd call these setbacks minor and temporary. The good news is that our competitive position in these businesses remains strong, and we have top-notch CEOs running them. So, I'm not too worried about these businesses in the long run.
What was the compounded annual gain in per-share investments for the entire 42-year period you're discussing?
For the entire 42 years, our compounded annual gain in per-share investments was 27.1%. That's a pretty impressive number, but I have to caution that it's not a guarantee of future performance.
You mention that Berkshire's past record can't be duplicated or even approached. Why is that?

Well, it's simple: our base of assets and earnings is now far too large for us to make those outsized gains we saw in the past. It's like trying to get a big ship to turn on a dime - it's just not going to happen. We'll do our best to make sure the future is not disappointing, but we can't come close to duplicating the past.
What are the key criteria you and Charlie look for when evaluating companies for potential purchase?

We look for four main things: a business we understand, favorable long-term economics, able and trustworthy management, and a sensible price tag. It's like checking off the boxes on a to-do list - if a company can tick all those boxes, we're interested.
What do you mean by a 'moat' in the context of a business, and why is it important for a company's long-term success?

A 'moat' is a barrier that protects a company's excellent returns on invested capital. Think of it like a castle - if you're earning high returns, competitors will try to storm the castle and take a piece of the action. A moat can be something like being the low-cost producer or having a powerful brand. It's essential because it helps a company sustain its success over time, rather than being a flash in the pan like those 'Roman Candles' I mentioned.
What kind of companies do you tend to rule out based on your investment criteria?

I rule out companies in industries that are prone to rapid and continuous change. You see, a moat that needs to be constantly rebuilt isn't much of a moat at all. It's like trying to hold water in your hands - it just won't work.
Can a business with a great manager still be considered a great business?

No, not if its success depends solely on that manager. A terrific CEO is a huge asset, don't get me wrong, but if the business requires a superstar to produce great results, then the business itself isn't great. I mean, think of a medical partnership led by a top brain surgeon - when the surgeon leaves, the partnership's advantage goes with them.
What was the pre-tax return on invested capital when Berkshire first bought See's, and what factors contributed to minimizing the funds required for operations?

When we first bought See's, the pre-tax return on invested capital was 60%. Two key factors helped keep the funds required for operations low: first, the product was sold for cash, which eliminated accounts receivable; and second, the production and distribution cycle was short, minimizing inventories. It's a great example of how a well-designed business can generate a lot of cash without needing a lot of capital.
How has See's performed since Berkshire's acquisition in terms of sales and pre-tax profits, and what has happened to the capital required to run the business?

See's has done fantastically well since we acquired it. Sales have grown from $30 million to $383 million, and pre-tax profits have jumped from less than $5 million to $82 million. Meanwhile, the capital required to run the business has increased from $8 million to $40 million. But here's the remarkable part: we've only had to reinvest $32 million of See's profits since 1972 to achieve this growth. The rest, $1.35 billion in pre-tax earnings, has been available for us to invest in other opportunities.
What makes a company like See's Candies unusual in terms of its growth and capital requirements?

Well, See's is unusual because it can grow its earnings significantly without needing a proportional amount of capital investment. Typically, companies need to invest a lot of money to finance their growth, but See's has been able to increase its earnings from $5 million to $82 million without requiring a huge amount of capital.
Can you give an example of a company that has good business economics but still requires significant reinvestment of earnings to grow?

Our own FlightSafety is a good example of this. It's a terrific business that delivers huge benefits to its customers and has a durable competitive advantage, but it still needs to reinvest a significant amount of its earnings to grow. Since we purchased it in 1996, we've had to reinvest heavily to keep it going, with depreciation charges totaling $923 million.
What was the outcome of your investment in U.S. Air preferred stock in 1989?

Well, I'd say it was a bit of a rollercoaster. Initially, it seemed like a bad idea - the company went into a tailspin soon after our investment, and our preferred dividend was no longer being paid. But we got lucky, and during one of those bursts of optimism for airlines, we were able to sell our shares in 1998 for a hefty gain. Of course, that gain was just luck, as the company went bankrupt not once, but twice, in the decade following our sale.
You describe three types of 'savings accounts' in terms of their interest rates and requirements for additional deposits. Which one does the airline industry resemble?

The airline industry is a perfect example of the 'gruesome account'. It pays an inadequate interest rate, and to make matters worse, it requires you to keep adding money at those disappointing returns. It's a bottomless pit, and investors have been pouring money into it for years, despite the lack of promising returns.
What was the purchase price you were willing to pay for See's, and what was the seller's initial asking price?
I was adamant about not going above $25 million for See's, while the seller was initially asking for $30 million. Fortunately, the seller caved, and I got a great deal.
How much did the Dallas-Fort Worth NBC station earn in pre-tax income in 2006, and what is its estimated capital value today?

In 2006, the station earned $73 million pre-tax. As for its capital value, it's estimated to be around $800 million today. I have to say, passing on that deal still hurts - it's a great example of an unforced error on my part.
What qualities do you look for in a manager, and how did Susan demonstrate these qualities to become CEO of Borsheims?

I look for brains, passion, and integrity in a manager. Susan demonstrated these qualities by being smart, loving the business, and loving her associates. She didn't have a traditional managerial background, but those qualities are far more important to me than an MBA degree.
What was the significance of Iscar opening a plant in Dalian, China, and how did it impact their operations?

Iscar opening a plant in Dalian, China was significant because it allowed them to move their brains - their expertise and knowledge - closer to the raw material, tungsten, which is mined in China. Instead of shipping tungsten to Israel, they can now process it locally, making their operations more efficient.
How do you evaluate the performance of your investments, such as American Express, Coca-Cola, and Procter & Gamble?

I evaluate their performance in two ways. First, I look at the improvement in their earnings, taking into account the conditions of their industry. Second, I consider whether their competitive advantages, or 'moats,' have widened over the year. It's not about what their market prices do in a given year, but about the fundamental strengths of the businesses themselves.
What was the earnings performance like for your four largest holdings in 2007?

In 2007, three of our four largest holdings - American Express, Coca-Cola, and Procter & Gamble - increased their per-share earnings by 12%, 14%, and 14%, respectively. The fourth, Wells Fargo, had a small decline in earnings due to the real estate bubble bursting, but I believe its intrinsic value still increased, even if only slightly.
How do the accounting rules for your derivative contracts differ from those for your investment portfolio?

The accounting rules differ in that changes in the value of our derivative contracts must be applied each quarter to earnings, whereas changes in value for our investment portfolio only affect earnings if we sell or write down a holding. It's a bit like the difference between getting a daily report card versus one at the end of the semester - one gives you a lot of ups and downs, while the other gives you a more stable view of how you're doing.
Will the large swings in reported earnings from your derivative positions bother you and Charlie Munger?

Not at all. We're focused on the long game, and we're willing to trade some short-term volatility in earnings for greater gains in net worth down the line. As we've seen in our catastrophe insurance business, it's a trade-off we're comfortable making.
How do you and your partner plan to approach the potential $1 billion or more swings in a quarter?

My partner and I won't be losing sleep over these swings. We're willing to trade short-term earnings volatility for long-term gains in net worth, just like in our catastrophe insurance business. It's a philosophy that serves us well in derivatives too.
Has the weakening of the U.S. dollar against major currencies helped reduce the U.S. trade deficit?

Well, the theory is that a falling currency should cure a trade deficit by making our products cheaper for foreigners and their products more expensive for us. And while the large drop in the dollar has undoubtedly tempered our deficit, the numbers don't entirely bear that out. For example, our trade deficits with Germany and Canada actually rose between 2002 and 2007, despite the dollar's decline.
Why do you believe America will continue to produce growing prosperity for its citizens?

I believe America's prosperity will continue because of its strong foundation - the rule of law, a market-responsive economic system, and a belief in meritocracy. These elements create an environment where people can thrive and innovate, and that's a recipe for success.
What is the current status of Berkshire's succession plan for the investment job?

We've made good progress on that front. We've identified four strong candidates who could succeed me in managing investments. All of them have experience managing substantial sums of money and have expressed a strong interest in joining Berkshire. The board is well aware of their strengths, so we're in good shape if the need for a transition arises.
What happened in 1994 regarding the Financial Accounting Standards Board and stock options?

Well, in 1994, the U.S. Senate voted 88-9 to tell the Financial Accounting Standards Board to back off from its plan to make companies record the value of stock options as an expense. The FASB had initially decided that stock options were a form of compensation and should be expensed, but after the Senate's vote, they changed their tune and gave companies a choice: they could either expense the value of the options or ignore the expense if the options were issued at market value.
How did CEOs of S&P 500 companies react to the new accounting guidelines for stock options?

Let's just say they took the low road. Out of the 500 companies in the S&P, only two chose to expense the value of their stock options. The rest decided to ignore the expense, which allowed them to report higher earnings. I think it's pretty clear that many CEOs were more interested in padding their bottom line - and maybe even justifying their own big stock option grants - than in giving investors an honest picture of their company's financials.
What annual return do the equities in the fund need to earn for the fund to achieve an overall return of 8%?
The equities need to earn 9.2% annually for the fund to achieve that 8% overall return, and that's after all fees, which are now higher than they've ever been.
How much would the Dow need to gain by the end of this century to match the 5.3% annual market-value gain of the last century?

To match that 5.3% annual gain, the Dow would need to close at about 2,000,000 on December 31, 2099. That's a staggering number, and it puts into perspective the hype around the Dow crossing certain thresholds – we've got a long way to go.
You mention that commentators hyperventilate when the Dow crosses an even number of thousands. Do you think this reaction is justified, given the historical performance of the market?

I don't think so. A 5.3% annual gain for the century is a reasonable expectation, but it's not something to get overly excited about. As I said, if they keep reacting that way, they'll have a lot of seizures over the next 92 years - 1,986 to be exact. It's just not a likely outcome that the market will be that volatile.
You discuss the role of 'helpers' in the investment process, such as consultants and high-priced managers. How do you think their involvement affects the average investor's returns?

Well, I think it's simple math. The helper-aided group, as a whole, must be below average because they incur high costs that diminish their returns. Meanwhile, the passive and index investors, who don't have those high costs, will earn the average return minus very low costs. That means the passive group will come out on top, not because they're geniuses, but because they're not paying all those extra fees.
Why do CEOs opt for high investment assumptions in their reporting?

I believe CEOs opt for high investment assumptions because it allows them to report higher earnings. It's a way for them to look good in the short term, even if it's not entirely realistic. And if they're wrong, the consequences won't come back to haunt them until long after they're gone.
What's the problem with public pension promises in the United States?

The problem with public pension promises is that they're huge and often woefully underfunded. Politicians make promises that are easy to keep in the short term, like early retirement and generous cost-of-living adjustments, but they'll be very difficult to keep in the long term, especially with people living longer and inflation being a certainty.
How do you estimate loss reserves for Berkshire's insurance units, and what challenges do you face in making these estimates accurate?

Well, we do our best to make these guesses accurate by putting a dollar value on each known loss event, including associated costs like attorney's fees. However, it's a tough task because we're dealing with a huge number of events, some of which we haven't even heard about yet, and payments can stretch out for 50 years or more. It's a bit like trying to predict the weather decades in advance.
Can you give an example of a situation where it might take a long time to discover a loss, and how that affects your estimation process?

Think of an embezzlement that remains undiscovered for years. We have to include a large reserve for losses like that, which we haven't yet heard about. It's a challenge because we can't just wait for all the facts to come in - we have to make an educated guess based on our experience and data. And sometimes, we'll hear about losses from policies that covered our insured many decades ago, which just adds to the complexity.
What kind of challenge do you face in estimating loss liability at your insurance companies?

We face the challenge of dealing with what I call 'rented suits' - old policies from many decades ago where we can't accurately estimate the total cost. It's like trying to predict the total bill for a funeral without knowing all the expenses upfront. We make our best guess, but even that's subject to surprises down the line.
Do you think your current reserves are adequate to cover these potential losses?

Personally, I believe our stated reserves are adequate, but I've been wrong before. It's a tough prediction to make, and we won't really know how accurate our guesses are until 10 or 20 years from now.
How much did GEICO spend on ads last year, and how has this amount changed over time?

Last year, GEICO spent $631 million on ads. To put that into perspective, this is up from $238 million in 2003 and a significant jump from $31 million in 1995, when Berkshire took control. It's been a remarkable increase, and we're committed to continuing this investment in advertising.
What's your perspective on the challenges of managing large organizations, and how does this relate to Berkshire's own growth?

Well, I've always been a bit skeptical about the ability of big entities to function well. Charlie Munger, my partner, and I have seen how size can make organizations slow-thinking, resistant to change, and even a bit smug. As Berkshire has grown to have 217,000 employees and nearly $100 billion in annual revenues, we've tried to stay mindful of these pitfalls. It's a challenge, but we're committed to staying agile and focused, even as we've become one of the larger players in the business world.
What was the outcome of your meeting with Eitan, Jacob, and Danny Goldman in Omaha, and how did it influence your decision to purchase ISCAR?

After spending a few hours with Eitan, Jacob, and Danny, I was convinced that they were extraordinarily talented managers who could be trusted to run the business. This meeting played a significant role in my decision to purchase 80% of ISCAR for $4 billion, as it gave me confidence in their ability to lead the company effectively.
What is the nature of ISCAR's business, and how do their products contribute to their customers' success?

ISCAR's business is quite straightforward - they produce small, consumable cutting tools used with large machine tools. The magic happens because of the talented people running the company, who continually develop tools that make their customers' machines more productive. Essentially, ISCAR makes money by helping its customers make more money, which is a recipe for continued success.
What kind of businesses has Fruit of Berkshire acquired recently and what impact do these acquisitions have on the company's sales and employee count?

Fruit has recently acquired Russell Corp., a leading producer of athletic apparel and uniforms, and the intimate apparel business of VF Corp. These acquisitions add about $2.2 billion to our sales and bring in around 23,000 new employees. It's a significant expansion, and I'm excited to have these new teams on board.
What kind of acquisitions is Berkshire focusing on, and why?

Charlie and I are focusing on the big ones - what we call 'elephants'. We need large acquisitions to make a dent in Berkshire's substantial cash flow. It's like the story of the two men searching for their wives in the grocery store; we're not looking for just anyone, we're looking for the 'gorgeous blonde' - the big, game-changing deals that will drive significant growth for our company.
What are your expectations for the insurance industry in 2007, specifically regarding the results from the bread-and-butter lines of insurance?

I expect our results from the bread-and-butter lines of insurance to deteriorate in 2007, though I think they will remain satisfactory. It's the super-cat insurance that's the big unknown, and that's where I see potential for significant impact.
How much are you willing to lose in a single event if you've been paid appropriately for assuming that risk?

We remain prepared to lose $6 billion in a single event, as long as we've been paid appropriately for assuming that risk. That's the key - we're not afraid of risk, but we do want to be compensated fairly for taking it on.
How do you approach risk in your business, particularly in terms of potential losses?

I approach risk by being prepared to lose a significant amount if the price is right. For instance, we're willing to lose $6 billion in a single event if we've been adequately compensated for taking on that risk. It's all about appropriate pricing - if the price reflects our evaluation of loss probabilities, we're in. But if it doesn't, we're out, no matter how small the exposure might be.
What led to your decision to sharply reduce wind exposures in the super-cat field?

We reduced our wind exposures because rates have fallen due to a flood of capital entering the super-cat field. It's a simple principle: be fearful when others are greedy, and be greedy when others are fearful. Right now, others are being greedy, so we're being cautious. It's the same behavior we use in financial markets - we don't want to take on risk at prices that don't make sense for us.
What was the primary source of information for the American public for most of the 20th Century?
That was newspapers, hands down. They were the go-to source for everything from sports and finance to politics.
In your 1991 letter to shareholders, what did you predict about the future of media businesses?
I said they would prove considerably less marvelous than many of us thought at the time. I knew the insulated world of newspapers was changing, and I wasn't optimistic about their future prospects.
What is the difference between 'real trade' and 'pseudo-trade' according to your perspective?

To me, real trade is when we exchange goods or services for other goods or services - it's a fair swap. On the other hand, pseudo-trade is when we import goods or services without exporting anything in return. It's like buying something on credit without having the money to pay for it.
What consequence of the U.S. spending binge did you predict last year that has now come true?

I predicted that the 'investment income' account of our country would turn negative, meaning foreigners would earn more on their U.S. investments than we do on our investments abroad. Unfortunately, that's exactly what happened in 2006. It's a sign that we've been living beyond our means and now we're paying the price.
What criteria do you and Charlie Munger look for when selecting a new director for the board?
We look for someone who is owner-oriented, business-savvy, interested, and truly independent. It's essential that our directors think like intelligent owners and can faithfully represent them.
Why do you think director compensation has increased significantly in recent years?

I believe it's because consultants, like the ones from Ratchet, Ratchet and Bingo, have been pushing for higher compensation packages. It's created a situation where some directors rely too heavily on these fees, which can compromise their independence.
How many employees does Berkshire have at its World Headquarters, and what is the total size of the space they occupy?

We have 19 employees at World Headquarters, and they occupy a total of 9,708 square feet of space. And if you include Charlie's space at World Headquarters West in Los Angeles, that adds another 655 square feet.
Can you give an example from your experience of how executives' financial behavior changes when they're spending their own money versus someone else's?

Well, let me tell you about Jimmy, the barber at Salomon. When the top brass had free haircuts, one executive would get a haircut every week. But when they had to start paying for it themselves, that executive suddenly decided he only needed a haircut every three weeks. It's a funny thing how the wallet can change one's perspective on what's necessary.
How do you and Charlie plan to price Berkshire's shares in relation to its intrinsic value?

Charlie and I aim to keep Berkshire's share price as close as possible to its intrinsic value, avoiding large discounts or premiums. We believe this approach will ultimately benefit our shareholders over time.
What's an example of how unrealistic expectations about investment returns can lead to poor decision-making, according to your allegory about the Gotrocks family?

Well, take private and public pension plans, for instance. They sometimes use overly optimistic investment assumptions to temporarily boost their earnings or delay tax increases. It's a bit like counting chickens before they hatch – and it can take decades for the truth to come out, by which time those responsible are long gone.
How does the 2-and-20 crowd's fee system work, and what's an example of how it affects investors?

Well, let me tell you - the 2-and-20 system is quite straightforward, but not exactly investor-friendly. Essentially, the manager takes 2% of your principal every year, no matter how they perform. And if they do happen to make a profit, they take 20% of that too. For instance, if a manager achieves a 10% gross return, they'd take 2% off the top and then 20% of the remaining 8%, leaving the investor with just 6.4%. It's a pretty lopsided deal, if you ask me.
Can you explain why you call the promise of above-average investment performance the 'adult version of Lake Woebegon'?

Ha! Yes, I call it that because, just like in Lake Woebegon where all the children are above average, the Wall Street crowd promises that everyone can achieve above-average performance. It's a statistical impossibility, of course, but they keep selling this dream to investors, and it's just not realistic. It's a fancy way of saying that someone's got to be below average, but nobody wants to hear that.
What is the main issue with the 2-and-20 arrangement, in your opinion?

The main issue is that it's a mathematically losing proposition for the investor, like the Gotrocks family. It's a deal where the people with experience, the 'hyper-helpers,' end up with the money, and the people with money end up with the experience - and not the good kind, if you know what I mean.
Can you describe Walter Schloss's investment approach, as you've observed it?

Walter's approach is straightforward and based on simple statistical methods he learned from Ben Graham. He doesn't rely on inside information or even much outside information. He and his son Edwin have kept things remarkably simple over the years, with minimal staff and overhead. It's a testament to the fact that you don't need a lot of bells and whistles to be a successful investor.
What was Walter's basic approach to selecting securities, and how did it differ from more complex investment strategies?

Walter's approach was pretty straightforward - he used simple statistical methods learned from Ben Graham to select securities. He didn't rely on fancy stuff like Modern Portfolio Theory, technical analysis, or complex algorithms. As Edwin put it, 'We try to buy stocks cheap.' That's it. And you know what? It worked beautifully for him over 47 years.
Did Walter's success come from just a few big winners, and could his results have been due to chance?

No, Walter's success wasn't just about hitting a few home runs. He invested in about 1,000 securities, mostly of a lackluster type, and still managed to dramatically surpass the S&P 500. And as for chance, I just don't buy it. If millions of investment managers had mimicked his trades, the luckiest of them wouldn't have come close to his record. There's no way his results over 47 years were due to luck.
What was the typical reaction of business schools teaching efficient market theory when they were presented with evidence that contradicted it, such as Walter's performance?

Well, I'd say they reacted in a pretty human way - they closed their eyes to the new evidence. Instead of studying Walter's performance and what it meant for their theory, they just kept on teaching efficient market theory as if it were gospel truth.
How did the widespread teaching of efficient market theory affect the investing landscape, according to your perspective?

It made my friend Walter's job a lot easier, that's for sure. If everyone else is taught that the price of every stock is always 'right' and that trying to evaluate businesses is useless, that's like telling all the other ships in the shipping business that the earth is flat. It gives you a nice advantage, let me tell you.
How has the task of calculating Berkshire's intrinsic value changed over time?

Well, let me tell you, it's gone from a snap to a much more complex job. Back in 1965, we were a simple textile operation, but now we've got 68 distinct businesses with all sorts of different characteristics. That makes it a lot tougher to figure out our intrinsic value just by looking at our financial statements.
What have you done to help make it easier for people to estimate Berkshire's intrinsic value?

We've tried to simplify things by grouping our businesses into four logical categories. We'll be discussing each of these groups later in the report, along with some key figures for each one. This should give our investors a better sense of what's going on, even if it's still not a perfect solution.
What was the compound growth rate of Berkshire's marketable securities from 1965 to 2005?
The compound growth rate of our marketable securities from 1965 to 2005 was 20.3% - no, just kidding, it was actually 28.0%. I'm glad I could give you the real number, not some made-up figure.
You mentioned being suspicious of growth rates and the years selected for calculation. Can you explain why the base year of 1965 was significant in the context of Berkshire's earnings growth?

Well, I brought up 1965 because it was actually an abnormally good year for Berkshire. We earned more money that year than in all but one of the previous ten years. So, if someone were to calculate our growth rate starting from 1965, they should keep in mind that the base year was already a high point, which can make the subsequent growth look a bit more modest than it really is.
Why do you and Charlie Munger want to increase the figures in both tables?

We want to increase those figures because, simply put, we're not satisfied with modest growth. Our current businesses will deliver some growth in operating earnings, but it won't be enough to truly impress. We need major acquisitions to really move the needle, and that's what we're aiming for.
What was significant about the base year of 1965 for Berkshire?

The base year of 1965 was significant because Berkshire earned more money that year than in all but one of the previous ten years. It was an abnormally good year, which is important to keep in mind when looking at our growth rates.
What was unique about the financing of the recent acquisitions you agreed to?

None of the deals involved the issuance of Berkshire shares. I think that's a crucial point, often overlooked. When you acquire a company using stock, the shareholders of the acquirer are essentially selling part of their interest in everything they own.
What do you believe will contribute to MedPro's success as part of Berkshire?

I think MedPro has a few things going for it. First, it will have the same underwriting discipline that all Berkshire insurers share - that means we prioritize sound underwriting over all other goals. Additionally, as part of Berkshire, MedPro will have financial strength that far exceeds its competitors, which is a big comfort for the doctors it insures. And lastly, it has a great CEO, Tim Kenesey, who thinks like a Berkshire manager.
What is the total amount that Berkshire will use to complete the purchase of MidAmerican's common stock?
The total amount is $5.1 billion, which is made up of $3.4 billion that Berkshire will buy of MidAmerican's common stock and $1.7 billion of borrowing by MidAmerican.
Do you have an exit strategy for the businesses you acquire?

No, we don't have an exit strategy. At Berkshire, we buy to keep. Instead, we focus on having an entrance strategy, looking for businesses that meet our six criteria and are available at a price that will produce a reasonable return.
How many contracts were outstanding at the start of 2005, and how many were left after reducing the inventory last year?

At the start of 2005, we had 2,890 contracts outstanding. After reducing our inventory last year, we were down to 741 contracts. It's been a long and costly process to unwind these derivatives, I might add.
What was the original rationale for establishing the derivatives unit at Gen Re in 1990?

The original rationale for establishing the derivatives unit at Gen Re was to meet the needs of our insurance clients. It's ironic, isn't it, that one of the contracts we liquidated had a term of 100 years? I'm not sure what kind of 'need' that would fulfill, except maybe the need for a trader to justify their compensation.
What was the main reason you didn't immediately close down Gen Re's trading operation after purchasing the company?

I have to admit, I was trying to find a way to exit the business painlessly, which was a mistake. I thought we could sell the operation, but it was a doomed endeavor due to the complex liabilities involved. I should have acted sooner and not wasted several years trying to find a solution that wasn't there.
Why do you share your experiences with problems like the Gen Re trading operation?

I share our experiences in the hope that they can serve as a warning to other managers, auditors, and regulators. We're like a canary in a coal mine, and our story can be instructive, especially given the growing number and value of derivative contracts in the world. By sharing our mistakes, I hope others can learn from them and avoid similar problems.
What happened to Chuck after his 34-year tenure at See's?

Well, Chuck turned the reins over to Brad Kinstler at the end of the year, so he's no longer running the show at See's. I'm hoping he and his wife Donna will join us at the annual meeting, though, so we can give him a well-deserved round of applause.
What do you mean by 'widening the moat' in the context of your businesses?

Widening the moat is just a fancy way of saying we're making our businesses stronger and more competitive over time. It's like building a bigger, deeper moat around a castle - it makes it harder for others to cross and easier for us to defend our position. We do this by delighting customers, cutting unnecessary costs, and improving our products and services, day by day.
What happens when a management prioritizes short-term earnings targets over long-term goals?

Well, let me tell you, it's a recipe for disaster. If a management makes bad decisions to hit short-term targets, they'll likely end up behind the eight-ball in terms of costs, customer satisfaction, or brand strength. And no amount of brilliance later on can overcome the damage that's been done. It's like trying to fix a broken bridge - sometimes, the damage is just too great.
What is the approach of your managers in terms of widening the moat and how does it contribute to the company's success?

Our managers are passionate about their businesses and focus on widening the moat. They're brilliant at it because they're not just managers, they're owners who have been running these businesses for a long time. We just stay out of their way and let them do what they do best. It's a simple approach, but it works. And I think that's why we've been successful - we've got the right people in charge, and we give them the freedom to make the right decisions.
What is your expectation for the growth of per-share earnings of the companies in question over the next decade?

I expect their per-share earnings to grow 6-8% per year over the decade, and I think their stock prices will more or less match that growth. Of course, their managers think I'm being too modest, and I hope they're right!
What changes did Jim Kilts bring to Gillette after becoming CEO in 2001?

Jim Kilts brought fiscal discipline, tightened operations, and energized marketing to Gillette after taking office in 2001. These moves dramatically increased the intrinsic value of the company, which is a testament to the importance of having the right CEO at the helm.
What is the current trend in executive compensation, according to your observation?

Well, it seems that nothing succeeds like failure in the executive suite these days. CEOs can receive huge severance payments and lavish perks, even for ho-hum performance, because compensation committees are too focused on comparative data and keeping up with what other CEOs are getting.
How do you think compensation committees should approach determining CEO pay, based on the example you provided?

I think they should take a page out of Hank Greenberg's book - a pay-for-performance approach. When deciding on pay, they should ask themselves, 'What did the CEO actually achieve?' - just like Hank asked about the outfielder's batting average. It's that simple.
What is the main reason you attribute the huge rise in American businesses over the past century?
I attribute this huge rise to the simple fact that American businesses did extraordinarily well, and investors were able to ride the wave of their prosperity.
Can investors as a whole earn more than the businesses they own, or are there limitations to their potential earnings?

No, investors as a whole cannot earn more than their businesses earn. In fact, owners must earn less than their businesses because of 'frictional' costs. It's like trying to get water from a well - you can't get more water out than what's actually in the well, and if you try to take some out, someone else has to put it back in.
How does the introduction of Helpers affect the Gotrocks family's wealth?

Well, let me tell you - the Helpers don't come cheap. When they start handling all these transactions for the family, the family's annual gain in wealth takes a hit. Essentially, their earnings get reduced by the commissions they pay to these Helpers. The more the family members trade, the smaller their slice of the pie and the larger the slice the Helpers get to enjoy.
What is the annual amount earned by the Gotrocks family from their corporations before any costs are incurred?

That's an easy one - it's about $700 billion annually. That's the amount the family would get to keep and compound for their benefit if they didn't have all these extra costs eating into their earnings.
What motivates broker-Helpers to encourage activity among the Gotrocks family members?

Well, it's quite simple really. Activity is their friend because it generates more business for them. The more the family members trade, the more commissions the broker-Helpers earn. It's a pretty straightforward arrangement, but not necessarily a beneficial one for the Gotrocks family.
How do the Gotrocks family members eventually feel about their financial situation after hiring various classes of Helpers?

They sink into despair, to be frank. Despite hiring broker-Helpers, manager-Helpers, and eventually consultant-Helpers, their financial results only seem to get worse. It's a bit like trying to find your way out of a maze by hiring more people to navigate it for you - sometimes, all you end up with is a bigger bill and more confusion.
What is the proposed solution by the hyper-Helpers to improve the Gotrocks' unsatisfactory results?

The hyper-Helpers say the solution is simple: pay more money. They claim that huge contingent payments, on top of stiff fixed fees, are necessary for the Gotrocks to really outmaneuver their relatives.
How do the hyper-Helpers justify their expensive profit arrangements, where they receive large portions of the winnings but leave family members with losses and fixed fees?

Well, they don't really justify it in a sensible way, if you ask me. They just assure the Gotrocks that their new uniforms and sexy names, like HEDGE FUND or PRIVATE EQUITY, give them magical powers - kind of like Superman's costume. It's a pretty thin explanation, if you ask me.
What percentage of the earnings of American business do you estimate is lost to frictional costs, such as paying Helpers?
I believe the frictional costs of all sorts may well amount to 20% of the earnings of American business. That's a significant burden on investors, if you ask me.
What was the annual compound gain of the Dow in the 20th century?
The Dow increased from 65.73 to 11,497.12 in the 20th century, which works out to a gain of 5.3% compounded annually. Not bad, if I do say so myself.
What was the annual compound gain of the Dow in the 20th century?
The Dow's annual compound gain in the 20th century was 5.3%. That's a pretty impressive run, if I do say so myself.
Under what circumstances do I consider using debt at Berkshire?

I'm not a fan of debt, but there are a few exceptions. We use it for certain short-term investing strategies involving super-liquid U.S. government securities, and we also borrow against portfolios of interest-bearing receivables when we understand the risk. That's about it - we're pretty conservative when it comes to taking on debt.
What will happen to Berkshire's operations if you were to pass away suddenly?

I'm pleased to say that our operations won't miss a beat. Most of our businesses have strong market positions, significant momentum, and terrific managers. Plus, our special Berkshire culture is deeply ingrained throughout our subsidiaries, so they'll continue to run smoothly.
How will the new CEO handle the investment side of the business, given that none of the current candidates have your crossover experience?

That's a great question. The new CEO will have no problem hiring a talented individual to handle marketable securities, which is an interesting job at Berkshire. We've done something similar at GEICO for 26 years with terrific results, so I'm confident it will work out well.
How does the tax treatment of Berkshire's results compare to the S&P 500, and what impact does this have on performance in different market conditions?

The S&P 500 numbers are pre-tax, whereas Berkshire's numbers are after-tax. This means if we simply owned the S&P 500 and paid the appropriate taxes, our results would lag the S&P in good years but exceed it in bad years. Over time, those tax costs add up and cause a substantial lag.
What is the relationship between book value and intrinsic value at Berkshire, and how have they changed over the 40 years since you took over?

Book value and intrinsic value are related but distinct. Our book value has grown at a 21.9% annual rate over 40 years, from $19 to $55,824 per share. However, intrinsic value, which is what really counts, has grown even more. We've transformed from a struggling textile business to a diversified enterprise worth more than our book value, so our intrinsic value gain has somewhat exceeded the book value increase.
Why do you consider the yearly calculations of book value at Berkshire to be 'slightly understated' as a gauge for measuring the long-term rate of increase in intrinsic value?

I consider the yearly calculations of book value to be slightly understated because, while they provide a useful measure, they don't fully capture the complexities of our intrinsic value. It's like trying to measure the size of a room by just looking at the door - you get an idea, but not the whole picture.
How does the shift in the composition of Berkshire's net worth, with equity holdings now being less than 50%, affect your performance compared to the S&P 500 index?

Well, it's simple: with less of our net worth tied up in equities, the stock market's ups and downs affect us less. Think of it like a ship that's less exposed to the waves. In years when the market soars, we might underperform, and in years when it tanks, we might overperform. But at the end of the day, our long-term performance against the S&P is what really matters.
What approach do you recommend for individuals trying to time their participation in equities?
I advise them to be fearful when others are greedy and greedy only when others are fearful. It's a simple yet effective strategy that can help them make informed decisions.
What is the significance of MidAmerican Energy Holdings to Berkshire, and what are some of its notable operations?

MidAmerican Energy Holdings is a significant part of Berkshire, with us holding an 80.5% interest. It owns a variety of utility operations, including Yorkshire Electricity and Northern Electric, which is the third largest distributor of electricity in the U.K., as well as MidAmerican Energy, which serves nearly 700,000 electric customers in Iowa.
What lesson did you learn from the zinc recovery project, and how do you apply it to your investments and operations?

Well, I learned that it's crucial to stick with simple propositions. When you have multiple variables that need to break in your favor, the chances of success decrease dramatically. In the case of the zinc project, we solved most of the problems, but one proved insurmountable. It's like a chain - it's only as strong as its weakest link. So, we look for investments and operations where the variables are fewer and more controllable. It's just common sense, but it's easy to get caught up in the excitement of a potential opportunity and overlook the complexities.
How many brokers do you employ through your 17 brokerage firms, and in how many states do they operate?

We employ more than 18,000 brokers through our 17 brokerage firms, and they operate in 18 states. It's a significant presence, and we're proud to have such a large and talented team serving our clients across the country.
What factors contribute to the high lifetime cost of adding a new employee, according to the text?

Well, it's not just the salary. When you factor in raises, benefits, and other expenses, the cost adds up quickly. As the text says, 'more people, more toilet paper' - it's a humorous way of looking at it, but it's true. All those extras can turn a seemingly small addition into a $3 million decision over time.
What is Don Wurster's approach to managing NICO, and how does it relate to the current market conditions?

Don's approach is to be disciplined and patient, much like a baseball player who'd rather take a walk than swing at a bad pitch. He's not chasing growth for its own sake, especially when insurance prices are falling. In fact, as NICO's volume declines, I'll be applauding him even more - he's making smart, long-term decisions that will pay off in the end, like amassing $950 million of negative-cost float.
What is the significance of Don amassing $950 million of float at NICO, and how will its volume be affected by falling insurance prices?

The $950 million of float at NICO is significant because it's likely to be the negative-cost kind, meaning it will ultimately benefit our business. As for the volume, it will soon decline very significantly due to falling insurance prices, but Charlie and I will actually applaud Don more loudly as this happens.
How did State Farm manage to capture about 25% of the personal lines business, and what was the key to its success?

State Farm's success can be attributed to its low-cost structure, which was achieved by employing a captive agency force. This approach kept its acquisition costs lower than those of the traditional bureau insurers, allowing State Farm to offer competitive prices and eventually outdistance its competitors.
What was the state of GEICO in 1976 and how did Jack Byrne contribute to its recovery?

In 1976, GEICO was on the brink of failure due to under-reserving for losses and inadequate pricing. Jack Byrne, who joined as CEO, made heroic efforts to save the company, including implementing major price increases. Though this led to a loss of policyholders, his actions were crucial in preventing the company's collapse.
How has GEICO performed under Tony Nicely's leadership, and what benefits has it delivered to its constituents?

Under Tony Nicely's leadership, GEICO has seen significant growth and profitability. By 2005, we expect to secure a 6% market share. More importantly, GEICO has delivered major benefits to all its constituents: our customers saved around $1 billion in 2004, our associates earned a $191 million profit-sharing bonus, and as the owner, we've enjoyed excellent financial returns.
What is the largest insured loss to date, and how does it compare to the potential loss of a mega-catastrophe?

The largest insured loss to date is the World Trade Center disaster, which cost the insurance industry an estimated $35 billion. However, I believe a $100 billion event, or even a larger catastrophe, remains a possibility if a particularly severe earthquake or hurricane hits just the wrong place.
How would Berkshire's financials be affected if a $100 billion industry loss were to occur?

If a $100 billion industry loss were to occur, our share of the loss would probably be 3% to 5%. But I'm confident that earnings from our investments and other businesses would comfortably exceed that cost, so when 'the day after' arrives, Berkshire's checks will clear.
What challenges have you faced in winding down Gen Re Securities, and how many contracts were still outstanding at the end of the year?

Well, getting out of the derivative operation has been easier said than done, kind of like trying to leave a bad habit behind. We started this process three years ago, but as of the end of the year, we still had 2,890 contracts outstanding, down from a peak of 23,218. It's a slow and tricky process, especially when you're dealing with instruments that are supposed to be liquid but don't always behave that way.

You mention that rapid growth can sometimes mask underlying problems in financial institutions. Can you elaborate on what you mean by this, and how does it relate to the real test of a derivatives operation's earning power?

Think of it like a tide coming in - it can make everyone look like a great swimmer. But when the tide goes out, you find out who's been swimming naked, meaning who's been hiding problems. For a derivatives operation, the real test isn't when it's growing rapidly, because that can cover up a lot of sins. The real test is when it's operating in a no-growth mode, over an extended period. That's when you see what it's truly capable of earning, without the mask of rapid expansion.
What was your initial opinion about opening the first Las Vegas store, and how did it perform?

I have to admit, I thought opening the first Las Vegas store was a mistake. I was concerned that our closed-on-Sunday policy would be a turn-off for customers who were used to shopping seven days a week. But, as it often does, the market proved me wrong. The store immediately became our number one unit, which was a resounding answer to my doubts.
How did the second Las Vegas store perform, despite your initial concerns about cannibalizing sales from the first store?

Well, I was wrong again. The second Las Vegas store not only didn't cannibalize sales from the first store, but both stores are now doing about 26% more volume than any other store in the chain. They're consistently showing large year-over-year gains, which is a great testament to the team's ability to execute and prove me wrong - again.
How do you typically find out about Lou's investment transactions?

I typically learn of Lou's transactions about ten days after the end of each month. Charlie and I give him a lot of autonomy, just like our operating managers, so I don't get informed about his decisions beforehand.
Why did Berkshire start investing in foreign currencies in 2002?

We started investing in foreign currencies because we believe our country's trade policies will put pressure on the dollar for many years to come. It's not that I doubt America's strength - we're the richest country in the world with a fantastic economy - but our trade practices are a concern for the dollar's value.
What is your view on true trade, which involves the exchange of goods and services with other countries?
I believe true trade is enormously beneficial for both the US and other countries. In fact, last year we had $1.15 trillion of such honest-to-God trade, and I think the more of this, the better.
What happens as a result of the US purchasing a significant amount of goods and services from the rest of the world without reciprocation?

The balancing item to this one-way pseudo-trade is a transfer of wealth from the US to the rest of the world. In other words, when we buy $618 billion more from other countries than they buy from us, it means we're essentially transferring wealth to them.
Why do you think the world won't tolerate the U.S. spendthrift behavior indefinitely?

Well, it's just common sense - no one likes a freeloader, and the world knows we're living beyond our means. Just like an individual, a country can't keep spending more than it earns without eventually facing the music. The world's patience won't last forever, and I think they'll eventually call us on it.
What's your recommendation for people who want to stay informed about trade and currency matters?

If you want to stay up-to-date on trade and currency, I highly recommend reading The Financial Times. Their reporting and commentary are top-notch, and they've been the go-to source for international financial news for a long time. They've even got an excellent American edition now, so it's easy to stay informed.

Why do you think following the conventional approach of leaving all of Berkshire's assets in dollars, even if they decline in value, would not draw criticism, while your current foreign-exchange commitment might?

Well, as I said, it's a bit like the lemming situation. If everyone else is doing something, even if it's not the best approach, it's harder to criticize an individual for following the crowd. In this case, if we just stuck with dollars and didn't try to manage our currency risk, we'd be doing what a lot of others do, and our mistake would be less visible. But by taking a different path, we're more likely to be noticed and criticized if we're wrong.
What inspired universities to start sending their students to visit you in Omaha, and which universities will be visiting this year?

It all started when Al Auxier, a professor from the University of Tennessee, brought his finance students to Omaha for a tour and Q&A session. They were involved in our acquisition of Clayton Homes, and I think they had a pretty positive experience. Word must have gotten around, because now we've got a whole list of universities sending their students to visit us. This year, we'll be hosting classes from schools like Chicago, Dartmouth, Stanford, and many more - a total of 20 universities, ranging in size from 30 to 100 students.
What are the two post-bubble governance reforms that you've found particularly useful at Berkshire?

I've found two reforms to be especially useful: regular meetings of directors without the CEO present, which helps ensure that dubious plans get thoroughly examined, and the 'whistleblower line,' which allows employees to report issues to me and the audit committee without fear of reprisal.
How do you think the implementation of a whistleblower line earlier on would have impacted Berkshire's value?

I believe Berkshire would be more valuable today if I had put in a whistleblower line decades ago. It's helped me catch important problems at our subsidiaries that I otherwise would have missed, and I think it would have made a significant difference over time.
Why do you often get assigned to the audit committee?

Well, it's quite simple really. Since directors must be assigned to one committee or another, and no CEO wants me on their compensation committee, I usually end up on the audit committee. I guess you could say I'm not their first choice for deciding on their pay!
How do you respond to concerns about your independence on the board due to Berkshire's business dealings with Coke?

I think it's pretty straightforward. Just because Berkshire's companies, like McLane and Dairy Queen, buy a lot of Coke products, it doesn't mean I'm not independent. My focus is on the well-being of Coke's shareholders, and with Berkshire holding $8 billion of Coke stock, that's a pretty strong incentive for me to make decisions in their best interest. As the saying goes, 'where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.'
What is your view on how director independence is affected by the fees they receive for board service?

In my view, directors who receive a significant fraction of their annual income from board fees are likely to be the least independent. It's just human nature - they wouldn't want to rock the boat and risk losing their livelihood. It's ironic that these are often the ones classified as 'independent'.
Can you describe the biblical standard you mentioned in relation to Berkshire's board of directors?

The biblical standard I mentioned refers to the idea that 'where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.' At Berkshire, our board members have a significant amount of their own 'treasure' - at least $4 million in stock - invested in the company. This aligns their interests with those of our shareholders, and I believe it makes a big difference in their decision-making.
What was unusual about the non-management directors' behavior regarding the acquisition proposal and their own stock purchases?

Well, it's quite simple really. These directors didn't want shareholders to have the opportunity to consider an acquisition offer, even though they themselves had passed on buying the stock at a much lower price. It's a bit like turning down a steak dinner at $10 and then not wanting to let others know about a $20 offer for the same steak.
How might the potential acquisition have affected the non-management directors financially?

If the deal had gone through, those directors would have lost their annual board and committee fees, which were around $100,000. That's a significant amount of money, and it's clear that for some of them, this 'treasure' was a big part of their income.
How do the tax costs affect Berkshire's performance compared to the S&P 500?

Well, it's quite simple really. If we had just owned the S&P 500 and paid the appropriate taxes, our results would have lagged behind the S&P in good years, but done better in bad years. Over time, those tax costs add up and cause a substantial lag. It's like trying to run a race with a weight on your back - it's just harder to keep up.
What has been the growth rate of Berkshire's per-share book value since you took over?

Since I took the reins 39 years ago, our per-share book value has grown from $19 to $50,498, which works out to a 22.2% annual compound rate. Not bad, if I do say so myself. And the good news is that our intrinsic value has actually grown a bit faster than that.
How has the relevance of book value calculations changed over time in measuring Berkshire's performance versus the S&P 500 index?

Well, I'd say book value calculations are less relevant now than they used to be in measuring our yearly performance against the S&P 500. You see, our equity holdings have decreased significantly as a percentage of our net worth, so the stock market's yearly movements just don't affect us as much as they once did.
What is the key benchmark you and Charlie Munger use to evaluate Berkshire's long-term performance?

That's an easy one - it's the S&P 500 index. We figure if we can't outperform the S&P over the long haul, then Charlie and I aren't adding any value for our shareholders. They can just buy an index fund and do just as well on their own, so we've got to deliver better results than that to justify our existence.
What do you believe is the main reason for Berkshire's managerial freedom, and how does this impact decision-making?

I think our managerial freedom stems from not being saddled with institutional constraints, such as a history that commits us to a particular industry or shareholder pressure to follow Wall Street's expectations. This freedom allows Charlie and me to make decisions without external pressures, and when we do make mistakes, they're truly our own, what I call 'unforced errors'.
You mention that when valuations are similar, you prefer owning businesses to owning stocks. Can you elaborate on why this is your preference?

Well, it's quite simple really. When the prices are right, we'd rather own the whole business than just a piece of paper representing a fraction of it. Unfortunately, in recent years, we've found it challenging to find significantly undervalued stocks, which has made it harder to put our money to work in the way we'd like.
Why did you choose 1968 as the starting year for your calculations?

I chose 1968 because it was the first full year we operated National Indemnity, which marked the beginning of our expansion into new businesses. It's a meaningful starting point for evaluating our performance over time.
What is your strategy for capital allocation, and how does it relate to market conditions?

Our capital allocation strategy remains straightforward: if stocks are significantly undervalued compared to entire businesses, we'll buy them aggressively. If bonds become attractive, like they did in 2002, we'll invest in those. And regardless of market conditions, we're always happy to acquire businesses that meet our standards - the bigger, the better.
What is your approach to buying businesses under different market conditions?

We're always happy to buy businesses that meet our standards, regardless of the market or economic conditions. The bigger the better, I should add. Our goal is to find great businesses, and we're not deterred by the state of the market.
How did the acquisition of Clayton Homes come about?

Well, that's a fun story. It was actually a group of finance students from the University of Tennessee, along with their teacher Dr. Al Auxier, who led us to Clayton Homes. They gave me a book - the autobiography of Jim Clayton, the founder of Clayton Homes - as a thank-you gift after visiting us in Omaha. It was a pretty unusual way for an acquisition to start, but it worked out well for us.
What did you learn from your experience with Oakwood Homes, and how did it influence your perception of the manufactured housing industry?

Well, let me tell you, I learned a valuable lesson from that experience. I didn't fully understand the consumer-financing practices in the industry at the time, and it cost me. Oakwood's bankruptcy was a wake-up call, and it taught me that the industry's business model was flawed, relying on unloading bad loans to unsuspecting lenders. It was a hard lesson, but it gave me a clearer picture of the industry's problems.
You mentioned that manufactured housing can deliver good value to home purchasers. Can you elaborate on that?

Yes, I believe that manufactured housing can be a great option for many people. For decades, the industry has accounted for over 15% of the homes built in the U.S., and the quality and variety of manufactured houses have consistently improved. The problem isn't with the product itself, but rather with the financing and distribution practices that have plagued the industry. When done right, manufactured housing can provide an affordable and decent place to live for many Americans.
Why do you think directors of funds don't directly select and sign up with the best bidding organization, rather than going through the current process?

I think it's because the current rules just don't foster the election of truly independent directors. These directors often have a significant portion of their income tied to director fees, which can influence their decisions and make them less likely to rock the boat.

Can you explain why you believe someone like Ron Olson, who receives a small percentage of his income from Berkshire, is still considered independent, while others who receive a larger percentage from director fees are not?

Well, it's just common sense. Ron's income is so large that the 3% he gets from us is a drop in the bucket. It's not going to sway his decisions. On the other hand, if someone's getting 20%, 30%, or 50% of their income from director fees, that's a different story. That kind of money can definitely influence a person's independence, especially if they're not already financially set.
Do you think the income of mutual fund directors from director fees can influence their independence?

I believe it can, especially if their overall income is not large. Receiving 20%, 30%, or 50% of their income from director fees might temper their independence, and I think it's clear that at mutual funds, it has.
What suggestion do you have for 'independent' mutual fund directors to demonstrate their commitment to shareholders?

I suggest they affirm in each annual report that they've looked at other management companies and believe the one they have retained is among the better operations, and that they've negotiated a fee comparable to what other clients would negotiate. It's not too much to ask, especially if they're receiving fees over $100,000 annually.
Why do Charlie and I prefer that Berkshire's directors own significant amounts of company stock?

We love it when our directors have real skin in the game, just like our shareholders. It's like the old saying goes: who ever washes a rental car? When our directors own a substantial amount of Berkshire stock, they're more likely to make decisions that benefit the company and its shareholders in the long run.
Do Berkshire's directors have any protection against potential losses if something goes wrong with the company?

Actually, our directors are more exposed to losses than our shareholders. We don't carry directors and officers liability insurance, so if something catastrophic happens on their watch, they could lose big. That's just the way it is, and we think it's a key part of what we call owner-capitalism.
What are the key tasks you expect the next leader of Berkshire to perform?

I expect the next leader to maintain Berkshire's culture, allocate capital effectively, and keep our talented group of managers happy and engaged in their roles. It's not a simple task, but I'm confident that any of the four candidates we've identified can handle it well.
How do you approach providing financial information to Berkshire's owners, and what challenges do you face in doing so?

Charlie and I aim to give our owners the same financial information and commentary that we would want to receive if we were in their shoes. The challenge is presenting this information in a clear and concise manner, especially as Berkshire's scope expands and our businesses become more diverse. We're careful not to overwhelm our owners with unnecessary data, focusing instead on the key figures that help them understand the company's intrinsic value.
What is 'float' in the context of Berkshire's insurance operations and how is it generated?

Float is money that doesn't belong to us but that we temporarily hold. It's generated because premiums are paid upfront, while the insurance protection we provide is delivered over a period of time, usually a year. Additionally, when loss events occur, it can take years for losses to be reported, negotiated, and settled, which also contributes to our float.
How would you describe the cost of float in the property-casualty industry and how has Berkshire performed in this regard?

The cost of float is determined by underwriting results, and unfortunately, the property-casualty industry as a whole often operates at a substantial underwriting loss, making the cost of float unattractive. As for Berkshire, we've had our ups and downs - five terrible years where float cost us more than 10%, but in 18 of the 37 years we've been in the insurance business, we've actually operated at an underwriting profit, meaning we got paid for holding the money.
What can be expected from Home Services in the next decade?
I'm quite optimistic about Home Services - we expect it to grow substantially over the next decade, driven by our strategy of acquiring leading localized operations.
What happened to the number of employees at Northern and Yorkshire after the U.K. electric utilities were denationalized?

That's a fascinating story - after denationalization, Northern and Yorkshire's employee count dropped from 6,800 to 2,539, even though they're serving about the same number of customers and distributing more electricity. It just goes to show that profit-motivated managers can find efficiencies that government-run operations often can't.
What were the pre-tax losses from your portfolio of contracts in 2002 and 2003?

Our pre-tax losses were $173 million in 2002 and $99 million in 2003. I'd like to note that despite these losses, our liquidation process was orderly and occurred in a benign market with no significant credit losses.
Do you believe that reading disclosure documents of a derivatives-intensive company can provide a clear understanding of the risks involved?

Frankly, no. The more you know about derivatives, the less you'll feel you can learn from the typical disclosures. It's a complex arena where ignorance can sometimes breed more confidence than knowledge, as Darwin once said.
What prompted you to enter the foreign currency market in 2002 and enlarge your position in 2003?

I became increasingly bearish on the dollar, primarily due to our country's large trade deficit, which was force-feeding huge amounts of American assets to the rest of the world. It seemed to me that this trend couldn't continue indefinitely without affecting the dollar's value.
Do you think your macro forecast about the dollar and trade deficit will prove accurate, or might you end up in the 'cemetery for seers'?

Well, I've been wrong before, and I could be wrong again. As I said, the cemetery for seers has a huge section set aside for macro forecasters, and I'm not making any bets on being 100% right. But I do think our trade deficit is a significant issue that will have consequences, even if I'm not sure what they'll be.
What is your approach when you can't find exciting investment opportunities, and how do you avoid taking unnecessary risks?

When we can't find anything exciting to invest in, our default position is to stick with U.S. Treasuries, both bills and repos. We're disciplined about not reaching for a little more income by compromising on credit standards or extending maturities. Charlie and I are just not willing to take risks unless we think the potential reward is worth it. As I like to say, we won't even take small risks without adequate compensation - and that's a principle we stick to pretty strictly.
