How do you currently manage your exposure to the US dollar, given your concerns about its potential decline?

Well, we've taken a few steps to manage our exposure. For one, we own about $12 billion in foreign-exchange contracts at market values, spread across five currencies. These contracts help offset our large holdings of cash-equivalents denominated in dollars. We also tried to buy junk bonds denominated in Euros back in 2002, and today we own about $1 billion of those. It's not a huge bet against the dollar, but it's a way for us to diversify our holdings and reduce our risk.
What is your approach to taking risks in investments?

Charlie and I are pretty conservative when it comes to taking risks. We only take them if we think the potential reward is well worth it. To put it simply, we don't like to gamble unless the odds are heavily in our favor. In fact, about the only risky behavior you'll catch us doing is eating cottage cheese a day past its expiration date!
Can you recommend any books that you think investors should read?

I've got a few favorites that I think are really worth reading. 'Bull!' by Maggie Mahar, 'The Smartest Guys in the Room' by Bethany McLean and Peter Elkind, and 'In an Uncertain World' by Bob Rubin are all well-researched and well-written. And if you haven't already, you should definitely check out the revised version of 'The Intelligent Investor' by Jason Zweig - it's my go-to book on investing.
Why did Berkshire initially refuse to limit the gifts to pro-choice operations despite receiving objections and boycotts?

We refused to limit those gifts because we believe in the right of our owners to make whatever charitable donations they choose, as long as the recipients are legitimate 501(c)(3) organizations. It's a matter of principle, and we didn't want to compromise on that.
What change did Berkshire make in response to the boycotts affecting independent associates of The Pampered Chef?

We stopped making contributions at the parent company level. Now, our subsidiaries follow their own philanthropic policies, just as they did before they joined Berkshire. And if former owners of those subsidiaries want to make personal contributions, they do so from their own pockets, not the company's.
What was the performance of Berkshire's reinsurance division and GEICO in 2002?
They both did exceptionally well - as I said, they 'shot the lights out' that year. Underwriting discipline was also restored at General Re, which was a big positive for us.
How does Berkshire's investment approach differ from that of LBO operators and private equity firms?

The key difference is that we don't have an 'exit' strategy - we buy businesses with the intention of keeping them, not flipping them for a quick profit. This approach makes us an attractive choice for sellers and their managers.
What happens to Berkshire's relative performance in down markets due to the change in the portion of assets committed to common stocks?

Our relative performance in down markets, such as the one we had in 2002, is actually helped by this change. You see, when we have less of our assets tied up in common stocks, we're less exposed to the downturns, kind of like having a smaller sail in a stormy sea.
How does Berkshire's reporting of earnings differ from the 'pro-forma' earnings statements commonly seen in financial reports?

Well, we're a bit of an exception to the rule. While many companies like to show 'earnings' that are far rosier than their audited numbers, we actually reported that our pro-forma earnings were lower than our audited earnings last year. That's right, we showed the less flattering number, and that's just the way we do business - straightforward and honest, no sugarcoating.
How did the absence of megacatastrophes in 2002 affect Berkshire's insurance earnings?

Well, it meant we earned more from insurance than we would have if losses had been normal. It's like getting a free pass - we got to keep more of the premiums we collected because we didn't have to pay out as much in claims.

You mentioned that certain gains from your finance and financial products business will diminish or disappear within a year or two. Can you estimate how much of an impact this will have on your pre-tax earnings?

Yes, we figure that 'except for' those favorable breaks, our pre-tax earnings last year would have been about $500 million less than what we actually reported. That's a significant chunk of change, and we're happy to have banked the excess while we could.
What is your approach to managing Berkshire's subsidiaries, and what is the rationale behind it?

My approach is simple: I stay out of the way of our talented managers and let them run their businesses as if they were their own. The rationale is that 'it's hard to teach a new dog old tricks.' Our operating CEOs are masters of their crafts, and I just need to allocate the excess capital their businesses generate. It's a straightforward model that has worked well for us.
What lesson do you draw from the story of Eddie Bennett, the batboy for the Chicago White Sox, Brooklyn Dodgers, and New York Yankees?

The lesson is clear: to be a winner, you need to work with winners. Eddie's story illustrates the importance of surrounding yourself with talented individuals who can help you achieve success. By joining the Yankees, Eddie was able to be part of a highly successful team, and his rewards reflected that. It's a principle that applies to business as well, which is why I'm so fortunate to have such an extraordinary group of managers at Berkshire.
What were the two main factors that hurt Berkshire's 2002 results?

Our 2002 results were hurt by a painful charge at General Re for past losses and a 'desirable' annual charge for retroactive insurance. These costs added up to $1.75 billion, which is about 4.6% of our float.
What are the three key requirements for our insurance operations to generate low-cost float over time?

For our insurance operations to generate low-cost float, they must: (a) underwrite with unwavering discipline, (b) reserve conservatively, and (c) avoid an aggregation of exposures that could threaten their solvency. These are the core principles we follow to ensure long-term success.
What was your initial impression of Gen Re's underwriting discipline and reserving practices when you agreed to merge Berkshire with the company in 1998?

I thought Gen Re stuck to my three rules and had consistent underwriting discipline and conservative reserving practices. I had studied the operation for decades and didn't detect any slippage in their standards at the time of the merger. But, as it turned out, I was dead wrong.
How did the World Trade Center attack impact Gen Re's operations, and what actions were taken to correct the weaknesses that were exposed?

The World Trade Center attack exposed weaknesses in Gen Re's operations that I should have detected earlier. Luckily, Joe Brandon and Tad Montross were on hand to rapidly correct the errors of the past. They worked to reduce our aggregation of nuclear, chemical, and biological risk to a tolerable level, which took some time since insurance policies need to run off.
What makes it challenging for reinsurers to reserve properly, and how has Berkshire approached this challenge?

Well, as a reinsurer, you face far more difficulties in reserving properly than a primary insurer does. At Berkshire, we've generally been successful in our reserving, and we're determined to maintain that at General Re as well. It's all about having the right mindset, you know, not just actuarial expertise.
You mentioned that 'cheap' reinsurance can be a fool's bargain. Can you elaborate on what you mean by that?

Think of it like this: when you buy reinsurance, you're essentially paying someone to promise they'll cover you years down the line. If that someone isn't rock-solid financially, you're taking a huge risk. I mean, what's the point of saving a few bucks today if the reinsurer might not be around to pay your claims tomorrow? It's just not worth it. You need to deal with the strongest reinsurers out there, like General Re, which is now the only one in its class with an AAA rating across the board.
What kind of results did Ajit's operation achieve last year, and how do you view the risks associated with it?

Ajit achieved a large underwriting gain last year, despite the drag on reported results. As for the risks, we assume huge ones - far larger than any other insurer. But that doesn't bother me; as long as we're paid appropriately, I love taking on short-term volatility. It's like choosing between a smooth 12% return or a lumpy 15% - I'll take the latter any day.
How did Berkshire's smaller insurers perform last year, and what were some of the notable results?

Our smaller insurers had an outstanding year, with their aggregate float growing by 38% and an underwriting profit of $32 million. That's a 4.5% profit margin on premiums. Of course, not all of them did well - our California workers' compensation operation had terrible results, and we've got some work to do there. But overall, these operations would make one of the finest insurance companies in the country.
What is your view on derivatives and the trading activities associated with them?
Charlie and I view derivatives as time bombs, both for the parties that deal in them and the economic system. We're not fans, to say the least.
How did General Re Securities perform last year, and what contributed to its results?
General Re Securities lost $173 million pre-tax last year. Part of that loss was due to a belated acknowledgment of faulty, albeit standard, accounting it used in earlier periods.
How have marking errors in the derivatives business typically affected companies and their stakeholders?

I can tell you that marking errors in the derivatives business have almost invariably favored the trader looking for a big bonus or the CEO wanting to report impressive earnings. The bonuses get paid, and the CEO profits from their options, but later on, shareholders find out the reported earnings were not what they seemed.
Can derivatives contracts exacerbate a company's existing troubles, and if so, how?

Yes, derivatives can indeed make a company's problems worse. Imagine a company gets downgraded due to unrelated issues, and then its derivatives contracts kick in, requiring a huge amount of cash collateral right away. It's like piling on, making a bad situation even worse for the company.
Why did the formation of the Federal Reserve System occur, and how does it help strong banks?

The Federal Reserve System was formed partly due to the 'linkage' problem in banking, where the failure of weak banks would put sudden liquidity demands on strong banks, causing them to fail as well. The Fed acts as a buffer, insulating the strong banks from the troubles of the weak ones, preventing a chain reaction of failures.
What is your view on derivatives, and how do you approach them in Berkshire's business?

While some people believe derivatives stabilize the economy and reduce systemic problems by allowing risk transfer, Charlie and I think the macro picture is dangerous. We do engage in large-scale derivatives transactions to facilitate certain investment strategies, but we're actually exiting derivatives because we see a 'chain reaction' threat in the industry, where solid firms can become troubled due to the issues of others.
What was the Fed's primary concern when it acted in the LTCM affair?

The Fed acted because its leaders were fearful of what might have happened to other financial institutions had the LTCM domino toppled. In other words, they were worried about a potential chain reaction that could have destabilized the entire financial system.
How do you and Charlie Munger feel about understanding the risk profiles of firms heavily involved with derivatives contracts?

To be honest, when Charlie and I finish reading the long footnotes detailing the derivatives activities of major banks, the only thing we understand is that we don’t understand how much risk the institution is running. It's like trying to grasp a handful of sand - the more we try to get a handle on it, the more it slips through our fingers.
What is your expectation regarding losses in junk issues?
We expect to have occasional large losses in junk issues, but so far, we've done reasonably well in this field.
What role do you believe corporate boards should play in preventing deterioration of conduct among CEOs?

I believe corporate boards should behave as if there was a single absentee owner, whose long-term interest they should try to further in all proper ways, essentially acting to prevent the kind of bad behavior we've seen from some CEOs in recent years.
Why do you think it's difficult for board members to question certain decisions in a boardroom setting?

Well, it's just plain awkward, like belching at the dinner table. When you're in a room full of well-mannered people, it's hard to be the one to raise uncomfortable questions, especially if the CEO and their team are all on the same page. It's a social difficulty that can prevent directors from speaking up when they should.
What qualities do you think are essential for directors to be effective?

I've said it before, and I'll say it again: directors need to be business-savvy, interested, and shareholder-oriented. It's not just about being 'independent' as defined by the rules; it's about having the right qualities to make informed, thoughtful decisions that benefit the company and its shareholders.
What qualities do you value in directors, and how did the majority of directors you've encountered fall short?

I value three key qualities in directors, though I didn't explicitly list them here. However, it's clear that many directors lacked sufficient knowledge about business and/or didn't care enough about shareholders to make a positive impact. They failed to question poor decisions like foolish acquisitions or excessive compensation, which ultimately hurt shareholder well-being.
What are the two important responsibilities of independent directors on the boards of investment companies, according to your analysis?

For investment companies, like mutual funds, independent directors have two critical jobs: first, to find the best possible investment manager, and second, to negotiate the lowest possible fee with that manager. These goals are straightforward and essential for protecting the interests of shareholders.
What are the two important responsibilities of directors on an investment company board, according to you?

The two key responsibilities of directors are to obtain the best possible investment manager and to negotiate with that manager for the lowest possible fee. It's pretty straightforward, really - just like how you'd want to get the best doctor for your money when you're sick, or the best mechanic for your car.
Why do you think independent directors rarely suggest looking at alternative managers, even if the current one has delivered substandard performance?

Well, it's quite simple - when they're handling their own money, directors are smart and look for the best deal, but when they're acting for others, they seem to go through the motions like zombies. It's a bit like they're more concerned with not rocking the boat than with doing what's best for the people whose money they're managing.
What happens to management fees if directors are promised a portion of any fee savings they realize?

Well, I've said it before - if directors were promised a portion of any fee savings they realized, the skies would be filled with falling fees. It's simple: give them a stake in the outcome, and they'll suddenly find a way to negotiate lower fees.
Why are investment company directors failing in their responsibilities?

In my view, it's because their interests aren't aligned with the fund's. When the manager cares deeply about their fees and the directors don't care as much about saving the fund money, you get a system where the managers win and the fund loses. It's a lack of a powerful countervailing force - and that's what's missing in today's corporate governance.
What do you believe is necessary to reform corporate governance and get rid of mediocre CEOs?

I think what's needed is a powerful countervailing force, which can be provided by big owners, specifically institutional managers, acting together to exert their will on problem situations. It's not that complicated - just 20 or fewer of the largest institutions could make a real difference by withholding their votes for directors who tolerate bad behavior.
How will we know if real reform is happening in corporate governance?

For me, the acid test for reform is CEO compensation. If that changes, then we're making progress. Managers will happily agree to other reforms like board diversity or process changes, but if CEO pay isn't addressed, then we're not seeing real change.
What do you think is the real test for reform in corporate governance?
The acid test for reform, in my opinion, is CEO compensation. It's easy for managers to agree to superficial changes, but when it comes to their own pay and perks, that's where the real fight begins.
How should directors on compensation committees approach their role, according to you?

Directors on compensation committees should be capable of negotiating on behalf of owners, explain their thought process on pay, and measure performance. They should behave as if they were dealing with their own money, not just shareholders' money. Anything less is a dereliction of their duty.
Why do you think regulators overlook the potential lack of independence among directors who receive a significant portion of their income from directors' fees?

I think regulators overlook this because they're focusing on the wrong metrics. They're looking at absolute numbers rather than the impact those numbers have on an individual's finances. It's like saying a $100 bill is the same to both a billionaire and someone living paycheck to paycheck. At Berkshire, we recognize that even small amounts can be influential if they make up a big part of someone's income, which is why we keep our directors' fees very low.
How do you plan to find new directors for Berkshire's board?

We're going to look for people who have a significant stake in Berkshire's success, literally. We'll be searching through our shareholders list for individuals or families who have held large amounts of Berkshire stock for a long time - we're talking millions of dollars. This way, we know they'll be motivated to make decisions that benefit the company in the long run, because their own net worth is tied to it.
What qualities do you and Charlie look for when selecting new directors for Berkshire's board?

When selecting new directors, we look for three main qualities. First, they should be interested in Berkshire and shareholder-oriented, which is often demonstrated by having large Berkshire holdings for a long time. Second, they should have business savvy, which is a competence that's not as common as you might think. And third, we consider their ability to nurture Berkshire's special culture, especially when it comes to succession planning.
Will the addition of new directors change the way you and Charlie run Berkshire?

No, the addition of new directors won't change the way Charlie and I run Berkshire. We'll continue to emphasize substance over form and keep our board meetings focused on the important stuff, without getting bogged down in show-and-tell or perfunctory activities. Our goal is to find directors who share our values and principles, not to alter our management style.
What is the primary role of the audit committee according to you?

The primary role of the audit committee, in my view, is to get the auditors to divulge what they know. It's not about auditing itself, since that's the job of the outside auditor. The committee's key job is to ensure that the auditors are more concerned about misleading the committee members than about offending the management.
Why have auditors in recent years viewed the CEO rather than the shareholders or directors as their client?

Well, it's quite simple really. Auditors have generally viewed the CEO as their client because the CEO and CFO are the ones who pay their fees and decide whether they're retained for auditing and other work. It's a matter of who they have a day-to-day working relationship with, and who they perceive as having the power to hire or fire them.
What was the outcome of the Senate vote regarding expensing options, and how did it relate to the pressure from major auditing firms and CEOs?

The Senate voted 88-9 against expensing options, which was a direct result of the pressure from major auditing firms and CEOs who stormed Washington with their large political contributions. It's a shame, really, as it showed that the voices of these protesters, amplified by their money, could overpower good sense and accountability.
How did Arthur Levitt, Jr., the then Chairman of the SEC, feel about his decision to bow to Congressional and corporate pressures on this issue?

Arthur Levitt, Jr. has since described his decision to bow to those pressures as the act of his chairmanship that he most regrets. I think that says a lot about the kind of pressure that was applied and the unfortunate outcome that followed.
What happened after FASB backed off its original position on expensing options?

Well, it's quite simple really. After FASB adopted an 'honor system' approach, 498 out of 500 companies in the S&P chose the less desirable method, which allowed them to report higher 'earnings'. It's no surprise that CEOs loved this outcome, as it lined their own pockets.
What advice do you have for investors regarding companies with weak accounting practices?

I'd say beware of companies that don't expense options or have fanciful pension assumptions. If management is taking the low road in visible aspects, it's likely they're doing the same behind the scenes. As I see it, when a company shows weakness in its accounting, it's a red flag that investors should heed.
Why do you think companies that don't expense options or have fanciful pension assumptions are problematic?

I think these companies are problematic because when managements take the low road in visible aspects, it's likely they're following a similar path behind the scenes. It's like finding one cockroach in the kitchen - there's seldom just one. It indicates a lack of transparency and potentially questionable practices.
What's wrong with focusing on EBITDA as a measure of a company's performance?

Focusing on EBITDA is misguided because it implies that depreciation isn't a real expense. But depreciation represents a cash outlay paid up front, before the asset delivers any benefits. It's like paying all employees for ten years of service upfront - just because the expense is 'non-cash' in subsequent years doesn't mean it's not a real cost.
How does the tax treatment of Berkshire's numbers compare to the S&P 500 numbers, and what impact does this have on performance comparisons?

The S&P 500 numbers are pre-tax, whereas ours are after-tax. This means if we simply owned the S&P 500 and paid the appropriate taxes, we'd lag behind the S&P in good years but do better in bad years. Over time, those tax costs add up and cause a substantial lag.
What was Berkshire's performance like in 2001, and how does that compare to your long-term track record?

In 2001, Berkshire's net worth took a hit of $3.77 billion, which reduced our per-share book value by 6.2%. However, looking at the bigger picture, over the last 37 years, our per-share book value has grown from $19 to $37,920 - that's a 22.6% annual compound rate. So, while 2001 was a tough year, our long-term performance has been pretty strong.
What benchmark did you initially use to measure the performance of your investment partnership, and why did you switch to a different one?

We initially used the Dow Jones Industrials as our benchmark, but we shifted to the S&P 500 when that index became widely used. It's just common sense to compare ourselves to the most relevant and widely followed index out there.
How do you respond to critics who argue that relative performance isn't enough, saying 'you can't eat relative performance'?

I think that criticism misses the point. If you expect the S&P 500 to produce reasonably satisfactory results over time, as Charlie Munger and I do, then beating that index by even a small margin annually can add up to significant rewards over the long term. It's like owning a seasonal business - you may not make money every month, but overall, you can still do very well.
What was your performance like in managing Berkshire's equity portfolio, and what mistake did you make with General Re?

My results in managing Berkshire's equity portfolio were poor, and it's not the first time that's happened in recent years. As for General Re, I made a mistake by allowing them to take on business without a crucial safeguard that I knew was important. This error came back to haunt us, particularly on September 11th. I plan to share more about what went wrong and how we're fixing it later on.
How do you and Charlie ensure that your economic results from Berkshire are aligned with those of the shareholders?

Charlie and I make sure our interests are aligned with yours by not taking cash compensation, restricted stock, or option grants that would give us a better deal than our shareholders. Personally, I keep well over 99% of my net worth in Berkshire, and my wife and I have never sold a share - nor do we plan to. This way, our economic results from Berkshire will mirror yours over the period of your ownership.
What was in the package you received from Gene Toombs, CEO of MiTek, and how did it lead to Berkshire's acquisition of the company?

The package contained a connector plate, which is used in making roofing trusses. When I received it, I had no idea what it was, but the accompanying letter from Gene Toombs explaining MiTek's business and his interest in selling to Berkshire sparked my interest. After a brief call with Gene, I was impressed by his managerial style and the company's potential, leading us to make a cash offer and eventually acquire MiTek.
How did the management team at MiTek participate in the purchase, and what benefits do I see in their approach?

The MiTek management team participated in the purchase by buying 10% of the company, with 55 team members each putting up a minimum of $100,000 in cash. I love this approach because it makes them true owners, facing both the upside and downside of decisions, incurring a cost of capital, and living with the consequences of their investments without the ability to 'reprice' their stakes. This entrepreneurial attitude is exactly what Charlie and I look for in our investments.
What was the price H.H. Brown paid to acquire the inventory and trademarks of Acme Boot, and how does that compare to the price P&R paid for the company back in 1956?

H.H. Brown paid $700,000 for the inventory and trademarks of Acme Boot. That's a far cry from the $3.2 million P&R paid for the company back in 1956. It just goes to show how the fortunes of a business can change over time - as Ben Graham and Dave Dodd noted, many shall fall that are now in honor.
How has R.C. Willey's business grown under Bill Child's leadership, and what was the significance of the company's move to Boise?

Bill Child has done a phenomenal job growing R.C. Willey's business - when he took over, the company was doing $250,000 in business, and now it's over $300 million in Utah alone. As for the move to Boise, it was part of Bill's plan to extend the company's home-furnishings operation beyond Utah. I'm glad to see our managers continually looking for ways to grow internally, whether through bolt-on acquisitions or strategic expansions like this one.
What was the outcome of the R.C. Willey store in Henderson, and how did its performance compare to your expectations?

The Henderson store has been a huge success, outselling all other stores in the R.C. Willey chain and doing twice the volume of business I had anticipated. It's been a real winner, and I'm glad we decided to locate there.
Can you explain what 'float' means in the context of the insurance business, and why it's important?

Float is money that we hold but don't own, which comes from the premiums we receive before losses are paid. It's like having an interest-free loan, and we get to invest that money during the time we hold it. The key is to understand that this float comes with a cost - the premiums we take in often don't cover the losses and expenses we eventually have to pay. So, it's crucial to evaluate an insurance company based on the amount of float it generates, its cost, and the long-term outlook for both.
What is the current challenge for insurers like yourself when it comes to the cost of float, and how has this changed over time?

Well, the challenge today is that the cost of float is relatively high compared to the returns we can get from investing it. In the past, when government bonds yielded around 8% and stocks offered even higher potential returns, a float cost of 4% was manageable. But now, with short-term funds earning less than 2%, we need to be much more disciplined in our underwriting to make a profit.
You mention that underwriting discipline is key to success in the insurance business. Can you elaborate on what you mean by this, and what principles do successful insurers follow?

Underwriting discipline means being selective about the risks you take on and only accepting those that you can properly evaluate and that are likely to be profitable. Successful insurers stick to three key principles: they only take on risks they understand, they carefully evaluate all factors including remote loss scenarios, and they prioritize profit over market share. It's about being smart and patient, rather than trying to chase every piece of business that comes along.
What criteria do you use to evaluate the risks you accept as an insurer?

I only accept risks that I can properly evaluate, and that have a good chance of making a profit after considering all the relevant factors, including the possibility of remote losses. It's like only swimming in waters I know well, and checking the depth before diving in.
What lesson did you learn from the events of September 11th regarding your underwriting practices at General Re?

We learned the hard way that we had been too weak in applying our own rules. We had overlooked the possibility of large-scale terrorism losses, which ended up being a huge factor. It was a mistake to only look at past experiences, like windstorms and earthquakes, and not consider other potential risks, no matter how unlikely they seemed.
What was the main mistake made by the insurance industry in pricing property coverages, according to you?

We focused on experience rather than exposure, which meant we didn't account for the huge terrorism risk we were taking on, and we didn't charge a premium for it. It was a fundamental underwriting mistake.
Can you explain how experience can be a useful guide in underwriting certain coverages, like California earthquake policies?

Well, knowing how many significant earthquakes have occurred in California over the past century can be useful, especially if you're writing a large statewide policy. It won't tell you exactly when or where the next big quake will happen, but it gives you some statistical insight, which can be helpful in pricing those policies.
What approach will Berkshire take when writing coverage for terrorist-related losses, and how will you manage your total exposure?

We'll write some coverage for terrorist-related losses, including a few non-correlated policies with very large limits. But let me be clear: we won't knowingly expose Berkshire to losses beyond what we can comfortably handle. We'll control our total exposure, no matter what the competition does. It's like not betting more than you can afford to lose at the poker table.
What was a significant factor in General Re's underwriting losses in 2001, according to your analysis?

General Re's failure to reserve correctly was a major contributor to its underwriting losses. Not knowing your costs is a recipe for disaster in any business, and in long-tail reinsurance, it's especially problematic. It's like trying to navigate a ship without a map - you're bound to run into trouble.
What is the key to producing outstanding long-term results in insurance, according to your experience?

I've found that it's not about making brilliant decisions, but rather about avoiding dumb ones. Just like in investing, insurers produce outstanding long-term results primarily by preventing foolish losses, and that's the key.
Can you give an example of a large policy written by Ajit Jain after September 11th?

Yes, one example is the $1 billion of non-cancelable third-party liability coverage for losses arising from acts of terrorism at several large international airlines. That's just one of the many jumbo risks we've taken on, and I'm confident in Ajit's discipline and judgment in writing these policies.
What is the potential risk when a daisy chain of retrocessionaires exists in the reinsurance industry?
When you have a chain of retrocessionaires, a single weak link can cause trouble for everyone involved. It's like a row of dominoes - if one falls, the whole chain can come crashing down.
How did GEICO perform in 2001, and what was the one area where they fell short?

GEICO did fantastically well in 2001, with a 6.6% growth in premium volume, a $308 million increase in float, and an underwriting profit of $221 million. However, we were disappointed that we couldn't add more policyholders that year.
What do you mean by 'loss development' in insurance reporting, and why do you consider it a misleading term?

Well, 'loss development' refers to the process of calculating loss reserves, which is a liability account stating the amount an insurer will have to pay for all losses that have occurred but not yet been paid. I consider it misleading because it's not a fund set aside for future losses, but rather an estimate of what's already owed. It's a bit like my golf game - I can claim a great score on a 'pro forma' basis, but that doesn't change the fact that I still have to make those putts!
Can you explain what IBNR stands for and what it represents in the context of insurance loss reserves?

IBNR stands for 'incurred but not reported.' It represents losses that have already occurred, but haven't been reported to the insurer yet. This can include things like product liability or embezzlement, where the insured might not even be aware that a loss has happened. It's a tricky thing to estimate, but it's crucial for insurers to get it right so they can set aside the right amount for future payouts.
What was the result of underreserving at your company, and how did it affect your pricing and compensation?

Well, our underreserving led us to believe our costs were lower than they actually were, which resulted in inadequate pricing. It also caused us to pay out substantial incentive compensation that we shouldn't have, and we ended up paying income taxes earlier than necessary. It was a costly mistake, to say the least.
You mention that underreserving is a common problem in the property/casualty insurance industry. Can you tell us about Berkshire's history with reserving?

Yes, we've had our share of problems with underestimation, which we openly discussed in 1984 and 1986. However, I'm pleased to say that generally our reserving has been conservative. We've learned from our mistakes and strive to be more accurate in our estimations.
What is your current outlook on the stock market for the next decade?

To be honest, I'm not overly enthusiastic. Charlie and I believe American business will do just fine over time, but we think today's equity prices suggest only moderate returns for investors over the next decade or so.
Did you make any significant changes to Berkshire's portfolio in 2001?
No, we made very few changes in our portfolio during 2001. Our larger holdings haven't performed well in recent years, but we still like the basic businesses of the companies we own.
What is your outlook on the returns for investors in the current equity market?

I believe that today's equity prices suggest only moderate returns for investors. The market has outperformed business for a long time, and that trend had to end. Now, a market that just keeps pace with business progress will likely leave many investors, especially the newer ones, feeling disappointed.
Can you describe your experience with investing in 'junk' bonds?

We've had a 50-year experience with distressed debt, and it's been rewarding so far. We don't buy newly-issued junk bonds, which are often pitched to the general public. Instead, we occasionally find a few interesting junk securities to invest in. It's a risky field, with potential for significant losses, but our approach has worked out for us.
How do you learn about the investment activities of Lou Simpson, who manages a $2 billion portfolio for GEICO?

I learn about Lou's activities when I look at a GEICO portfolio summary that I receive a few days after the end of each month. He doesn't typically tell me what he's buying or selling, so it's through these regular summaries that I get to see what he's been up to.
What is Berkshire's policy regarding charitable contributions from its operating subsidiaries?

We let our operating subsidiaries make their own charitable decisions, with one key condition: when our managers were once independent owners, we ask them to make donations to their personal charities from their own funds, not company money. When they do use company funds, we trust them to make gifts that bring tangible or intangible benefits back to their operations.
How do you respond to criticism regarding Berkshire's contributions to certain charities, such as Planned Parenthood?

I'd say it's essential to understand that it's not Berkshire itself making these charitable decisions, but rather our diverse group of shareholders. They have a wide range of opinions, just like the American population, and we follow their instructions as long as the charity has 501(c)(3) status. It's similar to paying a dividend that the shareholder then donates - we're just providing a more tax-efficient way to disburse those funds.
What types of organizations have been recipients of Berkshire's shareholder-directed contributions?

Our shareholders have named a variety of charities as recipients, including 437 churches and synagogues, as well as 790 schools. They've also designated organizations like Planned Parenthood and Metro Right to Life, demonstrating the broad range of their interests and values.
What are some of the negatives you're facing with Berkshire's current situation?

Well, let me tell you, it's become a lot more expensive to get new business, and our advertising efforts at GEICO didn't quite pay off as I thought they would last year. Additionally, our equity portfolio isn't looking too exciting, with most of our holdings being fully priced and unlikely to deliver more than moderate returns. And of course, Charlie and I are getting older, which isn't exactly a positive!
How do you plan to achieve your goal of increasing Berkshire's per-share value at a rate that exceeds the S&P 500?

To reach our goal, we need to do a few key things: add some good businesses to our stable each year, have the businesses we already own increase in value, and avoid issuing too many new shares. It's not rocket science, but it does require discipline and a long-term focus. As I like to say, a small annual advantage can add up to a big difference over time.
What is unique about the jobs of Berkshire's all-stars and how has it impacted their retention?

Our all-stars have exactly the jobs they want, and they're focused on maximizing long-term value. It's like they're the owners of their own businesses, and that's led to incredible retention - in 36 years, not a single manager of a significant subsidiary has voluntarily left for another company.
How has the size of Berkshire's home-office staff changed and what kind of workload do they handle?

Well, our home-office staff is tiny - we've got 13.8 people, and I'm not kidding about the 0.8, by the way. But despite the small size, they handle a massive workload, from regulatory filings to producing our annual meeting and dealing with routine tasks for a $40 billion company. They're a miracle workers, and I'm grateful to work with them.
What factors contributed to the rush of acquisition activity you experienced last year?

Well, I think two main factors played a role. First, many business owners and managers were expecting a slowdown in their industries, which made them more willing to sell. And second, the junk bond market dried up, which meant that some of our potential competitors didn't have access to the same kind of financing that they had in previous years. It was a good time for us to be buying.
Why didn't the expected decline in earnings of some of the companies you purchased bother you?

Look, we're long-term thinkers. We know that every business has its ups and downs, and we're not worried about a little bump in the road. What matters to us is the overall performance of the company over time. As I like to say, only in the sales presentations of investment banks do earnings always go up - in the real world, things don't always move in a straight line.
What happens when an owner shows a total lack of interest in what follows after selling their business?

When an owner auctions off their business without any regard for its future, you can bet that it's been dressed up for sale, especially if the seller is just a 'financial owner'. This lack of interest can also contaminate the attitudes and practices throughout the company.
Why do you think it's important for the owner of a business to personally select its permanent home after they're gone?

Well, think of a business like a masterpiece painting - a Rembrandt. The painter wants to make sure it ends up in good hands, where it will be appreciated and cared for. It's the same with a business. When the owner personally selects its permanent home, they can ensure that their life's work is treated with the respect and care it deserves. And that's exactly what we offer at Berkshire - a home where businesses can thrive under our stewardship.
What happened to the conversion rate of inquiries into sales for your auto policies in the period discussed?

The percentage of inquiries that we converted into sales actually fell for the first time in many years. It's a development that, combined with the lack of commensurate increase in inquiries from our extra spending, led to a sharp increase in our per-policy acquisition cost.
How do you and Charlie Munger approach analyzing errors or failed decisions in your business dealings?

Charlie and I believe in acknowledging and analyzing our mistakes. Unlike what we've seen in many corporate boardrooms, where there's rarely a candid post-mortem of a failed decision, we think it's useful to review what went wrong. In fact, we've noted that The Washington Post Company is one of the few exceptions that does this kind of review objectively, and we admire that approach.
What factors contributed to the increased costs GEICO experienced in obtaining new business last year?

Well, I'd say there were at least four factors that played a role. First, our advertising strategy might have been too aggressive in some media, leading to diminishing returns. Second, we might have already tapped into the most receptive customers, leaving us with a tougher crowd to convince. Third, our stricter underwriting standards, which were necessary due to increased losses and inadequate rates, made our offerings less attractive to some prospects. And lastly, the many rate increases we implemented during the year also made our policies less appealing to some potential customers.
Why did GEICO tighten its underwriting standards?

We tightened our underwriting standards because the frequency and severity of losses increased during the year, and in some areas, our rates became inadequate. We had to adjust to ensure we weren't taking on too much risk. It's just common sense - if you're seeing more accidents and paying out more claims, you need to be more careful about who you're insuring and at what price.
How did the rate increases at GEICO affect the attractiveness of your insurance offerings to prospects?

The rate increases made our offerings less attractive to some prospects. You see, people are willing to switch insurance companies to save a significant amount of money, like $200 per year, but they're not as likely to switch for smaller savings, like $50. It's like deciding whether to drive across town to save a few bucks on groceries - if the savings are big enough, it's worth the trip, but if it's just a few dollars, you might as well stick with what you've got.
How does State Farm's approach to pricing affect the competitive landscape in the personal auto insurance market?

State Farm's willingness to tolerate high underwriting losses by not raising prices quickly enough makes it tough for other companies, like GEICO, to compete. It's like trying to run a marathon with someone who's willing to take a loss on every step - it's hard to keep up when they're not playing by the same rules. State Farm's approach puts pressure on us to keep our prices low, even if it means sacrificing some profitability.
What makes State Farm's success story unique, and why do you think it should be studied at business schools?

I think State Farm's success is unique because it achieved fabulous success while defying conventional business wisdom. It was launched by a semi-retired farmer, competed against well-established insurers, and yet it thrived without access to capital markets or offering stock options and lavish salaries. I believe it should be studied at business schools because it provides valuable counter-evidence to traditional business dogma, and studying such exceptions can be highly useful.
How does GEICO's business model compare to State Farm's, according to you?

In my opinion, GEICO has a better business model than State Farm, primarily because it has significantly lower operating costs. When you're selling a product with commodity-like economic characteristics, like insurance, being the low-cost producer is crucial, and that's where GEICO shines.
What gives GEICO a competitive advantage over State Farm?

It's simple: GEICO's business model has significantly lower operating costs. When you're selling a commodity-like product, being the low-cost producer is key. That's why I believe GEICO will increase its market share and achieve excellent profits over time.
How did GEICO's CEO, Tony Nicely, respond to challenges in 2000, and what were the results?

Tony Nicely is a CEO who always keeps his feet on the ground. In 2000, he cut back on advertising that wasn't cost-effective and aggressively filed for price increases where needed. His practical approach led to an 8.8% profit-sharing payment, which amounted to $40.7 million, despite the headwinds we faced that year.
What was the total market value of your common stocks as of 12/31/00?

As of 12/31/00, the total market value of our common stocks was $37,619 million. That's a pretty big number, but I like to think of it in simpler terms - it's like having a really big piggy bank, but instead of coins, it's filled with shares of great companies like Coca-Cola and American Express.
Do you prefer buying marketable securities or entire businesses?

Well, let me tell you, I've always said that our first choice is to purchase businesses, not stocks. It's like choosing between being a part-owner of a company and being the boss - I'd rather be the boss. We've been consistent about this since 1983, and it's still true today.
Why do you prefer purchasing businesses over stocks?

I prefer purchasing businesses over stocks for a couple of reasons. First, I enjoy working with our managers - they're talented, loyal, and make rational, owner-oriented decisions. But there's also a significant financial advantage: when we own 80% or more of a business, the tax code makes it far more profitable for us than owning a smaller share of a public company.
How do taxes affect the profitability of owning a business versus a marketable security?

Taxes play a big role in this. When we own a business outright and it earns $1 million after tax, that entire amount is ours, with no additional tax owed if we choose to retain the earnings or sell the business. In contrast, if we own a 10% stake in a public company, our share of the earnings is subject to additional state and federal taxes - around 14% if the earnings are distributed as dividends, or 35-40% if they're retained and we eventually capture them as a capital gain.
What factors determine the maximum value of an investment, according to your explanation?

Well, it's quite simple really. To determine the maximum value of an investment, you need to know when the returns will emerge, how many there will be, and what the risk-free interest rate is. Think of it like figuring out how many birds you should trade for a bush - you need to know what you're getting and when, and what a 'safe' investment would give you instead.
Can growth always be considered a positive factor in the value equation of an investment?

Not always. Growth can actually destroy value if it requires too much cash upfront and doesn't generate enough returns later on. It's just one component of the value equation - sometimes it's a plus, but sometimes it's a minus. Don't just assume growth is always good, that's not how it works.
What is your view on the distinction between 'growth' and 'value' styles in investment?

I think it's nonsense to consider 'growth' and 'value' as contrasting approaches. Growth is just one component of the value equation - sometimes it adds to value, sometimes it subtracts. It's not a separate style, just a part of the overall calculation.
You mention 'speculation' in the context of investing. How do you define speculation, and is it something investors should avoid?

Speculation, to me, is when you're not focused on what an asset will produce, but rather on what someone else will pay for it. It's not illegal, immoral, or un-American, but it's a different mindset. I'm not saying investors should always avoid it, but they should be aware of when they're speculating and understand the risks involved.
What is your view on the practice of 'selective disclosure' that was prevalent among major corporations in recent years?

I think it's corrupt behavior, plain and simple. Companies were giving speculatively-minded institutions and advisors an information edge over individual investors through hints, winks, and nods. It's shameful that it took coercion, not conscience, to stop this practice.
Do you think CEOs should predict growth rates for their companies, and why?

No, I don't think CEOs should predict growth rates. Charlie and I believe it's deceptive and dangerous. These predictions often lead to trouble, and CEOs should resist the pressure from analysts and their own investor relations departments to make them.
Why do you think CEOs should resist making specific predictions about their company's future earnings growth?

I think CEOs should resist making these predictions because they often lead to trouble. When a CEO predicts a high growth rate, like 15% annually, it's unlikely they can maintain it over the long term. In fact, if you look at the record of the 200 highest earning companies from 1970 or 1980, you'll find that only a handful have achieved that kind of growth. It's just not realistic, and it can lead to all sorts of problems, including CEOs engaging in uneconomic maneuvers or even accounting games to try to meet their targets.
What kind of behavior have you observed in CEOs who try to meet their own lofty earnings predictions?

Unfortunately, I've seen many instances where CEOs have engaged in some pretty questionable behavior to try to meet their earnings targets. They might try some operating acrobatics, which can be harmful to the business in the long run. And when that's not enough, they might even resort to playing accounting games to 'make the numbers.' It's not a healthy way to run a business, and it's one of the reasons I think CEOs should be careful about making specific predictions in the first place.
What happens when companies engage in accounting maneuvers to meet earnings targets, according to your observations?

Well, these accounting shenanigans have a way of snowballing. Once a company starts moving earnings from one period to another, they often need to come up with even more creative maneuvers to cover up shortfalls that occur later on. It's a slippery slope that can turn fudging into outright fraud.
Why do you warn investors to be cautious of CEOs who make fancy predictions about their company's performance?

It's because some of these CEOs are what I call congenital optimists, or even charlatans. They might make lofty predictions to woo investors, but it's hard to know in advance whether they're being genuine or not. Charlie and I have learned to be leery of companies run by CEOs who make big promises, because it's often a sign of trouble down the road.
What happened to Conseco stock after the story was reported by the New York reporter for the Journal?
Well, the Conseco stock advanced sharply that day, and it ended up ninth on the NYSE most-active list due to exceptional volume. It was quite a reaction, and all based on what I'd call a rumor.
Do you think news organizations should be more transparent when reporting unconfirmed information, such as rumors?

I believe they should. Readers deserve honest terminology, a kind of warning label that says what they're reading might not be entirely factual. It's like warning labels on cigarettes - they protect people's health. In this case, it would protect their financial health.
What change in accounting rules are you pleased about and how will it affect Berkshire's reported earnings?

I'm pleased that the Financial Accounting Standards Board has moved away from the 'pooling' approach in accounting for mergers. With this change, if the proposed rule becomes final, we'll no longer have to take a large annual charge for amortization of intangibles. This means our reported earnings will more accurately reflect the economic reality of our business.
How do you think readers can benefit from the enclosed report of Charlie's remarks at the Wesco annual meeting?

I think readers can gain a lot of insight into business economics and investment matters by reading Charlie's comments. He's one of the best thinkers I know in this area, and I've personally learned a great deal from him over the years. Reading his remarks will help readers better understand Berkshire and our approach to business and investing.
What was the outcome of Ralph Schey's leadership at Scott Fetzer after Berkshire acquired the company in 1985?

Ralph's leadership was phenomenal - under his guidance, Scott Fetzer distributed $1.03 billion to Berkshire, which was a huge return on our initial investment of $230 million. His contributions to Berkshire's value are truly immeasurable.
How did attending Ben Graham's class at Columbia impact your investment performance?

It was a game-changer for me. After learning from Ben, my investment results improved significantly starting in 1951. His ideas were the key to my success, and I can honestly say that those few hours in his class were more valuable than a decade of my own trial and error.
What was the change in per-share book value of Berkshire's Class A and Class B stock in 1999?
The per-share book value of both our Class A and Class B stock increased by 0.5% in 1999.
What was the primary reason for Berkshire's poor performance in 1999?
The inferior performance of Berkshire's equity portfolio was what most hurt us during the year. I'm responsible for that portfolio, and I have to admit, my grade for 1999 is a D.
What was the primary reason for Berkshire's poor performance in 1999?

The main culprit was the inferior performance of our equity portfolio, particularly some of our largest investees that had disappointing operating results. It's my responsibility, by the way, since I'm the one overseeing that portfolio, except for the small part managed by Lou Simpson.
How do you think Berkshire's stock price will relate to its business performance over time?

Well, I think it's pretty simple: over time, the stock's performance has to roughly match the business's performance. It's like a marriage - they might not always move in perfect sync, but in the long run, they're tied together. And I'm confident that our business will do just fine, even if the stock doesn't always reflect that immediately.
Why do you believe the S&P will do less well in the next decade or two compared to its performance since 1982?

I believe the S&P will do less well because the prices of businesses and stocks are no longer as attractive as they were back then. Additionally, our capital base has grown significantly, limiting the range of investment opportunities available to us. I've also expressed my views on this matter in a recent Fortune article, which I've enclosed with this report.
What was your approach to acquiring new businesses in 1999, and what kind of businesses are you looking to acquire in the future?

In 1999, we acquired Jordan's Furniture and contracted to buy a major portion of MidAmerican Energy, and we did so by paying cash, without issuing any new Berkshire shares. Going forward, our goal is to acquire businesses with strong economic characteristics and talented managers, similar to those we already own. We're fortunate to have outstanding managers in place, which makes running our current businesses a relatively easy task.
Why do you and Charlie prefer to buy companies for cash, issuing no Berkshire shares?

We prefer buying companies for cash, without issuing new Berkshire shares, because it allows us to maintain control and avoid diluting our existing shareholders' interests. It's a straightforward way to make acquisitions, and we think it's the best approach when possible.
What two key components of value do you trace in the table to estimate Berkshire's intrinsic value?

In the table, we track two important components: our per-share ownership of investments, which includes cash and equivalents, and our per-share earnings from operating businesses before taxes and certain adjustments. These two columns give us a useful snapshot of Berkshire's intrinsic value.
How do you measure the success of your subsidiaries, and what is your goal for them?

I measure the success of our subsidiaries by the spread between their current value and the value at which they are carried on our books. Our goal is to continually widen this spread, and I'm pleased to say that businesses like See's and Buffalo News are now worth fifteen to twenty times their book value.
What motivates your managers to work hard, and how do you treat them?

My managers are motivated by their love for their businesses, not by a need for money or contractual obligations. I treat them with the respect and trust they deserve, giving them the freedom to run their companies as if they were their own family's sole asset. I believe in treating them as I would want to be treated if our positions were reversed.
What motivates you to continue working at Berkshire despite having no financial need to do so?

I love working at Berkshire because it gives me a sense of achievement, the freedom to act as I see fit, and the opportunity to interact with people I like and trust. It's a pretty simple formula, but it works for me.
How did the no-Sunday policy at R. C. Willey impact the business, and what was the outcome of expanding to Boise?

The no-Sunday policy was a challenge, especially when we expanded to Boise where our competitors were open seven days a week. But Bill Child, the founder, was adamant about sticking to his principles. I was skeptical, but I let him run with it. He even offered to personally buy the land and build the store, and then sell it to us at cost if it was successful. I have to say, I was impressed by his commitment, and it's a testament to the kind of people we have running our businesses at Berkshire.
What were the results of the grand opening of the Boise store in terms of sales?

I'm pleased to say that sales far exceeded our expectations, making us the largest home furnishings store in Idaho by a considerable margin. It was a great start, and I was happy to be there to cut the ribbon and share the good news with the crowd.
Can you explain what 'float' means in the context of the insurance business?

Float is simply money that we hold but don't own. In insurance, it's the premiums we receive before we pay out losses, which can sometimes take years. We get to invest that money in the meantime, which is a nice bonus. However, the premiums usually don't cover all the losses and expenses, so we end up with an underwriting loss - that's the cost of float.
What is float in the context of Berkshire's insurance operations, and how do you calculate it?

Float, in our insurance business, refers to the money we hold that doesn't belong to us - it's like having a large, interest-free loan from others. We calculate it by adding up our net loss reserves, loss adjustment reserves, funds held under reinsurance assumed, and unearned premium reserves, and then subtracting agents' balances, prepaid acquisition costs, prepaid taxes, and deferred charges applicable to assumed reinsurance. It's a bit like a recipe, but instead of baking a cake, we're figuring out how much of other people's money we're holding.
You mentioned incurring a $1.4 billion underwriting loss in 1999. Can you explain what that means and how it affected your float cost?

Well, an underwriting loss means we paid out more in claims than we took in from premiums. In 1999, that loss was $1.4 billion, which isn't exactly what I'd call a pleasant surprise. As a result, our float cost for that year was 5.8% - meaning we essentially paid 5.8% to hold other people's money. Now, it's worth noting that about $400 million of that loss was from business that will give us great float over the next decade, so there's a bit of a silver lining.
How does Berkshire's compensation policy at GEICO account for the costs of writing new business?

We essentially foot the bill for new business, so our associates aren't penalized for bringing in new policies, which are initially unprofitable but very much in Berkshire's interest. This way, they're rewarded for producing this business without worrying about the upfront costs.
What role does word-of-mouth play in GEICO's new business, and how does this impact your advertising spending?

Word-of-mouth recommendations from existing policyholders are our best source of new business. They're pleased with our prices and service, which is reflected in our low complaint ratio. This strong referral business means we could likely maintain our policy count with much less advertising spend, possibly as low as $50 million annually, but we won't be testing that theory anytime soon since we plan to keep advertising aggressively.
What is your approach to acquisition strategy at Berkshire?
Our acquisition strategy is simple: we wait for the phone to ring. We don't go out looking for deals; instead, we let opportunities come to us.
What was Charlie's response when the lead banker offered you a copy of the book on Scott Fetzer?
Charlie responded with his typical tact, saying 'I'll pay $2.5 million not to read it.' I think that sums up our opinion of the book's value pretty well.
Why do managements usually detest purchase accounting?

I'd say managements detest purchase accounting because it requires establishing a 'goodwill' account, which then has to be written off over time. This write-off results in a large annual charge to earnings that can persist for decades, making their financials look less rosy than they'd like.
What's your view on goodwill amortization charges?

To be frank, I think goodwill amortization charges are usually spurious. As I've mentioned before, most accounting charges relate to something real, even if they're not precise. But goodwill amortization just doesn't reflect reality in most cases. It's a bit like trying to measure the decline in value of a physical asset with perfect precision - it's just not possible, and the charges don't really describe what's going on.
Why do you think accounting rules mandating amortization of economic goodwill are troublesome?

I think these rules are troublesome because, in many cases, economic goodwill doesn't actually diminish over time - it often grows. It's like land, its value can fluctuate, but it's not destined to decrease. Look at See's, our economic goodwill has grown substantially over 78 years, and I expect it to continue if we keep running the business right.
Can you explain the concept of pooling in accounting and why managers might prefer it over amortization of goodwill?

Pooling is an accounting convention that treats a merged company as if it's indistinguishable from the larger enterprise, kind of like two rivers merging. Managers like this because it lets them avoid the fiction of goodwill charges. Essentially, they're swapping one fiction for another, but I suppose it's more palatable to them. Under pooling, the company isn't considered 'purchased' even if it received a big premium, which seems a bit poetic to me.
Why don't you and Charlie Munger invest in tech companies?

We don't invest in tech companies because we can't identify which ones have a truly durable competitive advantage. We may think their products and services will change the world, but we just can't predict which companies will come out on top in the long run.
What do you do when you're faced with investment opportunities outside of your area of expertise?

We stick to what we understand. If it's outside our circle of competence, we don't try to pretend we're experts. We just avoid those areas altogether, whether it's evaluating patents, manufacturing processes, or something else. We're not afraid to say we don't know something and leave it to those who do.
Under what condition will you repurchase Berkshire shares?

I'll repurchase shares only if I believe Berkshire stock is selling well below its intrinsic value, and I mean that intrinsic value has to be conservatively calculated. It's like buying a house - if the price is right, and I think it's worth more than what's being asked, then it's a good deal. But if the price is too high, I'll wait.
How does a repurchase program benefit a continuing shareholder?

A repurchase program can benefit a continuing shareholder only if the stock price falls and we can buy a significant amount of shares. Think of it like this: if we repurchase a small percentage of shares at a discount, the gain in per-share value is minimal. But if we can buy a lot of shares at a low price, that's when it gets interesting for long-term shareholders. So, as a continuing shareholder, you should actually hope the stock falls, not rises, if you want the repurchase program to have a real benefit for you.
What was the gain in net worth for Berkshire Hathaway during 1998 and how did it affect the per-share book value of both Class A and Class B stock?

Our gain in net worth during 1998 was $25.9 billion, which increased the per-share book value of both our Class A and Class B stock by 48.3%. I must say, normally a gain like that would be cause for celebration, but this year it's not quite as impressive as it sounds.
Why didn't the 48.3% gain in per-share book value necessarily translate to an immediate gain in per-share intrinsic value?

That's because most of the 48.3% gain came from issuing shares in acquisitions. When we issue shares, it instantly increases our per-share book-value figure, even though we haven't earned any additional income. Essentially, we're getting more per-share book value in these transactions than we're giving up, but it doesn't deliver an immediate gain in per-share intrinsic value because what we give and what we get are roughly equal. As Charlie Munger and I always say, it's the per-share gain in intrinsic value that really counts.
Why did Berkshire's gain in intrinsic value fall short of the 48.3% gain in book value in 1998?

Well, it's quite simple really. The transactions we made that year didn't deliver an immediate gain in per-share intrinsic value because what we gave and what we got were roughly equal. It's not about the book value, it's about the intrinsic value, and that's what counts.
How did your equity portfolio perform compared to the S&P 500 in 1998?

To be honest, our equity portfolio didn't do as well as the S&P 500. Several of the public companies we've invested in had significant operating shortfalls, which neither they nor I saw coming. But I believe these problems are temporary, and Charlie and I are confident about their long-term prospects.
What average rate of return do you and Charlie aim to achieve for Berkshire's intrinsic value in the future?
We're aiming for an average rate of 15%. That's what we consider to be at the very peak of possible outcomes. It's a tough target, but we're going to give it our best shot.
How do you plan to handle your personal net worth in relation to Berkshire?
I've made a promise to keep at least 99% of my net worth in Berkshire for as long as I'm around. I'm committed to this company and its future, and I'm putting my money where my mouth is.
How has the size of your staff at world headquarters changed, and what does the 0.8 refer to in the new staff size of 12.8?

Well, our staff at world headquarters has grown from 12 to 12.8, and I'm happy to report that the 0.8 doesn't refer to me or Charlie getting a fraction of a person more energetic. It actually means we've added a new person in accounting who works four days a week.
How much did Berkshire and General Re pay in federal income taxes for 1998 earnings, and what's the significance of this amount?

We paid a total of $2.7 billion in federal income taxes for 1998 earnings. To put that into perspective, if only 625 other U.S. taxpayers had paid as much as we did, no one else would have had to pay federal income taxes. It's a staggering thought, and I'm proud to say that our shareholders can truly say they 'gave at the office'.
How do you determine the bonuses and profit sharing for GEICO associates?

We base 50% of our associates' bonuses and profit sharing on the earnings of our 'seasoned' book, which means policies that have been with us for more than a year. The other 50% is tied to growth in policyholders. It's a simple, straightforward approach that incentivizes our team to pursue new business while also delivering strong results from our existing book.
What's the plan for GEICO's marketing budget in 1999?

In 1999, we plan to increase our marketing budget again, spending at least $190 million. And let me be clear, there's no cap on what we're willing to invest in GEICO's new-business activity, as long as we can build the necessary infrastructure to support our growing policyholder base.
What is your investment approach when it comes to GEICO's new-business activity?

I'm willing to invest without limit in GEICO's new-business activity as long as we can build the necessary infrastructure to serve our policyholders. My calculus is simple: if we're creating more than a dollar of value per dollar spent, the more we spend, the happier I am.
How did GEICO's profit margin in 1998 compare to your expectations, and what actions did you take in response?

GEICO's 1998 profit margin of 6.7% was actually better than we had anticipated. However, we didn't just sit on our hands - we responded by reducing rates 3.3% in 1998, and we plan to reduce them even more in 1999 to bring profit margins back down to our target of 4%.
What percentage of people who check your insurance rates find that they can save money by doing business with you?
About 40% of those who check our rates find that they can save money by doing business with us. It's not a guarantee for everyone, but it's a pretty significant proportion.
What guidelines do you give to your managers in terms of how to run their businesses?

We give them a simple mission: run your business as if you own 100% of it, it's the only asset you and your family have or will ever have, and you can't sell or merge it for at least a century. That's it. We trust them to make the right decisions and don't bother them with a lot of unnecessary oversight or bureaucracy.
How do you instruct your managers to run their businesses?

I tell them to run their business as if they own 100% of it, it's the only asset they and their family have or will ever have, and they can't sell or merge it for at least a century. This mindset helps them focus on what really matters in the long run.
What kind of environment do you try to create for your CEOs, like Tony at GEICO?

We create an environment that allows them to apply all their talents to what's truly important. We free them from distractions like board meetings, press interviews, and talks with financial analysts, so they can focus on building their business for the long haul.
How do you think Berkshire's ownership will benefit General Re?

I believe Berkshire's ownership will benefit General Re by offering its management the freedom to operate in the best way possible to exploit the company's strengths. This freedom is key because it allows General Re to make decisions that might not be possible under the scrutiny of public ownership, where smooth earnings are often prioritized over long-term strategic decisions.
Why do publicly-held reinsurers face challenges in managing volatility in their earnings?

Publicly-held reinsurers face a bit of an irony. They get paid for absorbing the volatility that primary insurers want to shed, but at the same time, they're graded by their owners and credit evaluators on how smooth their own results are. This means that even if a reinsurer is doing a great job of managing risk over the long term, wide swings in earnings can still hurt their credit ratings and p/e ratios.
How does Berkshire's approach to volatility in earnings differ from that of a publicly-held reinsurer?

Well, I'd say we're like the calm in the storm. While publicly-held reinsurers get penalized for volatile earnings, we at Berkshire are happy to accept it as long as it comes with the promise of higher profits over time. It's like being a long-term investor in the stock market - you've got to be able to stomach some ups and downs to reap the rewards.
What benefits does the merger with General Re bring to Berkshire's reinsurance business?

The merger with General Re gives us the distribution force, technical facilities, and management we needed to take our reinsurance business to the next level, especially in international markets where the growth is. It's like having the right tools and the right team to tackle a big job - now we can really make the most of our strengths.
What are the key benefits that Berkshire brings to General Re through the merger?

Well, as I see it, Berkshire brings tax and investment benefits to General Re, but the real game-changer is that General Re's top-notch management can now operate without the constraints that were holding them back. We're talking about unleashing their full potential here.
What are the key determinants you consider when evaluating an insurance company?

When it comes to evaluating an insurance company, I focus on three key factors: the amount of float the business generates, the cost of that float, and the long-term outlook for both. It's pretty straightforward, but these factors can make all the difference in the world.
What is float in the context of an insurance company, and how does it arise?

Float is money that we hold but don't own. It arises in an insurance operation because premiums are received before losses are paid, which can sometimes take many years. This interval allows the insurer to invest the money, which can be a pleasant activity, but it also comes with a downside - the premiums usually don't cover the losses and expenses, leading to an underwriting loss.
How can errors in estimating loss costs affect an insurance company's reported earnings?

Errors in estimating loss costs can have huge consequences that flow directly into earnings. Because loss costs must be estimated, insurers have a lot of latitude in figuring their underwriting results, making it tough for investors to calculate the true cost of float. I've seen cases where even big-name auditors have implicitly blessed some pretty amazing numbers, which can be surprising, to say the least.
What is the significance of the float generated by Berkshire's insurance operations, and how has it grown over the years?

The float is a crucial aspect of our insurance business, and I'm pleased to say it's grown significantly over the years. As the table shows, our average float has increased from $17 million in 1967 to $22,762 million in 1998, which is a compounded annual growth rate of 25.4%. But what's more important than the size of the float is its cost, and I'm happy to report that our average cost over the 32 years has been well under zero.
Why do you and Charlie aim to be conservative in presenting Berkshire's underwriting results?

We've found that in the insurance business, surprises are usually unpleasant ones. So, we err on the side of caution when presenting our underwriting results. It's just common sense - we'd rather be safe than sorry. And I've seen some big-name auditors bless some pretty questionable numbers over the years, which only reinforces our approach.
What is the role of you and Charlie in the management of Berkshire, and how do you approach allocating capital?

Charlie and I have it easy - our main job is to allocate capital, and we don't even do that very energetically. We believe that in the fields of investments and acquisitions, activity doesn't necessarily lead to achievement, and sometimes frenetic behavior can even be counterproductive. So, we mainly just wait for the right opportunities to come along, rather than chasing after them.
How do you compensate your operating managers, and what drives their extraordinary performance?

While our managers do want to be paid fairly for their efforts, I believe their extraordinary accomplishments can't be explained by pay alone. They're a talented group, and many of them are truly legends in their industries. I think it's a combination of their hard work, dedication, and the fact that we give them the autonomy to run their businesses effectively that drives their success.
What was one of your biggest investment mistakes last year?

Selling McDonald's - that was a big mistake. I mean, it would have been better for our investors if I had just taken a break and gone to the movies during market hours instead of making that decision.
What are you and Charlie looking to do with the $15 billion in cash equivalents Berkshire is holding?

We're on the hunt for large equity investments or a major business acquisition that can put our liquid assets to good use.
